HEADLINE: Basic Shift In Japan Over Rates

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 7

 BODY:
While the Government has intervened heavily in the last two weeks to stabilize the tumbling stock market and bolster the yen, economists and business leaders here say these short-term tactics cannot alter the fundamental economic shift behind the turmoil: the era of extraordinarily low Japanese interest rates is ending.
After an economic boom fueled by low rates, most countries would find the long-term adjustment to higher rates to be difficult, bringing such repercussions as a rise in corporate bankruptcies, a drop in consumer spending and a general economic slowdown.
But as economists, bankers and other experts here see it, the sharp rise in interest rates will merely give the Japanese economy another chance to demonstrate its resilience. Assuming that rates do not go much higher, the effect is expected to be modest, providing an instructive study in what makes the Japanese economy so strong.
 
Huge Cash Reserves
Many potentially negative consequences will be mitigated by the remarkable health and huge cash reserves of corporate Japan, these experts said. In effect, Japanese companies used the period when interest rates held below 5 percent, along with a powerful stock market, to protect themselves against the day when those favorable conditions would end. 
There will be some jolts from the higher interest rates, these experts said, including an increase in inflation and a rise in the cost of imported goods. The worst potential consequence could be an added strain on the already tense relationship between Japan and the United States. Continued weakness of the yen and any reduction of demand in Japan could result in a push for more exports to the United States to make up for slower sales at home.
 
Worries About Trade Imbalances
That is something that both countries have tried to avoid, in the face of concerns about the United States' trade deficit with Japan, which amounted to $49 billion last year.
There are many reasons for the shift in Japanese interest rates: concerns that inflation might rise in Japan because of a severe labor shortage and rapid growth in the supply of money; even higher interest rates in West Germany and the United States, which tend to pull Japanese money to those countries, and a yen that continues to tumble in value against other currencies.
One important Japanese rate, the long-term prime rate charged by banks to leading corporations, has jumped to 7.5 percent, from 6 percent last year. The prime had stayed below 5 percent for about two and a half years.
Certain short-term rates have moved to 7 percent from 4 percent in mid-1989. Those levels are particularly high relative to Japan's annual inflation rate, which remains slightly more than 2 percent.
''We have entered a period where there will be a new interest rate regime,'' said Keikichi Honda, general manager of economic research at the Bank of Tokyo. ''It's a fundamental change that will not just go away.''
And Susumu Kato, chief economist for Goldman, Sachs & Company in Tokyo, commented: ''After almost a decade of lower interest rates, we're adjusting to a new period. It's not a temporary move.''
In sharp contrast to the United States, where many corporations borrowed heavily against assets to pay for mergers and takeovers, most of Japan's big corporations are swimming in money.
The Toyota Motor Corporation is often referred to as Toyota Bank, because it has amassed more than $20 billion in cash, a result of record profits and a huge program of raising capital in the markets during the era of low interest rates. That mountain of money means that higher rates and lower stock prices will not hamper the ability of Toyota to invest in research and new plants, or to improve its old factories.
Toyota is an extreme example, but other companies tend to be similarly rich in capital.
This is largely because Japanese companies used low interest rates to pay for improvements that have raised their productivity. They also sought markets and products that would increase profits - investments that are just starting to produce returns. They are thus much better able to pay for further improvements without having to borrow.
Still, the end of the era of low rates could produce some harmful fallout. If the uncertainty in the markets persists, some Japanese executives say, they will trim their investment plans.
The tumble in stock prices has also forced several major corporations to cancel efforts to raise capital from the market. The Yasuda Trust and Banking Company said today that it was canceling a proposed bond and stock offering that would have raised slightly more than $900 million. On Tuesday, Mitsukoshi Ltd., the large department store company, abruptly withdrew a $278 million offering. Earlier, the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company pulled out of a $1 billion deal.
The cancellations provide a clear sign that the shaken markets will not provide as rich a source of cheap capital as they had for the last several years. Over time, this will take a toll on companies' profitability.
The stock market seems to have awakened to the permanent nature of the changes in interest rates about two weeks ago, when prices started to slide. The Nikkei index of 225 stocks closed today at 33,362.34, compared with 38,712 at the beginning of the year.
''The stock market was just adjusting to this reality,'' said Yoshihisa Kitai, manager of the economics division at the Long Term Credit Bank. ''It is a hard reality that collided with the euphoria in the markets before.''
 
Shift Has Come Quickly
The change in interest rates and the shift in Government monetary policy that it signals have been amazingly steep. Japan's long-term interest rates peaked in April 1980, when the yield hit 10.3 percent on the Government's 10-year bond, a benchmark figure determined by the market and the basis for many other lending rates. After that, the rate fell and did not stop until May 1987, when it bottomed out at 3.4 percent.
Although rates edged higher afterward, the yield on the 10-year bond still hovered below 5 percent until last fall. That was less than two-thirds the level of long-term rates in the United States. But since December the 10-year bond rate has soared and is now at 7.2 percent, its highest since 1984. The yield on 10-year bonds in the United States is now about 8.6 percent.
In the United States, interest rates edged higher earlier this year, reflecting the moves toward the reunification of the Germanys, which is expected to have an inflationary effect, as well as the Federal Reserve Board's concerns about inflation. American rates have since appeared to stabilize.
As the yen grew weaker, it forced the Bank of Japan to raise interest rates to try to give investors a better return and to encourage currency traders to buy the yen. The Bank of Japan announced a rise in its official discount rate, its third in six months, on Dec. 25.
But it now seems that the central bank responded too gingerly. The yen continued to weaken and market-level interest rates continued to rise, in part on anticipation that the central bank would move again.
The prospects are for a further decline in the yen and an increase in the dollar's value. The Bank of Japan is estimated to have spent $5 billion to $8 billion last week alone, and several hundred million dollars more this week in a futile effort to strengthen the yen. The exchange rate has risen to more than 150 yen to the dollar, the highest in more than a year.
''The Bank of Japan has been in the market every day,'' said Yoshi Hashimoto, head of foreign exchange here for the Chase Manhattan Bank. ''They have smothered the market a little bit, but demand for the dollar is still strong.''
A further drop in the yen could send ripples through the country, and higher rates could impede corporate investment. Such investment now equals nearly 25 percent of the gross national product, compared with about 10 percent in the United States, said Mr. Kato of Goldman, Sachs.
But, given the present outlook, all those factors are considered relatively minor. ''There will be some slowdown in growth,'' said Mr. Honda of the Bank of Tokyo. ''It's unfortunate. But corporations are earning record profits. We don't expect that cash flow to really slow soon.''

HEADLINE: Hilton Hotels Rejects Bids; Sale Ended

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 7

 BODY:
Seven months after soliciting bids for all or part of the company, the Hilton Hotels Corporation rejected two acquisition proposals today and said it now intended to remain independent.
Hilton did not provide any details of the offers it rejected, and Hilton executives did not return phone calls requesting comment. But investors apparently expected the news, as Hilton's stock price fell $5.375 a share before the announcement to close at $61 on the New York Stock Exchange. 
A number of potential acquirers are reported to have considered or made offers at various times since the company put itself up for sale last summer, including the JMB Realty Corporation of Chicago, the Miller-Klutznick-Davis-Gray Company, the real estate development company headed by the investor Marvin Davis, a group led by Alfred Checci, who led the buyout of NWA Inc., and a number of Japanese and other foreign concerns.
In a statement, Barron Hilton, the company's chairman, attributed the disappointing bids to the difficulty faced by potential acquirers in raising financing and to the clouded outlook for real estate.
''We have been considering a sale of the company, among other alternatives, since last summer,'' Mr. Hilton said. ''At the time we began the exploration process, the world economy, the market for acquisition financing and the investment climate for real estate and hotels were each far stronger than they are today. The significant adverse developments in each of these areas were reflected in the acquisition proposals we received.''
In a separate statement, the company pointed to a number of ''adverse developments'' affecting potential Japanese acquirers, including increased financing costs in Japan, negative reaction in the United States to Japanese acquisition of highly visible properties and a growing reluctance to pay the premium prices seen in previous hotel deals.
 
Speculative Frenzy
When Hilton put itself on the block, it set off a speculative frenzy in the stock market. Investors, betting that the company would bring a premium price, bid the stock up as high as $115 a share last fall, and some analysts predicted that Hilton could be worth as much as $130 a share.
The stock price, however, declined steadily as it became apparent that there was less interest in Hilton than investors had assumed.
Hilton, which is based in Beverly Hills, Calif., owns and operates hotels and owns casino-hotels in Nevada. The company's earnings last year slumped by 15 percent, to $110.1 million, or $2.27 a share, from $130.9 million, or $2.72 a share.
Mr. Hilton said the company would now focus on expansion plans, including the opening of hotels in London, Hong Kong, Monte Carlo and Cancun, Mexico, and the opening of a new casino-hotel in Laughlin, Nev.

HEADLINE: Fed Currency Activity Low

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The United States sold a modest $750 million for Japanese yen in the foreign currency market and did nothing against the West German mark in the three months ending Jan. 31, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday.
The period had the least amount of intervention of any period since late 1986. 
The intervention occurred on five days during the period when the Fed acted to resist the dollar's rise against the yen, the bank said in its quarterly report to Congress.
A rising dollar makes imports cheaper and exports more expensive, aggravating the United States trade deficit.
The dollar rose 1 percent against the yen in the period but fell 8.5 percent against the West German mark. The mark's gain was fueled by positive sentiment about the opening of the borders between East and West Germany, the report said.
Against the yen, the dollar benefited early in January because of uncertainties about parliamentary elections in Japan. The dollar rose to its high for the period, 146.80 yen, on Jan. 3, the report said. Since then it has risen 2.4 percent to close in New York yesterday at 150.35 yen, despite Fed intervention.
Intervention in the latest period was much lower than in the previous period, when $5.87 billion was sold against the yen and the mark.
The intervention was the least since the period from November 1986 to January 1987, when the Fed bought $50 million. The central bank buys dollars when the currency is weak and poses a danger of inflation.
The latest period had the lowest dollar sales since the August-to-October period of 1987, when the Fed sold $631 million for marks.

HEADLINE: Consumer Debt Rose 5.9% In January on Auto Sales

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 7

 BODY:
Americans took out $3.54 billion more in consumer credit than they retired in January as they flocked to auto dealerships to lock in the latest round of sales incentives, the Federal Reserve reported today.
The Fed said overall consumer credit advanced at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.9 percent following a 7.3 percent gain in December, when holiday shopping was at its peak. Consumer credit includes all consumer loans except mortgages. 
Credit card debt slowed to a 1.4 percent gain at an annual rate, after rising 23.7 percent in the December holiday shopping period.
Revolving credit rose just $243 million in January, compared with a $3.94 billion advance in December. The January gain was the lowest since a $904 million advance last September.
 
Buying Sluggish
Except for auto sales, sluggish consumer buying as the new year began was also reflected in last week's Commerce Department report on personal consumption spending. The report showed that spending slowed from a 1 percent gain in December to a rise of six-tenths of 1 percent in January.
Automobile credit, on the other hand, jumped by a seasonally adjusted $1.86 billion, or 7.7 percent at an annual rate, after falling four-tenths of 1 percent in December before rebates and lower interest rates were reintroduced.
Bank and credit union loans not secured by real estate were up a sharp $1.45 billion, or 8.6 percent, after a 3 percent gain in December.
But outstanding mobile home debt fell $18 million, or nine-tenths of 1 percent. It was the fourth consecutive monthly decline. Mobile home debt for December was revised from a rise of 1.9 percent to a decline of nine-tenths of 1 percent. Mobile home debt fell in 11 of the last 12 months reported, with September's 2.8 percent gain the exception.
The various changes left total consumer debt at the end of January at $720.1 billion.

HEADLINE: Productivity Gain Stands

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 7

 BODY:
The Government left unchanged today its earlier estimates of gains in productivity of two-tenths of 1 percent for the fourth quarter of last year and of nine-tenths of 1 percent for the year.
The Labor Department, in its regular recalculation of figures based on additional data, said output in the fourth quarter was unchanged after reporting earlier that it had declined two-tenths of 1 percent. The figure for hours worked in the quarter was also changed, from a decline of four-tenths of 1 percent to a drop of two-tenths of 1 percent.
The 1989 increase in productivity of nine-tenths of 1 percent compared with a climb of 2 percent in 1988.
Economists have said that the relatively poor showing in productivity is a signal that the economy is weak and might face increased inflationary pressures.
But the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Alan Greenspan, has said the economy has passed its weakest point and sees economic activity increasing at a modest pace this year.
The Labor Department also revised hourly labor costs, a major inflation measure for businesses, to a rise of 5.4 percent in 1989, instead of 5.5 percent. That is up from 4.7 percent in 1988 and represents the biggest rise in such costs since the 1981-82 recession.

HEADLINE: Dow Slides 7.21 Points on Light Volume

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stocks moved narrowly yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average falling 7.21, to 2,669.59, in light volume, as traders marked time until tomorrow's key employment figures for February. The numbers are expected to show continued weakness in the economy.
Volume rose to 163.6 million shares, up from 143.6 million shares on Tuesday. Advances numbered 740 issues and declines 762. 
''The real key to today was yesterday,'' Laszlo Birinyi, president of the Manhattan research firm Birinyi Associates. ''We just stopped and caught our breath. The market overreacted on Tuesday and today was a digestion of Tuesday's 27.25-point gain.''
He noted that there were six periods of computerized ''sell'' programs - most of them of just two or three minutes' duration - when the market lost 17 points. The most significant selling program, he said, was between 3:13 and 3:24 P.M., when the Dow fell 6.98 points, or almost the same as the drop in the Dow at the close of the day.
The industrials moved ahead about 12 points almost from the start but quickly zigzagged a few points up or down until noon and within half an hour headed down 10 points, to 2,674. The Dow rose 5 points within the next hour, fell 4 and then recovered the lost ground by 3 P.M. From that point on, the market headed as low as 2,665 before recovering a few points at the close.
 
Special Market Situations
Special situations continued to dominate the market, with the New York Stock Exchange briefly delaying the start of trading in MGM/UA, Great Northern Nekoosa, Businessland, AAR Corporation, Xtra and Bandag until news developments crossed the stock ticker.
The Big Board halted trading in Nynex between 11:16 A.M. and 1:53 P.M., initially reporting an imbalance of sell orders but quickly changing the reason to pending news. Nynex, the owner of the New York Telephone Company, fell 1 from the price at the halt when trading resumed and ended the day down 2 3/4, to 80 1/2. The New York Public Service Commission said it had rejected a $445 million rate increase for New York Telephone next year.
MGM/UA, the 10th-most-active issue on the Big Board, jumped 3 3/4, or 20 percent, to 17 3/4. The film company said it had agreed to be acquired by Pathe Communications for $20 a share, or $47.2 million. Nekoosa fell 5/8, to 65. Georgia-Pacific, which completed its $65.75-a-share offer for Nekoosa on Tuesday, said it had accepted about 53.8 million shares from stockholders and now held 97.3 percent of Nekoosa.
Businessland, the computer store chain, rose 2, or 22.9 percent, to 10 3/4 on 1.2 million shares. After breaking with Businessland last April, Compaq Computer said it had authorized the chain to sell and service its products nationwide.
 
Airline Supplier Down
AAR slid 4 1/8, or 15 percent, to 27 1/2, with 909,300 shares traded. The airline supplier said its profits in the third fiscal quarter would be lower than expected because a foreign contract did not develop. Xtra fell 1 5/8, to 30 1/4. The leasing and transportation company said it would not consider bids it had invited for the company before its annual meeting next Thursday, when a proxy fight by dissident stockholders would determine the makeup of the board.
Bandag, the world's biggest producer of rubber and supplies for retreaded tires, rose 3 1/4, to 83 3/4. Scott Merlis, an analyst with Morgan Stanley & Company, said Bandag would benefit from laws in 20 states that encourage retreading instead of creating environmental problems by throwing tires away.
Polaroid, which rose 2 3/8, to 45 1/4, last week and 2 5/8, to 46 1/4, in the first two days of this week, fell 5/8, to 47 1/4. Kodak rose 1 1/2, to 39 7/8, with 1.28 million shares changing hands.
Alex Henderson of Prudential-Bache Securities cut his rating on the stock to a ''hold'' from a ''buy,'' contending that the stock had already risen in response to a big court award it was expected to get from Kodak in a patent-infringement suit. Reuters, the news agency, said Mr. Henderson estimated Polaroid's award at $1.5 billion but that Peter Enderlin of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company reiterated Polaroid as a ''buy,'' forecasting a $2 billion award soon.
USX, the oil and steel producer, fell 1 3/8, to 35 5/8 in heavy trading. Armstrong World fell 1, to 35 3/8. The Wall Street Journal mentioned both yesterday among companies threatened by battles to unseat management. Hilton fell 5 3/8, to 61, in brisk trading amid growing sentiment that the hotel company might not be sold.
Among other market averages, the Dow transportations fell 13.16, to 1,135.31, with USAir off 1 5/8, to 28 3/8; Conrail 1, to 46 1/8, and Union Pacific 1 3/8, to 74 3/8. The S. & P. 500 fell 0.98, to 336.95, and the Big Board composite 0.40, to 185.77. The Amex market value index rose 0.22, to 359.03, and the Nasdaq composite 0.14, to 432.47.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Trading in Dollar Is Mixed Despite Central Banks' Sales

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed in foreign exchange trading yesterday as it struggled against a concerted effort by central banks to lower it.
Gold prices fell, closing below $400 an ounce in London and at $400.20, down $3.40, on the Commodity Exchange in New York. The Republic National Bank of New York later quoted a bid of $400.60 an ounce, down $2.85 from late Tuesday. 
Traders said the Federal Reserve and other central banks had entered the currency markets to sell dollars, and a published report in Tokyo said the members of the Group of Seven industrial nations had agreed to intervene to try to stop the dollar's climb.
A Treasury official in Washington, however, said that there was no G-7 meeting and that confusion apparently had arisen because of a quarterly meeting that is taking place in Tokyo of the so-called Working Party 3 of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. The Working Party 3 group is made up of officials from the leading industrial nations and they discuss balance of payments outlook of the member countries.
The way was set, however, for closer coordination between the United States and Japan last weekend when President Bush and Prime Minister Kaifu discusssed cooperation in the currency markets at their Palm Springs meeting.
 
Up Against Yen
The intervention in the markets yesterday was only partly successful. The dollar rose sharply in Europe and was mixed in New York, where it still managed to advance against the yen, the currency that the Group of Seven is trying the hardest to bolster.
In New York, the dollar rose to 150.35 yen, from 149.85 late Tuesday. In Tokyo, the dollar climbed to 150.75 yen, from 149.50 yen on Tuesday. It was quoted in London at 151.15 yen.
Richard Levine, the vice president for foreign exchange at Elders Futures Inc., said the dollar appeared to be rising on commercial and investment demand, and not just on speculation.
''We haven't seen this kind of demand for dollars since the end of 1989, and probably going back to the summer of 1989,'' Mr. Levin said.
Overseas traders said the continuing lack of confidence in the yen and the West German mark, as well as a brighter view of the United States economy, was also supporting the dollar.
Against the West German currency, the dollar fell in New York to 1.69815 marks, compared with late Tuesday's 1.7035.
The dollar gained against the pound. In New York, sterling slipped to $1.6465, from 1.6475 late Tuesday. In earlier London trading, the pound fell to $1.6388, from $1.6495.
Gold dealers blamed the high dollar and a stronger Wall Street for gold's decline. Advances in the dollar and the stock markets have made gold a less attractive investment.

HEADLINE: William Appleman Williams Dies; Gadfly of Foreign Policy Was 68

BYLINE: By PETER B. FLINT

 BODY:
William Appleman Williams, a historian known for his sharp critiques of American foreign policy, died of cancer Monday at Newport (Ore.) Community Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived on the Oregon coast at Waldport. 
Dr. Williams was a prolific and influential writer of a dozen revisionist books that challenged prevailing views of American history, deploring the United States as an imperialist power pressing its economic and ideological will around the globe. He was a professor at the University of Wisconsin from 1960 to 1968 and at Oregon State University from 1968 to 1986, when he retired with the title emeritus.
The genially combative professor, who termed himself a radical and was often called the founder of the New Left school of American history, was particulary critical of America's role in the cold war and in Vietnam.
With passionate argument and complex analysis, he championed self-determination for all people and argued that a refusal by Americans to acknowledge a national desire for expansion and global hegemony has led to major errors and confusion over the nation's future.
 
Focus on Self-Determination
''The act of imposing one people's morality upon another people is an imperial denial of self-determination,'' he wrote in his 1976 book ''America Confronts a Revolutionary World: 1776-1976.'' ''Once begun, there is no end of empire except war and more war.''
Detractors accused him and other revisionists of employing a double-standard: of justifying or explaining Soviet actions by citing national security while measuring western actions against a utopian ideal. Reviewers termed his works provocative, honestly stated and admirable, but they challenged some arguments as flawed, simplistic and naive in relying on good intentions and communal feeling.
His other books include ''American-Russian Relations, 1781-1947'' (1952), ''The Shaping of American Diplomacy, 1750-1955'' (1956, 1962, 1970), ''The Tragedy of American Diplomacy'' (1959, 1962, 1972), ''The Contours of American History'' (1962, 1966) and ''The Roots of the Modern American Empire'' (1969).
The historian was a native of Atlantic, Iowa, and a graduate of the United States Naval Academy, where he earned a bachelor's degree in engineering. In World War II, he was a Navy line officer in the Pacific and was later treated for battle wounds for more than a year.
He earned master's and doctoral degrees at the University of Wisconsin and taught history at six colleges. He also taught at the University of Melbourne as a Fulbright scholar in 1977, was president of the Organization of American Historians in 1980 and taught a course in maritime history at the Oregon Coast Community College last fall.
Survivors include his wife, Wendy; a son, Ward, of San Francisco; two daughters, Kyenne, of Madison, Wis., and Savoy Jade, of Hull, Mass.; two stepchildren, Justin, of Eugene, Ore., and Kathy, of Beavercreek, Ore., and three stepgrandchildren.

HEADLINE: Study Calls $2,200 Heart Drug No Better Than Cheaper One

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN

 BODY:
An expensive drug that is widely used to treat heart attacks in the United States is no more effective than a cheaper alternative commonly used in Europe, researchers in Italy reported yesterday.
In the first large-scale direct comparison of the two drugs, the researchers found no statistically significant difference in the death rates, heart function or complications among 12,381 heart attack patients. The drug commonly used in this country, tissue plasminogen activator, or T.P.A., and streptokinase, dissolve the blood clots that form within fat-damaged coronary arteries to cause heart attacks.
The results of the Italian study could have a major impact on the treatment of heart attacks in the United States because of the vast difference in cost of the two drugs. 
 
A Dose Costs $2,200
T.P.A. was developed in the 1980's through advanced genetic techniques. It costs $2,200 for each dose, and more than one dose might be necessary during hospitalization. It is sold as Activase by Genentech Inc. of South San Francisco. Streptokinase, which is a protein derived from streptococcal bacteria, costs $186 each dose, although some hospitals pay as little as $76. It is made by Hoechst-Roussel Pharmaceuticals Inc. of Somerville, N. J. ''Streptokinase would now appear to be the drug of choice based on factors of cost,'' said Dr. Claude J. Lenfant, the director of the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute in Bethesda, Md. But he added that the price of T.P.A. might fall as technological improvements reduced production costs.
G. Kirk Raab, president and chief executive of Genentech, said the results were disappointing for his company but argued that they were ''inconclusive'' because the researchers did not immediately report results on the use of T.P.A. in combination with another drug, heparin. He said many American doctors believe the combination is highly effective.
The value of clot-dissolving drugs has been proved in earlier studies, and much smaller comparative studies of these two drugs have shown results similar to those reported yesterday. The drugs are credited with helping to improve survival and shorten the length of hospital stays among the 1.5 million Americans who suffer a heart attack each year. About half a million of them die, making heart attacks the leading cause of death in the United States.
The new study, reported at a meeting of Italian cardiologists in Florence, also showed that the standard therapies, including one of the clot-dissolving drugs, aspirin and other heart drugs, are continuing to improve prospects of survival.
 
Debate Over Drug Choice
Despite the benefit of clot-dissolving drugs, doctors throughout the world heatedly debate the choice of which one to use. T.P.A. is the overwhelming choice among American physicians, while streptokinase is heavily favored in Europe.
American doctors have turned heavily to T.P.A. because a number of studies of that drug alone have shown its ability to dissolve a clot quickly and effectively in a large percentage of cases. It is also considered less likely to cause an allergic reaction. The drug has also been heavily promoted by Genentech.
One other clot-dissolving drug, Eminase, is marketed in the United States by SmithKline Beecham. It was not included in the Italian study but is being directly compared with T.P.A. and streptokinase in an international study now under way. A fourth clot-dissolving drug, urokinase, is not licensed for use in this country.
 
Findings of Other Studies
The results released yesterday dealt only with the period of a heart attack patient's stay in one of the 223 Italian coronary care units in the study. Dr. Lenfant cautioned that further analysis would be needed to determine whether differences in the benefits of the two drugs would arise over a longer period.
Other studies have shown that T.P.A. can dissolve a clot quicker and more effectively than streptokinase, which is one reason American doctors prefer it over streptokinase. Thus, Dr. Lenfant said, long-term data from the Italian and other studies now under way might show a weakening of the heart muscle when the results are further analyzed six months after the patients suffered heart attacks.
Nevertheless, Dr. Lenfant said, the Italian study will have an impact because everyone was waiting for the results. ''It is provocative, but not necessarily in the way many people expected,'' Dr. Lenfant said.
In the Italian study, all 12,381 patients received standard cardiac care, including aspirin, and other heart drugs like those belonging to a class known as beta blockers. The patients also agreed to receive by random choice either streptokinase or T.P.A. if they were admitted to the hospital within six hours of the onset of the symptoms of a heart attack.
Heart attack symptoms can include steady pain in the chest or arm and nausea and vomiting.
Of the 6,182 patients who received injections of T.P.A., 556 died; 478 suffered clinical heart failure; 117 suffered a second heart attack during the hospital stay, and 576 developed angina, which can produce chest and arm pain from an inadequate supply of blood to the heart as a result of blockage of the coronary arteries.
 
Comparison of 2 Groups
By comparison, of the 6,199 patients who received streptokinase, 536 died; 502 developed clinical heart failure; 146 suffered a second heart attack during the hospital stay, and 619 developed angina.
The 70 strokes suffered among recipients of T.P.A. compared with 54 among the streptokinase group. But the numerical differences of the complications or results among the streptokinase and T.P.A. groups were not found to be statistically meaningful.
''Clearly, you cannot say on clinical grounds that T.P.A. is better than streptokinase, or vice versa, because they are just the same,'' said Dr. Silvio Garattini , the director of the Mario Negro Pharmacological Institute in Milan. His institute sponsored the study with Italian cardiologists.
But Dr. Garattini added that other medical considerations like allergies to streptokinase might lead a physician to choose T.P.A..
The Italian researchers said that the choice of drug ''must take full account of public health economy considerations.'' In the United States, health insurance plans generally cover the costs of clot-dissolving drugs.
Each of the two groups was divided into two additional groups. By another random selection these patients received either no additional drug or heparin, a drug that reduces the ability of the blood to form clots.
 
Excess of Bleeding
The researchers said they found ''a clear excess of bleeding complications in the heparin-treated group'' without any benefit to their survival or heart function.
American researchers have criticized the Italian study because the heparin was started 12 hours after admission to a hospital. But Dr. Garattini, the chairman of the meeting where the findings were reported, said the choice of timing ''was logical when we began the study two years ago and no one has any data to say it is better to give it any earlier.''
The study reported yesterday was the second by the same Italian group. The first involved only streptokinase and in 1986 the researchers proved the value of the drug in reducing the death rate from heart attacks. Aspirin was not widely used in the first study, but beta blockers and other cardiac drugs were often prescribed.
 
Typical Heart Patient
Dr. Garattini said in a telephone interview from Florence that the study represented the typical patient treated for a heart attack in Italian hospitals.
He said the newest combination of therapies led to a continued improvement in survival from heart attacks. The Italian researchers said the 8.8 percent probability of dying during hospital treatment for a heart attack had dropped dramatically from a baseline of 13 percent in 1986 before the first study.
The 8.8 percent figure was also a drop from a baseline of 10.2 percent recorded in the group that was treated with streptokinase in the first study.

HEADLINE: Sharm el Sheik Journal;
Hotels. Divers. Next for a Fragile Reef: A Bridge?

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SHARM EL SHEIK, Egypt

 BODY:
This is a place where the fish, the foreigners and the flights of entrepreneurial fancy blend in symbiosis: the fish bejewel the coral reef, the foreigners dive to see them and the entrepreneurs build the hostelries where the foreigners rest when the fish viewing is done.
Yet, as environmentalists and ecologists contemplate the future of one of the region's last unspoiled marine sanctuaries, they see perils on the horizon.
One is the hunger of distant collectors for rare species of the fish that congregate in spangled multitude along the reef. Another is the unbridled rush into hotel building that has turned the beachfront into a construction site. But the largest, laden with issues of Arab pride, is a suggestion by Saudi Arabia and Egypt that they link their lands by a 15-mile system of causeways and a bridge soaring over the waters of the Strait of Tiran just north of here. 
''This is a very sensitive issue,'' said a foreign expert, who cited the sensitivity as his reason for asking not to be quoted by name. ''Each time outsiders start talking about it, the resolve to go ahead with the plan deepens.''
 
Backpackers and Scuba Divers
If the project proceeds, the expert said, great chunks of coral reef will be destroyed, causing unforeseeable ecological harm elsewhere along the reef, which hugs the coastline for miles.
Egypt regained the Sinai under its 1979 peace treaty with Israel, which seized it during the 1967 Middle East War. Israeli entrepreneurs had already, planted the seeds of mass tourism with a hotel and holiday apartments here. Until last year, it was still possible to find road signs in Hebrew pointing the way north through the dry, serrated mountains, where an array of fortifications displays the area's potential as a focus of conflict. Indeed, the 1967 war began after Egypt closed the Strait of Tiran.
In more recent years, the warriors have largely given way to backpackers and scuba divers from Europe arriving in increasing numbers at the small airport. With the people have come more hotels, and boutiques and antique shops. And, as modernity has spread where once the Bedouins and their camels roamed undisturbed, the Egyptian authorities and foreign conservationists have sought to preserve the pristine waters, to protect the angelfish and parrotfish as well as the tourism they lure.
A project sponsored by the United States Agency for International Development seeks to persuade about 300 Bedouin fishermen to abandon the traditional way of catching fish by standing on the coral reef with gill nets. The idea, an American official said, is to persuade the Bedouins to use larger nets and fish beyond the reef from boats.
 
Project's Affect on the Region
Environmentalists, moreover, try to keep watch for the shadowy agents of companies supplying aquariums, who offer the local fishermen good money for rare fish.
A wedge of land around the Sinai's tip has been declared a national park and other places have been named protected areas where developers may not build hotels. At the entrance to the Ras Mohammed National Park, a warden checks car trunks for booty - coral or rare fish.
But the Saudi-Egyptian bridge project could change the region's character.
''The bridge is still an idea that is going through a lot of studies at the moment,'' said Abdel Maqsud Ahmed, an official of the Ministry of Transport and Communications who is said to be the leader in pressing for the construction of the bridge. ''We are studying all aspects of the project, including the environmental aspect and the environmentalists' objections. Environment and nature are now very important to Egypt as a means of living.''
 
Threat to Coral Reef
Despite those assurances, some remain unconvinced. ''Those who think the project will be a plus do not think in terms of environmental considerations, but maybe in other terms,'' said Mohammed Ibrahim of the Government's Environment al Affairs Department. He declined to go into detail, saying the authorities had given no ''green light'' for open debate of the idea.
Others, who asked not to be identified, seemed less constrained. ''You open that bridge and there'll be traffic jams for miles either side of it,'' said a foreign specialist. ''You'll be getting bridge tolls. But you'll lose tourism.''
The idea apparently is to build a series of causeways from the Saudi side to Tiran Island, and then to build a single span across the remaining two miles of strait.
''It would mean destroying coral reef to sink foundations, and no one knows how that would effect the ecological chain,'' the foreign expert said.
 
Issues of Arab Brotherhood
The idea became public when Saudi Arabia renewed ties with Egypt last year and King Fahd visited Cairo and talked with President Hosni Mubarak. The project would provide a road link for the Muslims of Egypt and North Africa to the Islamic shrines of Saudi Arabia during the annual pilgrimage to Mecca.
The idea thus evokes not only issues of Arab brotherhood and pride in the face of perceived interference by outsiders opposing the idea but also the profound passions of Islam.
It is unclear what benefits the bridge would bring to travelers in other seasons, because of the distance between the major cities the bridge would connect. The trip to Sharm el Sheik is now six hours by car from Cairo, and Jidda and Mecca are another 600 miles to the southeast.
But for those who would build it, at least, the bridge project conjures images of great profit.
Newspaper reports in Cairo initially suggested that the bridge would cost $600 million. But some informal estimates by American engineers put the final cost in billions of dollars. That helps explain why, shortly after the idea was made public last year, six Japanese businessmen arrived here, residents said, inquiring about contracts.

GRAPHIC: Photo: For the coral reefs and tropical fish that attract tourists and divers, above, to coastal Sharm el Sheik, Egypt, the ecological future is uncertain. Marine life may be threatened by the surge in development along the beach, as well as a proposed 15-mile system of causeways to link Saudi Arabia with Egypt. (The New York Times/Ingeborg Lippmann); map of Egypt showing location of Sharm el Sheik (The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Nixon Treated as Hero In Halls of His Disgrace

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 8

 BODY:
Congressional aides with only distant childhood memories of Watergate applauded, cheered and jostled one another to shake his hand. Newt Gingrich, the House Republican whip, positively glowed. Even the worldly Bob Dole, the Senate Republican leader, seemed a bit nonplussed.
Richard M. Nixon returned today to Capitol Hill, the scene of his downfall, for his most public appearance here since the Watergate scandal drove him from the Presidency in 1974. 
Grayer, more hesitant in his walk than when he last strode the corridors of Congress, but holding himself regally and exuding good humor, Mr. Nixon lectured Republicans in Congress on the dramatic turnings in world events.
The former President, who knows something about how to make a comeback, gave advice to senators seeking re-election this year, held his first Washington news conference since he resigned and basked a bit in the restored political glow that he has been carefully acquiring.
 
Living History Speaks
Mr. Dole said as he emerged from a 30-minute meeting with Mr. Nixon that the former President was ''rehabilitated'' and jested that as for making a new bid for office, ''I think he's going to announce.''
Mr. Gingrich, after a 90-minute meeting of the House Republican Conference - Mr. Nixon's official reason for being here - said several times that it had been an ''extraordinary'' experience to hear Mr. Nixon speak about China, Eastern Europe and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union. ''It's almost eerie to hear a man who is a living example of history,'' he said.
Mr. Nixon applauded President Bush's overtures to China, said Poland's efforts at free-market reform ''must not fail'' and said it was up to the United States to assure ''the victory of freedom'' as Communist power crumbled. But he opposed economic aid to the Soviet Union and said that while the cold war was ''probably'' over in Europe, it was continuing in the developing nations.
In recent years, Mr. Nixon has systematically shed the seclusion of those days after his resignation. He has lectured widely, granted television and print interviews and written treatises on foreign affairs.
 
Heavy Turnout by the Young
He visited the Reagan White House with other former Presidents. Mr. Bush had him to an intimate dinner last year to talk about China, which Mr. Nixon was responsible for ''reopening'' in 1972.
He visited Congress last December for a quiet dinner at which Mr. Dole was the host. Today's trip was far more public, with a news conference, photo opportunities with members of Congress and staffs and halls lined with well-wishers. It seemed to symbolize emergence from the chrysalis of a political disgrace into a new role as an elder statesman, at least within the Republican Party.
Congressional aides in their early 20's turned out by the dozens for him today. Ripples of applause and cheers followed Mr. Nixon as he walked, limping slightly, down the corridors of the Longworth House Office Building, just next door to the Raeburn Building, where the House Judiciary Committee once deliberated his fate.
Mr. Nixon came late to the crowded news conference in the building's lobby after his session with the House Republican Conference: he had to pose for pictures with scores of lawmakers, lobbyists, staff members and others.
 
On Reagan: No Cover-Up
Mr. Dole said several Congressional security officers wanted to be photographed with Mr. Nixon ''and we didn't ask for their party affiliations.''
At the news conference Mr. Nixon, who never seemed comfortable in hot television lights, wiped his face several times with a handkerchief. When a reporter called him ''Mr. Gorbachev'' by mistake, he laughed and said, ''I've been called worse.''
He was asked about the Iran-contra affair and the videotaped testimony in which Mr. Reagan said he could not recall much of those events. Mr. Reagan, Mr. Nixon said, was not a crook. ''How this man, who is 79 years of age, could not have made more mistakes and forgotten more I don't know,'' said the 77-year-old Mr. Nixon. ''I think that President Reagan was not trying to dissemble. He was not trying to cover up.''
He was asked if he felt ''at peace'' now with himself. ''I'll save that for the next conference,'' he said. ''I know that I'm getting older and the press seems to be getting younger.''
 
U.S. Policy, China, Communism
Asked about his return to Capitol Hill, he again avoided answering in the context of his resignation. ''It's good to be back here where my political career started 43 years ago,'' said Mr. Nixon, who was a California Congressman in the late 1940's.
Generally, he tried to keep the focus on foreign policy, He said he supported Mr. Bush's secret missions to China: ''If the United States does not play a role in China, who does that leave among the major powers? It leaves the Soviet Union and Japan. Does anyone think the Soviet Union is going to export human rights to China? And anyone that thinks Japan is going to export democracy to China must be smoking pot.''
He spoke of the changes in Eastern Europe with admiration and said Mr. Bush and Congress must ''see that after the defeat of Communism that freedom works.''
Senator Dole overflowed with praise for Mr. Nixon's foreign policy acumen, even if he was a bit more reserved about his political role. ''I think he's an excellent fund-raiser,'' he said. ''Rehabilitated? That means a lot of things to a lot of people. I think he is.''
A Republican senator's aide scurried out of Mr. Dole's office to grab colleagues for picture-taking with Mr. Nixon. ''He's doing great,'' the aide shouted over his shoulder. ''He's back.''

CORRECTION-DATE: March 13, 1990, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article on Friday about a visit to Washington by former President Richard M. Nixon misidentified the building in which the House Judiciary Committee met to consider articles of impeachment against Mr. Nixon. It was the Rayburn House Office Building; the Russell Senate Office Building is on the other side of the Capitol.

HEADLINE: Bush Transportation Policy Assailed

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 8

 BODY:
The Bush Administration's new transportation policy was sharply criticized today by many members of Congress and by state and local officials, most of whom disagreed with its shift from Federal spending toward local spending on mass transit and highways.
''It does nothing to show me a recognition that the nation is facing a growing transportation crisis,'' said Representative Glenn M. Anderson, a California Democrat who is chairman of the House Public Works and Transportation Committee. ''When it comes to the crunch of making a national commitment to invest in our future, the report is lacking.''
The policy, announced today at the White House, calls for the Federal Government to focus its efforts on projects of national significance, like major interstate highways. It also calls for state and local governments to increase their own taxes and expenditures for other projects, at a time when major cost increases are forecast for roads, airports, rail lines and other transportation needs. 
 
Opposition Grows More Vocal
Many details of the Administration's policy had been disclosed in recent days and weeks. Today, opposition to its central premises grew more vocal.
''This plan perpetuates the existing Federal fiscal policies that continually seek to force state and local governments to pick up the slack for proposed Federal cutbacks in domestic programs,'' said Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York.
He released a state study showing a steady decline in the Federal Government's share of national spending on highways and mass transit over the past decade.
Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, a New York Republican who is on the Senate Appropriations Committee's transportation subcommittee, said: ''I don't see how we make any progress with this approach. The policy limps because there is not sufficient revenue allocated to it.''
Bipartisan groups, like the National Governors' Association, that had been involved in consultations with the Administration on its policy praised the Administration for issuing a report focusing attention on transportation needs. But the praise was faint.
''I feel like the fellow with one foot in a bucket of ice and the other in a bucket of hot coals,'' said Gov. Wallace G. Wilkinson of Kentucky. ''On average, I feel okay.'' A Democrat who is vice chairman of the governors' transportation committee, he spoke to reporters outside the White House after hearing President Bush and Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner present the policy report.
''Will more of the burden be shifted to the states, and if so, how much?'' he asked. ''More and more and more of the burden is being shifted to the states, and our ability to handle those things is getting less and less and less.''
 
Skinner Confirms a Shift
Mr. Skinner, at a White House news conference, said, ''We feel that state and local governments have not provided a sufficient amount of infrastructure funding.'' The Administration feels strongly that operating subsidies for mass transit should stop, and it also has proposed eliminating Federal subsidies for Amtrak, the passenger railroad. Both of these policies have been adamantly resisted by Congress for years.
Although the policy statement released today contains no specific budget or cost figures, Mr. Skinner said that the Federal Government would continue to increase total transportation spending even as it shifts many responsibilities to state and local governments. The amounts, he said, would depend on legislation to extend and renew aviation, highway, mass transit and other programs, which Congress is expected to enact in the coming two years. Currently, the Federal Government spends $27 billion a year on transportation, about one-fifth of all public spending on transportation.
''Over all, I am hopeful that it will be growing,'' he said. ''We call for a greater local share and a greater Federal share.''
But Francis Francois, executive director of the American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials, said: ''We have been doing more for some time. In point of fact, the Federal Government has been a junior partner.''
Mr. Francois said his group wants Federal highway aid to increase initially to $18 billion annually from $14.7 billion and grow over a four-year period to as much as $26 billion a year. He said states and local governments should make proportionate increases.
The National Conference of State Legislatures, however, strongly supported the Administration plan to increase state financing of transportation. ''We applaud Secretary Skinner for his effort to realign roles and responsibilities,'' said William Pound, the group's executive director. ''State officials are best able to determine the needs in their individual states.''
Some transportation experts focused on the management of several multibillion-dollar trust funds that collect fees from users of the transportation system and allocate the money to Federal aid programs.
A coalition of 16 aviation industry groups, for example, denounced the Administration's plans to increase airline ticket taxes to 10 percent from 8 percent and to use the aviation trust fund to pay a higher percentage of the operating costs of the air traffic control system. Instead, the industry argued, the Administration should leave ticket taxes where they are and use the fund for a faster modernization of air traffic control equipment.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Bush greeting members of Congress yesterday after he presented his new transportation program. Secretary of Transportation Samuel K. Skinner, left, also gave a briefing on the program. (The New York Times/Michael Geissinger)

HEADLINE: SENATOR TO SEEK BIG MILITARY CUTS

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 8

 BODY:
The chairman of the Senate Budget Committee said today that he would seek to cut $12 billion from the Bush Administration's proposed military budget of $303.3 billion for the next fiscal year.
The chairman, Senator James Sasser, Democrat of Tennessee, offered only a limited picture of the effect such a cut would have on weapons, personnel levels and research spending.
But as justification for seeking a cut of about 4 percent from the Administration's proposal, he cited testimony last week from the Director of Central Intelligence, William H. Webster, that the Soviet threat is fast receding.
''I believe Director Webster has pushed the defense debate beyond its early stages of uncertainty,'' Mr. Sasser said at a hearing where the Congressional Budget Office outlined options for cuts in military spending. 
 
Warning on 'Internal' Inertia
''The impediments to achieving a real peacetime defense budget are managerial, bureacratic, sometimes political,'' he said. ''They have little to do with the threats we face from without and a lot to do with the inertia we must overcome from within.''
Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has publicly disagreed with Mr. Webster's assessment, and over the weekend said the intelligence chief's comments were ''not helpful'' to his effort to gain Congressional support for the Administration's defense plans.
Mr. Sasser said there was a good chance other Democrats on the budget panel would support his recommendation. He described Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia, who heads the Senate Armed Services Committee, and Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, who heads the Senate Appropriations Committee, as neutral.
 
First Step of Many
Although Mr. Sasser's recommendation represents the first of many steps in Congressional consideration of the military budget, and precedes a more detailed review of strategy and spending by the House and Senate panels that directly oversee military policy, it is likely to serve as a benchmark figure for the Senate in the months ahead.
The Congressional Budget Office, the nonpartisan research arm of Congress, has prepared five different alternatives for spending. They range from saving $9 billion over five years, by making minimal changes in policy to meet the requirements of expected agreements on arms and conventional forces, to saving up to $80 billion over five years, through large reductions in active American forces and scrapping strategic weapons systems.
If current policies were to continue unchanged, military spending adjusted to keep pace for inflation would be $306.4 in the 1991 fiscal year.
The Senate Armed Services Committee, which is still months away from drafting guidelines for the military program, is looking at a spending level that would translate to cuts of between $3 billion and $4 billion from the Bush proposal, said Senator Jim Exon, a Nebraska Democrat a member of both committees and generally a conservative on military matters.
''I can't tell you exactly where it will come out, but I'll be recommending something below $300 billion,'' he told reporters today.
 
Voice for Smaller Cuts
Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, the senior Republican on the Senate Budget Committee, said cuts in that range sounded far more plausible than the reduction Mr. Sasser was discussing. ''I just don't believe that much is possible in the first year,'' he said, adding that for now he is prepared to stick with the Bush figures.
While the Armed Services Committees in both the House and Senate are responsible for drawing up a comprehensive plan for what the Pentagon spends and for how military resources are deployed, the Congressional budget process requires the House and Senate budget panels to act first and produce a blueprintfor the overall Federal budget. Mr. Sasser's committee is hoping to begin is budget drafting in late April.
In the House, Democrats remain deeply divided over how much to cut the military spending and are looking at cuts that range between $10 billion and $16 billion. Liberals in the House say they are convinced that the Senate will ulitmately approve a military spending level much higher than most Democrats would favor, and part of the jockeying that has started reflects a desire to give the House bargaining room on the final number.
''Those of us who want to cut the defense budget realize that this is a five-year struggle, not a one year struggle,'' said Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat who is a member of the House Budget Committee. ''We want to really get the number lower, not just have an opportunity to vote for a lower number and lose.''

HEADLINE: $150 Billion a Year

SERIES: Second of two articles.

 BODY:

How to Spend It
Yes, there is a peace dividend, a fabulous fortune to be amassed as defense spending is gradually scaled down. By 1999, the amount could readily reach $150 billion a year. But already the line of people with worthy claims on the windfall stretches around the block.
Spend the money, some say, to strengthen the new democracies of Eastern Europe. Use it, others say, to make up for starved social spending in this country. No, say still others, including President Bush, use it to reduce the immense Federal deficit. Indeed, last week the Senate passed a non-binding resolution to do just that. 
How should the country spend the peace dividend? One principle can usefully guide debate because it guarantees political consensus:
Invest in the future. Make Americans more productive by focusing on two urgent needs - the health and education of youth, and the crumbling national infrastructure.
Cutting back the mountainous deficit, per the Senate resolution, is responsible. But it is misguided and unnecessary. It's misguided because public investment in the economic future is every bit as important as reducing the deficit. It's unnecessary because deficit cuts already scheduled under the Gramm-Rudman law should suffice.
The larger task before Congress is to promote economic growth. Using the dividend to reduce the deficit would help do that. Smaller deficits would mean less Government borrowing, leaving more money in private capital markets to fuel corporate innovation and investment.
But it would promote growth at least as much to earmark the dividend for the needs of children and infrastructure. The economy needs a better-educated work force and an efficient transportation system at least as much as more investment by General Motors and Sears. Public investments need to be debated on their individual merits, not rejected in slavish devotion to deficit reduction.
 
What's the Right Size Deficit?
Experts disagree about the desirable level of deficit, leaving the public uncertain. Benjamin Friedman, a Harvard economist, cites the savings rate, low and falling, as a cause of low investment, sluggish productivity and increased reliance on foreign capital. No one of these trends is cataclysmic; the combination is frightening. His remedy is to increase savings by insisting that the $100 billion deficit - counting Social Security - be converted by tax hikes and spending cuts into a $60 billion surplus.
But Robert Eisner, an economist at Northwestern University, vehemently disagrees. He argues that the savings rate, excluding public investment, is not too low. Keeping deficits in the vicinity of $150 billion is just fine, because that would keep Federal debt from growing faster than the economy does.
Even without the peace dividend, the deficit is already scheduled to fall. Unless Congress wholly abandons its Gramm-Rudman targets, the deficit -counting Social Security - will be eliminated by the mid-90's. That target is stricter than Dr. Eisner's, looser than Dr. Friedman's. If it is the wrong target, it would not seem to err by much. For the next few years, the Gramm-Rudman targets will produce deficits that are modest by both historical and international standards.
The case for driving the deficit much lower is unproven. That being so, Congress would be wise to use the unexpected peace dividend for public investment. The proper test is how well the investment works - will it enlarge the economic pie? - not how much it affects the deficit. America's human resources and physical capital are too important to sacrifice at the arbitrary altar of deficit reduction.
 
Put Americans in the Fast Lane
For a decade, needed public investments have been squeezed out by tax cuts, rising military spending and middle class entitlements. Americans pay the cost in the form of airport congestion, decrepit bridges and freeway tie-ups. They also pay for the lost investment in people.
Investments in Human Resources. The most compelling challenge is to give a fair chance for productive lives to the next generation of Americans, one in four of whom is now born into poverty. Programs that do that pay off immediately, commonly saving three and four times their cost in remedial programs.
Funds from the peace dividend would magnify the gains - and the savings. A billion dollars would give comprehensive prenatal health care to an additional 1.5 million poor pregnant women. An additional billion would add 400,000 children to Head Start, which, though widely successful, still reaches only one eligible child in five. Every dollar spent on Head Start, experts say, saves almost $5 in welfare, remedial education and other costs.
Investments in Infrastructure. The nation's transportation network has also been allowed to deteriorate. According to the Federal Transportation Department, urban areas now experience two billion hours a year of highway delays. Flight delays at 21 primary airports amount to 20,000 hours a year. Peace dividend money can bring relief and promote economic growth.
There are other worthy, perhaps even compelling purposes for which the peace dividend might be earmarked - including, notably, the environment. If there's to be public debate about the agenda, however, it better start soon. Otherwise, this rare windfall will dribble back into Washington's workaday stew of needs, claims and special interests. The point resounds, for Congress and even more for the present occupant of the Bully Pulpit: This is a precious moment, but only if they seize it.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Nicaragua Votes for End to Washington's Siege;
Cuba's Turn?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
William Safire gleefully predicts in ''Castro's Last Stand'' (column, Feb. 19) the ''coming downfall'' of President Fidel Castro of Cuba. He links this event to ''the economic crisis facing his Soviet sponsors'' and other political changes sweeping the Communist world in Eastern Europe.
I am neither a seer nor a booster of the Castro regime, and Mr. Safire's prediction may well come true. His views, however, appear to be based on wishful thinking and an astonishing ignorance of Cuba. 
President Castro, in power since 1959, has outlasted seven United States Presidents, and I am willing to make a modest even-money wager with Mr. Safire that he may still be around when President Bush completes his term in 1993.
One key reason President Castro stands a chance of survival is that his Government must be viewed in its regional context. The crumbling Communist regimes of Eastern Europe were economic basket cases compared with their Western European neighbors. But Cuba, while far poorer than the neighboring United States, provides a standard of living that is comparable, and in several cases superior, to that in most other Caribbean and Central American countries.
Cubans, despite limits on personal freedom and the clear (to me) shortcomings of a centralized Communist economic system, are better fed, housed and educated, and enjoy better health care than do the citizens of several nearby countries with a capitalist system. Infant mortality in Cuba, for example, is now about 11 per 1,000 births, about the same as New Zealand and Israel, far lower than that of such free enterprise neighbors as the Dominican Republic (66), Haiti (118), Honduras (70), Guatemala (60), El Salvador (60), Trinidad (20), Jamaica (18) and Costa Rica (18).
And while Cuba is in the midst of a serious economic crisis, the same can be said of many of its non-Communist regional neighbors, overwhelmed by debt and inflation. Their exports command successively lower prices on the world market, and their citizens continue to migrate to the United States in search of opportunity. Third world underdevelopment is a tenacious problem that crosses ideological barriers and defies simple formulas.
These facts Mr. Safire forgets or chooses to ignore. As for human rights, he is curiously selective when he rails against the ''tyranny'' in Cuba, while making no mention of murder and mayhem committed by governments in Haiti, Guatemala and El Salvador.
 
KAL WAGENHEIM
Maplewood, N.J., Feb. 21, 1990
 The writer is editor of Caribbean Update, a monthly newsletter.

HEADLINE: Nicaragua Votes for End to Washington's Siege

 BODY:
To the Editor:
To understand what happened in the Feb. 25 Nicaraguan elections, Penn Kemble needs to take off his ideological glasses. ''Sandinistas Out: No Surprise'' (Op-Ed, Feb. 27) is at best half-right, containing profound misperceptions of both Nicaragua and United States policy.
Contra supporters trumpet the results as a vindication of the Reagan Administration's unremitting hostility toward the Sandinistas, or as Mr. Kemble, senior associate of Freedom House, describes it, ''the support of the U.S. in securing . . . democratic rights.'' 
Is that what the elections prove? Or is it that a superpower that lays siege militarily and economically to a small, impoverished country can bring it to its knees? Nobody ever argued that the United States could not cripple and paralyze the Nicaraguan economy.
The Sandinistas mortgaged their economy to fight Washington's war. For years, more than half the budget was directed toward the military. The gross national product dropped by half. Purchasing power plummeted by 80 percent. A radical structural adjustment introduced in 1988 sent prices spiraling. These were indeed harsh truths of life in Nicaragua, and they cannot be understood apart from Washington's harsh policy.
It is also true that Sandinista zealotry alienated many people. Most of Nicaragua's peasant population are historically conservative and have resisted any government (Sandinistas included) that told them what to do. So the Sandinistas lost the election - and so did incumbent governments recently in Costa Rica, El Salvador and Honduras. This trend is visible all over the hemisphere. It is a bad season to be an incumbent.
The Central American peace process initiated by President Oscar Arias of Costa Rica in August 1987 -and fought every step of the way by the Reagan Administration - created the conditions for the Nicaraguan elections. Had the contra war continued, there would have been no elections and no triumph of the opposition led by Violeta Barrios de Chamorro.
In opting for Mrs. Chamorro, Nicaraguans were not voting for Washington's policy, which they knew. They were voting for Washington's economic aid, which they hope for. They were not celebrating Washington's intervention in their internal affairs. They were voting for relief from Washington's unmitigated hostility.
Mrs. Chamorro and the UNO coalition have declared their intention to respect and honor the accomplishments of the revolution. They have given the beneficiaries of land reform assurances that their land will not be returned to the old owners. And they have publicly acknowledged that to govern they must respect and work with the Sandinistas, who remain even after their defeat far the largest and best organized party in Nicaragua.
There is wisdom in this recognition, for Mrs. Chamorro's government and for United States policy. The Sandinistas, who organized the elections and give every sign of abiding by their results, are crucial if Nicaragua is to bind up the wounds for which Washington bears so much responsibility.
 
JOE ELDRIDGE, ALEX WILDE
Washington, Feb. 27, 1990
 The writers are former directors of the Washington Office on Latin America, a nongovernmental organization working for social justice in United States Latin policy.

SECTION: Section B; Page 1, Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1012 words

HEADLINE: Youth Held in Burning of Boy Called Thuggish but Lonely

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
On the block where he lives, the accused youth is known as a bully with a vicious streak - a boy who taunted and beat smaller children, stole their lunch money and other property and sometimes whipped stray dogs into snarling fury and set them on one another for the fun of it.
But behind the mask of anger, acquaintances say, the 13-year-old Brooklyn youth charged with kidnapping, beating and critically burning a younger boy is also a troubled and lonely foster child with learning disabilities, himself an outcast tormented by older youths, a school dropout who spent aimless days in the streets and playing video games.
As the police, neighbors and anguished families tried to fathom the attack, an outpouring of concern from across the city and the country - from the White House, former President Ronald Reagan, Mayor David N. Dinkins and scores of ordinary people - was expressed for the victim, David Aupont, who marked his 12th birthday yesterday in the burn unit of New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in Manhattan.
David, who suffered third-degree burns over more than half his body in the attack in a basement in the Flatbush section on Wednesday morning, was listed in critical condition a day after his ordeal and was being given a 50-50 chance of survival. 
 
Motive Called Robbery
''He's a fighter - he's tough,'' Dr. Cleon Goodwin, director of the burn unit, said of the patient. Teddy bears, balloons, presents and many telephone calls from well-wishers arrived at the hospital yesterday, but no one but his doctors and parents were allowed to see him.
The police, who had said on Wednesday that David was attacked on his way to school by a youth who tried to force him to smoke crack, gave a different version of events yesterday, saying the assailant's motive had apparently been robbery and that there was no evidence that crack had played a role in the case.
But it was the horror of the crime and not the motive that stunned the city and the neighborhood where David and the accused assailant - a youth whose name was withheld because of his age - were known among children, teen-agers and adults as virtual opposites.
David was described as a quiet, clean-cut boy who had emigrated from Haiti a year ago and, though unable to speak English fluently, studied hard at the Walt Whitman Intermediate School at 72 Veronica Place and got along well with his family and neighbors at 754 East 23d Street in the Midwood section.
The accused youth, however, was described as a surly and thuggish boy who intimidated, beat up on and extorted money from other children, who dropped out of the sixth grade at Jackie Robinson Intermediate School, 46 McKeever Place in Flatbush, a few months ago, and who spent hours a day playing video games at home and in arcades on Flatbush Avenue.
School officials declined to discuss the youth or his status, but a teacher at Jackie Robinson said the youth had been enrolled in special education classes for the learning disabled. But several students said the youth had not attended any classes for months and had apparently dropped out of school.
 
An Isolated Boy
There was no one home yesterday in the third-floor apartment at 2537 Bedford Avenue, near Clarenden Road, where he lives with his foster family -Martha Stokes, an unemployed mother, her son, Anthony, 12, and two younger daughters, Keesha and Precious.
Lisa Paulycarpe, 14, who lives downt the blocks at 2553 Bedford Avenue, said that neighborhood residents knew the youth as an islolated boy - a bully who intimidated and sometimes beat up smaller children, but who also was mistreated and scorned by older youths whose company he sought.
''They think he's strange,'' she said. ''He's an outcast. He wants to be in, but people say, 'We don't want to hang with you.' ''
Another neighborhood youth, who gave his name only as Randy, said the 13-year-old loved playing nasty tricks. ''One time, he picked up a dead cat and chased me with it,'' he said. On another occasion, at a restaurant, he said he saw the youth empty salt and garlic shakers on a chair and mix up the contents with ketchup, then push the chair in so that an unsuspecting person would sit on the mess.
Randy said that, in an effort to ingratiate himself with older toughs a couple of months ago, the youth once stripped naked and ran across the rooftops. He also collected stray dogs and, after beating them into a snarling fury, set them on one another, Randy said.
''He's crazy,'' the boy said. ''He's really weird.''
 
No Evidence of Crack Involved
Others said the youth occasionally used crack and other drugs, but the police said there was no evidence of this. In particular, the police said, there was no evidence that crack was involved in the attack on David Wednesday.
Deputy Inspector Joseph DeMartino, commanding officer of Brooklyn North detectives, said at a news conference at the 67th Precinct station house in Brooklyn that the 13-year-old had intercepted David and three other boys about 8:35 A.M. at Beverly Road and Lott Street.
The boys recognized the older boy. ''He's known in the neighborhood as a bully,'' Inspector DeMartino said.
While the other three boys fled, David was seized by the 13-year-old and was forced to walk several blocks and taken into a basement at 2534 Bedford Avenue, across the street from the the suspect's apartment house. First reports had said David was taken to a nearby garage, but this was based on a bloodhound's false tracking, the police said.
In the basement, the Inspector said, the older boy beat David with his fists, stole a small amount of money from him and tied him to a radiator with strips of cloth. Then, he said, the youth doused him with an as-yet unidentified flammable liquid and set him on fire.
With his clothes blazing, David broke free, ran out a rear entrance, climbed over a fence and ran to a nearby auto body shop, where mechanics snuffed out the flames. The initial reports about crack apparently had come from the mechanics, who said the boy had made the allegation.
