HEADLINE: WEEKENDER GUIDE

BYLINE: By Andrew L. Yarrow

 BODY:

FRIDAY
 
ARABIAN DAYS
Despite a handful of exotic, often contradictory images culled from ''Lawrence of Arabia'' and television news, to most Americans Saudi Arabia might as well be the moon. For those who wish to learn more about this huge, rich, all-too-stereotyped country, the next best thing to being there is a free weeklong exhibition called ''Saudi Arabia Yesterday and Today,'' which opens today at the New York City Passenger Ship Terminal on Pier 88, at 48th Street and 12th Avenue. This large-scale presentation, sponsored by the Saudi Arabian Government, includes 65,000 square feet of exhibits on the country's geography, culture, architecture, religion, politics, and arts and crafts. Highlights include nearly life-size re-creations of a desert oasis, complete with palm groves and a Bedouin tent, and the outdoor marketplace known as a souk. Gold and silver doors that were once part of the Kaabah, Islam's original house of worship, are displayed in a courtyard with exhibits and a slide show about the Islamic religion and culture. In addition, the show includes a video-and-laser show on recent Saudi history and economic development, demonstrations of crafts like rug-weaving and calligraphy, and folk dance performances daily at 10:30 A.M. and 12:30, 4 and 6 P.M. The exhibition is open daily from 9 A.M to 7:30 P.M. through March 17. Information: 765-9244. 
 
LOVE IN THE TEENS
Adolescent amour, or love at first write, might best describe tonight's literary program in the Writer's Voice series of readings at the West Side Y.M.C.A., 5 West 63d Street. This 8 P.M. reading, called ''First Love,'' will feature romantic and other teen-age writings by Fran Lebowitz, author of ''Social Studies'' and ''Metropolitan Life''; Ntozake Shange, author of ''For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Suicide/When the Rainbow Is Enuf,'' and Meg Wolitzer, whose novels include ''This Is Your Life'' and ''Sleepwalking.'' Admission is $8, or free for high-school students and teachers with identification. Reservations and information on the series: 787-6557.
 
SATURDAY
 
LIFE UNDERGROUND
Every straphanger has stories to tell about life aboard the New York City subway system, but what about the people who drive the trains, sell tokens and work on the tracks and signals? Some of the vast folklore of subway workers may be discovered on Saturday at the New York Transit Museum in downtown Brooklyn, where four past and present employees of the New York City Transit Authority will talk about subjects like drilling subway tunnels, delivering a baby on the subway, saving a woman who had jumped in front of a train, and filming movies like ''The French Connection'' and ''The Taking of Pelham One Two Three.'' The 90-minute program, beginning at 2 P.M., will be led by Sally Charnow, a folklorist and historian. This museum of local mass-transit history is at Boerum Place and Schermerhorn Street, in a former subway station near the present Borough Hall station. The program is free with museum admission, which is $1.15 - the price of a token - or 55 cents for children. Information: (718) 330-3063.
 
FAMILY SHAKESPEARE
Egland in the days of William Shakespeare will be brought to life this weekend in a new musical for families presented at the Promenade Theater, Broadway and 76th Street. ''The Play's the Thing,'' by Thomas Edward West with music by Robert Waldman, is a lively tale of a Puritan girl whose father opposes the theater. Disguising herself as a boy, she joins Shakespeare's troupe shortly before the premiere of ''Romeo and Juliet.'' The production is by Theaterworks/ USA, the children's-theater company, and is directed by R. J. Cutler. Performances are on Saturday at 12:30 P.M. and Sunday at 10:30 A.M. and 12:30 P.M. Tickets are $12 and $15. Reservations: 677-5959 or 947-5850.
 
SYMPHONY PREMIERE
A new symphony by Richard Danielpour called ''Journey Without Distance'' will be given its East Coast premiere by the Stamford Symphony Orchestra on Saturday at 8:30 P.M. and Sunday at 3 P.M. in the orchestra's home at the Palace Theater/ Stamford Center of the Arts, 61 Atlantic Street (near Exit 8 of Interstate 95), in Stamford, Conn. Mr. Danielpour, a 34-year-old New York composer, has said that the symphony was inspired by ''A Course in Miracles,'' a work of spiritual psychotherapy by Helen Schucman. The orchestra, conducted by the music director Roger Nierenberg, will also perform Ottorino Respighi's ''Ancient Airs and Dances Set II,'' Nikolai Rimsky-Korsakov's ''Capriccio Espagnol'' and two pieces by Maurice Ravel: ''Tzigane'' and ''Pavane for a Dead Princess.'' Tickets are $6 to $32; discounts for students and the elderly are available. Reservations: (203) 325-1407.
 
SUNDAY
 
WAR AND ART
Germany's turbulent history from the eve of World War I to the end of World War II, and artists' reactions to the horrors and tumult of those years, are the subject of an exhibition that opens at the Jewish Museum on Sunday and continues through May 23. The show, ''War, Resistance and Politics: Dusseldorf Artists, 1910-1945,'' includes 125 paintings, drawings and illustrations by 39 artists, Many of the artists served on the front lines in World War I; others were active in liberal and left-wing politics during the Weimar Republic, and some survived the Nazi era. In addition to works by Kathe Kollwitz, Otto Dix and Max Ernst, lesser-known artists from the Dusseldorf avant-garde like Conrad Felixmuller and Otto Pankok are also included in the show. Most works are on loan from the Stadtmuseum Dusseldorf. The Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92d Street, is open Sundays from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.; and Mondays through Thursdays from noon to 5 P.M. (Tuesdays till 8 P.M.). Admission is $4.50; $2.50 for students and the elderly. Information: 860-1888.
 
CENTENNIAL CONCERT
Choral and vocal chamber works by the Swiss composer Frank Martin will be performed by the New Amsterdam Singers, with the mezzo-soprano D'Anna Fortunato, at 4 P.M. at St. Ignatius Episcopal Church, West End Avenue at 87th Street. The concert, which marks the centennial of Martin's birth, will include pieces written between 1921 and 1971 to texts by writers including Shakespeare, Pierre de Ronsard and Francois Villon. This program of rarely performed works also will feature Martin's a cappella Mass for double chorus. Martin, whose choral works and better-known orchestral pieces tend to be melodic yet technically complex, was influenced by Arnold Schoenberg and Alban Berg, but he never abandoned tonality. The New Amsterdam Singers, a 22-year-old New York ensemble of about 70 members, are directed by Clara Longstreth. Tickets are $10; $8 for students and the elderly. Information: 662-6523.
 
DANCING TOWARD SPRING
The spring dance series at the 92d Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue, will continue on Sunday at 7 P.M. with a performance of new works by the choreographer Francis Patrelle. The program will include ''State of Mind,'' excerpts from ''Fuoco e Fiamma,'' a revival of Mr. Patrelle's homage to George Gershwin's ''Rhapsody in Blue'' and a contemporary musical collage called ''Jazz/ Fools.'' The Dances Patrelle company will feature Donald Williams, a principal with Dance Theater of Harlem, and members of the New York City Ballet. Tickets are $5. Information: 996-1100.

HEADLINE: Patent Suit Becomes Trade Battle

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 8

 BODY:
A Swiss machine-tool company won a victory today over a Japanese rival in a battle that has been marked by bare-knuckles practices rarely seen in multinational business.
Also facing off in the dispute were officials in Washington and Zurich and at the Defense and Commerce Departments.
The case originally involved patents for advanced machine tools, which the AGIE Group of Zurich accused the Sodick Company of Yokohama of infringing. But it escalated into the area of international trade practice and matters of national security. 
 
Federal Agency Involved
Because the issue involved access to American markets, the battleground was the Federal agency that adjudicates trade disputes, the International Trade Commission. The commission found in favor of AGIE and barred Sodick's machine tools from the United States. The ruling now goes to the President, who is unlikely to overturn it; if he takes no action for 60 days, it becomes final.
''We're disappointed and intend to seek reversal either in the Presidential review or the Federal circuit,'' said P. Jay Wilker, a lawyer for Sodick.
The two opponents are aggressive postwar companies, both with annual sales in the $200 million to $300 million range. Sodick was formed in the mid-1970's and AGIE in the mid-1950's.
The dispute involved AGIE's assertion that it had a 1975 United States patent covering parts of a special type of electrical-discharge machine tool that cuts the hardest metals and also flushes away debris. The market for such tools has been growing at about 20 percent a year and is now valued at $100 million annually. Sodick asserted that the technology covered in the patent had earlier origins and therefore it was free to make and import similar equipment without paying royalites to AGIE.
In one of the more unusual aspects of the case, and as the exchange between the companies grew more volatile, Sodick accused the Swiss company of selling the Soviet Union militarily valuable machine tools and transferring technology to make the equipment in a joint venture with the Dzerzhinsky Machine Tool Association of Kaunas, Lithuania.
This drew the Pentagon into the argument. ''We're still looking at it,'' said Lieut. Comdr. Edward H. Lundquist, spokesman for the Defense Department's Defense Technology Security Administration.
The case has also led to inter-agency strife between the Defense and Commerce Departments, other officials said, over the ability to control export of such machine tools. The Pentagon says they could be used for Soviet missile guidance, radar, jet engines, helicopters, naval drive systems and other military purposes. But the Commerce Department has given a green light to their export.
 
Strong Rejection From Zurich
The Zurich company strongly rejected the allegation that it was selling contraband to the Soviet Union. David M. Yarborough, president of AGIE USA, which imports the tools from Switzerland for sale in the United States, called the accusation ''a total red herring.''
Jean-Daniel Gerber, the Swiss Embassy's economics minister, said, ''We have absolutely no evidence that AGIE exported anything that it is not allowed to under Swiss export regulations.''
The Pentagon investigation has stirred concerns about Switzerland's informal commitments to enforce export controls as rigorously as the United States and other Western allies do. Neutral Switzerland is not a member of the trade alliance, but because of the informal commitments, it now gets unimpeded access to American technology as if it were a member.
 
The Toshiba Provision
Sodick's line of attack was based on the so-called Toshiba Provision of the 1988 Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act, under which any foreign supplier may be barred from the United States for two to five years if found selling restricted products to the Soviet Union.
The Toshiba Machine Company, a 51 percent owned subsidiary of the giant Toshiba Corporation, the Japanese electronics company, was punished by the 1988 legislation for selling embargoed machine-tools for propeller-silencing equipment to the Soviet Union in the mid-1980's.
While AGIE had originally threatened to have Sodick excluded from the market for patent violation, Sodick, matching punch for punch, threatened to have AGIE excluded for export violations.
In its petition, AGIE sought a ruling that its 1975 American patent related to the flushing system of the electrical-discharge machine tool - United States patent number 3,928,163 - was enforceable under Section 337 of the Trade Act of 1930.
 
Patent Ruled Enforceable
The six commissioners, under the chairmanship of Anne E. Brunsdale, unanimously affirmed the judgment last December by its chief administrative law judge, Janet Saxon, that the 1975 patent was indeed enforceable and that Sodick was an infringer.
But Sodick argued that the technology had earlier origins. It traced development to a Soviet inventor in Moscow who took out a patent there in 1949. The developer's name was V.V. Kupchenko; little is known about him. The Sodick brief also reprinted a 1965 article on the machine-tool flushing process in a Soviet technical journal written by E. Y. Grodzinsky and V.D. Proklova; little is known about them.
AGIE lawyers argued that the Swiss company had taken novel and inventive steps to advance the earlier knowledge, which under American law establishes a patent's enforceability.
While three other Japanese companies - Fanuc, Mitsubishi and Hitachi - recognize the AGIE patent claims and pay the Swiss company royalties, Sodick has refused.
''We believe those companies made a mistake because they were misled on the enforceability of the patent by AGIE,'' said Mr. Wilker, a lawyer for the Park Avenue law firm of Marks Murase & White, representing Sodick.
Today's decision could mean more work in Davidson, N.C., where AGIE operates a production subsidiary, the Elox Corporation. AGIE says it has pumped $20 million into Elox over the last two years.

HEADLINE: Hotel Chains' Woes: Just Too Many Rooms

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
Overbuilding, operating cost increases and stiffer competition among major hotel chains have turned the fast growth-and-earnings pace of the early 1980's into a crawl of consolidation and strains on profits, corporate executives and industry analysts say. Many experts believe that it will take the industry years to overcome most of the problems and that shakeouts could affect some familiar hotel names.
Fresh evidence of the widespread troubles of the once-booming American hotel industry came Wednesday when the Hilton Hotels Corporation announced it had rejected two lower-than-expected takeover proposals.
The Marriott Corporation, Ramada Inc., Holiday Inns and other large, well-established chains that dominate the broad middle market are struggling to improve their bottom lines by expanding into the one remaining bright area: the rapidly growing budget-priced sector. This has made operations like Marriott's Fairfield Inns and Ramada's Rodeway Inns hot properties. These no- and low-frills operations offer rooms that are increasingly attractive to business travelers whose employers are looking to cut costs. 
 
Financing Short for Some
But some smaller companies, like Prime Motor Inns (which also owns Howard Johnson's), lacking big financial bases, have been hurt by the savings and loan crisis and ''junk bond'' turmoil. Those problems have cut off much of the financing for those companies, leaving many of them unable to compete in an environment where expansion and refurbishment of older rooms are important for success.
''It will take several years to absorb the current oversupply'' in the overall hotel industry, said Thomas Lattin, a partner in Laventhol & Horwath, a Philadelphia accounting and consulting firm that specializes in the hospitality industry. ''The large chains that overbuilt in the middle market are now suffering.''
Just last September, for example, analysts were predicting that Hilton, one of the premier names in the industry, would fetch a record-setting price, as did other big chains sold in the last few years. Estimates then even said that a price of more than $6 billion, or about $130 a share, would be reasonable for a company whose stock had languished below $50 for months, but which appeared to be solidly profitable.
So when Barron Hilton, the chain's 62-year-old chairman and chief executive, put his venerable lodging company on the auction block in August, its shares soon skyrocketed to a high of $115.50. But after seven months passed with no one dangling offers that approached those prices, Mr. Hilton lamented yesterday that ''the investment climate for real estate and hotels'' was just not what it used to be. Hilton's stock closed at $50.625 yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, down almost $16 since the no-sale announcement.
It is not hard to see why even a Hilton is finding high bidders hard to come by. The average occupancy rate for the major full-service hotel chains has fallen to about 63 percent, below the 65 to 68 percent range that persisted for most of the 1980's. More important, the rate is well below the 70 percent level that analysts say the hotels need to break even and the rate is expected to fall further, to about 61 percent next year.
As occupancy rates have fallen, the discounts and special packages offered in slack periods have climbed, although in many cases the net price to the consumer has continued to rise. And a few cities, most notably New York and Los Angeles, seem to have defied the industry trend. But analysts say the problems will catch up with hotel operators in those cities in a couple of years.
 
Sharp Discounting
A survey by Laventhol last year of more than 9,000 hotels in nearly 60 cities found a median discount rate of 25.5 percent from posted room rates, called rack rates in the industry. Such discounting has made it hard for hotels to maintain profit margins and many have started to cut operating costs and to buy or otherwise expand into segments of the market with the lowest operating expenses and higher profit margins.
One result is that hotels lost an average of $429 on each room before taxes in 1988, but managed to cut the loss to $369 last year, another Laventhol study reported. Most of that reduction in losses, according to Mark Lomano, director of research at Laventhol, came from a slowdown in building and sharp cuts in operating expenses. For example, hotels are laying off room-service workers and replacing them with self-service food and beverage bars in the rooms.
The overbuilding of the 1980's, when the number of rooms grew by about 37.5 percent, with 774,00 rooms added in the decade, was a result of an early shortage of rooms, the prospect of continued appreciation of real estate values and easily obtainable financing. Analysts say the boom also anticipated continued tax write-offs, many of which were eliminated with the 1986 Tax Reform Act.
''Sixty-five percent of the hotel rooms built between 1981 and 1986 were built with the full intention that they would lose money,'' Mr. Lomano said. ''They were built as tax losses, but the tax laws changed.''
 
Artificial Boom
Although investors, syndicators and builders profited handsomely from this artificial boom in the early 1980's, the people now left holding the bag are the hotel owners who have no income and big losses that they cannot use to offset other income.
To increase business, most of the big chains are battling to broaden their lines to include lower-priced hotels and increase their name recognition among different segments of consumers. In the last three years, the big chains, from Ramada, with its acquisition of Rodeway Inns, to Marriott, with its development of Fairfield Inns, have entered the budget end of the market as their full-service operations become less profitable. In the last three years, 175,000 rooms have been added to the economy sector, representing nearly half of the hotel rooms added over that time.
This has turned economy hotels, where no-frills rooms cost about $30 a night, into one of the most hotly contested parts of the market, said Michael G. Mueller, an analyst with Montgomery Securities. Budget hotels are not new, but the recent success of companies like Motel 6 and Days Inns, the biggest of the budget hotel group, underscores that money is to be made at the low end.
A. Bradford Bryan, the president of Marriott's Courtyard, Fairfield Inns and Residence Inns, said his limited-service market, as opposed to the full-service Hyatts and Sheratons, could not grow fast enough to meet demand. He expects most of the growth in both demand and room supply to come in the limited-service sector.
''All the statistics I have seen indicate that industrywide demand is growing at 5 percent and rooms at 3 percent,'' Mr. Bryan said, ''but in the limited-service market demand is outstripping supply by at least 3 to 1.''
 
'The Weakest Segment'
Hit particularly hard are the older and well-established chains, like Ramada and Holiday Inn, that steadily raised room rates in the last 10 years and now find they have old hotels that need heavy capital investments to compete with new middle-market hotels.
''At this point the midmarket is the weakest segment and the only new product coming out in this market is the Marriott Courtyard,'' Mr. Lattin said.
But even Marriott, long regarded as one of the best-managed companies in the industry, has had recent troubles. It announced costly changes late last year that have already resulted in a $200 million write-off against earnings.
If the weakness in the broad middle market of the business was not bad enough, hotel companies, especially those that focused on growth through developing new properties, are finding that the industry is caught in a financing squeeze. The traditional sources of money for building, refurbishing or otherwise improving hotels are no longer interested in lending to the troubled industry. Except for the large, well-established companies, financing is increasingly hard to find.
 
Stocks Decline
The stock market has also been sharply re-evaluating hotel stocks over the last six months. Avner Arbel, a professor of finance in Cornell's School of Hotel Administration, said hotel stocks, which led the market a year ago, have lost one-third of their value over the last six months.
''The six-month loss went across the board for virtually all hotel companies,'' Professor Arbel said. ''The weak performance of the hotel industry as a whole represents an extreme turnaround.''
Most experts in the hospitality industry believe that the financing squeeze will continue the consolidation already under way by forcing small chains to sell out to larger chains or combine with each other. As for those chains that expanded by assuming large debt at the high rates of the early 1980's, they too will be forced out as debt service costs, falling revenues and the inability to get new loans squeeze their bottom lines.
''The changes and upheavals in terms of the marginal players being put out of business is in the long term healthier for the industry and certainly for the bigger players,'' said Richard Saltzman, a Merrill Lynch managing director and a highly regarded investment banker in the hotel industry.
''What you'll have is a sort of oligopoly,'' he added. ''The big players will go through a rough period but ultimately they will benefit significantly because they'll have the market to themselves.''

HEADLINE: Brady Going To Group of 7 Talks in April

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 8

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said today that he will go to Paris next month to meet with financial leaders of the Group of Seven industrial nations to discuss recent economic developments around the world.
Before appearing at a House Appropriations Committee hearing on the Treasury Department budget, Mr. Brady was asked about a report that he and Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, were planning to travel to Paris on April 7. ''Definitely,'' he replied. Asked further if the trip involved meetings with the leaders of the Group of Seven, he said, ''Yes.'' 
 
First Meeting Since Changes
The meeting of finance ministers and central bank presidents from the world's most powerful industrial democracies - the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Canada and Italy - would be the first such session since the dramatic changes in Eastern Europe.
An official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the United States had proposed the meeting to discuss how changes in Eastern Europe are affecting currency markets and the economic coordination efforts among the major powers.
A spokeswoman for the Federal Reserve declined to comment on any aspect of the meeting.
In recent weeks, the value of the dollar on world markets has climbed sharply while the Japanese yen and West German mark have declined.
A stronger dollar threatens to worsen America's already huge trade deficit since it would make United States products more expensive on overseas markets and imports less expensive for American consumers.
 
Moves to Stem Dollar's Rise
The Group of Seven countries have been coordinating efforts this week to sell dollars and buy Japanese yen and West German marks in an effort to dampen the dollar's climb. But so far the Government currency sales have had limited impact.
At their last meeting, on Sept. 23 in Washington, the Group of Seven's economic ministers also expressed concern about the dollar, which had been rising over the summer. They said a further strengthening could undercut efforts to promote a healthy global economy and they vowed fresh efforts to try to keep a lid on the dollar. On the next trading day after their meeting, they followed up that commitment by intervening strongly in the currency market, and the dollar fell almost four Japanese yen and more than five pfennigs against the West German mark.
Since then, the dollar has risen more than 6 percent against the yen Against the mark, the dollar is 10.5 percent lower than at the end of September, but it has been strengthening recently.
The mark shot up at the end of last year and early this year amid positive sentiment about the opening of the borders between East and West Germany. The yen's decline, meanwhile, has been laid to concerns about political and economic uncertainties in Japan.
In addition to the recent volatility in exchange markets, the Group of Seven officials are expected to address the question of the unification of West Germany and East Germany. Some economists fear this development could worsen inflationary problems in West Germany, especially if a proposal to exchange the West German currency for the East Germany currency on a one-to-one basis is carried out.
The April 7 meeting will be held just one month before a previously scheduled May 7 meeting of the Group of Seven's finance ministers in Washington.

HEADLINE: Freer Rein On A.T.&T. Is Proposed

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 8

 BODY:
In another step toward deregulating the long-distance telephone market, the Federal Communications Commission proposed yesterday giving the American Telephone and Telegraph Company a freer hand in cutting or raising rates and offering additional services for large business customers.
The proposal is expected to be approved by the agency after a period of public comment, review and revision. It was made after the agency tentatively concluded that there was now significant competition in the $55 billion market for interstate telephone services.
Under the proposal, A.T.&T. would have to give only one day's notice to change some prices and services for large businesses and would no longer have to supply cost information to the F.C.C. Current regulations require 14 or more days' notice and A.T.&T. must also produce varying amounts of cost data. 
 
Company Complains of Delays
A.T.&T. has protested in the past that its competitors have used the longer notice periods to file complaints blocking or delaying many price cuts and service improvements it wants to offer in the market for WATS lines and for dedicated long-distance lines used by the biggest customers. That market ranges in size from $5 billion to $7 billon a year. Current regulations on A.T.&T.'s residential and small-business services would be retained at least until 1992 under the proposal.
The F.C.C. also proposed giving A.T.&T. greater freedom to negotiate contracts with specific - usually very large - companies, while reducing the amount of information it must provide. Such information can be used by its competitors to price their own services just a little below that of A.T.&T.
 
Plan on Toll-Free Lines
The agency also proposed an eventual relaxation of regulation of A.T.&T.'s international and toll-free 800 services. But the agency linked deregulation of the 800 market to companies' being able to change long-distance companies without having to change their existing 800 numbers. Companies have often spent heavily on advertising to make their 800 numbers swell known and are reluctant to change numbers, but it is not technologically feasible for them to retain the number if they switch long-distance companies.
The F.C.C. does not expect local telephone companies to have the technology to allow such changes until 1992, said Alfred C. Sikes, the F.C.C.'s chairman.
The U S Sprint Communications Company had lobbied for just such an agency stance on 800 numbers. J. Richard Devlin, the general counsel and an executive vice president of the United Telecommunications subsidiary, said yesterday that while the company was concerned about loosened regulation on other A.T.&T. services for large businesses, it was pleased over all with the agency proposal because of the stance on 800 services. ''It's a statesman-like decision,'' he said.
A.T.&T.'s rivals, notably the MCI Communications Corporation and U S Sprint, have said that A.T.&T. remains too big and has retained too many advantages from its days as a monopoly to be allowed to compete on an equal regulatory footing.
Businesses with about $200 a month or more in long-distance services generally use WATS lines and may be affected if yesterday's proposals are adopted, said Joseph Nacchio, A.T.&T.'s vice president for business communication services.
 
'Competitive Battles'
Gary L. Phillips, a lawyer with the Common Carrier Bureau of the F.C.C. who presented the agency staff's recommendations at a public hearing today, said, ''What we have in effect today is competitive battles being waged at the F.C.C. instead of in the marketplace.''
Reducing the notice period to one day would mean that A.T.&T.'s price and service changes would be argued after they have gone into effect and A.T.&T.'s competitors would be prevented from using the Federal agency to create delays, Mr. Phillips said. The F.C.C. does not plan to allow competitors to try frequently to delay A.T.&T.'s moves by filing complaints the same day that A.T.&T. submits its price or service change, he said.
Among the A.T.&T. business services delayed by regulatory action have been so-called software-defined networks, which use computers combined with regular long-distance A.T.&T. facilities to mimic a private phone system custom-built for a company.
Consumer groups have expressed concerns that increasing A.T.&T.'s ability to reach different contracts with different companies will allow the company to discriminate in its pricing.
A.T.&T. has about 66 percent of the long-distance market, while MCI has about 12 percent and U S Sprint 9 percent.
The F.C.C. also asked today for public comment on whether it should declare an end to A.T.&T.'s designation a decade ago as the ''dominant'' long-distance carrier. This designation has been accompanied by regulations that restrict to certain ranges any changes in A.T.&T.'s prices for specific services. Its elimination would revolutionize regulation of the telephone industry.
The F.C.C. staff did not make any recommendation concerning the designation, and few industry or agency officials expect it to be adopted in the near future.
 
A Period for Comment
The F.C.C. declared that it would allow 60 days for public comment after the proposals are published in final form in a few weeks. A 30-day period would follow for companies and individuals to file replies to the comments, after which the F.C.C. is scheduled to vote on the proposals.
Mr. Sikes said in an interview after the hearing that he expected the commission to reach a final decision by the end of this year. He said he did not know when the proposals might take effect.
Mr. Nacchio of A.T.&T. said that if carried out, the F.C.C.'s proposals would enable the company to offer new services more quickly. He said the new rules would let A.T.&T. cut prices because reduced regulation means lower compliance costs and less forgone revenues from services whose introduction is delayed.
Any price reductions, which MCI and U S Sprint would be under pressure to match, might encourage some customers to remain on the nation's main telephone network instead of building their own systems. But the main significance of today's F.C.C. actions lay in the agency's taking the stance that significant competition has arrived in the long-distance market and that regulation should accordingly be reduced, he said.
Today's proposals represent the most important milestone in the deregulation of the long-distance telephone market since last July, when the F.C.C. abandoned limiting A.T.&T.'s profits to a fixed percentage of its investment in plant and equipment in favor of limiting price changes to narrow ranges pegged to the rate of inflation. The new method is intended to give A.T.&T. an incentive to improve productivity by allowing it to keep the gains from cost reductions.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The Denial Of the Obvious

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
STEPHEN POTTER, the author of ''Gamesmanship'' and ''One-Upmanship,'' said an economist has two basic ploys. The first, labeled Economic Approach A, is to cloak the obvious in ''a little wild incomprehensibility.'' Thus, Mr. Potter's model economist, named Regil, would tell listeners that if they wanted to influence ''the general liquidity situation of banks and public,'' they had better not forget that the central bank's ''discretionary action on the cash basis took the shape of dealings in Treasury bills, the market rate of discount on which could and did fluctuate.''
In the opposite direction is Economic Approach B, the more classical ploy, which requires the economist to practice ''the stupefaction of the exhaustingly clear.'' For instance, in a crisis, the model economist might say: ''Unless something happens to change the state of demand, more will be bought at any given price than at any higher price.'' 
In recent years, however, we have witnessed the emergence of what might be called Economic Approach C, which may be designated ''the denial of the obvious.'' Thus, the economist, employing Ploy C, may deny that the United States budget deficit is too big and deny that it has anything to do with the trade deficit. Indeed, he may also deny that the heavy inflow of foreign capital is creating any future problems for the United States.
The denial-school members reject evidence that American productivity and living standards have lagged as a result of inadequate capital formation, and will lag further if foreign capital inflow slackens and rising interest rates, aimed at preventing the outflow of capital, cut further into domestic spending on new plant and equipment, and on research and development.
They may deny the national debt problem, private as well as public, pushing back into their unconscious the multibillion-dollar failures of savings and loan institutions and the growing problems of many commercial banks and heavily leveraged corporations as evidence of excessive debt.
Tying these problems together - in particular the foreign deficit and slow productivity growth -is the inadequacy of saving relative to what individuals, businesses and politicians want to spend. Here is the heart of the nation's foreign trade and overall payments problem: If any country invests more than it saves and consumes more than it produces, the excess must be covered by an inflow of foreign savings.
Can monetary policy extricate the nation from its foreign economic troubles? Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Fed, recently testified that the central bank could address either the stabilization of domestic prices or exchange rates but could not achieve both objectives simultaneously. ''Monetary policy alone,'' he said, ''is not readily capable of addressing today's large current account deficit, which is symptomatic of underlying imbalances among saving, spending and production within the U.S. economy.'' Cutting the Federal deficit, he added, was a better way of raising domestic saving and freeing additional resources for productive investment. But some economists, including strange bedfellows from the Keynesian left and the supply-side right, now insist that the budget deficit does not matter and that there is no saving problem, once savings are correctly defined. The most prominent economist taking that line is Prof. Robert Eisner of Northwestern University, who represents the Keynesian left. He would adjust the budget deficit for the effect of inflation on the public debt, set up a capital budget and increase domestic saving by including in the category outlays on public goods, like roads and education.
All of this, however, is irrelevant to the issues of the relationship of national savings to the foreign deficit or domestic growth. As Charles L. Schultze of the Brookings Institution observes: ''Making the inflation adjustment does not change the estimate of national saving one iota. If the inflation adjustment is subtracted from the deficit because it is not truly income to bondholders, then current statistics overstate not only the budget deficit but also the income and the saving of those same bondholders. The Eisner adjustment simply reallocates national saving among its components: less private saving, less government dissaving, with no net effect on national saving itself.''
And if a Federal capital budget were used to raise the level of national saving, it would raise the level of national investment by the same amount, and hence not change the existing gap between domestic saving and national investment.
Such definitional arguments can be used, however, to advance their proponents' policy objectives: in the case of the Keynesian left, to justify stronger aggregate demand to push the economy faster and cut unemployment, or, in the case of the supply-side right, to justify continued opposition to any tax increases to close the Federal budget gap.
But such ploys may encourage public disdain for what the 19th-century critic, Thomas Carlyle, called ''the dismal science'' and his contemporary, Matthew Arnold, called ''the plonking science'' -the science of the utterly obvious, or, sometimes, the science that denies the utterly obvious.

HEADLINE: 6 Environmental Issues In Exxon Proxy Report

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
The proxy statement issued by the Exxon Corporation yesterday includes six shareholder proposals addressing environmental concerns, which indicates that the Securities and Exchange Commission approved their inclusion.
That means that the management of the company, already beleaguered by bad publicity surrounding some large oil leaks in recent months, will face a debate over its corporate environmental policy at its annual meeting April 25 in Houston.
At the meeting a year ago, some stockholders angrily asked questions about the company's Valdez oil spill off the coast of Alaska. But this year formal votes will be held on the resolutions, including those inspired by the Valdez Principles, a 10-point agenda that urges corporations in general to take steps like reporting annually on their environmental activities. 
 
Terms of Other Proposals
The other proposals call on Exxon to take many steps, ranging from limiting emissions of carbon dioxide and other gases to establishing an environmental committee on its board.
The company said it opposes all six shareholder proposals. Its proxy statement gives several reasons, one of which is that the board thinks some of the resolutions do not recognize the need to ''balance the environment with important adequate energy resources and stable, healthy economies.''
The company also said it was preparing a report on its ''past and continuing efforts on environmental protection, health and safety.''
Even supporters say they doubt the proposals will pass.
 
A Trend Seen Forming
Several experts called environmental proposals the trend of the future and the start of a campaign that will equal in fervor the one that compelled many institutions, as a protest against apartheid, to sell shares in companies that operated in South Africa.
Lewis Gilbert, long a stockholder advocate, said he would attend the meeting and vote for the proposals. ''I think a great thing has happened,'' he continued. ''A lot of institutional holders have indicated they will vote for the proposals.'' He added that the proposals might persuade many more large pension funds and other institutional holders to ask questions.
''I say it is their fiduciary duty,'' he said, ''and not many of their representatives have been coming to annual meetings. We support Tim Smith.''
 
Institutional Support Seen
Timothy Smith, executive director of the Interfaith Center on Corporate Responsibility, confirmed that a large number of institutions heavily invested in Exxon stock, like the New York City pension funds and the California state retirement system, would vote in favor of at least some of the environmental proposals on the proxy statement now in the mail to shareholders.
Mr. Smith said that 75 percent of the 25 companies he had asked to approve the Valdez Principles had agreed to do so. He said those companies included Chevron, Texaco, Mobil and Amoco, all oil companies; Union Pacific, a holding company; Waste Management; Aetna, the insurance company, and McDonald's, the fast-food chain.
Dr. James Post, professor at the Boston University School of Management and an expert on environmental problems, called the proposals ''very reasonable and modest requests.''
He added: ''I think Exxon's initial positions opposing the proxy proposals are without merit. The attitude casts doubt about the integrity of Exxon's management system.''
 
Outside Audit Group Suggested
Professor Post yesterday suggested the need for an external audit commission. He is a member of such a commission organized in 1981 by former Senator Edmund S. Muskie to monitor Nestle S.A.'s infant formula, about which there were health difficulties in developing countries some years ago.
''It is called the Nestle Infant Formula Audit Commission,'' Professor Post said. ''It meets quarterly or more often to provide continuing oversight by an outside group. This includes investigating complaints and doing field investigations.''

HEADLINE: A.T.&T. Card Offer Seen

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company is expected to offer Mastercard and Visa credit cards in an effort to increase revenues, industry analysts said this week.
The company has been studying such a move for some time. Analysts said A.T.&T. would probably offer the cards this month to many if not all of the 40 million holders of its A.T.&T. phone credit cards.
A company spokesman, Walter Murphy, declined to comment on A.T.&T.'s plans for charge cards. But last year the company confirmed that it was studying such a move. ''We've looked at ways to advance the A.T.&T. card,'' Mr. Murphy said on Wednesday.
The new cards would be used for purchases at stores, restaurants, hotels and other retail locations, unlike A.T.&T.'s phone cards, which can be used only for long-distance calls.
Several industry sources said A.T.&T. might consider establishing its own retail card eventually but would use its initial offering of Visa and Mastercard as a test.
Analysts said A.T.&T. had contracted with Total Systems Services, a subsidiary of the Synovus Financial Corporation, a Columbus, Ga., bank, to serve as the initial data processor for the cards.
A.T.&T. plans to attract customers by waiving fees for the card in the first year and charging interest rates of 14 percent to 15 percent, well below prevailing rates on other cards, industry sources said.

HEADLINE: More Defaults Are Predicted

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 8

 BODY:
A panel of credit experts told Congress today to expect an increase in the number of defaults by debt-burdened corporations in the early 1990's. But they said there was little that the Federal Government should do to reverse the trend. 
''Further policy action may make the situation worse, rather than better,'' said David A. Wyss, senior vice president of DRI/McGraw Hill, an economic forecasting company based in Lexington, Mass.
 
The hearing was called by
Representative Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts and chairman of a House finance subcommittee, to examine the ''junk bond'' market of high-yield securities.
Thomas J. McGuire, an executive vice president of Moody's Investors Service, a credit-rating company, said the default rate of speculative-grade issues had risen to 5.4 percent.
He said 51 companies defaulted on a total debt of nearly $12 billion last year.
''The outlook - given the increase in lower-rated issuers and the potentially unfavorable economic environment - is for still higher levels of defaults in the early 1990's,'' he said.
Mr. Wyss said his company expected defaults to peak this year at 8.9 percent and to drop back to an average of 3.7 percent over the next five years.

HEADLINE: Sales Up For Many Retailers

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Several big specialty retailers and department store chains yesterday reported strong February sales growth as demand heated up for spring apparel.
The results from some of the nation's largest retailers indicated consumer interest in shopping had not cooled despite a lukewarm economy.
K Mart, the mass merchandiser, said its February sales rose 14.7 percent, while the Limited Inc., the nation's largest specialty apparel retailer, reported a 21 percent gain in sales for the month, and Gap Inc., another nationwide apparel chain, said its sales surged 29 percent.
 
'Retailing Is Not Dead'
''Certainly retailing is not dead,'' said Karen Sack, an analyst at the Standard & Poor's Corporation in New York. 
Linda R. Morris of the PNC Financial Corporation in Philadelphia said the February figures ''signal that the consumer is continuing to spend.'' She added, ''Although it's not a robust retail environment, it certainly bodes well for a decent year.''
Among the retailers reporting yesterday were department store groups, specialty clothing chains, discounters and mass merchandisers.
Other national chains reported their February results a week ago, including the nation's largest general merchandiser, Sears, Roebuck & Company; Wal-Mart Stores Inc.; the J. C. Penney Company, and others. Variations in fiscal-year calendars have caused retailers to have differing sales-reporting schedules.
Last week's reports - with the exception of the ones from Sears and Montgomery Ward & Company -showed solid sales increases. Sears had virtually flat sales in February and Ward's were up 1.7 percent. In contrast, Wal-Mart sales surged 33 percent from a year earlier, and J. C. Penney posted an 8.1 percent gain.
 
Sales Better Than Expected
Thomas Tashjian, an analyst at Seidler Amdec Securities Inc. in Los Angeles, said sales generally were better than expected across the board in February.
Some retailers, he said, benefited this year from a seasonal pickup in shopping because there was an additional week in the winter period.
Retailers that specialize in apparel continued to outrun general merchants in February as they did last year. In a time of sluggish economic growth, purchases of expensive items, like furniture and home appliances, are typically the first things to be sacrificed.
Sales at the Limited rose to $318.2 million in the four weeks ended March 3 from $263.8 million last year. Sales at stores open a year or longer were up 16 percent.
Results at stores open at least a year, called same-store sales, are considered the best reflection of a retailer's performance.
Based in Columbus, Ohio, the Limited operates its flagship stores plus Victoria's Secret, Abercrombie & Fitch, Lane Bryant and others.
At the Gap, sales surged to $103 million, from $80 million a year earlier. Same-store sales rose 20 percent.
K Mart said its overall results benefited from good gains in women's, men's and children's clothing lines. Sales for the four weeks ended Feb. 28 grew to $1.9 billion, from $1.66 billion a year earlier. Same-store sales were up 4.4 percent. The retailer, second in 1989 sales volume behind Sears, also owns the Waldenbooks bookstore chain, Pay Less Drug Stores and other chains.
K mart recently said it was speeding up plans to open additional stores and refurbish others as it tries to capitalize on the weakness at Sears and to stay ahead of its fast-growing rival, Wal-Mart. Wal-Mart is widely considered a powerful contender for the No. 1 ranking in terms of annual merchandise sales revenue in the United States. Currently, it is No. 3.
Several top retailers do not report their sales monthly, including the Campeau Corporation units, Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores; R.H. Macy & Co., and Batus Inc., owner of Marshall Field & Company and Saks Fifth Avenue.
Here are the retailers that reported their domestic sales yesterday for February, the first month of their fiscal years:
 
K Mart Corp.: Four weeks ended Feb. 28: $1.9 billion, up 14.7 percent from $1.66 billion.
Dayton Hudson Corp.: Four weeks ended March 3: $821 million, up 13.1 percent from $725 million. May Department Stores Co.:
Four weeks ended March 3: $596.1 million, up 10.6 percent from $538.8 million.
Limited Inc.: Four weeks ended March 3: $318.2 million, up 21 percent from $263.8 million.
Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc.: Four weeks ended March 3: $176.8 million, up 3.1 percent from $170.8 million. First 7 months: $1.82 billion, up 5.7 percent from $1.72 billion.

HEADLINE: Stocks Up in Light Trading As Dow Gains 26.58 Points

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stocks advanced in light trading yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average gaining 26.58 points, to 2,696.17.
Except for Monday and Wednesday, when the Dow fell slightly, the bellwether index has climbed every day for two weeks, tacking on 131.98 points.
Michael Metz, chief market analyst for Oppenheimer & Company, remarked: ''This really is symptomatic of a sold-out market where lots of major participants keep looking for bargains. And where the market refuses to cooperate by giving ground, these participants get anxious about missing the market and become more aggressive in their buying.'' 
''The message,'' he said, ''is that just about all the known negatives on interest rates, inflation and the uncertain economic outlook have already been discounted.''
''You haven't had any decent good news to spark this rally,'' he said. ''What you have is basically a situation where nobody owns any stock.''
Other than the Dow industrials, most other key indicators rose only a few points, with the Dow transportation index ahead 1.96, to 1,137.27, the Dow utilities rising 1.58, to 221.51, and the S.&P. 500 up 3.32, to 340.27.
 
Volume at 170.9 Million Shares
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange rose to 170.9 million shares, from 163.6 million the day before, with 983 issues rising and 507 declining.
Coca-Cola, one Dow stock, rose 1, to 72 3/8, in heavy trading. In a move to take on Pepsi more aggressively with a sweeter drink than Coke Classic, the company said on Wednesday that it would soon begin test-marketing Coke II, the old ''New Coke'' renamed.
Other Dow stocks moving higher included 3M, up 1 3/8, to 82 5/8; Procter & Gamble, up 1 5/8, to 65; USX, up 1, to 36 5/8, and Woolworth, up 1 1/2, to 62 5/8. After Carl C. Icahn, the Manhattan investor, said he would seek support to distribute to investors most of USX's steel operations, Standard & Poor's affirmed the debt ratings of USX's oil and steel business.
Genentech, the West Coast health-care company, fell 1 1/8, to 26 1/8, on volume of 1.1 million shares, before the Big Board halted trading late in the day, pending an announcement. Genentech announced that an Italian study of its blood-clot-dissolving drug and of another made by Hoechst A.G. had been ''inconclusive'' in deciding which was better, although it said both were ''equally effective in saving lives'' of heart-attack patients.
Among aircraft, electronics, computer and technology stocks, Boeing rose 1, to 67 1/2; McDonnell Douglas 1 3/8, to 56 5/8; Martin-Marietta 2, to 42 3/4; Motorola 2 1/8, to 64 3/8; I.B.M. 1 1/2, to 107; Digital Equipment 2 3/8, to 76 7/8; Apple Computer 1 3/8, to 36 3/4; Compaq 3 5/8, to 95 7/8, Hewlett-Packard 1 1/8, to 44 3/4; Computer Associates 1 1/8, to 14 1/8, and Microsoft 3 1/2, to 106 1/4.
Doug van Dorsten, a computer analyst at Shearson Lehman Hutton, issued a ''buy'' recommendation on Compaq. Wendy Abramowitz, an analyst with Argus Research, told Reuters a week ago that analysts expected Microsoft to introduce several new software products this year.
Motorola advanced in the wake of reports on the Financial News Network that Hitachi, the Japanese electronics company, might buy a piece of Motorola. Traders seemed skeptical.
Buttressed by strong February sales reports from several retailing companies, J.C. Penney rose 1 1/8, to 68 7/8; May 1 1/2, to 48 7/8; Dayton Hudson 1 3/8, to 66 5/8; Gap 1 3/4, to 59 1/4; Limited 1 3/4, to 39 3/4; Melville 1 3/4, to 48 5/8; Toys ''R'' Us 1 5/8, to 41 5/8.
Bard slid 3 1/8, or 23 percent, to 13 5/8, with 3.35 million shares traded. Hilton, the most active issue on the Big Board, plunged 10 3/8, to 50 5/8, on 7.79 million shares after Hilton decided not to sell the company.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Higher As Gold Prices Slip in U.S.

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished mostly higher yesterday in lackluster trading worldwide.
Gold prices slipped in New York after finishing mixed overseas. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold settled at $400 an ounce, off 20 cents from Wednesday. The Republic National Bank of New York later quoted a bid of $399.80 an ounce, down 80 cents. 
''The day never really got started,'' said Bob Morrissey, a senior trader with the Bank of Boston in New York. ''It was almost like a holiday market.''
Traders said trading was dampened by the threat of central bank intervention. Dealers were surprised on Wednesday when a group of central banks aggressively and repeatedly sold dollars to keep the currency from rising.
The Federal Reserve was believed to have entered the market more than once yesterday to sell dollars against the yen, but the action was modest compared with the previous session, traders said.
Still, sentiment toward the dollar remains very bullish.
''More and more people are seeing that the economy is not doing as badly as original expectations, so there should be no real easing of interest rates,'' Mr. Morrissey said.
Higher interest rates generally support the dollar by enhancing the value of fixed-income securities. Foreign investors, typically major purchasers of instruments like United States Government bonds, need dollars to make their investments.
Further evidence about the economy will come this morning, when the Labor Department issues its unemployment report for February. The consensus is for non-farm payrolls to show an increase of about 240,000 jobs.
Separately, officials confirmed that finance ministers from the Group of Seven leading industrialized countries will meet in early April in Paris, where they are expected to discuss global currency exchange rates.
In New York, the dollar finished at 151.09 yen, up from 150.35 yen on Wednesday. It also gained against the pound, which ended at $1.6385, cheaper than $1.6465 on Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Wednesday's late rates, included: 1.7008 West German marks, up from 1.6982; 1.5080 Swiss francs, up from 1.4995; 5.7495 French francs, up from 5.7400; 1,255.25 Italian lire, up from 1,252.75, and 1.1807 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1831.
Silver prices were mixed. On New York's Comex, silver for current delivery finished at $5.112 an ounce, down from $5.122 on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: For Younger and Older, Workplace Day Care

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
The Stride Rite Corporation is bridging the generations in the heart of its workplace with a day care center where working parents can bring not just their preschoolers but also their aging relatives.
While many companies offer child care, Stride Rite is the first to bring together in one location those under 6 and those over 60 whose biggest problem is not personal health but filling lonely days with a sense of purpose.
It is easy to forget that there are bigger social policy questions here while watching 79-year-old Eva DaRosa sharing peanut butter crackers with preschoolers or hearing 85-year-old Geraldine Keane spinning a story about dinosaurs that rivets the attention of 4-year-olds.
But the center is indeed dealing with broader questions: How can businesses attract and keep a qualified work force? How should the nation care for its oldest and youngest citizens?
''By the year 2000, almost half the employees in the work force will be providing child care, elder care or both,'' said Dr. Michael Creedon, a former professor of gerontology at the University of Bridgeport who is now director of corporate programs at the National Council on the Aging in Washington. ''We can expect more companies already providing child care to convert to intergenerational day care in order to help their employees.'' 
The companies also gain, in increased productivity and decreased turnover in workers. Dr. Creedon said a number of studies showed that employees tended to lose five days a year on average because of problems providing care for a family member. Such problems are also likely to cause workers to quit their jobs, come to work late or use the telephone excessively for personal reasons.
The recently opened Intergenerational Day Care Center here in Stride Rite's headquarters fulfills a vision of Arnold Hiatt, the company's 62-year-old board chairman, who had read about working parents spending frantic hours each day coordinating care for family members both old and young.
''I'm in business trying to orchestrate workers, materials, consumers and markets and to bring it all together,'' Mr. Hiatt said. ''Why not a similar business approach to a societal problem? There are risks involved in engaging two vulnerable populations and no certainty of success. But they are nice risks.''
 
Track Record as Innovator
Stride Rite, a leading footwear manufacturer, already had a track record as an innovator. In 1971 it became the first corporation to open an on-site child care center. It still operates that center, at its plant in nearby Roxbury, one of the city's most economically depressed neighborhoods.
To develop the new center, Mr. Hiatt enlisted the help of Wheelock College, a Boston-based school specializing in child care and family studies, and Somerville/Cambridge Elder Services, a local nonprofit agency providing help to the elderly.
The partners were determined that the center not have the look and especially not the antiseptic smell of an institution, and it does not. The aroma of chicken soup wafts from the kitchen at noon. And sometimes at snack time, there is the tempting smell of pretzels baked by Mrs. DaRosa and Mrs. Keane. (The children prefer sticks they can wave to the twisted variety.) When the center is in full operation, it will accommodate 55 children, who can range in age from 18 months old to 6 years, and 24 older adults. It will be open not only to relatives of employees but also to people in the community.
''It is more than likely that one of Stride Rite's 500 employees one day will enroll both a child and a parent at the center,'' said Karen Leibold, director of work and family programs for Stride Rite.
 
Benefits Are Assessed
''If we look ahead, we see a chance for the two generations to get to know each other,'' Ms. Leibold said. ''The elders will find and experience again what it is like to be a contributing member to the community.''
Since February the children have been coming to the center, which has a gym and rooms filled with a dream world of stuffed animals and toys.
The children, in groups labeled ''peanuts,'' ''Muppets,'' ''rainbows'' and ''eagles,'' depending on age, have already made an impact on the neighborhood. On a typical afternoon walk, they stop at the Hotel Marriott next door and induce the bell captain to let them try on his plumed hat. They then visit the florist shop and Legal's Seafoods to see the lobster tank, returning home with day-old flowers and bags of oyster crackers.
The section for older adults opened two weeks ago with no formal ceremony except for the display of a finger-painted banner saying, ''Welcome Eva and Gerry.''
Mrs. DaRosa is dropped off at the center by her 48-year-old daughter, Maria, who works across the street at the Cambridge Redevelopment Authority.
 
Mother's Idle Hours Filled
The center, open from 8 A.M. to 5:30 P.M., now fills her mother's idle hours, Maria said, and she rides home animatedly talking about the day's events. The adults have their own retreat at the center, a cozy area of couches, chairs and piles of flowered chintz pillows that Mrs. DaRosa calls ''the porch.'' Last Monday, the program was built around the history of Cape Verde, the former Portuguese colony off the West African coast from which the DaRosa family came generations ago. Happily, Mrs. DaRosa danced a Mazuaka she learned in her younger years.
Mrs. Keane learned about the care center from her daughter, Nancy Kruger, vice president of training and development at the Greater Boston Y.M.C.A. Ms. Kruger, in turn, heard about it at a conference on child care.
Mrs. Keane, a former teacher, usually arrives with a book in hand. She gets herself to the center and home by taxi. She has volunteered to use the word-processor that will be installed so that the participants can help prepare a newsletter about the center.
Next week, the two widows expect to be joined by 74-year-old Josephine Campanelli, whose granddaughter, Ronna, is a real estate leasing assistant at Stride Rite.
Ms. Leibold said the company had expected enrollment of elders to be slow. ''No one wanted to be the first through the door, and many wanted to see how the center looked and what food was served,'' she said.
For the moment, the adults and the children meet only at meals and occasionally take outdoor walks together, but a few of the youngsters now come looking for Mrs. Keane to read.
 
Patient View of Relationships
''We realize you cannot push children and elders together,'' Ms. Leibold said. ''You have to provide the opportunity for the relationships to develop. It cannot be forced.''
An early childhood teacher, Ms. Leibold came to Stride Rite seven years ago to direct its children's center. Her staff of 25 full- and part-time members includes teachers with advanced degrees as well as a professional dancer, a musician, social workers and recreational therapists. Ultimately there will be a nurse, but the center is not designed to care for older adults with debilitating illness.
Stride Rite hopes other companies will emulate the care center. ''My only reservation,'' Dr. Creedon said, ''is we not forget that an intergenerational center only meets the needs of some elders. It does not serve those now in nursing homes, confined to bed at home or severely incapacitated.
''For them, we still need a broad array of other responses such as flexible work schedules and more generous leave-of-absence policies for employees who are care-givers.''
Stride Rite spent $700,000 to convert 8,500 square feet of its fourth-floor headquarters for the center.
The company will subsidize the center's operating expenses, estimated to be $600,000 a year. The center estimates that it costs $150 a week to take care of a preschooler, $170 for a toddler and $140 for an elder.
 
Meeting the Center's Expenses
Stride Rite employees pay fees of $20 to $130 a week for the children, depending on family income, and $85 a week for the older adults. The balance comes from a foundation set up by the company. Outsiders pay full costs, with some low-income families aided by state subsidies. The company is prepared to make up the difference between what the fees bring and the center's expenses with money from the company's foundation.
Although Mr. Hiatt is proud of his company's program, he expressed serious misgivings about whether it will be cited as evidence that the business sector has the resources to take responsibility for the nation's preschoolers, insisting that this remains a government responsibility. ''Companies can be innovative and experiment but I don't believe corporate day care answers the need of intervening in the lives of 20 million children under 5,'' he said.
And he noted that such fringe benefits for employees have historically been one of the first things to go when companies retrench in difficult economic times.
''If business turned down for a few years, I'd probably get a lot of flak about my mishigas,'' he said, using the Yiddish word for foolishness.
But such practical considerations have not dimmed his dream of what the center can be:
''Here we do not share the same names,'' he said, ''but we have a chance to interact that is as old as the family of man.''

HEADLINE: Lima Journal;
On the Front Line in Guerrilla War: Power Pylons

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, March 4

 BODY:
Just off the Pan-American Highway, a desert lot here serves as a drive-in showroom for Peru's latest fashion in power pylons - pillboxes, electric fences and ''concrete pants.''
''The concrete pants can withstand a 15-pound dynamite charge,'' Tomas Espinola Carranza, director of transmission for the state electric company, said as he braked his station wagon in the dust by a tower. Each of four supports was encased in a steel-reinforced concrete legging.
Fortifying pylons has become a new industrial art in Peru, where Marxist guerrillas blew up 1,196 of the nation's 5,000 high-voltage transmission towers in the 1980's. Plagued with similar terrorism, power company engineers from El Salvador and Colombia have recently visited the desert lot here to exchange ideas and inventions with their Peruvian counterparts. 
For Peru's far-left Shining Path guerrillas, cutting electric power is an important propaganda tactic in this capital of eight million. Power outages have become so predictable that some factory managers tell their workers to stay home on dates commemorated by Shining Path. $15 Billion in Losses Blackouts accounted for a large share of the $15 billion in economic losses attributed to political violence in Peru from 1980 to 1988, according to a recent study by Peru's Congress. In the 1980's, the Electroperu utility lost $110 million in energy sales, repair costs and fuel purchases to run thermal generating plants.
''Shining Path uses the blackouts selectively to show that the Government is powerless,'' said a Western diplomat who has studied the terror tactic. Over one year ending last July, the blackouts were regularly spaced every 40 to 50 days, he said.
A series of attacks around the time of Peru's city elections in November led to 45 days of power rationing here that ended Jan. 15. With the first round of Peru's presidential election scheduled for April 8, the Shining Path guerrillas, who are calling for a boycott of the election, are expected to topple more towers along the thinly defended Andean tranmission lines.
''Forget about the blackouts - immediate delivery,'' promised a recent newspaper advertisement for Lima's new status symbol, an auxiliary diesel generator.
 
Adapting to Blackouts
In Lima, people have seemingly adapted to the blackouts that hit neighborhoods without warning. Many people avoid elevators for fear of getting trapped for hours. Service station attendants have learned how to pump gasoline manually, and drivers have learned to thread through intersections jammed by extinguished traffic lights.
And at the power company, engineers are learning how to fortify 30-ton, 165-foot transmission towers.
''The problem gets worse every day,'' said Col. Angel Valdivia, a retired army colonel who is Electroperu's chief of security. Indeed, company statistics show that attacks on power pylons doubled last year, from 163 in 1988 to 335 in 1989.
The challenge is to modify Peru's graceful Italian-made pylons, which were designed 30 years ago when their worst imaginable enemies were winter storms in the Italian Alps.
In addition to encasing pylon legs in 15-foot-high concrete casts, Peruvian engineers have experimented with enclosing the four legs in a square, 15-foot-high pillbox with broken glass embedded in the concrete walls.
 
Electrified Wires Used
In another tactic, engineers drop from a tower a cable carrying 23,000 volts to electrify three wires strung around the base. To keep cows, llamas and people away, the pylon is then surrounded with a perimeter of concertina wire.
To convert local peasants into energy guards, engineers are also running lines from towers to remote mountain villages.
''Peasants would always say, 'The towers go through here, but I don't have any electricity,' '' said Anibal Tomecich Cordova, the utility's general manager.
In another tactic, Peru's Energy Police, a division of the National Police, have surrounded 600 Andean towers with anti-personnel mines. To protect a mountain line that runs far from roads, the army is drawing up plans to build a series of helicopter landing pads.
Worried about Shining Path's alliance with Andean coca leaf growers, the United States this year is to give Peru $36 million, the first substantial American military aid seen here in 20 years.
Citing aid that the United States gives El Salvador to keep electricity flowing there, Peruvian officials hope that the United States will consider helping Electroperu.
''We don't even have a single helicopter,'' said Mr. Tomecich, noting that his lines cross mountain passes as high as 16,500 feet. ''We need helicopters, all-terrain vehicles and a satellite communications system. The terrorists would just blow up microwave dishes.''

HEADLINE: Haitians Take to the Streets Again To Call for Military Ruler's Ouster

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, March 9

 BODY:
Demonstrations aimed at bringing down this country's military ruler continued for the fifth day today as protesters marched and built flaming barricades to block main roads.
The police used gunfire, truncheons and tear gas to break up some of the protests, and at least three young people were reported wounded in the capital. Most stores and offices in the capital were shuttered, and schools across Haiti, the poorest country in the Western Hemisphere, were closed. 
Lieut. Gen. Prosper Avril, who came to power in a coup 18 months ago, was believed to be meeting with aides in the presidential palace. He issued no statements as the crisis deepened. Haitians who follow politics and several foreign diplomats said reports on Thursday that General Avril's wife had fled Haiti were incorrect.
 
Widespread Disapproval
Most of the country's leading political and business groups have called on the 52-year-old general to resign, saying they no longer believe his promises to lead the country to democracy. General Avril has also been accused of mismanaging the economy, allowing soldiers to skim profits from Government agencies and failing to end months of robberies and killings.
Ordinary Haitians are usually cautious in criticizing their presidents, but their restraint seemed to have vanished today. ''We need another president,'' a gasoline station attendant said. ''Avril has to go.''
''It looks bad,'' a civil servant said. ''It is not a minority against him. It is people in many towns.''
In an interview on Wednesday, General Avril told an independent Haitian television reporter that he was prepared to step down if that was ''the will of the people.'' But he added, ''If I step down hurriedly it will create a lot of turmoil.''
 
Opposition Alerts Army
On Thursday, the most violent day of demonstrations so far, 3 people, including a police officer, were killed and at least 12 were wounded.
An informal coalition of 11 political groups urged the armed forces today to prepare for General Avril's departure and to ''take all necessary measures for a smooth transition.''
Political and business leaders are urging that General Avril be replaced as President by Gabriel Volcy, the Vice President of the Supreme Court. They have suggested that the judge govern in consultation with a council of about a dozen members chosen from all sectors of Haiti, including the military.
In January, after the unexplained killing of an army colonel, General Avril abruptly declared a state of siege in which dozens of civilian political leaders were arrested and beaten. Seven were forced into exile. Under pressure from the United States and other aid donors, General Avril lifted the state of siege after nine days. But public confidence, never firmly established, was destroyed. One by one, the political leaders announced their refusal to take part in elections promised this year by General Avril.

HEADLINE: Europe Giving Thatcher Bad Press on Germany

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, March 9

 BODY:
Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher is being described by influential British and West German newspapers these days as the skunk at the garden party of German unity.
But her public position on the issue is quite close to that of the United States and France, and mirrors some of the Soviet Union's concerns.
This is important because East and West Germany plan to negotiate the terms of unification, after elections in East Germany on March 18, with the four countries, the Allied powers of World War II.
Yet Timothy Garton Ash, the foreign editor of The Spectator magazine, wrote not long ago that in recent travels through both Germanys, he could find only one person who had a good word for the British Prime Minister - Egon Krenz, the deposed and now unemployed Communist Party leader who briefly succeeded Erich Honecker last October. 
 
Criticized by Schmidt
The former West German Chancellor Helmut Schmidt described Mrs. Thatcher last week as the only outstanding personality among European leaders, but said that she no longer had enough respect from her colleagues to lead them or the Germans into the European future. ''She has gone too far,'' he said.
The weekly newspaper he now publishes, Die Zeit, reported last week that Mrs. Thatcher was against German unification because she was a ''little Englander,'' a British nationalist who could not stand the thought of a Europe dominated by a united German nation.
Mrs. Thatcher's image as a European leader, in most European newspapers, including British ones, has faded in the course of the last year. She has repeatedly thrown cold water on hopes for rapid European political and monetary union, and her domestic troubles have piled up. It is also well-known that she and Chancellor Helmut Kohl have never struck up a warm relationship.
In both Britain and West Germany, these things have colored the reporting of what Mrs. Thatcher does best, which is to keep turning over bedrock ideals like European unity and German reunification and pointing out all the scorpions and centipedes below.
 
Uncertainty Over Currency Union
Her aides keep finding more. The prospect of a currency union between East and West Germany, one of them said, created ''a whole area of new uncertainty'' for European monetary union. The prospect of German unity, he said, would also require renegotiating the European Community's policies on fisheries and agriculture.
German unification, Mrs. Thatcher says, should take place deliberately, not all of a sudden, something her critics in Germany hold against her. But a close examination of what Mrs. Thatcher may have been saying about German unification in recent weeks shows her remarks to be no more obstructionist than those of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union, who has been hailed in West Germany for giving it the green light.
That was after he told Mr. Kohl in Moscow last month that how and when the two Germanys came together was for them alone to decide - but that the security framework within which they did it was a concern of their neighbors.
Mrs. Thatcher used almost identical words a week later in a widely quoted speech to the Board of Deputies of British Jews on Feb. 18. ''German unification must take into account not only the feelings of the two German states, but the sensitivities and interests of others in Europe as well,'' she said.
 
Inflexibility 'Confirmed'
Several leading British newspapers characterized the Prime Minister's remarks as an attempt to slow down the pace of unification. The Guardian's report said the comments ''further confirmed the Prime Minister's inflexibility and apparent reluctance to play a constructive role in building the new European architecture.''
Mrs. Thatcher's aides concede that she has in fact been trying to slow the pace. But they noted today that in the Feb. 18 speech, she also said she supported Poland's wish to see its Western border guaranteed by treaty.
But Mr. Kohl's long refusal to address that concern brought him trouble. President Bush subtly underlined the difference between the American and the West German position on the border at Camp David, Md., on Feb. 25.
By last Thursday, the French Foreign Minister, Roland Dumas, was saying openly in West Berlin: ''There are moments when silence is heavy with ambiguities. That border is untouchable. That must be said without delay. It has to be stated clearly to the people concerned, first of all the Poles.''
 
Statement by Kohl
Finally, on Tuesday, Chancellor Kohl, conceding mistakes, proposed a joint declaration by the East and West German parliaments after the elections to guarantee the border.
''In all this we want to insure that Germany's unification upholds peace and prosperity in Europe and does not become a new source of instability,'' Mrs. Thatcher said in her speech last month. ''Chancellor Kohl and his colleagues share this aim, and I am sure they will remain staunch supporters of NATO,'' she said.
Mr. Gorbachev, whose own domestic political preoccupations in the Soviet Union have led officials in Washington to assume that he can no longer prevent German unification on NATO's terms, repeated on Tuesday that NATO membership was unacceptable for a united Germany. Mrs. Thatcher believes it is indispensable.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
