HEADLINE: Thaw Is Hinted In School Strike In West Virginia

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHARLESTON, W.Va., March 9

 BODY:
What has become one of the most serious teacher strikes in the nation in recent years shut down more than half of West Virginia's schools today, the third day of the strike.
There was no sign when the dispute would be resolved. But late tonight, in what his aides called a ''positive gesture,'' Gov. Gaston Caperton recommended that any teachers returning to the classrooms Monday not be punished or have to forfeit pay. Teachers' organizations said they would respond Saturday to the Governor's remarks. 
The State Board of Education said the walkout, mainly over pay, had closed all schools in 24 of the state's 55 counties and had left schools badly understaffed in other counties.
At least 100,000 pupils, about a third of the state enrollment, were unable to attend classes because of the walkout.
Before the Governor's suggestion late tonight, state officials and leaders of teachers' organizations said they were willing to negotiate. But they could not agree on conditions or timing for talks.
 
Ahead of Mississippi
According to the West Virginia Education Association, whose membership includes about three-fourths of the state's 22,000 teachers, West Virginia ranks 49th in teacher pay, with an average annual salary of $21,904. Only Mississippi teachers earn less.
''I'm not proud of what I'm doing, but what we earn is a disgrace,'' Susan Coffman, a second-grade teacher, said this morning as she picketed on a spring-like, overcast day in front of the Piedmont Elementary School in downtown Charleston. On the school's bright green doors were tacked copies of court injunctions prohibiting the pickets from blocking entrances and exits.
The West Virginia strike is the third statewide teacher strike in the country this year, following one-day walkouts over pay in Utah and Washington State. Citywide or countywide teacher strikes are fairly common around the nation, but statewide actions are rare. That three have been called already this year has caused some educators to wonder whether the nation might be headed for a new spell of school unrest over money.
''This many statewide strikes is very unusual,'' said Howard Carroll, a spokesman for the National Education Association, the Washington-based organization that represents about three-fourths of the nation's teachers. Who Inflicted the Wounds? Henry Marockie, the West Virginia education superintendent, said this afternoon he saw no sign of a quick end to the walkout.
''It looks like about half our schools are in and about half are out,'' he said, ''and they're going to stay that way for a while. This is going to create a lot of wounds that will take a long time to heal.''
Kayetta Meadows, the president of the West Virginia Education Association, said state officials had inflicted the wounds.
''Eight years ago, we ranked 33d in the nation in pay,'' she said. ''We're falling farther and farther behind, not even keeping up with inflation. Our paychecks today have $250 less in spending power than they did 10 years ago. We'll stay on strike forever, if necessary, to turn the situation around.''
State officials, including Governor Caperton, readily concede that the pay is too low, making it difficult for the state to recruit and hold teachers. But the officials say the state, one of the most economically troubled in the country, does not have the means to meet the teachers' demands.
 
A Turnip Without Blood
''We put together a package that would have given them a 5 percent pay increase and many other improvements in benefits, but they rejected it and walked out,'' said Governor Caperton, who has frequently called himself ''the education Governor.''
''There's no more blood in the turnip,'' he added. ''We all know that this state's young people are its future. But this is a very poor state, and we can only do so much.'' While both sides insisted today that they were willing to negotiate, both set conditions. State officials said the teachers would have to return to work before there could be any talks.
Indeed, only hours before his conciliatory gesture, Governor Caperton said: ''We won't talk while there's an illegal walkout under way. State law doesn't permit teachers to have any collective contract with the state, so this is not a strike. It's just an attempt at intimidation.''
But officials of teacher organizations said they reserved the right for their members to stay off the job. ''Nothing says you can't talk while you're on strike,'' Ms. Meadows said.
 
Warning From Legal Official
Earlier this week, the West Virginia Attorney General, Roger Tompkins, warned teachers that they could be suspended, dismissed or charged with a misdemeanor for walking off the job. ''A strike or work stoppage by teachers constitutes an attack upon the most important duty and function of this state,'' he said.
Some state officials contend the strike was precipitated in part by competition among teachers groups for members. Besides the West Virginia Education Association, which is affiliated with the National Education Association, the American Federation of Teachers is active in the state.
 
No Strike Benefits
But teachers insist the sole reason for the strike is money, and not just salaries.
''It's really more than just pay for teachers,'' said Ghee Gossard, a third-grade teacher who was picketing today at Piedmont Elementary. ''There are a lot of school systems around the state that don't get the money from the state that they deserve.''
How long the teachers can hold out is anybody's guess. They have no strike funds and, they say, not much money in their personal bank accounts.
While concerns about money had been building among teachers for some time, they did not crest until a month ago, after Governor Caperton said in his annual budget address that there would be no raise this year. Within days, thousands of teachers descended on the state Capitol, marching noisily through legislative halls and threatening to strike.
Mr. Caperton threw together a plan that included a 5 percent pay increase, as well as some money for benefits and school improvement programs. He proposed to pay for the package with a new tax on coal and, aides said, had rounded up the votes for it.
But when he offered the package to the teachers, on condition that they drop all strike threats, they balked. He withdrew the offer, and the strike followed, on Wednesday. The Legislature is scheduled to end its session on Saturday.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 20, 1990, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article on March 10 about the West Virginia teachers' strike misstated Mississippi's rank among the 50 states and the District of Columbia in teachers' annual salary. It is 45th, not 51st.

HEADLINE: Senator Makes Scathing Attack on Gephardt Over Criticism of Bush

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 9

 BODY:
In an unusual breach of senatorial custom, Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming, the deputy Republican leader, delivered a scathing personal attack today on Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the Democratic leader of the House.
Speaking from the floor of the Senate, Mr. Simpson described Mr. Gephardt as a ''frustrated fount of trivia'' and ridiculed his recent criticism of President Bush as the frustrated railings of a man who lusts to have the President's job.
In a speech on Tuesday, Mr. Gephardt criticized the President, asserting that he lacked vision and leadership in shaping the country's response to the emerging democracies in Eastern Europe and changes in the Soviet Union. Mr. Gephardt was widely rebuked by Republicans, who have pounced particularly on the Missouri Democrat's call for economic aid to the Soviet Union. 
While Mr. Simpson has been taking aim at Mr. Gephardt all week, his speech today went well beyond the earlier partisan jabs, focusing less on the substance of the speech than on the majority leader himself. It came on the heels of similar comments issued earlier in the day by Ed Rollins, the director of the Republican Congressional Campaign Committee, who called Mr. Gephardt a hypocrite for his criticism of President Bush's use of public opinion polls.
 
'All You Need Is a Shrill Voice'
''It doesn't take any brains to be a critic,'' Mr. Simpson said of Mr. Gephardt. ''All you need is a shrill voice and a human target, and when the target happens to hold a job that the critic desperately lusts for and has been repeatedly denied by his own party, then the frustration levels must be enormous.''
Representative Gephardt ran unsuccessfully for his party's Presidential nomination in 1988.
Mr. Simpson accused the Democratic leader of using the foreign policy speech to further his own political ambitions. ''Richard Gephardt ought to try to resist the desire to have the camera lights bleach his suits out while he rails on in classical personal aggrandizement trying again for the big brass ring,'' Mr. Simpson said.
Mr. Gephardt, who was in California at the time. did not hear Mr. Simpson's comments in the Senate. David Dreyer, a spokesman for Mr. Gephardt, said, ''It shows a low opinion of the American people when the Republicans launch a personal attack on Congressman Gephardt, who is urging greater American leadership to advance democracy in the Eastern bloc.''
''This was a setup,'' said Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York. ''It is very clear to me that someone in the White House was very upset by what the majority leader said, or we would not have had this kind of response in the Senate.''
Mr. Moynihan added that during his 13 years in the Senate he had never witnessed such a statement about someone not present to respond.
Touching briefly on the policy issues raised in Mr. Gephardt's speech, Mr. Simpson said that it was Mr. Gephardt who was out of touch with the American people, not President Bush. ''Two-thirds of the American people oppose substantial aid to the Soviet Union at this time,'' he said. ''No wonder Mr. Gephardt doesn't like the polls. They don't tell him what he wants to hear.''
Mr. Simpson called the Democratic majority leader ''a very bright and thoughtful man'' who had unwisely chosen to become ''the self-appointed trasher of the Administration.'' The American people were waiting for original ideas and thoughtful leadership from Mr. Gephardt, he said. ''All they got was reprocessed cud.''

HEADLINE: Unemployment Remains Steady at 5.3%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 9

 BODY:
The economy generated many more jobs in February than analysts had expected, but the growth was not sufficient to affect the civilian unemployment rate. It stood at 5.3 percent for the ninth straight month, the Labor Department reported today.
The report, the first comprehensive indicator of economic activity last month, suggested a rebound from recent stagnation and was hailed by the Bush Administration as tending to confirm its projections of a fresh expansion this year.
''We believe the economy, after a period of slower growth, is likely to show progress,'' said Michael J. Boskin, the President's chief economic adviser. 
But the report was greeted nervously by the securities markets. Prices fell on both bonds and stocks. The bond market was especially hard hit. Investors there saw the report as a sign of economic strength, raising their fears of inflation and higher interest rates. Either inflation or higher interest would reduce the value of existing Government notes and bonds. [Page 34.] Bigger Gain Than Expected The report showed that jobs as determined by the department's survey of business payrolls jumped 372,000 for the month, a gain of about 100,000 more than had been expected. The report also revised the increase for January to 332,000, or 20 percent more than first reported. The February increase in jobs was the biggest since mid-1988 and included the first rise in manufacturing jobs since last March.
In all, according to the department's survey of households, which is separate from the payroll survey, the civilian labor force totaled 124,630,000 last month, with 118,035,000 people holding at least one job. The unemployed numbered 6,595,000 people, for a civilian jobless rate of 5.3 percent.
The overall jobless rate, which includes military personnel stationed in the United States, was 5.2 percent last month, also unchanged from its January level.
 
Impact of Auto Employment
Special factors contributed heavily to the improvement portrayed in the number of jobs, and analysts said the economy was not nearly so buoyant as the numbers might at first suggest.
The Commissioner of Labor Statistics, Janet L. Norwood, noted today in her monthly appearance before Congress that 90,000 of the new jobs reported last month represented the return of laid-off workers in the automobile and related fabricated-metal industries. This reflected some improvement in demand for American-made cars, but the number of auto jobs is still 50,000 below the level of February 1989.
Another special factor was the second straight month of exceptionally warm weather. That led to a 60,000 increase in construction jobs, after a 105,000 rise in January. Dr. Norwood warned that some of this surge might prove to be borrowed from the industry's usual rebound in the spring.
Most of the figures reported by the Labor Department are adjusted for seasonal variations: the department uses recent history to take account of generally predictable things like extreme weather, holidays, the beginning and end of the school year and the changeover in automobile model years.
This is done to allow more accurate examination of underlying economic trends. Sometimes, however, the adjustments are not enough to offset extraordinary circumstances or may exaggerate them.
 
Factory Employment Still Weak
Apart from automobiles and metals, factory employment was relatively weak last month, the department said. One measure of this was an index that compares the percentage of companies adding workers with those reducing their work force. That index showed only 46.1 percent of 141 manufacturing industries increasing employment or keeping it unchanged in February. This was the 10th month in the past 11 in which this gauge measured less than 50 percent.
The department's survey of business payrolls also showed that service industries posted substantial gains while smaller increases in jobs were recorded for transportation, public utilities, finance, insurance and real estate.
In all, service jobs, which are the driving force in the economy, climbed 221,000 last month while jobs in goods-producing industries rose by 151,000.
The report also showed that the length of the workweek in private industry edged up six minutes, to 34.6 hours.
The unemployment rate is based on a separate department survey of about 60,000 households. It showed that the increase in civilian jobs of 172,000 was not quite as rapid as the 233,000 rise in the number of people seeking work. But this shortfall was not enough to raise the jobless rate, which has been flat since late last spring.
 
Decline in Jobless Rate for Blacks
There was little change in the jobless rates of most population groups except that the rate for blacks fell eight-tenths of a point, to 10.5 percent. This put it about one point below its average for the second half of last year.
The unemployment rate for auto workers, which had soared to 20 percent because of temporary plant shutdowns in January, fell back to 8 percent last month.
In the Northeast the jobless rate edged up two-tenths of a point, to 5.7 percent. In the West the rate rose by one-tenth of a point, to 5.5 percent. For the South, the rate was unchanged at 5.8, while the rate for the Midwest fell six-tenths of a point, to 6.1 percent. The regional figures are not adjusted for seasonal variations.
The ranks of the domestically based military fell to 1,678,000 in February from 1,697,000 in January, department figures indicated.

HEADLINE: Civilian Rate As Main Gauge

 BODY:
The Labor Department statistics published today by The New York Times show the civilian unemployment rate as the primary gauge of the nation's labor market rather than the overall rate, whose base includes domestically stationed military personnel.
The Times will continue to report both rates. But it is shifting its focus to the civilian rate because that is widely viewed as a slightly more accurate reflection of labor market conditions.
When military personnel are included in the work force, the overall unemployment rate that results is frequently one-tenth of a point lower.
Focusing on the civilian rate is intended to reduce confusion and provide consistency, since the details in the monthly report, including the jobless rates for various population groups, relate only to civilians.

HEADLINE: Artists, Accepting Federal Grants, Worry About Strings

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 9

 BODY:
Grants are godsends for writers like Martha Collins, but she still had to think long and hard before accepting a $20,000 fellowship this year from the National Endowment for the Arts.
The financial freedom was tempting, but it came with a few strings attached: Ms. Collins, who is a poet, and 96 other writers nationwide had to sign letters promising to comply with Federal restrictions imposed last fall after some legislators objected to Government financing of exhibitions featuring works by the photographers Robert Mapplethorpe and Andres Serrano. Under the restrictions adopted as part of the arts endowment's appropriations bill, it agreed to weed out grant recipients whose art might be construed as obscene.
''I signed because I can live with it, but I'm concerned by the tone - concerned that things could get worse instead of better,'' said Ms. Collins, who also directs the writing program at the University of Massachusetts at Boston. 
 
'Obligated to Obey'
The chairman of the endowment, John E. Frohnmayer, said Thursday that he did not endorse the legislation, though as a Federal official he was prohibited from lobbying against it.
''I'm obligated to obey the law,'' he said in a telephone interview from Washington. ''I do think that the statute is unnecessary and I hope that Congress in its wisdom will not see fit to continue it.''
Among the 1990 applicants, five writers were singled out for closer examination and all of the more than 4,000 artists who eventually were granted funds received a package containing the promissory letter, the endowment said.
''Like a lot of writers, I was in a financially desperate situation so I signed, but not without a lot of outrage,'' said Alison Demming, a poet in Provincetown, Mass. ''The N.E.A. is giving us freedom from economic stress, but they're saying we can't exercise it freely.''
 
'Create as You Wish'
That's not the perception the endowment wants its writers to have, said Virginia Falck, a spokeswoman for the agency.
''Our stand is, 'Don't let this intimidate you,' '' she said. ''Feel free to create as you wish. When you're funding creativity, you've got to allow room for people to do all kinds of things - warts and all.''
But grant recipients are now being asked to refrain from producing artworks that include, but are not limited to, ''depictions of sadomasochism, homoeroticism, the sexual exploitation of children or individuals engaged in sex acts and which, when taken as a whole, do not have serious literary, artistic, political or scientific merit.''
Some writers said they felt they were facing the possibility of increased censorship and state control of the arts.
''It's ironic that we've spent all these years reading about restrictions on artists in Eastern Europe and just when they're gaining freedom we're beginning to feel restricted,'' Miss Collins said. She also objected to ''sandwiching'' homoerotic art between images of sadomasochism and sexually exploited children. ''Everyone I've talked with feels it's alarming,'' she said.
 
To Monitor Agency
Other writers were more sanguine. Ursula Hegi, of Spokane, Wash., said she had signed without hesitation because ''it was not in any conflict with what I'm doing.''
Ms. Falck said the endowment had not so far developed a procedure for checking on the thousands of photographers, dancers, urban designers, painters and other artists who each year receive Federal funds.
Meanwhile, the Writers' Coalition, an umbrella organization for 50 groups, including PEN America, the Modern Language Association and the National Writers' Union, plans to monitor closely the agency's next steps.
The endowment ''is supposed to be an arts advocate and at the same time must comply with this law,'' said Liam Rector, director of a writers' group called Associated Writing Programs in Norfolk, Va. ''The endowment finds it difficult to defend itself, so it falls to the field and to the artists themselves to protect First Amendment rights.''

HEADLINE: Report Denied on Not Renaming Greenspan

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 9

 BODY:
A published report that President Bush is unlikely to ask Alan Greenspan to stay on as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board when his term expires in 17 months drew strong denials today from the White House and the Treasury. It also prompted ringing endorsements of Mr. Greenspan from both Democratic and Republican lawmakers.
The report appeared to have little influence on financial markets. But it was taken seriously by some analysts here, who saw it as another sign of White House unease with monetary policies that have led to about a half-percentage-point increase in long-term rates so far this year as rates were rising in other big industrial countries. 
More broadly, the article, which appeared today in The Los Angeles Times, was seen as marking another chapter in a long story of uneasy relations between the White House and the Federal Reserve, stemming from the frustration of Presidents over their inability to control the central bank's power to create money. Created by Congress just before the outbreak of World War I, the Federal Reserve System was given independence in an effort to insulate the management of money and credit from politics. In the postwar era alone, duels with Fed chairmen have been fought during the Truman, Johnson, Carter and Reagan Administrations.
The Los Angeles Times article appeared as one more incident in the Bush Administration's low-key running debate over interest rates. Richard G. Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, and President Bush himself have said that the Fed should lower interest rates to maintain growth.
The day before Mr. Bush's remarks, to a home builders' group in January, Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, had been more direct, saying that he hoped that new statistics showing a steady inflation rate and a faltering housing industry would persuade the Fed to ease. But Mr. Fitzwater later sought to play down the disagreement. And no Administration official has suggested publicly that Mr. Greenspan's job might be on the line if he failed to respond to this pressure.
Nevertheless, some experts said that The Los Angeles Times article probably came from some top Administration official annoyed at the Fed's reluctance to make further reductions in interest rates at a time when a recession is possible.
''The Administration wants to be in a position that if someone were to announce a recession next week, it would not be viewed as the Administration's fault,'' said Joseph Minarik, staff director of the Joint Economic Committee.
William Greider, author of a recent history of the Fed, ''Secrets of the Temple,'' said: ''This is the Administration's way of turning the heat up on the Federal Reserve Board. The article should be treated as serious politics.''
Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat who sits on the House Banking Committee, said that ''if the White House is leaking this, it's both counterproductive for the White House and pretty abhorrent.'' He described it as an effort to ''sacrifice the long-range stability of the country for short-term political gain.''
 
Treasury Called Likely Source
Some experts said the Treasury Department, rather than Mr. Darman or other White House officials, might be the source of the latest pressure on the Fed to lower rates. There is a faction at the Treasury that wants lower rates to stimulate the economy and reduce the value of the dollar, said Jude Wanniski, a supply-sider who is president of Polyconomics Inc., an economic consulting firm.
Both White House and Treasury officials took the occasion today to knock the report hard.
''I don't know where this story came from, but it is out of left field,'' said Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers. Asked whether White House officials like Mr. Darman were angry at Mr. Greenspan, Mr. Fitzwater said, ''No one is angry.''
 
Treasury's Response
Roger Bolton, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for public affairs, characterized The Los Angeles Times story as ''totally unfounded.''
''The matter hasn't even been discussed,'' he said.
The Fed had been reducing interest rates in small steps from the middle of last year into December. Some Administration officials argue that more reductions are needed to encourage greater spending on credit and thus avoid a recession, and to stimulate exports. Lower rates usually reduce the value of the dollar, which makes American goods less expensive in foreign currencies.
Mr. Greenspan has argued before Congress that rates need to stay high to combat possibly resurgent inflation. Among other factors, his supporters say, are global economic developments, like the need to find enough capital to finance development projects in Eastern Europe.
 
Fed Officials Surprised
Whatever the source of the pressure, the article apparently came as a surprise to Fed officials. Mr. Greenspan was in San Francisco, vacationing after attending a two-day gathering of directors of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco. His two top press officials, Joseph Coyne and Robert Moore, were on vacation.
Representative Lee H. Hamilton, Democrat of Indiana and chairman of the Joint Economic Committee, also expressed surprise.
''I think there is very broad support for Fed policy in the Congress and indeed in Washington,'' he said. Mr. Hamilton is the chief author of a bill now before Congress that would force the Fed to be more accountable to the public for its interest-rate policies.
Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, the Texas Democrat who is chairman of the House Banking Committee, said of Mr. Greenspan, ''He's done an admirably good job and is entitled to be considered for reappointment.''
 
Denials Discounted
But one prominent supply-side economist with close links to the White House said that despite the Administration denials, he thought the article - in which a longtime Bush adviser was quoted as saying the President was ''mad as hell'' about Mr. Greenspan's high-interest-rate position - was true.
''I know they are unhappy with him, and I sure know they are considering not reappointing him,'' said this economist, who insisted on anonymity. He said the view at the White House was that Mr. Greenspan ''seems to fear economic growth, but this President favors economic growth.''
Andrew F. Brimmer, a former Federal Reserve Board governor who is now a Washington financial consultant, said: ''I believe Bush is unhappy with Alan Greenspan, and I believe his associates are unhappy. I believe the unhappiness extends to the Treasury.''
But Mr. Brimmer, like many other other market specialists, said he thought it would be a mistake for the President not to reappoint Mr. Greenspan.
Because of Mr. Greenspan's ''sterling reputation,'' it would be a ''real shock'' to the markets if he was not renamed, Mr. Brimmer said.

HEADLINE: A Raw Nerve in Tokyo

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 9

 BODY:
As the largest industrial groups in Japan and West Germany explore collaborations in aerospace, automobiles and electronics, Tokyo's habitually nervous business community is facing a troubling question:
How will the United States react if Japan and Germany enter broad alliances in technologies where America still holds an edge?
Like the prospect of German reunification, the proposed alliance of the Mitsubishi companies with Daimler-Benz, announced Tuesday, is something Government officials and business leaders talk about publicly in the most positive, non-threatening terms. Japan would be foolish not to make a broad move into Europe before the creation of a single market there in 1992, they argue, and the United States has little to fear in the ties with Germany's biggest automobile, aircraft and arms maker.
''The relationship of Japan with the United States has been very close and Japan should strengthen it,'' Toyoo Tate, chairman of the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation and one architect of the possible collaboration with Daimler, said in his office this week. ''But we are now in the age of globalization, and this is a manifestation of Japan's need to get closer to Europe. Because we are taking this step does not necessarily mean relations with the U.S. will become worse.'' 
At least so far, little objection has been voiced, but lurking beneath the surface is a fear among many Japanese that the United States will soon view the alliance as vaguely threatening.
Europe already appears to have a stronger hand in dealing with Japan than does the United States, especially as 1992 nears and Eastern Europe opens. One senior official of a company affiliated with Mitsubishi noted that Western Europe could still offer something Japan desperately needs: access to a market that seems as foreign and impenetrable to some Japanese companies as Japan seems to some Americans.
Japanese officials say they are also bracing themselves for unwanted references to 50 years ago, when the corporate ancestors of Mitsubishi and Daimler built the war machinery of the Axis powers.
''The timing is not exactly ideal,'' a senior Japanese diplomat said the other day. Talk of the possible alliance fuses ''two of America's biggest worries,'' he said, the power of a recombined Germany and the prospect that Japan's seemingly unstoppable industrial advances could be given another lift.
No one is yet sure that the vaguely described alliance - actually a series of alliances between individual Mitsubishi companies and Daimler divisions - will prove workable. Some European nations, especially France, are already warning of the dangers of Japanese ''transplants,'' and are attempting to extend the limits to Japanese car sales there.
 
Guarding Technologies
Both corporate groups are likely to guard their best technologies and richest markets jealously, so analysts expect the biggest deals to come in areas where the two giants do not compete directly. There is widespread speculation, for example, that Mitsubishi Motors may build a small, inexpensive car that both it and Daimler could market in Eastern Europe, where few will be interested in a $50,000 Mercedes-Benz. Mr. Tate refused to discuss that possibility today, but said officials would first have to make clear exactly what kinds of limits would be imposed on Japanese cars made in Europe.
There are already warnings in the press here that the two companies should know their limits and avoid making the United States feel frozen out.
''As the recent Japan-U.S. summit and trade talks have revealed, political and emotional conflicts between the two countries have not abated in any way, and anti-Japanese sentiments in America are still strong among those who regard Japan as a menace to their country,'' Asahi Shimbun, one of Japan's largest newspapers, reminded its readers this morning in an editorial headlined ''A Colossus Is Born.''
 
'Must Be Most Annoying'
''To these people, it must be most annoying that the same Japanese group that bought Rockefeller Center has decided to collaborate with the most powerful conglomerate in West Germany,'' it said. In October, Mitsubishi Estate bought 51 percent of the Rockefeller Group, which owns Rockefeller Center and other mid-Manhattan office buildings, for $846 million.
In Germany, the bigger worry seems to be Europe itself. Even before the alliance was announced, many expressed fears that Daimler-Benz was growing too big and too powerful, especially after its acquisition of the Messerschmitt-Bolkow Blohm G.m.b.H., the aircraft maker.
''If the partners of such a joint venture are German and Japanese, then it is also a political matter,'' said Suddeutsche Zeitung, a leading Munich daily.
Technological alliances are hardly uncommon, especially recently. A host of American and Japanese electronics manufacturers have agreed to share technology and market products jointly; on Wednesday, A.T.&T. and NEC, the world's largest semiconductor maker, announced ties for developing advanced chips over the next five years.
 
On a New Scale
But the Mitsubishi-Daimler alliance promises to be a linkage on an entirely different scale. Not only does it involve a wide range of technologies, it also involves a host of closely linked companies - Mitsubishi Motors, Mitsubishi Electric, Mitsubishi Heavy Industries and the Mitsubishi Coproration - that rarely act together, at least publicly.
''Such a large-scale corporate linkage is very uncommon,'' said Kenichi Imai, a professor of economics at Hitosubashi University, who studies the relationships of what in prewar days were known as ''zaibatsu,'' Japan's business groups. Today the company members of those groups ostensibly operate independently, despite the fact that they hold big stakes in each other and exchange members on their boards. It is not uncommon these days for a Mitsubishi-related company to buy a product or technology from Toshiba or NEC, which belong to rival groupings. A decade ago, that would have been unheard of.
Moreover, executives at Mitsubishi say that each of its companies will have to strike separate deals with Daimler's divisions. It is unlikely, experts here say, that the Mitsubishi companies would pool their resources and negotiate collectively with Daimler.
Thus, if Mitsubishi Heavy Industries needed Daimler's help building jet engines - an area where Japan has been persistently frustrated - it would have to offer something of its own in return, like the advanced composite materials for wings that it has been developing for military and commercial use.
''The companies work closely, and the leaders meet every week,'' one Mitsubishi executive said recently. ''But when they get back to the office, they still have to make money.''

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Digital Offer Of Severance

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: MAYNARD, Mass., March 9

 BODY:
The Digital Equipment Corporation, trying to cope with a slumping computer industry and a weak New England economy, said today that it would soon offer a voluntary severance package to as many as 8,000 employees.
The nation's second-largest computer maker said last month that it might post its first quarterly loss in its 32-year history in the third quarter ending March 31 and that it was considering various cutbacks. 
Digital, which has 125,900 employees, said it would offer a voluntary severance plan to between 5,000 and 8,000 workers. It does not plan forced layoffs. Brad Allen, a company spokesman, said plant closings were being considered in the United States. He said the severance plan would not be completed in the third quarter, The Maynard, Mass., company initiated a similar plan last October, when it offered 700 workers at its Salem, N.H., plant the option to leave the company. Digital said 260 workers had accepted the offer.
Digital, ranked second only to the International Business Machines Corporation among the nation's computer makers, has met increasing competition to the VAX mid-sized computers that have been its main product.
Digital's stock slipped 25 cents a share today, to $76.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Treasury Prices Fall on Jobs Report

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities tumbled yesterday after the Government reported an unexpectedly large rise in civilian employment in February.
Traders said the jobs report unnerved investors in fixed-income securities because it was taken as a sign of economic strength that raised fears of inflation and higher interest rates, either of which would reduce the value of existing fixed-income debt issues.
In its report, the Government said 372,000 jobs were created in February. It also revised the increase in January jobs to 332,000, from 275,000. 
Credit market analysts were quick to note that the February increase included the hiring of some 30,000 census takers and the rehiring of roughly 70,000 auto workers laid off in January, as well as an increase in construction work brought on by the mild weather of much of the last two months. Nonetheless, prices of fixed-income securities plunged in the morning and remained depressed throughout the day.
 
Big Losses in Bond Futures
The biggest losses were posted in trading of bond futures at the Chicago Board of Trade. People in the futures market took the job data at face value, traders said, and sold throughout the session.
Dealers in Treasury securities said the heavy selling of bond futures undermined prices in the cash market. Only when bond futures trading in Chicago ended at 3 P.M., New York time, did the cash market begin to recover some of its losses.
In late trading in the cash market, the Treasury's benchmark long-term bonds, the 8.5 percent issue maturing in 2020, were offered at 98 22/32, down 25/32. Just before the bond futures market closed, the cash price of the long bond had been down a point, or $10 per each $1,000 of face value.
At 98 22/32, the long bond's yield was 8.62 percent, up from 8.54 percent the day before. A week ago, the yield was also 8.54 percent.
In Chicago, the March bond futures closed down a point, at 92.1, for a loss of 1.3 on the week. The more active June bond futures contract fell 1.2, to 91.26, for a loss of 1.6 on the week.
 
Growth in Money Supply
''Allowing for the possible distortions in the latest jobs data, it still shows that the economy is not fading as fast as some think,'' said Leif H. Olsen, who heads an investment management firm bearing his name in New Canaan, Conn.
Given indications that the Fed has not done anything to cause, or prevent, rising interest rates, Mr. Olsen said, ''We can only assume that the bond market, in demanding higher rates, is questioning the Fed's anti-inflation policy, because the Federal funds rate is the cheapest rate in the money market.''
Manipulation of the Federal funds rate, which banks charge each other for temporary loans, is one of the Fed's chief tools. The funds traded at 8.25 percent most of the day, roughly the rate of recent weeks.
Discount rates on Treasury bills continued to rise. The change was again attributed to an increase in the supply of bills.
The rate on the 90-day bills rose 7 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 7.98 percent; the six-month bills gained 7 basis points, to 7.88 percent, and the one-year bills climbed 8 basis points, to 7.84 percent.
Among some short-term coupon issues traded in the secondary market, the 8.5 percent notes of 1992 lost 8/32, to 99 20/32, for a yield of 8.71 percent, and the 8.5 percent issue of 1995 dropped 14/32, to 99 10/32, for a yield of 8.65 percent.

HEADLINE: Dow Ends Positive Week With a Decline

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stocks gave up more ground yesterday in slow trading in the wake of a sharp rise in bond yields and computerized sell programs that depressed the market severely.
The Dow Jones industrial average slid 12.84 points, to 2,683.33. That cut the gain for the last two weeks to 119.14 points, 22.97 of which came this week. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange slumped to 150.4 million shares, from 170.9 million on Thursday, with declines outnumbering advances, 876 to 602. 
But in what could be seen as a favorable sign, only 18 issues touched new lows, while 28 reached new highs.
 
Rate Cut Seen as Less Likely
Traders took new signs of unexpected strength in the economy as further support for their long-held feeling that the Federal Reserve has no intention of forcing interest rates down for the time being. Lower rates would put more money - and thus pep - into the economy.
The Labor Department reported that the unemployment rate remained steady at 5.3 percent in February, while non-farm payroll employment rose by 372,000.
Hugh A. Johnson, chief investment officer for the First Albany Corporation, an Albany brokerage firm, said the employment figures were ''significantly stronger than expected and pretty much removes any hope that the Federal Reserve is going to lower interest rates anytime soon.''
He said, ''The employment data suggest that the economy is showing enough resilience that the economy doesn't need lower rates.''
 
Two Negatives for Stocks
That, he said, was doubly negative for stocks because rising rates ''offer investors an attractive alternative to stocks'' and ''darken the outlook for corporate earnings.''
Among the 30 Dow industrials, Du Pont fell 1, to 39; Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing dipped 1 1/4, to 81 3/4, and Philip Morris was off 7/8, to 37 1/4. NCNB, the North Carolina banking company, fell 2 1/8, to 41 1/2, in heavy trading. The company said problem loans might rise in the first quarter.
Retailing stocks, buoyed by February sales gains, continued to show strong advances. Gap, the apparel chain, which rose 1 3/4 on Thursday, rose an additional 2 1/4 yesterday, to 61 1/2. Edison Brothers, a women's shoe chain, rose 1 3/8, to 34 7/8. Nordstrom, the department store, rose 1 5/8, to 30, with heavy buying by institutions.
Airline stocks were also strong, with Delta Air Lines up 1, to 70; UAL up 1 1/4, to 134, and USAir up 1 1/8, to 29 3/8. USAir said its load factor rose in February.
Digital Equipment, which rose 4 7/8 last week and 2 1/4 the first four days of this week, fell 1/4 yesterday, to 76 5/8. Digital said it would offer voluntary severance to between 5,000 and 8,000 workers and was considering new plant consolidations.
 
Trading of Genentech Shares
Genentech, the South San Francisco biotechnology company, was unchanged at 26 1/8, with 1.06 million shares changing hands, almost half of them going to big insitutions. Genentech said that Roche Holdings Ltd., parent of Hoffmann-La Roche, would go ahead with its previously announced plans to buy 60 percent of Genentech.
Rorer Group, the drug company, rose 7/8, to 62 7/8, in heavy trading, after rising 2 points earlier in the week. Traders pointed to rumors that Rorer might announce Monday a multibillion-dollar sale of the company to Rhone-Poulenc, the French chemical giant.

HEADLINE: Saudi Oil Minister Predicts A 'Sellers' Market' in 90's

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
The Saudi oil minister, Hisham M. Nazer, said yesterday that he did not anticipate an oil crisis in the 1990's but added that ''the market will slowly but steadily turn into a sellers' market.''
He predicted a 20 percent increase in oil demand in this decade, which other experts said would be a continuation of the trend in recent years. That increase would come with world economic growth of 3.2 percent, he said. 
The Saudis' own growth rate would also be about 3.2 percent, he said, which some experts describe as a modest figure.
Mr. Nazer would not make specific predictions about oil prices. But he said, ''We do not think higher prices will sustain economic growth.'' Conversely, he said, lower prices would not ''maintain the proper stability in producer countries.'' Saudi Arabia has run a budget deficit in some years recently because of lower oil prices.
Asked whether his country would make further investments in refining and marketing operations in consumer countries, Mr. Nazer said such expansion was ''an important ingredient of stability'' in the industry. His country already owns half the Texaco marketing and refining network in 23 Eastern states, including three refineries and thousands of gasoline outlets.
Mr. Nazer spoke at a conference on the Saudi economy at the Kevorkian Center for Near Eastern Studies at New York University. He arrived in New York on Wednesday, when he helped open a 65,000-square-foot exhibit on Saudi history and culture at the Passenger Ship Terminal, Pier 88. The exhibit runs through March 17 and then moves to Los Angeles.
 
Would Lease Oil
In response to a question yesterday, Mr. Nazer said his country would be interested in leasing oil to the United States for storage in the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. An Energy Department report recently endorsed the idea of filling the reserve caverns, mostly in Louisiana, with oil that was leased instead of purchased, to lower the cost. Mr. Nazer said, ''We're interested in the strategic reserve simply because we're interested in penetrating the American market.''
Some American analysts suggested that leasing could be a way for a member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to earn extra oil revenue without violating the group's quotas, which cover sales and do not anticipate leasing.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up in Quiet Trading After Employment Report

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar moved mostly higher yesterday in quiet trading on world currency markets, bolstered by a better-than-expected employment report.
Gold prices slipped worldwide. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold settled at $399.80 an ounce, off 20 cents from Thursday. The Republic National Bank of New York later quoted a bid of $399.75, down 5 cents. 
The dollar got a lift from a Labor Department report showing that non-farm payrolls gained 372,000 jobs in February, the largest increase since June 1988. Most estimates had called for a gain of roughly 250,000 jobs.
''The data gave the dollar good background support,'' said Marc Chandler, an analyst at MMS International in Chicago. ''The numbers gave greater credence to the 'soft landing' scenario and reduced lingering hopes of a near-term easing'' of interest rates, he said.
The Federal Reserve keeps the economy from overheating by holding official interest rates at current levels or by raising them, as some analysts have suggested the Government might be considering. Higher interest rates enhance the value of dollar-denominated securities.
 
Intervention Seen in Europe
 Despite the bullish sentiment surrounding the dollar, Mr. Chandler said that the fear of central bank intervention had prevented the currency from rising further. Several central banks stepped in to sell dollars in European trading, but they did not follow through in domestic markets.
Because of nagging political and economic problems in Britain, analysts predicted that the pound would continue to weaken against the dollar.
The pound lost nearly 2.5 cents amid anxiety over recent demonstrations against a new tax imposed by city halls across Britain. In addition, opinion polls show that the popularity of the Conservative Government and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher is at an all-time low as inflation rises and interest rates remain high.
Earlier in Tokyo the dollar rose to 151.15 yen from Thursday's 150.83. Later in London, the dollar closed at 151.32 yen. In New York the dollar closed at 151.27 yen, up from 151.09.
In London, 1 cost $1.6183 late yesterday, cheaper than Thursday's late price of $1.6427. In New York, 1 cost $1.6170, less expensive than $1.6385 on Thursday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Thursday's late rates, included: 1.7025 West German marks, up from 1.7008; 1.5095 Swiss francs, up from 1.5080; 5.7560 French francs, up from 5.7495; 1,257.50 Italian lire, up from 1,255.25, and 1.1804 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1807.
Gold closed in London at a bid of $399.05 an ounce, down from $401.95 on Thursday. The closing bid in Zurich was $399.50, down from $400.75. Earlier in Hong Kong gold closed at $400.65 an ounce, down from $401.95.
Silver prices also fell. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery finished at $5.095 an ounce, down from $5.112 on Thursday. In London, silver traded at a late bid of $5.11 an ounce, down from $5.15.

HEADLINE: Chairman for Bank of New England

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BOSTON, March 9

 BODY:
The troubled Bank of New England Corporation today named Lawrence K. Fish chairman and chief executive.
Mr. Fish, a former Bank of Boston executive vice president, joins Bank of New England as it is trying to revamp and restore public confidence. 
Analysts generally praised the appointment, but they warned that Mr. Fish might not be able to rescue the bank. ''If the economy does not cooperate, a miracle worker is going to have a hard time,'' said Gerard Cassidy, an analyst with Tucker, Anthony Inc.
Mr. Fish, whose hiring has been expected since late last month, replaces Walter J. Connolly Jr., who oversaw the bank's striking growth in the 1980's but was ousted after the company suffered huge losses.
Much of the trouble has been traced to the bank's unbridled lending practices in a construction boom in the mid-1980's. When the economy slowed near the end of the decade, the real estate market tumbled, and the bank was saddled with a mountain of problem loans.
Last month, the bank announced that its losses for 1989 totaled $1.11 billion and disclosed it was reviewing financial data from previous quarters to see whether larger provisions against bad loans should have been made earlier.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER'S WORLD;
Shipping Furniture Overseas Is Costly

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
More and more American tourists will be heading for vacations abroad as the spring tourist season approaches. For many of them, part of the fun will be making a major furnishings purchase - perhaps an antique chest, a rug or fine crystal.
But unlike those who buy perfume or a wristwatch or something they can tuck into their suitcases, buyers of dining tables and armoires have to contend with shipping their purchases back to America. They, or the merchant they buy from, must arrange for packing, air or sea shipment, local transportation on both sides of the ocean, insurance and, if required, customs duty.
In most situations, the merchant or dealer who sold the item will offer to take care of it all. But each of these services can be expensive, and the total can cause sticker shock. 
''It's a real trap for somebody who is buying something and thinks that he is getting a great deal,'' said Dennis J. Rowles, vice president of the Wolf D. Barth Company, a Philadelphia freight forwarder and customs broker. ''You may find that in the end you're paying just as much as you would in the United States, plus you've got a great deal of aggravation.''
Once you decide that the item you want to buy is something you are not likely to find at home or do not want to search for again, there is one cardinal rule before buying it: find out the exact cost to have it sent home and decide whether you are willing to pay that price. It is costly to send big pieces, or even fairly small ones, from overseas. And when you learn the cost, you might decide not to buy. Freight forwarders act as agents for the purchaser, preparing the shipping documents and generally orchestrating the movement of goods from their point of origin. Customs brokers serve as a contact with the United States Customs Service to secure release of the goods to the purchaser. Many overseas travelers who buy personal items use freight forwarders or customs brokers to avoid problems in transporting the items they have acquired.
Paul F. Wegener, chairman of the National Customs Brokers and Forwarders Assocation of America, a trade group, said, ''Transportation and handling should not add more than 40 percent to the price of an article when you get it back.''
With purchases of smaller items, one way to save is to have them packed inside a large one for the passage home. ''Basically, you're sending the small items for almost nothing, except for the price of the additional insurance and bit of extra packing,'' said Cliff Williams, export manager of Hedleys Humpers Ltd., a London freight forwarder.
 
Beware of Price Inflation
 Even if a foreign dealer or retailer says the entire cost of shipping the product is included in the purchase price, travelers should be wary. In some cases, this purchase price may be inflated to account for transportation, and in others, the merchant may not bother to send the item.
Local transportation in the city of purchase and the destination city, also known as inland freight, coupled with packing and unpacking the items, is charged by the hour. A typical fee might be $50 an hour for each packer or driver, which could easily push the bill for this segment alone well into the hundreds of dollars.
Transoceanic shipping charges are usually based on either the volume or the weight of the item. Mr. Wegener, who is also vice president of M. G. Maher and Company, a freight forwarder and customs broker in New Orleans, said trans-Atlantic shipping by sea costs $175 to $200 for 40 cubic feet or for 2,000 pounds.
If the shipment is sent by air, that price is doubled, he said, but the packaging you choose can affect the shipping cost. For instance, objects are typically sent by air from France in one of two ways: ''container de groupage,'' where the item is shipped in a container with many others and may be delayed until the container is full, or ''messagerie,'' where it is shipped individually. Shipping things individually costs at least twice as much as container shipping.
Insuring the delivery against loss or damage from door to door is strongly advised.
There may be duty to pay when and where the goods are received. Most people leave it to customs brokers, who comply with Government regulations and clear the entry, typically for a fee of $60 to $200. The broker will have on hand the required documents - invoice, bill of lading, entry manifest and customs declaration - and showthose papers to a customs inspector at the airport or other arrival point, where the goods may be examined before being released.
 
How the Duty is Figured
 When shipping merchandise, there is no personal duty-free exemption of up to $400 or flat rate of 10 percent on the next $1,000 worth of fair retail value, as there is when travelers personally take home foreign-made items. The duty that must be paid is determined by tariff classification. For example, the rate for furniture other than chairs is 2.5 percent.
Thus the duty on a $10,000 wardrobe would be $248.75, after allowing for the $50 deductible granted on goods that are shipped. And the overall cost of sending the wardrobe by air from, say, London to New York would be in the neighborhood of $1,500.
When you add it all up - and you can have that done for you before you make a purchase abroad - you might decide you don't need that wardrobe after all, unless it is an antique that may increase in value or is something you cannot live without.
 
 
 
BUY HERE, DRIVE THERE
 Shipping new cars back to the United States from overseas is quite a different matter from shipping furniture.
 The purchase is normally made from an authorized dealer in the United States, who sells a version of the vehicle that meets American safety and emission requirements. The car must usually be ordered at least six weeks before the desired European delivery date and paid for in advance.
In Europe, the car can be picked up at the factory, an airport or other pre-arranged location, depending on the manufacturer. After driving the car during a vacation, the customer leaves it at one of the many designated drop-off sites established by the company - usually in a major city like London or Paris.
The vehicle is then transported to the United States by ship and sent to the dealer from which it was purchased. Buyers may have to wait three to eight weeks to pick it up.
The price is typically all inclusive. The cost of ocean freight, processing, local transportation, duty at the rate of 2.5 percent, customs clearance and insurance for a specified driving period in Europe is added to the price of the car. Manufacturers say this overall price is still 5 to 10 percent less than the suggested advertised delivered price in the United States.
A 300E Mercedes-Benz sedan, for example, costs $41,350 when delivered overseas. The suggested price in the United States is $45,950. The Peugeot 405 sports wagon costs $15,570 if it is delivered in Europe. The manufacturers suggested United States retail price is $16,390. Remember that most automobile sales in this country are made under the list price.

HEADLINE: BUSH DISTRESSED AS POLICY FAILS TO MOVE CHINA

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 10

 BODY:
President Bush and many officials in his Administration say they are deeply disappointed by the failure of the Chinese Government to relax its repressive rule in response to numerous conciliatory gestures by Mr. Bush.
The American officials explained that divisions within the Chinese leadership, compounded by fears about a resurgence of the democracy movement in China after the rapid democratic change in Eastern Europe, have made it difficult for Beijing to respond as the President had hoped.
Those concerned about the meager results so far include the architects of Mr. Bush's policy and some who carried it out, like Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger. He acknowledged in recent Congressional testimony that the repression continued after his visits to China, that there has been no ''rapid payoff'' from Mr. Bush's policy and that China has no plan to lift martial law in Tibet. Mr. Eagleburger secretly visited Beijing with Brent Scowcroft, the President's national security adviser, in July and December. 
 
Getting Worse, Not Better
Administration officials say the crackdown has become harsher in the last few months, with more surveillance of dissidents, more political education classes for students, more restrictions on overseas study and more persecution of the Roman Catholic Church and other religious groups.
In addition, the officials said, the Government has recently purged or punished many Chinese journalists and police officials who expressed support for the democracy movement or did not take a firm stand against it.
Administration officials said they hoped that, by openly expressing their disappointment with China, they could coax Beijing to end the abuse of human rights.
In a surprise to the Administration, trade with China was booming even as repression increased there. Commerce Department data show that Chinese exports to the United States rose 42 percent last year, to a total of $12 billion. Much of the increase occurred in the second half of 1989, despite the killings in and near Tiananmen Square early in June. The Beijing authorities have been hard pressed to obtain convertible currency to pay off foreign-debt obligations.
 
Personal Embarrassment to Bush
For Mr. Bush, these developments represent a special problem because he invested a lot of political standing in defending his China policy and risked his reputation as someone knowledgeable about the country, where he served as chief of the United States mission in 1974 and 1975.
Mr. Bush now voices such disappointment, sometimes even irritation, but has no new policy. In an interview with NBC News last week, he acknowledged that ''there hasn't been much'' give yet by the Chinese, and he said, ''I wish there would be more.''
His criticism of China is far milder than that in the State Department's annual report on human rights, which sharply assailed Chinese abuses. ''I believe I know how to go about trying to see things move forward again,'' Mr. Bush said. ''Some think isolation -bring them to heel by publicly slapping people. I think I know China well enough to know that this isn't the way to do it.''
Beijing vilified Mr. Bush for allowing the State Department to issue the report. It further strained relations with Washington this week when it expelled an American businessman, John P. Cragin, on a charge of conducting ''illegal religious instruction.'' China said he had done ''missionary work under the guise of holding English-language- training courses in Tianjin since October 1989.''
 
How State Dept. Sees It
A State Department official said: ''We hoped there would be more of a response to the President's overtures. We are still hoping. The people in power in China today fear that if they do the things we would like them to do to heal the wounds of last June, they will jeopardize their own personal positions.''
The increase in trade between China and the United States would have been impossible if Congress had imposed stiff economic sanctions, as many lawmakers advocated last summer. Mr. Bush persuaded Congress to hold off, arguing that commercial contacts were good because they ''have led, in essence, to this quest for more freedom'' in China.
''The Chinese are desperately trying to increase exports,'' said Jan M. Whisler, an economist at the United States International Trade Commission. ''China must now depend almost entirely on export revenues for the hard currency needed to service its foreign debt of nearly $40 billion.'' Major payments on the debt are due this year.
A new fight looms in June over trade benefits. China's most-favored-nation status, which generally guarantees the lowest possible tariffs on exports to the United States, is scheduled to expire July 2. Administration officials say Mr. Bush will seek a regular annual extension of that status for China. Many in Congress are already gearing up to resist. At least six bills have been introduced to suspend or terminate China's status as a most favored nation.
 
Use of 'Forced Labor'
Senate Republicans are collecting evidence to show that some of China's exports, particularly textiles, were produced in prisons and labor camps. Federal law prohibits the importing of any goods produced in a foreign country by ''forced labor'' or ''convict labor.'' Textiles accounted for $3.2 billion of the $12 billion in Chinese exports to the United States last year.
Roger W. Sullivan, president of the United States-China Business Council, a trade association of 300 American companies doing business there, said there would be ''a very strong challenge by Congress to renewal of most-favored-nation status for China.''
Although quick to acknowledge that Mr. Bush has not achieved his objectives, White House officials are sensitive to criticism of the President's China policy.
Mr. Scowcroft complains bitterly that his toast ''to U.S.-Chinese friendship,'' at a banquet in Beijing on Dec. 9, has been misread as an endorsement of the military crackdown. Likewise, Douglas H. Paal, the senior specialist on China at the National Security Council, severely criticized a report on China issued last month by Asia Watch, a human rights group. When Is Ferocity Restraint? Mr. Paal marked up a copy of the report with marginal commentary, like a professor's comments on a student's essay. Asia Watch said that the Chinese People's Liberation Army had shown ''ferocity'' in suppressing the democracy movement.
Mr. Paal wrote: ''Some of the P.L.A. actions were indeed ferocious - other units at other times did show great restraint.''
Asia Watch said that thousands of peaceful dissenters were being detained in China without trials. Mr. Paal wrote, ''The very fact that so many detainees have not been tried indicates some degree of restraint.''
People who originally backed Mr. Bush's policy say they, too, have been disappointed. A. Doak Barnett, professor emeritus of Chinese studies at Johns Hopkins University, said he supported Mr. Bush's effort to ''halt the downward spiral in our relations with China'' by sending Mr. Eagleburger and Mr. Scowcroft to Beijing in December.
''That mission had valid objectives and was worth trying,'' said Mr. Barnett, who has been studying China for more than four decades. ''But the Chinese have not responded sufficiently to indicate a reversal of repressive trends or to have a significant impact on American public opinion or Congress.''

HEADLINE: MILITARY LEADER RESIGNS IN HAITI; ELECTION PROMISED

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, March 10

 BODY:
Lieut. Gen. Prosper Avril, Haiti's military ruler for the last 18 months, stepped down today after a week of nationwide protests. An army officer said a provisional government would take power within 72 hours to organize elections.
The announcement of the resignation was read over national television shortly after 3 P.M. by Gen. Herard Abraham, who until now has been the acting Chief of Staff of the army.
General Avril made no statement. Diplomats said he was expected to leave the country in the next day or so. 
 
Fifth Change in Four Years
General Avril's resignation is the fifth time power has changed hands in four years of political turmoil since widespread unrest forced President Jean-Claude Duvalier to flee the country in February 1986, ending nearly three decades of family dictatorship. Continuing abuses under successive military regimes, including an election day massacre in 1987, have prompted Washington to withhold assistance considered vital to Haiti, the poorest country in the Western Hemisphere.
General Abraham said the mission of the army was ''to re-establish peace and order within 72 hours in order to hand over power to a provisional Government that conforms with the spirit of the Constitution and will have the task of organizing elections.''
 
Court Justice to Be Elevated
Haitian political leaders and foreign diplomats said that according to a plan worked out with General Avril, an as yet unidentified justice of the Supreme Court was to be named by General Abraham to lead the new government. The selection of the head of government, the leaders and diplomats said, will be made through a consensus of civilian leaders.
Haiti's Consitution calls for the chief of the Supreme Court to replace the President when a vacancy develops. But the present chief of the court, Gilbert Austin, is regarded as a close ally of General Avril.
The sole mandate of the new government is to be to organize presidential elections ''in a minimum of three months and a maximum of six months,'' said Marc Bazin, a former executive of the World Bank and one of the leading contenders for the presidency.
 
General Pledges Democracy
General Abraham pledged that the army would work with the rest of the country to establish democracy.
The army, he said, would ''assist and not oppose'' the people of Haiti in ''taking a first step toward resolving the institutional crisis that the country is experiencing.''
He said the task of restoring order and installing a new Government was ''a real challenge.''
''But,'' he said, ''the army of Haiti, showing discipline and embodying the ideal of greatness, will employ all its resources to to this end.''
In a cautious statement issued here and in Washington, the United States Government said it welcomed General Abraham's declaration that he planned to turn over power within 72 hours and said it would be prepared to help the provisional government ''conduct free and fair elections under international observation at the earliest possible date.''
Pressure had been building against General Avril as Haitians became convinced that he was unlikely to lead them to democratic elections and as economic conditions grew steadily worse. The 52-year-old general was accused of condoning human rights abuses and of permitting soldiers to terrorize Haiti with violent robberies and street killings.
In a series of radio interviews, many of Haiti's civilian political leaders reacted favorably to the statement from General Abraham. But some radical leaders and many ordinary Haitians expressed concern that General Avril was still in the country, that the transfer to civilian authority was not immediate and that General Abraham did not explicitedly state that a civilian would be taking power. Civilian political leaders said General Avril had apparently left the presidential palace, but they said they were not sure where he would spend the next hours.
 
Bonfires in Streets
Crowds of Haitians had begun milling in the streets of the capital from late morning as news of the impending resignation announcement spread. Some streets were blocked with bonfires, and three buildings, including two Government offices, were sacked. But no injuries were reported.
The political leaders and diplomats said General Avril, who took power in a coup on Sept. 17, 1988, had disclosed his decision to resign in meetings with the Vatican and American ambassadors at his family mansion in the cool hills above the capital.
The politicians and diplomats said that in negotiations over the last few days, General Avril had sought assurances that there would be no reprisals against him or the soldiers of the Presidential Guard, who have been his main source of power. In an attempt to prevent violence by the Presidential Guard, diplomats said, the force of about 1,200 soldiers was being dismantled and dispersed to military posts around the country.
Shortly after noon, before the resignation announcement, mobs sacked two Government offices in the capital and the offices of Gregoire Eugene, a lawyer and presidential candidate widely regarded as having been a supporter of General Avril. The police used tear gas to disperse another mob that was advancing on a radio station operated by an Avril supporter. There were no reports of injuries.
After the collapse of the Duvalier dictatorship four years ago, mobs rampaged through the main cities, lynching members of the civilian security forces known as the Tontons Macoute and wrecking homes of Duvalier officials. Similar attacks took place 18 months ago when Lieut. Gen. Henri Namphy was deposed and replaced by General Avril.
The political leaders, meeting as a group of 12, declared on local radio stations on Friday that no actions would be taken against members of the armed forces. But one diplomat said: ''That's the leaders talking. Let's see how the people react.''
The Haitian politicians and diplomats said they believed General Avril had decided to step down as the demonstrations, which started Monday, spread to all the major cities of Haiti and promised to continue into next week. Stores, offices and schools across the country had been shut.
 
'We Were Going Nowhere'
''The whole country was blocked up,'' Mr. Bazin, the former World Bank official, said. ''We were going nowhere.''
A diplomat added: ''The country was falling down all around him. It became apparent that nobody had any confidence in his Government.''
Though the police had been seen clubbing protesters and shooting into crowds during the week, no more than about half a dozen deaths and 40 or 50 injuries have been reported in the demonstrations. The Presidential Guard is the only effective armed unit in the country, and General Avril appeared to have at his command far more force than he chose to use.
''The impression people have had from the beginning was that Avril was not a ruthless killer, not the kind to give the order to mow down groups of civilians,'' a diplomat said. ''The reason he's leaving, I think, is that he feels that otherwise there would be a lot more unrest and bloodshed.''
President Duvalier had even more force available to him, and he, too, stepped down earlier than diplomats studying the balance of power had expected. Several dozen people are believed to have died in anti-Duvalier protests, but he was also said to have had no stomach for bloodshed.
In addition to the mounting pressure from Haitians in the streets, General Avril faced a call for his resignation from political, civic and business leaders, who for the first time in recent history united to speak with a single voice.
Some of the Haitian political leaders said the United States Ambassador, Alvin P. Adams, had played a key role in bringing General Avril's opponents together. They noted a sharp contrast from the days preceding the disastrous attempt at presidential elections in November 1987 when the American Embassy here, led by Ambassador Brunson McKinley, repeatedly expressed confidence that the regime of General Namphy would insure free and fair elections. The elections were halted after more than 34 voters had been gunned down or hacked to death; witnesses said that both civilians and soldiers had been wielding weapons.
''It was very positive,'' Mr. Bazin said of the role of Mr. Adams. ''It was quite a positive change.''
The United States suspended more than $70 million in economic aid after the election killings in 1987 but continued to provide about $35 million in aid to private social organizations for food and medical assistance.
''The United States certainly urged the political groups and the different sectors to work together to effect peaceful democratic change,'' an American official said.
General Avril had been a close adviser to both Francois Duvalier, the founder of the family dictorship, and his son, Jean-Claude, and he had grown wealthy as a result. He served as a broker with foreign weapons dealers and had an office in the national bank. Documents recovered after the collapse of the dictatorship showed that the family had drained millions of dollars from Government agencies.
General Namphy was widely regarded as brutal and incompetent. When General Avril replaced him, in a coup that was said to have been carried out by enlisted members of the Presidential Guard, he was viewed as intelligent and crafty, but perhaps not trustworthy.
He promised from the start to lead the country to elections. But like General Namphy before him, he stalled repeatedly, saying the country was not yet ready for them. He worked out a schedule of elections for this year, starting with voting for mayors and town councils and ending in the selection of a president. He said the process would give voters the experience necessary to make a wise decision for the highest office.
Most political leaders wanted to have presidential elections first, but agreed to go along the Avril plan.
The United States, France and Canada were considering restoring and increasing aid to Haiti, based on the general's promises and limited progress.
But in late January, for reasons that are still unclear, General Avril abruptly declared a state of siege, arresting, beating and exiling some political leaders. Aides said the leaders would be permitted to come back to Haiti after a national legislature had been selected. The political leaders said this would enable General Avril to engineer the selection of legislators and through the national assembly influence the presidential election and ultimately curtail presidential powers.
Street violence, believed to have been carried out by members of the armed forces, remained high under General Avril. International human rights groups accused the Avril Government of abuses. Foreign aid and loans from the World Bank and other international financial organizations strongly influenced by the United States were not forthcoming. Foreign investors stayed away.
Prices of basic foods rose and the Government's cash reserves dwindled. The Government teetered on the brink of economic collapse, often uncertain until the last minute whether it would have the money to pay for monthly petroleum and wheat shipments.
The Haitian political leaders said that in addition to the American Ambassador, the French and Vatican Ambassadors, Rafael Dufour and Msgr. Paolo Romeo, were also instrumental in discussions with General Avril.
The political leaders said General Avril had hoped to remain as commander of the army, after relinquishing the presidency, and to continue living in the country. But he was told that was not possible, they said.
The politicians and diplomats said General Avril was expected to leave Haiti a day or so after handing over power. He reportedly owns a house in Belgium, but it was not clear where he would go.
''I think he was perhaps concerned that if he got on a plane immediately, some members of the Presidential Guard might be scared into some kind of reaction,'' a diplomat said.
