PUB-DATE: March 11, 1990

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1, Page 1, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 3192 words

HEADLINE: American Voices: Doubts As the Cold War Ends - A Special Report:
In U.S, Unease as World Changes

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 10

 BODY:
For Americans everywhere, the news from abroad in recent months has been both dazzling and disorienting.
The faraway events that have played across the nation's living rooms - the collapse of the Berlin wall, the overthrow of Communist governments, reforms sweeping the Soviet Union - came with such velocity and drama that at times they seemed unreal, as if someone had punched the fast-forward button on history.
From conversations around the country - with college students in Michigan and farmers in Nebraska, military industry workers in Southern California and civil rights workers in Mississippi, business leaders in Dallas and high school students in suburban Denver - it is clear that those events have had another profound effect. They have begun to reshape how Americans view themselves and their country.
 
Visions of Opportunities
Some see this as a moment of fresh opportunity, of peaceful possibilities that will in time allow the nation to switch resources from the military to domestic programs that will improve lives. 
''Isn't this what we all have been praying for all these years?'' asked Harold Cooprider, a retired psychologist living in Newport Beach, Calif. ''Every American should be proud.''
But if there was a common mood among the scores of Americans interviewed, it was hardly a mood of triumph. While there was a strong sense that the Soviet Union had probably lost the cold war, few were willing to say the United States had won.
Most of those interviewed expressed apprehension, as if the fading of the Communist threat only illuminated other perils, especially the specter of sharpened economic competition with the Germans and the Japanese, who now loom larger than life as masters of technology and manufacturing. ''We're just not a superpower anymore,'' said Douglas Hausman, a junior at Albion College in Michigan. ''Economically, we are not as strong as Japan or West Germany right now. Maybe militarily we are stronger. But these countries can call our bluff anytime they want because they own so much of us.''
Some said the moment should serve as a wake-up call to the country to save its economy. ''On a personal level, the fact is that my generation may not have it as good as our parents did,'' said Julie French, another Albion student. ''The fact is that we are going to have to work harder.''
Throughout the conversations ran a strain of wariness about the permanence of reforms in the Soviet Union. Many people expressed admiration for Mikhail S. Gorbachev, but a few are not sure exactly what he is up to. ''He's either the greatest statesman in history or the world's greatest aluminum-siding salesman,'' said Larry Worsham, who manages a small radio station in Louisiana.
 
The Diminishing of America?
 Many of those interviewed seemed to think that America's institutions and leaders might not be quite up to the new world taking shape. And some said they believed that with its adversary diminished America would be diminished, too, as it cuts back its forces and its presence in Europe.
''The decline of the Soviet Union is also the decline of the United States in terms of its relative importance in the world,'' said Shari Cohen, a graduate student in Soviet affairs at the University of California at Berkeley.
All those interviewed - the students, the workers, the business people - say in their own way that the country is passing through a watershed and Americans will have to make some fundamental decisions about where they are going and what they intend to be.
 
Dallas
 
The Fading Of an Enemy
 At Hoffbrau Steaks, a restaurant and tavern in Dallas, there used to be a sign over the bar. It read: ''Russian vodka not served here.'' The general manager, Matt Hanifen, put the sign up in 1980, when the Soviets had just invaded Afghanistan and President Carter boycotted the Olympics. ''No one liked the Russians back then,'' he said.
Last year the bar quietly started serving Stolichnaya, a Russian vodka, and about three months ago Ray Bond, the bartender, took the sign down. No fanfare. ''The sign just wasn't right anymore,'' Mr. Bond said.
Besides, Mr. Hanifen said, America's mood has changed. ''Russia isn't our enemy anymore,'' he said.
And that leads to a question: If the Soviet Union is no longer America's enemy, does the country need another one?
 
A Choice of Necessary Enemies
Just across town Richard Condon had an answer. Mr. Condon is the author of ''The Manchurian Candidate,'' about American prisoners in Korea who are brainwashed by their Chinese Communist captors and programmed to assassinate on coded command.
''Now that the Communists have been put to sleep,'' Mr. Condon said, ''we are going to have to invent another terrible threat. And we have four choices, which isn't bad. We have Iran. We have Japan. We have Latin America. And we have the Common Market juncture in 1992.''
For politicians, enemies are necessary, even vital, Mr. Condon said. ''The basic ruse of the professional politician is, whenever possible, to set people against one another, because it keeps them from thinking about how the infrastructure is falling apart,'' he said.
He says he sadly fears that the enemy of choice will be Japan. ''It's just so much easier to create an enemy out of people who don't look like Aunt Mary,'' the writer said.
 
The Russians as Bugs Bunny
Down in Bastrup, in northern Louisiana, Larry Worsham, general manager of KMYQ, a small radio station operating out of a tumbledown house, said he did not feel any safer with the changes overseas. Nor did he believe America had won.
''Let me put it this way,'' Mr. Worsham said. ''Do you remember those cartoons where Elmer Fudd would come running at the door and just before he got there Bugs Bunny would open the door and Elmer Fudd would go running right on through and off a cliff? And he would just hang there in mid-air?''
''Well,'' Mr. Worsham said. ''I feel like the Russians just pulled open the door on us.''
 
 
 
Kimball, Neb.
 
All-Quiet Front Of the Cold War
 Farmers sow their crops right up to the edge of the fences that surround the missile sites scattered across remote Kimball County, Neb., and parts of neighboring Colorado and Wyoming. Cattle graze nearby. Except for the small metal signs on fences warning trespassers that ''deadly force'' will be used against them, the missile sites are just another break in the long horizon.
In a way, this is about as close as one comes in America to the front lines of the cold war. Armed with nuclear warheads, the Minuteman 3 missiles buried in the High Plains are aimed at targets in the Soviet Union, where, presumably, there are missiles aimed at Kimball County.
''I know things are a long way from settled,'' said Jim Robinson, a jeweler in Kimball, a town of about 3,000 people. ''But with the changes in Europe and Russia, I do feel Kimball is a little less of a target than we once were.''
 
Missiles? Few Were Worried
At the Holiday Restaurant Walt Thummel, a wheat farmer, said he was like most people around Kimball: they never paid much attention to the missiles because they never believed the missiles would be used.
''I don't know how a serious threat they ever were,'' Mr. Thummel said, adding that he could not recall when he last thought of the Soviets, the bomb or nuclear war. ''No, it's not the military threat I worry about; I worry more about the economics.''
''That's right,'' said Frank Rasmussen, another farmer. ''Ten years from now, how do kids make a living? What's going to happen to them when they can't afford houses or pay their taxes?''
Life has been tough in Kimball, as in a lot of small towns. Export markets for its wheat have dried up, and prices have been flat. The price of the oil that used to be pumped from the surrounding plains has fallen so low that most of the stripper wells have been capped. And there isn't much profit anymore in beef either. ''We're just slipping farther behind Japan, and maybe Europe too,'' Mr. Rasmussen said.
Mr. Thummel nodded. ''I don't think America is the world's savior anymore,'' he said. ''We got too many problems of our own, and people just don't respect us the way they used to. It's the same way with the Russians, except they ran out of money first.''
 
A Vote for Gorbachev
But, he said, he sure does like Mr. Gorbachev. ''If he ran for President here, he'd probably he elected,'' Mr. Thummel said. ''I think he does not speak with a forked tongue. I think you can believe him.'' Alden Anderson, also a farmer, listened and shook his head. ''Well, I hope you boys are right,'' he said. ''I hope he turns out to be what we hope. But we've got to keep our eyes open too. Those people don't know how to handle democracy yet. What happens if they get impatient?''
Mr. Rasmussen laughed. ''I can agree with that,'' he said. ''It's like me and my Social Security check. I always want it right now.''
 
 
 
Orange County, Calif.
 
Optimism At Yacht Club
 At a Kiwanis Club luncheon last month in Corona Del Mar, a wealthy and very Republican part of Orange County, Charles Hoover rose to speak, He told his colleagues that a friend in Germany had just mailed him a chip of concrete from the Berlin wall.
It was a small but emotional memento, Mr. Hoover explained. He treasures it, he said, not as a souvenir but as a symbol of the ideals that Americans and Germans now share.
''I am not so much proud about what has happened in Germany, but rather humble,'' said Mr. Hoover, who owns a small heating and air-conditioning business. ''I'm glad we have a system that works, and I hope it will work for them now, too.''
These are comfortable people, several of them retired, living in one of America's most favored places. They were eating their lunch at a yacht club overlooking Balboa Island, on the kind of bright, warm late-winter day that does credit to the local Chamber of Commerce.
For the most part, they are optimists as they discuss what is happening overseas. ''For someone who went through a war, the greatest joy for me is the realization my grandchildren will most likely grow up in a world where there is no threat of a bomb,'' said Eric Roberts, an insurance broker from Newport Beach, Calif.
They see themselves reflected in the democratic movements in Eastern Europe and feel at one with the people there, especially with Mr. Gorbachev.
''I think he is a miracle man, a person of courage and charisma,'' said Dave Gambill, a real estate man from Corona Del Mar. ''I think he would make a good Republican.''
 
 
 
Palmdale, Calif.
 
The Road Back After B-1's Fall
 As many as 7,500 workers were once employed at Rockwell International's aerospace plants in Palmdale, in the desert north of Los Angeles. They were helping to build the B-1 bomber. But now that work is done, and nearly all were laid off.
About 1,500 of them are now back, hired for a variety of projects, like building a new Air Force gunship and renovating commercial airliners. An additional 425 are building a fifth space shuttle, for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.
These are not good times for manufacturing workers in America, given the decline in high-paying factory jobs as a result of foreign competition and new production technology. Now the changes overseas appear to make life even more perilous for some workers in the arms-making industry.
 
'We Didn't Win Anything'
''It's great the wall came down,'' said Gary Sanders, who works at Rockwell. ''It's great that families who have been separated for so long can come together - that people can now choose their own government.''
But that's where the sentiment ends. ''We didn't win anything when Communism collapsed,'' Joseph Dagg Jr. said, ''because we're not No. 1 anymore. And unless we change our attitude and stop letting Japan and Korea and everyone else kick us in the butt every day of the week, we're never going to be America again.''
Like the Western grain farmers who once decried the faraway Eastern banks and Eastern railroads for manipulating their lives and markets, there is a frustration among many American workers who see their lives and their livelihoods as hostage to distant financial interests, to foreign banks and foreign investors.
 
'Save Ourselves First'
''What we need are tariffs; our industries need protection,'' said Raymond Michaud, another worker. ''All these other countries have checks and balances to protect themselves. Here we just open the door. No wonder the Japanese paid Ronald Reagan $2 million to come speak. They owe him.''
Rose M. Dagg, who is Mr. Dagg's wife and a union official, said, ''Instead of talking about how to rebuild Eastern Europe, I'd like to hear more talk about rebuilding this country,'' adding, ''Maybe we ought to save ourselves first.''
''What there is left to save,'' Mr. Sanders added.
But what about nuclear war? Shouldn't people feel safer now?
''Well, it's true that I don't worry about Japan trying to bomb us,'' Mr. Dagg said, ''because I know they're not going to bomb something they already own.''
 
 
 
Fort Worth
 
Unneeded Arms, And Alternatives
 Robert H. Trice is director of business development for General Dynamics, which makes the F-16 fighter jet and heavy tanks, among other things. His is a tough job these days.
If the changes in Europe mean a need for fewer tanks and fewer aircraft, it will almost certainly mean less work for his company and other military contractors.
So, one of Mr. Trice's jobs is to look at new opportunities and new markets for General Dynamics. The company is working now on a project with the Japanese for joint production of an advanced fighter jet. What of Traditional Allies? And there is more. Counterterrorism, for example. ''We are going to need to provide increased security assistance and economic aid to our traditional allies,'' Mr. Trice said. What happens, he asks, when Turkish workers displaced in Germany stop sending money back home to Turkey? Or what if Yugoslavia falls apart and unrest threatens Greece?
''We may have to spend more to secure these allies than before,'' he said. ''But instead of doing it with heavy weapons, they will need surveillance aircraft and verification equipment.''
And then there is the war on drugs, and the possibility of what Mr. Trice called ''limited incursions'' into other countries. ''It's just going to shift,'' he said. ''You are going to need forces who are retrained and more mobile. That could mean a whole new generation of light equipment.''
 
 
 
Chicago
 
Picking Up The Pieces
 When change is rampant, opportunity abounds. And people from bankers to students are looking to Eastern Europe to see what's in it for them. Even the Communist Party in America sees some dividends coming its way.
The day the Berlin wall came down, said Scott Marshall, the Illinois state organizer for the Communist Party U.S.A., he was visited by a real estate agent who works in an office below party headquarters, on Chicago's South Side.
''He came in and said, 'Pretty tough day for you guys, huh?' '' Mr. Marshall recalled. ''But I think we kind of surprised him. Because I told him we thought it was a pretty good day. I told him Communists believe in democracy and personal freedom too.''
 
An Eye on the Mainstream
If anyone thinks the turmoil in the Soviet Union and the collapse of Communist governments are bad news for the Communist cause in America, Mr. Marshall said, they should think again.
''Back when the cold war fears were going, people were suspicious of Communists,'' he said, adding that now people would be a little more open. He pointed to the visit by the real estate agent as an example. ''I think it will help us get into the mainstream.''
For those looking for financial, rather than ideological, gains from the events in Europe, there is a new magazine, Bloc, published in New York City that addresses business opportunities in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe.
And in Dallas, John H. Falb, executive vice president of NCNB Texas, the state's biggest bank, said he and other international bankers around the country were being besieged by investors trying to make sense of what was going on in Eastern Europe.
''We're trying to learn how to pronounce the names of places we haven't heard of since World War I,'' Mr. Falb said.
He added that a bank customer in North Carolina had acquired the cable television rights for much of Poland, although he said the success of the venture depends on more Poles' owning television sets.
 
 
 
Greenville, Miss.
 
Awaiting A New World
 Over the last couple of months, said Larry Farmer, a community organizer in the Mississippi Delta, people have marveled over the changes in Europe and the Soviet Union.
''They say, 'Well, democracy works, doesn't it?' '' Mr. Farmer said. ''And I usually say, 'Why don't you go to Metcalfe, Miss., and tell me if you still think democracy works.' ''
''We have communities in Mississippi without running water or toilets,'' he said. ''We got crack cocaine killing our youth. We got horrible statistics on venereal disease. If we are going to talk about millions or billions for Poland or Czechoslavakia, let alone the defense industries, let's talk about money for Mississippi. We could use a little foreign aid, too.''
Mr. Farmer was speaking at the scene of a a conference in Greenville on poverty and the rural family. The changes in Europe were not on the agenda, but he said he thought there was a strong connection.
''The warming of the cold war ought to now allow us time to back off, to reflect and look inward at our problems,'' Mr. Farmer said. He helps organize community groups in the small, rundown, mostly black towns of rural western Mississippi.
 
Pioneering for Democracy
Nearby, in the sunroom of his large home, Charles Victor McTeer recalled coming to Mississippi in the late 1960's, as a young black law student from Maryland who wanted to help bring democracy to the rural South. Now he watches with awe and disbelief as the forces of democracy challenge Communist regimes and authoritarian rule from Moscow to Pretoria.
Referring to Mr. Gorbachev, Mr. McTeer said, ''He has forced all of us to rethink our existence on the planet, from the people in Lithuania and Romania and South African to blacks in rural Mississippi and poor whites in West Virginia and Mexicans in Texas looking for a job.''
In this new world, Mr. McTeer said, everything is interdependent. ''Think of the impact of all this. If the Russians are now going to be driving Hondas too, it means in 20 years from now the price of gas is going to be astronomical. And that means that even if Mandela is free, we are still going to have to figure out to how to feed South Africa.''
There is a new world coming, Mr. McTeer said. ''And in that new world, everyone eats; everyone is entitled to a piece of the action.''
''And I think it is going to happen,'' he added. ''I just think it is funny if George Bush does it instead of Jesse Jackson.''

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: March 11, 1990

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1, Page 1, Column 5; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1241 words

HEADLINE: Bush Distressed As Policy Fails To Move China

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 10

 BODY:
 President Bush and many officials in his Administration say they are deeply disappointed by the failure of the Chinese Government to relax its repressive rule in response to numerous conciliatory gestures by Mr. Bush.
The American officials explained that divisions within the Chinese leadership, compounded by fears about a resurgence of the democracy movement in China after the rapid democratic change in Eastern Europe, have made it difficult for Beijing to respond as the President had hoped.
Those concerned about the meager results so far include the architects of Mr. Bush's policy and some who carried it out, like Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger. He acknowledged in recent Congressional testimony that the repression continued after his visits to China, that there has been no ''rapid payoff'' from Mr. Bush's policy and that China has no plan to lift martial law in Tibet. Mr. Eagleburger secretly visited Beijing with Brent Scowcroft, the President's national security adviser, in July and December. 
 
Getting Worse, Not Better
Administration officials say the crackdown has become harsher in the last few months, with more surveillance of dissidents, more political education classes for students, more restrictions on overseas study and more persecution of the Roman Catholic Church and other religious groups.
In addition, the officials said, the Government has recently purged or punished many Chinese journalists and police officials who expressed support for the democracy movement or did not take a firm stand against it. Administration officials said they hoped that, by openly expressing their disappointment with China, they could coax Beijing to end the abuse of human rights.
In a surprise to the Administration, trade with China was booming even as repression increased there. Commerce Department data show that Chinese exports to the United States rose 42 percent last year, to a total of $12 billion. Much of the increase occurred in the second half of 1989, despite the killings in and near Tiananmen Square early in June. The Beijing authorities have been hard pressed to obtain convertible currency to pay off foreign-debt obligations.
 
Personally Embarrassing to Bush
For Mr. Bush, these developments represent a special problem because he invested a lot of political standing in defending his China policy and risked his reputation as someone knowledgeable about the country, where he served as chief of the United States mission in 1974 and 1975.
Mr. Bush now voices such disappointment, sometimes even irritation, but has no new policy. In an interview with NBC News last week, he acknowledged that ''there hasn't been much'' give yet by the Chinese, and he said, ''I wish there would be more.''
His criticism of China is far milder than that in the State Department's annual report on human rights, which sharply assailed Chinese abuses. ''I believe I know how to go about trying to see things move forward again,'' Mr. Bush said. ''Some think isolation -bring them to heel by publicly slapping people. I think I know China well enough to know that this isn't the way to do it.''
Beijing vilified Mr. Bush for allowing the State Department to issue the report. It further strained relations with Washington this week when it expelled an American businessman, John P. Cragin, on a charge of conducting ''illegal religious instruction.'' China said he had done ''missionary work under the guise of holding English-language- training courses in Tianjin since October 1989.''
 
How State Dept. Sees It
A State Department official said: ''We hoped there would be more of a response to the President's overtures. We are still hoping. The people in power in China today fear that if they do the things we would like them to do to heal the wounds of last June, they will jeopardize their own personal positions.''
The increase in trade between China and the United States would have been impossible if Congress had imposed stiff economic sanctions, as many lawmakers advocated last summer. Mr. Bush persuaded Congress to hold off, arguing that commercial contacts were good because they ''have led, in essence, to this quest for more freedom'' in China.
''The Chinese are desperately trying to increase exports,'' said Jan M. Whisler, an economist at the United States International Trade Commission. ''China must now depend almost entirely on export revenues for the hard currency needed to service its foreign debt of nearly $40 billion.'' Major payments on the debt are due this year.
A new fight looms in June over trade benefits. China's most-favored-nation status, which generally guarantees the lowest possible tariffs on exports to the United States, is scheduled to expire July 2. Administration officials say Mr. Bush will seek a regular annual extension of that status for China. Many in Congress are already gearing up to resist. At least six bills have been introduced to suspend or terminate China's status as a most favored nation.
 
Use of 'Forced Labor'
Senate Republicans are collecting evidence to show that some of China's exports, particularly textiles, were produced in prisons and labor camps. Federal law prohibits the importing of any goods produced in a foreign country by ''forced labor'' or ''convict labor.'' Textiles accounted for $3.2 billion of the $12 billion in Chinese exports to the United States last year.
Roger W. Sullivan, president of the United States-China Business Council, a trade association of 300 American companies doing business there, said there would be ''a very strong challenge by Congress to renewal of most-favored-nation status for China.''
Although quick to acknowledge that Mr. Bush has not achieved his objectives, White House officials are sensitive to criticism of the President's China policy.
Mr. Scowcroft complains bitterly that his toast ''to U.S.-Chinese friendship,'' at a banquet in Beijing on Dec. 9, has been misread as an endorsement of the military crackdown. Likewise, Douglas H. Paal, the senior specialist on China at the National Security Council, severely criticized a report on China issued last month by Asia Watch, a human rights group. When Is Ferocity, Restraint? Mr. Paal marked up a copy of the report with marginal commentary, like a professor's comments on a student's essay. Asia Watch said that the Chinese People's Liberation Army had shown ''ferocity'' in suppressing the democracy movement.
Mr. Paal wrote: ''Some of the P.L.A. actions were indeed ferocious - other units at other times did show great restraint.''
Asia Watch said that thousands of peaceful dissenters were being detained in China without trials. Mr. Paal wrote, ''The very fact that so many detainees have not been tried indicates some degree of restraint.''
People who originally backed Mr. Bush's policy say they, too, have been disappointed. A. Doak Barnett, professor emeritus of Chinese studies at Johns Hopkins University, said he supported Mr. Bush's effort to ''halt the downward spiral in our relations with China'' by sending Mr. Eagleburger and Mr. Scowcroft to Beijing in December.
''That mission had valid objectives and was worth trying,'' said Mr. Barnett, who has been studying China for more than four decades. ''But the Chinese have not responded sufficiently to indicate a reversal of repressive trends or to have a significant impact on American public opinion or Congress.''

HEADLINE: U.S. Pressed to Pay for Boat People in Hong Kong

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GENEVA, March 10

 BODY:
Britain is pressing the Bush Administration to pay most of the cost of caring for the tens of thousands of Vietnamese boat people now being housed in its colony of Hong Kong, as well as for building a new refugee camp, possibly on Guam, diplomats and United Nations officials here say.
The British request for up to $80 million in American aid for the Hong Kong boat people, who now number about 55,000, reflects London's concern that the international community is not paying its share of the cost and irritation with the United States for opposing the forcible return of boat people to Vietnam.
The new United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, Thorvald Stoltenberg, a former Foreign Minister of Norway, has also written to President Bush underscoring the seriousness of the crisis Hong Kong faces and urging him to change America's position and agree to the compulsory repatriation of those boat people judged economic migrants rather than refugees from persecution, those officials say.
Last year the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, who has traditionally reimbursed Hong Kong for caring for the boat people, paid only about $8 million of the $20 million cost. This year the cost of all the boat people seeking asylum throughout Southeast Asia is supposed to be met by the 29 member governments of the Comprehensive Plan of Action on Indochinese Refugees, adopted at a United Nations-sponsored conference in Geneva last June. 
 
U.S. and Hanoi Block Accord
Although those countries promised to contribute a total of $108 million on a voluntary basis, they have only paid about $15 million so far, with the United States giving $11 million. As a result, Britain fears Hong Kong will again be left to pay most of its bill itself.
Last January the member governments of the Comprehensive Plan of Action came close to approving a British proposal to return those Vietnamese who do not qualify as refugees under international law. But the United States and Vietnam blocked the accord by insisting on at least a year's delay before mandatory repatriation could begin, while Britain refused to wait beyond June.
As a result, diplomats say, Britain feels the United States should be held responsible for the extra bills it faces for looking after the Hong Kong boat people as well as for the cost of building the new camp that would be necessary to house any new influx that arrives this year. To underscore its irritation, Britain has even suggested that the United States build such a camp on its own territory, the island of Guam, or in the Philippines.
The Bush Administration's refusal to sanction the boat people's forced repatriation is criticized by many diplomats from recipient countries as being essentially a domestic political gesture that reflects its reluctance to be seen endorsing the return of refugees to the Hanoi Government.
Of the 55,000 boat people in Hong Kong, about 44,000 are eligible for screening by the British authorities to determine whether they are political refugees and may thus face possible return to Vietnam. About 8,000 have been screened so far, with only about 12 percent of those gaining refugee status.
Although Britain wanted international endorsement for its plan to start returning boat people by force, it has said it will go ahead without that once it has completed arrangements with Vietnam, including permission for international agencies to monitor the treatment the returning boat people receive.
Refugee officials say the number of new arrivals in Hong Kong and elsewhere in Southeast Asia so far this year is well below last year's levels. They say that is one of several indications they have received that Northern Vietnamese, who make up most of the boat people, are becoming more aware of the overcrowded conditions awaiting them in refugee camps and the danger of forced repatriation.

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
Romanian Rebel Predicts Slow Progress

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
The clergyman whose defiance helped start the rebellion that toppled Romania's Communist dictatorship in December says he believes that centrist forces can retain enough strength in elections on May 20 to maintain momentum toward democracy.
''I think there will not be an absolute winner,'' the cleric, the Rev. Laszlo Tokes, said in an interview in Manhattan on Friday.
''But with a small majority,'' he said, ''the National Salvation Front will continue to lead the country.
''The apparatus men realize they cannot turn back the wheel of history, but they want to save themselves,'' Mr. Tokes said, referring to the bureacracy that in large part remains in place despite the overthrow of the Ceausescu regime. 
The right-wing parties that surfaced after the execution of President Nicolae Ceausescu ''are not strong enough to form a coalition government,'' the 37-year-old Protestant pastor said, and will act as ''a counterpoint against the other extremity.''
''I assume that in a slow and compromised way the changes will go on,'' he added. The minister spoke in English throughout the interview.
 
A Trip to Rally Support
Mr. Tokes, a Romanian of Hungarian descent, said he arrived in the United States last week on a visit to rally support for democracy in Romania. ''The guarantee of the success of this social change is the international democratic forces,'' he said. ''We have to strengthen these guarantees for the world and for Romania.''
Two and a half months ago, Mr. Tokes (pronounced TOE-kesh) was in hiding, spirited from village to village as remnants of the Securitate, Romania's hated security police, sought to kill him.
For eight years, as minister of the Reformed Church in Timisoara, a city in Transylvania in western Romania, Mr. Tokes wrote treatises and organized protests in defiance of Mr. Ceausescu's systematic repression of the Hungarian minority.
''Our school system was dismantled,'' he said. ''Quotas were forced so our churches couldn't admit students of theology in adequate number.
''In recent years,'' he continued, ''Ceausescu made public the plan to demolish our villages - more than 7,000 villages to be demolished - and to gather the people in official living centers.''
 
Shielded by His Parishioners
On Dec. 15, as the Securitate was attempting to take him away, about 200 people, most of them parishioners, jammed the narrow street in Timisoara where Mr. Tokes lived. Hour by hour the crowd grew, lighting candles, praying, refusing to move.
By dusk on Dec. 16, at least 5,000 people were in the street, he said. ''Not only Hungarians,'' Mr. Tokes said. ''This is the qualitative change. The solidarity demonstration for me changed into a general protest against the regime.
''The people cried, 'Down with Ceausescu,' 'We want liberty.' In front of our windows, they sang national songs and started towards the center of the town, the party house and the official buildings in Timisoara.''
Within an hour, he said, 50,000 people had gathered in the city's center. ''Then appeared the water cannon,'' the minister recounted. ''They used tear gas and batons - Securitate, army and milita together, with small tanks, shields, helmets, rifles. Out broke the revolution.''
 
Revised Estimate of Killings
Reports on the number of people killed in Timisoara that weekend have varied. ''At the beginning, the number was manipulated to be more and more, to emphasize the heroism of Romanians,'' Mr. Tokes said. ''Now, the apparatus men try to manipulate it down.'' By his estimation, 500 people were killed and several thousand injured.
Reports of the repression filtered out. ''First, the movement has spread in Transylvania,'' Mr. Tokes said. ''Then in Arad. Then from town to town. But we knew if Bucharest didn't join, the revolution would not succeed.''
Mr. Ceausescu, hurriedly returning from a visit to Iran, made a tactical error. ''He was so conceited, thank God,'' Mr. Tokes said, ''that, according to Communist recipe, he gathered that meeting on Dec. 21. He wanted to make the people condemn Timisoara as hooliganism and fascism.''
But students at the rear of the crowd in Bucharest's central square that night began to boo. Like a wave, the jeering rolled toward the speaker's platform. And, in a pivotal moment for the revolution, Mr. Ceaucescu was seen on national television to be shaken by the derision.
 
In Hiding Until Mid-January
Mr. Tokes, meanwhile, was on the run. He said that in early January, after he visited Bucharest for the first time since the revolution, bullets pierced the walls of his compartment on a train carrying him out of the city. For several weeks, Mr. Tokes remained hidden in a remote village as remnants of the Securitate tried to track him down.
Finally, in mid-January, when he emerged from hiding, Mr. Tokes was hailed as a hero of the revolution and became a member of the provisional parliament. But the revolution ''got stuck,'' he said.
''The beginning was uplifting,'' Mr. Tokes said. ''The continuation, not so good. The people of Romania weren't prepared for liberty. In that liberty, all the problems which were supressed are now broken out. The people are impatient. They waited for liberty as manna.''
The economy is now in disarray. ''Food, for example,'' Mr. Tokes said. ''Distribution is a little better now, but there is no essential change.''
 
Fascists 'in Masked Form'
The right wing, he said, is trying to turn the people's impatience against the transitional government. He said that ''organizations with fascist character'' like the Iron Guard, which existed during the war, had been reactivated ''in masked form.''
''They use the traditional national contradictions as a weapon, quite as Hitler used the Jews, as the blame for everything,'' Mr. Tokes said. And Communists, he said, remain in the system.
The fate of democracy is riding on the election, he said. ''If not, there is the terrible alternative of military rule.''

HEADLINE: Cuomo in the Lead in Counterattack on G.O.P.

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 10

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York said today that personal attacks on Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri for criticizing President Bush's policy toward Eastern Europe were part of a Republican pattern of evading major issues.
''The one thing they seem to be afraid of is intellectual discussion,'' Mr. Cuomo said of the Republican Party in a telephone interview from the Governor's mansion in Albany. Among Republicans, he added, ''there is a proclivity to avoid intelligent exchanges and to convert every disagreement into a personal attack.'' 
Mr. Cuomo made his comments after his staff told reporters that he was interested in discussing the scathing attack on Mr. Gephardt delivered by Senator Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming, the deputy Republican leader.
 
Attack on Senate Floor
In a speech on the Senate floor on Friday, Mr. Simpson mocked Mr. Gephardt's criticism of the President as the frustrated railings of a man who lusts after Mr. Bush's job. He called Mr. Gephardt a ''frustrated font of trivia.'' Telephone calls today to Mr. Simpson went unanswered.
Earlier this week, Mr. Gephardt, the House majority leader, who unsuccessfully sought the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1988, said Mr. Bush lacked vision in dealing with the emerging democracies in Eastern Europe and changes in the Soviet Union. He called for economic aid to the Soviet Union, and he accused the Administration of ''government of the polls, by the polls and for the polls.''
Ronald H. Brown, the chairman of the Democratic Party, joined the exchange today, saying there has not been a President as ''thin-skinned'' as Mr. Bush since Richard M. Nixon occupied the White House.
Mr. Cuomo said of the Republicans: ''They're very effective at vituperation. They get the decibel level high. It gets you into trading punches, instead of trading ideas.''
A White House spokesman said the Administration would have no comment on the Governor's remarks.

HEADLINE: Nonprofit Community Groups Rebuild Housing in the Bronx

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
With a sweep of her hand, Charlene Moats traces the cycle of devastation and renewal that has changed the face of her Bronx neighborhood.
Not long ago, all five blocks along Southern Boulevard from East Tremont Avenue north to the Bronx Zoo were lined with shells that once housed hundreds of people. ''I've been here 30 years,'' Ms. Moats said, ''and I remember when this whole block was abandoned.''
Today every apartment building is either rebuilt or under reconstruction. ''It makes me feel good,'' said Ms. Moats, who will soon become the manager of a handsome five-story walk-up nearing completion at East 181st Street and Southern Boulevard. ''People used to be running. Now they're not going anywhere. We have a new laundromat, new stores opening up. It means a lot to the community.'' #1,000 Apartments Created The building, along with one across the street and two others nearby, has been restored by a nonprofit community group called Build, one of two dozen local agencies that represent the most successful nonprofit component of New York City's effort to create tens of thousands of apartments in the city's poorest neighborhoods. 
In all, the local groups have produced more than 1,000 new apartments, and 2,000 more are either under construction or being designed. And while they represent but a small fraction of the 47,000 that the city has pledged to create from abandoned shells in its 12-year, $5.1 billion housing plan, they are significant in several ways.
The buildings will serve a poorer population than many of the others renovated under the city's plan. They are financed in part with Federal tax credits that have been sold by two national nonprofit groups. And they demonstrate the potential of the city's nonprofit housing and community development groups.
''In a town that is still obsessed with private developers, this program has been an important statement,'' said Paul S. Grogan, president of the Local Initiatives Support Corporation, one of the national groups in the program. The other group is the Enterprise Foundation, created by the developer James W. Rouse to help the poor.
''It has demonstrated that you don't sacrifice anything in efficiency, cost control and timeliness if you work through local nonprofits,'' Mr. Grogan said.
 
Management a New Challenge
Although the tax credits have been used by the two groups in cities around the nation, nearly half the housing produced has been in New York City.
Having demonstrated this ability, the grass-roots groups now face the challenge of showing they can manage the housing. Many experts say the groups have unusual assets for this task: They know their neighborhoods extremely well, and they often seek to connect housing to larger community needs, like fighting drug trafficking and encouraging job training and economic development.
The local groups vary considerably in size and experience. Some, like the Banana Kelly Community Improvement Association and Build - an acronym for Bronx United in Leveraging Dollars - have been in the forefront of local housing development for a decade or more.
Others, like Asian-Americans for Equality on Manhattan's Lower East Side and the Aquinas Housing Corporation in the West Farms and East Tremont sections of the Bronx, have been active in tenant organizing or other forms of community advocacy, but have never before developed housing.
Still others, like the Ridgewood-Bushwick Senior Citizens Council, have histories beyond the world of housing and community development.
 
A Range of Rents Offered
Depending on their needs, they have been supervised and assisted in myriad ways by the two national groups, which have sold more than $100 million in Federal tax credits to major corporations that invest in low-income housing in New York.
The money raised through the credits accounts for about one-third of the cost of the building renovations. The city pays the rest, with some help from the state. The rehabilitations have cost an average of $70,000 an apartment, city officials say.
Rents for two-bedroom apartments in the program range from about $400 to $450 a month and are deemed affordable to families earning between $16,000 and $18,000 a year. Ten percent of the units in most buildings are set aside for the homeless, who pay the welfare shelter allowance, or $312 a month for a family of four.
In addition to selling the tax credits, the national organizations provided technical assistance on development, financing and management to the local groups. ''Other times, we learned things from them,'' said William R. Frey, director of the Enterprise Foundation's New York office.
 
Sweat Equity Employed
Banana Kelly, for example, began to fight housing abandonment in the Longwood section of the South Bronx in the mid-1970's. The group took its name from the sweeping banana-shaped block of Kelly Street, where it began organizing ''sweat equity'' projects, in which residents rebuild abandoned shells basically by themselves.
Today Banana Kelly is a major developer in Longwood and Hunts Point and manages buildings containing more than 700 apartments. It has supervised the reconstruction of eight large abandoned apartment buildings through sweat equity, said Getz Obstfeld, Banana Kelly's president, and has organized a similar effort at five small abandoned buildings on Fox Street.
The group has also overseen the moderate renovation of 20 occupied but rundown buildings taken over by the city after landlords defaulted on their property taxes. And it runs a program in which 30 young people are learning construction by renovating, under supervision, a five-story abandoned structure.
Build, which works in poor neighborhoods in the central and northwest Bronx, has supervised the moderate renovation of occupied buildings for more than a decade under many different city programs. The work usually involves such things as installing new plumbing, heating and electrical systems.
The group owns and manages 29 buildings containing a total of 1,100 apartments. They are scattered in a two-mile radius from Build's basement headquarters in a small building on Briggs Avenue, two blocks east of the Grand Concourse.
 
Tenants Picked by Lottery
Under the program run by the Local Initiative Support Corporation, Build has nearly completed the reconstruction of four shells. They contain a total of 165 apartments, and a lottery determines who gets them. Melva Ramos is one of 6,000 people who applied.
''I was very lucky,'' she said in her new five-room apartment on the third floor of a sparkling building at Southern Boulevard and East 180th Street. Mrs. Ramos and her four young children moved in three months ago.
''It's comfortable,'' she said. ''The heat is good. There's always hot water. The walls are not cracked. It's beautiful. I love it.''
City officials and foundation executives say the community groups are likely to provide solid, long-term management.
''The not-for-profits bring something that dollars and cents can't measure,'' said Felice Michetti, the acting Commissioner of Housing Preservation and Development. ''They know neighborhoods as no private developer could know them. They look at tenants as neighborhood residents; there's a difference between a tenant and a neighborhood resident.''
 
Families Helping Themselves
Banana Kelly, among others, works hard to link housing to community purposes. In a small building that it renovated for the homeless at Fox Street and Longwood Avenue, the group is helping the families take control of the building and their lives.
On a recent afternoon, members of the first 10 families who have moved in gathered in a basement meeting room to decide by themselves how the final eight families would be selected.
One woman suggested that the new families, who will come from shelters for the homeless and welfare hotels, be required to demonstrate that they have maintained their own apartments in the past. ''Can we be sure that someone who's only lived in a hotel or a shelter or their parents' house is responsible?'' she asked.
Another woman quickly noted that those in the room were themselves homeless just two months ago. ''We can set an example,'' she said. ''Just because you come from nowhere doesn't mean you're going nowhere.''

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Centenary;
Love Is Message As Maya Angeloub Addresses 700

DATELINE: SHREVEPORT, La.

 BODY:
Maya Angelou was no stranger to the 700 people who listened to her speech at Centenary College of Louisiana here last week.
In preparation for her appearance, this 165-year-old liberal arts college of about 850 undergraduates passed out 1,300 copies of her autobiography to students and members of the faculty and staff. Everyone from college trustees to custodians was discussing ''I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings,'' and most of those who heard her brought their copies with them.
''I can stop pretty much anyone on campus and say, 'What did you think about the part where she did such and such?' '' said a campus spokeswoman, Janie Flournoy. 
Ms. Angelou took it all in stride. Noting that the book, published by Bantam, is in its 34th paperback edition, she said she was grateful to anyone who had read it.
While she recalled her 10 years growing up in nearby Stamps, Ark., Miss Angelou went beyond childhood experiences. Her smooth alto voice seemed to vibrate the mortar of the campus chapel as she stepped into the pulpit and took the microphone, singing a spiritual.
Her speech, she said, was about love - ''about romantic love, agape love, familiar love and self-love.''
If love, especially self-love, was the message, poetry was the medium. Not only her own poems but also the works of black poets long swallowed by history.
''This is your life, young man, young woman,'' she said. ''This is it. It is one thing to come to 'An Evening With Maya Angelou,' but if I can be of any inspiration to you, then you must look at me, and be renewed. Look at me. I come from a town in Arkansas smaller than the exposed portion of that stage down here.
 
'I Was Determined'
''Look at it,'' she said. ''I was determined. I am still determined. I'm the Reynolds Chair at Wake Forest, and a Fellow at Yale. I'm on the board at Harvard and U.C.-Berkeley, and visiting professor at Radford University. And I teach French and Spanish. And I teach in Europe, at Oxford.
''See me now: black, female, American and Southern. See me and see yourselves. What can't you do?''
''If I have anything to give you,'' Ms. Angelou told the audience, ''it is this encouragement: that you may encounter defeats but you must not be defeated. It may even be necessary to encounter defeat.''
 
Experience of Literature
Ms. Angelou, 61 years old, lamented the forgotten works of 19th-century writers who recorded early trials of the black race. ''How have we survived? I project the literature handed from one generation to the next generation to encourage the next generation to survive, and to do better than that, to thrive. And to do better than that, at all odds, to thrive with some passion, some compassion, some humor and some style.''
She warned that without the common experience of literature, people become fragmented. ''We allow our ignorance to prevail upon us and make us think we can survive alone, alone in patches, alone in groups, alone in races, even alone in genders,'' she said.
The message was delivered in a city that has been divided by a surge of racial unrest for a year and a half. Tension has not eased since September 1988, when a group of blacks attacked police officers with rocks and burned two stores after a teen-age white girl was said to have shot into a group, killing an unarmed black man.
Tuesday night, it was Miss Angelou's books that bound students of Centenary College, 94 percent of whom are white, with students from the Shreveport campus of Southern University, a predominantly black institution, who attended. The Mayor of Shreveport, John Hussey, sat in a front pew.
 
'Changes the Way I Feel'
''The way she portrays her own life and all her stuff makes everything the same,'' Clinton Gwin, a junior at Centenary majoring in economics junior and from Shreveport, said after the speech. ''It's not that she's a black woman; she's just a person.''
Laura Hemmings, a freshman English major at Centenary from Shreveport, said, ''It changes the way I feel about certain things, like being a woman.''
Miss Angelou's visit, including the $8,500 fee, was sponsored by the student government and paid by Centenary student fees. Patricia Matthew, chairwoman of the student government forum committee, said she wanted to bring Miss Angelou because ''she'd be good for the college.''
''I have people here who don't even know me very well who came up and said, 'Thank you,' '' said Miss Matthew, a junior majoring in English from Bossier City, La.
The books were bought after Centenary's president, Donald Webb, requested $1,500 from his Fund for Innovation, which is endowed by the Women's Endowment Quorum at the college. He said the size of the college allowed the fund to purchase books for everyone.
''You couldn't do it at Ohio State,'' he said, laughing.
Following the speech, Miss Angelou attended a reception in her honor, where she was pressed by people who wanted to shake her hand and say a few words.
Earlier she herself thanked the audience. ''I needed to be with you,'' she said. ''And I think maybe, you needed me to be with you.''

HEADLINE: Pastimes;
Coins

BYLINE: By Jed Stevenson

 BODY:
The value of paper money is just a chimera unless you can convince someone of its worth. Today our conviction in the value of United States dollars is so high so that we accept them without a second thought although the bills are only redeemable in other bills or coins made of nearly worthless alloy.
During the Civil War, however, confidence in the stability of the dollar was low, very low. The United States Treasury was nearly bankrupt, having sent most of the gold and silver to Europe for arms purchases.
A panicky population trusted only precious metals, hoarding coins until severe shortages developed. The Government was faced with the problem of finding ways to make the paper currency more palatable to a population that was increasingly reluctant to deal only in paper. 
To solve the problem, the Government issued several remarkable financial instruments, one of which will auctioned by Stack's, coin dealers in New York City. The auction will take place on Thursday at 6:30 P.M. at the Omni Park Central Hotel, Seventh Avenue at 56th Street.
The article for sale is a $20 Compound Interest Treasury Note and it combined the features of a regular $20 bill and a bond.
These notes were authorized by the Acts of Congress of March 3, 1861 and June 30, 1864 and the Treasury issued notes that bore an attractive six percent interest compunded semi-annually.
All six denominations - $10, $20, $50, $100, $500 and $1,000 notes - were issued for a period of three years only but the notes could be redeemed before that time. A table showing the interest and value of the note after each six-month period appears on the back of each bill.
The date of issue was surprinted in red ink on the front of each note so anyone accepting the note could easily compute the exact value at any given time. The notes circulated as legal tender, but it's more likely that most of them were saved for the three years and then redeemed.
All the notes have a surprinting in gold ink on the front in large letters, ''Compound Interest Treasury Note.'' The denomination is also surprinted in gold on the front although each bill already has its face-value printed extensively elsewhere.
Each of the notes has an allegorical figure on the front denoting such topics as Peace, Victory, Loyalty or Justice. The $10 note has a portrait of Samuel P. Chase, Lincoln's Secretary of the Treasury, while the $20 note shows Lincoln's portrait and curiously a seige mortar, one of the few indications that these were actually a type of war bond. The $500 note shows the ship, ''New Ironsides.''
Few of these notes have survived, and any in better than Fine condition are extremely rare. Most of the notes were redeemed three years or so after their date of issue - they did not accrue interest after the three years.
Those that were not turned in at the time were marred by the gold ink used in the surprinting. The ink is highly acidic and many notes have holes where the ink ate through the paper.
Another problem facing the collector is that the higher denominations that may have been widely circulated - the $50 and $100 notes - were counterfeited so extensively during the Civil War that the U.S. Treasury began withdrawing its own notes.
Today, there are no known examples of the $500 and $1,000 denominations, athough the U.S. Treasury lists several that were never redeemed. If one turns up, Stack's says it would probably be sold for around $60,000 to $90,000. The $20 note at auction is expected to sell for $4,000 to $6,000. But it could also be redeemed at the U.S. Treasury in Washington, D.C. They'll give you $23.88.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 18, 1990, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
Last Sunday, this column misidentified President Lincoln's Secretary of the Treasury. He was Salmon P. Chase.

HEADLINE: ANTIQUES;
Treasures From a Napoleonic Trove

BYLINE: By PAULA DEITZ; Paula Deitz is co-editor of The Hudson Review.

 BODY:
In French, the word ''Vitrine'' conjures up the imaginary and unattainable world that exists behind glass in shop windows and showcases. And each year, the glass of the now-famous gallery-long vitrine in the costume exhibitions at the Metropolitan Museum of Art must be cleaned of fingerprints several times a week, as the crowds press in for a closer look at the magical array of small decorative accessories that have become the heart of the shows.
This year, for ''The Age of Napoleon: Costume From Revolution to Empire'' (until April 15), the vitrine is filled with the luxuries of the realm that Napoleon found it expedient to encourage for the political and economic reason of keeping artisans and craftsmen well employed. In surveying the rich assortment of ornamental jewelry, snuffboxes and sabers, one can understand why Mrs. James Monroe, who was in Paris in 1805 as the wife of the American Minister, made a beeline for the same quartier that Americans shop in today, near the Place Vendome. 
She selected a matched ensemble of a comb, necklace and earrings in citrine and gold. No doubt, she brought this imperial touch to the White House when she wore the jewels during her husband's Presidency, perhaps still with the fawn-colored cut-velvet dress she had also purchased in Paris, which is in the exhibition as well.
To make a point about the need for a new style of adornment, Katell le Bourhis, an associate curator at the Met and the exhibition's organizer, has lined the vitrine gallery with 25 mannequins in the sheer white muslim neo-classical high-waisted dresses that made any assembly of women at court look like an antique colonnade.
Clare Le Corbeiller, the associate curator in European sculpture and decorative arts who wrote the catalogue chapter on ''Jewels of the Empire'' said in an interview, ''With these pared-down monochromatic dresses as backgrounds, and with hairstyles both flatter and closer to the head, there was an opportunity for more color and variety in jewels.''
The adornments, and period portraits of women wearing them, trace not only the rise of wealth and power following the stringencies of the Revolution, but also personal relationships that evolved during this period, most notably the one between Napoleon and Josephine de Beauharnais, his first Empress. The simple initialed rings they exchanged, with a figure of love engraved on one of them, provide the only intimate moment in the display.
Josephine had a passion for jewelry, and she had at her disposal a generous civil allowance and what was left of the state jewels to transform into the new trend-setting forms. The most luxurious of these were the matched ensembles called ''parures,'' from the Old French word meaning ''to adorn.''
Among these elaborate suites of jewelry in the exhibition is one the Empress gave away - as she often generously did after wearing something only once - to Josephine van Hee, whose portrait miniature next to the porphyry and gold necklace and earrings shows how well they suited her. But the major parure of the exhibition in the neo-classical style is in carnelian and pearls with delicate chains of gold leaves.
The new sleeker, Grecian coiffures required statelier diadems, combs or bandeaux around the forehead, sometimes worn in tandem. When Jacques Louis David painted his tableau of Napoleon's 1804 coronation ceremony, he did justice to the graceful curve of Josephine's gold and silver diadem set with 1,040 diamonds, a gift to her from Napoleon. Now in the collection of Van Cleef & Arpels, the crown is only one item in the vitrine whose brilliance resonates the pageantry of that occasion.
Cameos and micromosaic medallions, recalling scenes of antiquity, were also in keeping with the political mood. A cameo diadem carved from a single shell, with mythological scenes framed by gold, pearls and precious and semiprecious stones, was a present to Josephine from her brother-in-law Joachim Murat. Simply marrying into the Bonaparte family was like opening a treasure chest. Even the short-lived marriage between the young, wealthy Baltimore beauty, Elizabeth Patterson, and Napoleon's brother Jerome yielded at least one garnet and seed pearl ornamental comb.
When Napoleon married Marie Louise, Archduchess of Austria, in 1810, he commissioned for her an eight-piece parure in diamonds and rubies designed by Etienne Nitot. Though the original was dispersed long ago, Nitot wisely kept a copy in white sapphires and garnets, which is on loan from the successor Parisian establishment, Chaumet: a coronet, diadem, comb, necklace, earrings and bracelets.
No design of the period was without symbolic significance, most charmingly demonstrated by a suite of three gold and gem-set acrostic bracelets sold by Sotheby's two years ago. The first letter of each stone - including emeralds, rubies and sapphires - spelled out the names of Napoleon and Marie Louise and the dates of their births, first meeting and wedding, with the numerals set in rose diamonds. So much cachet is associated with Napoleonic jewelry that the bracelets sold for $75,000 when the high estimate was for only $16,000. Currently at Ares Rare, an antique jewelry gallery at 961 Madison Avenue, one can see an 1810 French diadem, a delicate wreath in gold with acorns and oak leaves ($12,500).
For all the imperial wealth, there is still a reference in the exhibition to more humble origins, particularly in the gold earrings called poissardes, based on those worn by fishermen's wives. And set apart in another showcase are earrings of a more revolutionary nature in the form of a guillotine with a Phrygian cap and a crowned head rolling away - suitable for Madame Defarge.

HEADLINE: Currency;
The Pound Takes Another Beating

 BODY:
It is down, down, down for the British pound, which has fallen more than nine cents, to $1.6160, in the last two weeks. The Bank of England was in the foreign exchange market Friday buying the sagging sterling, which until several weeks ago had been one of the surprise strong currencies of the year. And the central bank may have to intervene again this week if the downward slide continues. The fortunes of the pound have turned sour on fears of inflation, higher interest rates and growing doubts about the performance and staying power of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. And the malaise has spread to the London stock market, which has managed to be volatile without gaining any ground.

LENGTH: 1509 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIARY

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson

 BODY:

 
COMPANIES
The Great American Express Cut-Rate Buyback
 
Finally, the American Express Company has found a way to come out ahead at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. But it's at the expense of Shearson shareholders. In 1987, American Express sold the public a minority interest in Shearson at $34 a share. Last week, American Express decided to buy each share back - for American Express stock worth about $11.93. American Express actually had wanted to sell more, but plans for another public offering and for a deal with Sanford I. Weill of the Primerica Corporation fell through. So with the help of more money ($1 billion), fewer employees (at least 2,000 layoffs) and a new chief executive (Howard L. Clark Jr.), American Express hopes to revive its brokerage. Some analysts say it will be years before Shearson can be peddled again. ''These companies are clearly wed for quite some time,'' said Michael L. Blumstein, a First Boston Corporation analyst. 
 
 
 
Coke: Another Generation
 
''New'' Coke is about to become even newer. The Coca-Cola Company said last week that it will test a Coke II brand as a renamed, repackaged, remarketed version of ''new'' Coke. The new, sweeter than the old, was supposed to appeal to the Pepsi generation, but its sales have slipped to 1.4 percent of the domestic soft drink market. Analysts say the Coke II name also might help the company distinguish new Coke from its original product, now called Coca-Cola Classic. Coke II cans will have dashes of blue, a color more familiar on the cans of Coke's largest competitor. And what if Coke II succeeds? As Joseph J. Doyle, an analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, put it, ''They have 'Karate Kid III.' I can't wait for Coke III.''
 
 
Will They Go Back to Greyhound?
 
Will Fred G. Currey become the Frank Lorenzo of the bus business? Mr. Currey's Greyhound Lines Inc., like Mr. Lorenzo's Texas Air Corporation, is perilously leveraged. And, as Mr. Lorenzo did at Eastern Airlines, Mr. Currey is trying to replace strikers with nonunion workers. The union walked out March 2, but Greyhound claimed last week to be operating 30 percent of its bus system, a figure disputed by the union. Prior to the current troubles, Mr. Currey arguably improved service, investing in his bus fleet, increasing ridership and, last year, eking out a small profit. But if a 1983 Greyhound strike under previous owners is any guide, it could take the company years to win riders back.
 
 
Demystifying Food Labels
 
How not to cash in on the nutrition boom: Dr. Louis Sullivan, Secretary of Health and Human Services, called last week for food companies to have mandatory nutritional labeling on nearly all their packages. Saturated fat, fiber, cholesterol, percentage of calories from fat - all would have to be clearly listed. No longer would food packages rival supermarket tabloids in telling stories that are mystifying, creative and incredible. Ideally, consumers would be able to see at a glance that a frozen dinner now labeled low-calorie was actually a meager, starvation-ration serving laden with fat. Said Dr. Sullivan: ''The grocery store has become a Tower of Babel, and consumers need to be linguists, scientists and mind readers to understand the many labels they see.''
 
 
The $2,000 Difference
 
The main difference between Genentech Inc.'s genetically engineered clot-dissolving drug and a more conventional product is about $2,000 a dose, European researchers reported on Thursday. They found that streptokinase, at $186 a dose, could treat heart attacks as well as Genentech's tissue plasminogen activator, or Activase, at $2,200 a dose. The study raises questions about whether sophisticated genetic engineering can produce drugs any better than those made by cheaper means.
 
 
USX and Dumping the Steel
 
Corporate raiding in the post-junk-bond era somehow seems a lot more complicated. The most that Carl C. Icahn has gotten from the management of the USX Corporation so far was a promise on Thursday to have shareholders vote on spinning off at least 80 percent of the steel business. Though he may be the largest shareholder, some analysts say he is unlikely to win the vote. But they note that Charles A. Corry, the USX chairman, has no long-term commitment to making steel. USX also has major interests in oil and gas.
 
 
In Brief
 
A 32-year-old great-grandson of the Ford Motor Company's founder moved a step closer last Wednesday to someday maybe running the company himself. William Clay Ford Jr., who already sits on the board, will direct the company's worldwide automotive strategies.
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY

 
Riskier Munis?
 
 Since the turn of the year, Treasury and corporate bond prices have tumbled but municipals have remained as solid as an old granite courthouse. Rates on long-term municipals have hovered near 7 percent since last year while 30-year Treasury bonds have gone from 7.8 percent in December to about 8.5 percent now. David Johnson, a portfolio manager at Van Kampen Merritt Inc., said municipals have held stable because of relatively low supply. But some analysts see a risk: As more cities and states face financial troubles, their credit ratings, and the value of their bonds, will fall.
 
 
Melamed to Leave the Merc
 
Leo Melamed plans to resign as head of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange to spend more time with his family and, in his own fashion, explore outer space. He announced on Monday that he will retire as executive committee chairman at the end of the year. The father of financial futures, he turned a market once most concerned with pork bellies into an arena with global influence on currency exchange levels, stock prices and interest rates. His tenure has also seen a Federal investigation of trading abuses. Mr. Melamed intends to continue trading for his own account. But he might find the cosmos more peaceful than the commodity pits: He also plans to write a sequel to his 1987 science-fiction novel, ''The Tenth Planet.''
 
 
Coloring for Babyboomers
 
How to cash in on the graying of the baby boom: Open a beauty salon and concentrate on hair coloring. American Salon magazine predicts that salon customers will spend $5.5 billion on hair coloring this year, up 29 percent from last year. ''More women are going out into the work world,'' said Norma A. Lee, speaking for next week's International Beauty Show. ''They don't have time to fool around and do it themselves.''
 
 
Unemployment Holds Steady
 
The unemployment rate continues to defy predictions of an economic slowdown. The Labor Department reported on Friday that the rate stayed at 5.3 percent in February for the ninth month in a row. Meanwhile, January's 5.4 percent drop in factory orders, the steepest in 15 years, only reflected weak manufacturing, said Allen Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Company. ''What stands out,'' he added, ''is the enormous strength of the service sector.''
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
 
Brussels: The Boring Boom
 
Brussels is blossoming as the headquarters of an increasingly unified Western Europe. The European Community concentrates its offices there, with most European Parliament meetings there as well. As European companies have crowded in, commercial real estate values have doubled and tripled. Construction cranes are everywhere; seven major downtown hotels are going up or have just been completed. But the boom has brought more discount shopping stores than sophistication. The city's real attractions remain the Gran' Place, some classic restaurants and a naughty little statue. The hottest ticket in Brussels come Friday night is for the train to Paris - which is where the Group of Seven industrial nations has chosen to meet next month.
 
 
Mitsubishi Finds a Friend
 
The Mitsubishi companies of Japan have found a friend to induct them into the corporate club in Europe. On Tuesday, they announced plans for ''intensive cooperation'' in automobiles, aerospace and microelectronics with Daimler-Benz of West Germany. Japanese companies have been rushing to enter Europe before a single, borderless market takes shape in 1992. Daimler, whose products include Mercedes-Benz cars, stands to gain access to Japanese technology and markets.
 
 
Small Business, Soviet Style
 
Soviet leaders seem determined to keep passing laws making small businesses legal until everyone gets the message. In 1988, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev allowed small businesses to open their doors as worker-owned cooperatives. In some areas, they have flourished; in others, they have been squashed by local politicans. Last Tuesday, the Supreme Soviet tried to encourage the spirit of enterprise some more, voting 350-to-3 to allow citizens to own the means of production. But local officials will still apparently own the means of obstruction: Workers can possess a factory, but only the government will be entitled to own the land underneath.

HEADLINE: Managing;
Getting Women Down to the Site

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

DATELINE: PORT WENTWORTH, Ga.

 BODY:
Robert E. Coker, the project superintendent at the paper plant expansion in this tiny town just outside Savannah, thinks Sheryl T. Hamlett is a terrific carpenter's helper. She works hard, takes classes on her own time and never balks at working late or weekends. She is, he said, ''one of the best workers we've got.''
She is also a single parent with two children under the age of 4. Until now, that might have kept her out of a business where workers stay home when it rains, work weekends when it doesn't and work late on a half-hour's notice. ''If they didn't help with day care I couldn't swing it,'' Ms. Hamlett said. 
As it happens, B.E.& K. Inc., the industrial construction company based in Birmingham, Ala., which is building the plant, is more than helping out. Less than two months ago it opened BEKare, arguably the nation's most novel corporate day-care experiment. Built by hooking trailers together, it is open when the workers are working, closed when they're not - and it will pack up and drive off when the project is complete.
''If a foreman says one of his people will be two hours late, or if the site is open on Saturday, we'll keep the kids,'' said Debra Halveston, a child-care worker at BEKare.
For women in construction, that is more than a convenience; it is a necessity. ''I've got to place my three kids when school lets out,'' said Betty Branham, a project timekeeper. Shirley Johnson, a foreman who waited until her children were grown to go into construction, knows what Ms. Branham means. ''I would have started a lot earlier if there had been day care,'' Ms. Johnson said.
Earlier, she would have been an anomaly. Today 11 percent of B.E.& K.'s workers at Port Wentworth are local women. But that influx has not been problem-free.
''We started to suffer excessive absenteeism,'' said Theodore C. Kennedy, B.E.& K's chairman. ''We had to remove the concerns the women had about their children.''
But how? Few day care centers or private sitters are flexible enough to accommodate a construction worker's schedule. The waiting list for decent child-care centers in all parts of the country ''can be tremendous,'' said Stacey J. Pomerantz, a program associate at Catalyst, a group that researches women's issues. Moreover, construction projects only last a year or so, so it would be economic foolishness for a construction company to build a full day-care center.
Then Mr. Kennedy had a brainstorm: Why build a permanent center when a movable one would do just as well? Thus, BEKare, which Mr. Kennedy projects will cost B.E.& K. $750,000 a year, was born. Now it is comprised of five 14- by 40-foot trailers, but can easily be expanded to nine. Mary Jo Cline, BEKare's director, reckons it can be moved four or five times before it falls apart.
Women's rights advocates applaud the thought that went into BEKare. ''This shows that a company can creatively solve its problems and those of its women workers,'' said Ms. Pomerantz. Ellen Galinsky, co-president of the Families and Work Institute, another research group, added: ''Work/family problems do not have cookie-cutter solutions, and it is a joy to see such innovation.''
Right now, two local ex-schoolteachers take care of about half a dozen children at BEKare. But B.E.& K. expects to hire as many as 600 more workers in Port Wentworth as the construction project gathers steam, and it expects that many will be mothers who will readily pay the $51 a week that BEKare charges for each child. Ms. Cline expects that within a year BEKare will have 12 teachers handling 65 children ranging in age from 6 weeks up through pre-teen.
B.E.& K. pays wages comparable to those paid by local schools, and has thus been able to woo qualified teachers. Most will probably go back to the school system when the Port Wentworth project is complete. But Ms. Cline says she will go with BEKare, and Ms. Halveston does not rule out the possibility.
Just as important to B.E.& K., some of the construction workers may go along, too. ''I'd be tempted to go to the next project,'' said Cheryl L. McGlohon, a laborer whose 4-year-old son is at BEKare. ''I'm not sure I'd feel that way if they didn't have the day care.''
 
 
 
CONSTRUCTION'S ATTRACTIONS
Until now, construction sites were the last places one would expect to find child care centers. Male construction workers certainly were not clamoring for them, and construction companies were not exactly rushing to hire women.
But in the last few years, the shortage of skilled workers has grown critical. In the construction downturn of the 1980's, many male workers, fed up with getting laid off all the time, moved into lower paying but more stable jobs like auto repair, or even opening businesses of their own. And the recent upsurge of construction activity, particularly in the Southeast, has not lured many of them back.
Meanwhile, new technologies have made physical strength less important for many construction tasks. The upshot is that companies are recruiting more women to be carpenters, electricians, even welders and pipefitters. And, since the money is generally good, many women are lining up for training in those professions.
''We are encouraging more females to come into our profession,'' said Theodore C. Kennedy, B.E.& K.'s chairman. ''And that means we must worry about day care.''
