HEADLINE: All About/Accountants;
Rivalries, Responsibilities and Some New Risks

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
Forget about accountants being a mild-mannered bunch of milquetoasts. When it comes to competing for clients, they are actually some of the most ruthless predators known to humankind. As Barry R. Wallach, a tax expert with Arthur Andersen & Company, boasted, ''I kind of view nonclients as clients being held in trust for us by the competition until we get there.''
Although the large accounting firms have long enjoyed nearly exclusive franchises for checking the books of public companies, their rivalries have only intenstified despite a flurry of mergers last year that reduced the Big Eight to just six.
The firms that remain - KPMG Peat Marwick, Ernst & Young, Deloitte & Touche, Arthur Andersen, Coopers & Lybrand and Price Waterhouse - slug it out every time a prestigious audit is up for grabs. These days, the attention is on Pepsico Inc., a $9 million account that Ernst & Young forfeited at the insistence of another client, the Coca Cola Company. Coke was upset that the merger of Ernst & Whinney and Arthur Young left the combined firm with both accounts. 
The hunt for new clients, and new services, is taking some startling new directions. Most firms cultivate former employees, who often go to work for potential clients, with lavish parties and alumni relations programs. The firms have targeted Eastern Europe as a vast, unconquered frontier for their audit skills, and they have pitched their services to the Federal Government, arguing that it should be run more like private enterprise.
But as they scramble for clients, accounting firms are becoming more likely to face responsibility for their clients' problems. Stockholders are taking accounting firms to court over audits that failed to warn of financial risks. No major firm is close to insolvency, but several face claims totalling hundreds of millions of dollars.
 
 
 
After the Mergers
 
 The Big Six Court Distinguished Alumni
 In the layoff wave that is following the merger wave, accounting firms seldom give pink slips. Instead, they give parties. And rather than allowing terminated employees mere hours to empty their desks, the firms give them six months, sometimes a year, to find new jobs. Then, they offer a stream of newsletters, alumni directories, reunions and training sessions. It's an accounting firm ritual that makes layoffs and resignations seem more like college graduation. ''We'd seen what universities do to cultivate their alumni,'' said Larry D. Horner, chairman of KPMG Peat Marwick. ''This is nothing more than a takeoff of that.''
Just as universities depend on their alumni for donations, accounting firms look to their alumni for more business. Accounting firm turnover runs as high as 25 percent a year, and most of those who leave go not to the competition, but rather to companies that could become clients.
''Very often, they will rise into positions of prominence where they'll have the opportunity to be a good friend of the firm,'' said J. Michael Cook, chairman of Deloitte & Touche. ''And that might mean the opportunity to refer busines to us.''
Many in the accounting industry had predicted that the mergers would result in sweeping staff cuts. At Ernst & Young, rumors have persisted for weeks, despite the firm's denials, that more than 300 of the combined firm's partners would be eased out.
The firms have done their best to keep any layoffs all but invisible. Those let go sometimes feel better appreciated as former employees. The New York office of KPMG spends $40,000 a year to publish an alumni directory and another $25,000 to distribute an alumni newsletter.
In October, KPMG rented the ballroom of New York's Marriott Marquis to fete 1,200 ex-employees. Roving waiters bore trays of shrimp and the banquet tables were piled high with roast beef. The cost: $75,000. Taking the reunion theme a step further, the firm put guests' classes -the years they joined the firm - on their name tags.
''It's funny,'' said Robert Serio, a Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company stockbroker who attended as a former KPMG employee. ''Even when the accounting firms were pulling back on their own employees' Christmas parties, the alumni parties were still going full swing.''
 
 
 
The Rating Game
 
Redefining What It Is To Be No. 1
 Not only are accounting firms vying for clients. They are also competing for recognition as the best salespeople in their business.
Accounting Today, a biweekly magazine, keeps box scores. For 1989, the magazine ranked Arthur Andersen first, with the best won-lost record, or the greatest margin of clients gained over clients lost. But now comes Deloitte & Touche with a claim on the salesmanship title as well. Deloitte figures that when the 1989 rank is adjusted to reflect the new clients' sales volumes (which tend to be proportional to accounting fees), the firm leaps ahead of the pack. Deloitte finished first in a ranking, adjusted for clients' sales volumes (which tend to be proportional to accounting fees), that Accounting Today compiled for the first six months of 1989. The firm's new accounts in 1989 included RJR Nabisco Inc. and the Morrison-Knudsen Corporation.
Arthur W. Bowman, the editor of Bowman's Accounting Report in Atlanta, says that Andersen and Deloitte & Touche will have the edge in the 1990's as well. Though Andersen is best-known for its huge consulting arm, Mr. Bowman admires the enormous investment it is making in its traditional audit and tax-related business. And he praises Deloitte & Touche because of the smoothness of its merger last year, between Deloitte Haskins & Sells and Touche Ross & Company.
 
 
 
The Trouble With Clients
 
Got a Problem? Sue the C.P.A.
 The more accounting firms chase new business, the more they seem to end up with some clients they wish they had never touched. The firms are increasingly vulnerable to lawsuits by investors who claim to be the victims of slipshod audits. As Harris Amhowitz, general counsel for Coopers & Lybrand, said, ''A very substantial loss could bankrupt an accounting firm.''
Many accounting executives say a major firm - although not one of the Big Six - could wind up being among the failures.
In exchange for an exclusive franchise to review the books of public companies, most state laws require accounting firms to operate as private partnerships - without the limited liability enjoyed by corporations. As the firms have expanded, partners are increasingly jittery about having their personal net worth on the line every time a client's business stumbles. With more exotic transactions and more business failures, claims have grown.
''There's this presumption that anytime there's a business failure, there's also been an audit failure,'' said J. Michael Cook of Deloitte & Touche.
Shareholder attorneys make few apologies. ''We're in very rough times financially, and the accountants are very often the ones who know or should know what's going on,'' said Arthur Abbey, a New York lawyer who specializes in suing accounting firms.
Just the week before last, Federal regulators sued Ernst & Young for $560 million for failing to spot problems at a Dallas-based savings and loan, the Western Savings Association. Arthur Young, part of the newly merged firm, had already had troubles at Lincoln Savings and Loan. There, a class-action suit filed after another well-publicized business failure seeks damages of $250 million from accounting firms.
Laventhol & Horwath, a mid-size Philadelphia-based firm that has grown rapidly through acquisitions, has also had a string of adverse settlements, serious enough to have forced its partners to take a deep pay cut last year. Edward A. Suarez, a senior Laventhol partner, blames policy-makers. Accountants, he argues, deserve better protection from lawsuits.
''If you believe accountants add value to the economic system, it's madness,'' he said. ''The courts have got to put a stop to this.'' Many accountants say their firms should be allowed to incorporate.
Most firms complain that the legal threat will drive young talent from the profession. Annual insurance premiums and deductibles can consume up to 5 percent of a firm's total fees, and perhaps as much as one-quarter of partners' pretax profits. Ernst & Whinney and Arthur Young, the only two firms where information has become public, spent $41 million and $17.5 million respectively in the 12 months before their merger on outside legal fees and insurance premiums. Their experience is believed to be fairly representative of the Big Six.
For these sums, Ernst had $140 million of insurance coverage atop a $5 million deductible on each claim, with a $30 million worldwide annual deductible. Young, which is facing serious lawsuits in the wake of the savings and loan crisis, had arranged $145 million of insurance coverage atop a $2.9 million deductible per claim and a $35.5 million worldwide deductible. Policies of this sort buy a firm some peace of mind. , though one huge case could blast through the limits of its coverage.
 
 
 
THEN THERE'S FEE FATIGUE
Turning the average accountant into a rainmaker is not easy. At Arthur Andersen's 1,725-bed, $130 million training center in St. Charles, Ill., 40 miles outside Chicago, television is banned and chairs are few. ''We want them out networking,'' said Richard Nerad, who runs the center. ''Distractions are eliminated.''
At a recent class, Barry R. Wallach, of Andersen's Chicago office, discussed the A B C's of business-getting. Why handle a problem yourself, he asked, when you can send in a team - and find other problems to solve? ''This is the profile of the old accountant,'' said Mr. Wallach, showing a videotape of a man on the phone. ''The guy's Rambo, a one-man answer team. Got a question? Boom. I don't want to say he's wrong. He's incomplete.''
The videotape continues. A new, team-spirited accountant gets a prospect to meet with a squadron of experts from across the nation. And the final, best role model is the accountant who suggests other, urgent problems to solve each time a project is formally finished.
But Richard L. Measelle, who manages Anderson's entire tax and accounting practice, warns that these techniques can become too effective. Then, he said, clients might contract a dreaded disease: ''Fee fatigue.''

HEADLINE: Only Washington Can Solve the Health Care Crisis

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Stuart Butler (''Coming to Terms on Health Care,'' Jan. 28) ignores the well-recognized and much publicized causes of the health care cost crisis and lays the full blame on corporate employees who use ''free'' health care. According to Mr. Butler, the employee is to blame for the crisis. 
Where is the alternative coverage to be found? Far from competing with each other for medical business, insurance companies have been stampeding to get out of the individual medical insurance market. When I entered the insurance business in 1973, there were about 25 companies offering individual medical policies in New York State. Now there are two.
Mr. Butler declares that ''all workers and their families would have equal access to health care coverage'' under his plan. Who is guaranteeing equal access?
He recommends requiring by law that all families be insured. Would he require insurers to insure all applicants? The current cost of insuring a family in New York exceeds $6,000 per year. Is Mr. Butler proposing that unemployed families be required to pay this bill instead of the rent?
If we guarantee universal coverage, we must require universal payment according to family means. The insurance industry cannot solve the problem. Only the Federal Government has a mechanism to require universal payment. America faces a choice between national health insurance and the toleration of an increasing population of uninsured families.
Tax gimmicks won't stop this hemorrhage. Is the Heritage Foundation in Washington or on Mars?
 
KAREN OLSON
President
Benefits Design Group Inc.
New York, Jan. 31

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Quality Control for Health Care

BYLINE: By JERRY J. JASINOWSKI; Jerry J. Jasinowski is president of the National Association of Manufacturers.

 BODY:
A painful back injury recently sent me to top medical specialists in Washington and New York. One doctor rated the injury an 8 on a scale of 1 to 10 and recommended immediate surgery. The other rated it a 2 and suggested plenty of rest and physical therapy. I opted for the latter and am in fine physical shape today.
But this mind-boggling experience - and near brush with the surgeon's knife - underscored more than statistics ever could the appalling quality deficiencies in our health care system. 
Had I elected surgery, I unwittingly would have added to the alarming number of unnecessary surgical and medical procedures in this country: up to 34 percent of those performed each year, according to the Rand Corporation and other researchers. Rand says nearly $50 billion is wasted annually on such unneeded services. I'd bet the figure is substantially more than that.
Consider that more than a third of the nation's hospitals fail to meet standards designed to guard against inappropriate surgery, unnecessary blood transfusions and poorly coordinated treatment of patients in special coronary and intensive-care units, according to the Joint Commission on Accreditation of Health Care Organizations.
Consider that residents of New Haven are about twice as likely to undergo a bypass operation for coronary artery disease as their counterparts in Boston, who tend to be treated by other means. How does one explain such enormous treatment inconsistencies between two renowned medical centers whose residents are remarkably similar in demographic characteristics?
One reads and hears very little about these shocking quality shortfalls.
An important lesson for health care organizations can be learned from the resurgence of manufacturing in the past decade. The all-out campaign for quality that helped American manufacturers jump back into the competitive fray must now be extended to health care.
While quality is an ambiguous concept, the focus should be on how to increase the value of health care products and services without raising the costs. Operationally, that means getting the waste out of the system by striving for more appropriate and efficient care.
Quality care, for example, means setting up a system to evaluate medical technologies and services, and establishing guidelines to improve treatment and limit unnecessary procedures. It means reforming our medical liability system to curb defensive medical practices, like redundant consultations and diagnostic tests used by physicians to protect themselves from lawsuits.
Quality care also means providing consumers with the information they need to make intelligent buying decisions. The regrettable truth is we often know more about the televisions and cars we buy than about the medical care we choose. One way to foster better choices on our part is to make publicly available data on hospitals and physicians a state requirement, as is the case in Pennsylvania, Iowa and Colorado. The Hershey Foods Corporation, instrumental in getting the Pennsylvania law enacted, is convinced that it is the most powerful tool they have to boost health care quality and lower costs.
Quality care similarly means giving the medical payment system a shot of quality control. Consumers still pay a relatively small share of the cost of services, giving them little incentive to use those services judiciously. Employers can play an important educational role, emphasizing to workers the individual responsibility for one's own health and placing greater emphasis on preventive health care.
Companies can take other specific steps to improve the quality of health care for their employees. They can, like Honeywell Inc., negotiate cost-saving deals with medical facilities with proven track records - ''centers of excellence'' - for high-intensity, low-frequency procedures. They can directly contract with multi-specialty clinics that select and hire physicians based on rigid criteria and that perform ongoing quality-improvement programs.
Or, like Allied-Signal Inc., they can give employees financial incentives to use general care physicians selected by the company who have agreed to serve patients for a negotiated fee. Employees who go outside the physician network are required to pay very high deductibles.
The basic objective of quality improvements is doing the job right the first time. Companies should insist on this throughout the process - from informing the consumer, to consulting with physicians, to demanding greater hospital efficiency.

LENGTH: 2663 words

HEADLINE: BIG WHEELS;
How Dreams of Clean Air Get Stuck in Traffic

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
''LOVE AFFAIR'' isn't strong enough; the automobile is part of the American identity. And more and more it looks like the Mr. Hyde part.
The smog-causing gases that cars give off are a prime target of the new clean air bill that is making its way through Congress. Senate leaders and the White House struck a deal on March 1 on exactly what further steps would have to be taken by auto makers and fuel producers, among others, to try to reverse the degradation of the atmosphere.
In fairness, it might be said that Mr. Hyde has already made passable efforts to be a good citizen. The auto manufacturers, often under duress, have managed to produce cars that give off vastly less carbon monoxide, nitrous oxide and hydrocarbons - three ingredients of smog - than the models of the 1960's. Scared by enthusiastic talk of alternative fuels like methanol and natural gas, the auto makers are pressing oil companies to make cleaner gasoline. 
But air quality in major American cities has nevertheless continued to worsen. In the 1986-88 period, 101 metropolitan areas did not meet the standard on ground-level ozone pollution, up from 64 that were not complying in the 1985-87 period. Weather was a factor, but most of the problem is cars.
One reason is that the Hydes of the world, not to mention the Smiths and the Joneses, are victims of circumstances seemingly beyond their control or anyone else's. While manufacturers were making cleaner cars, the number of cars and the number of miles they were driven increased enormously.
Statisticians try to make the astronomical numbers more comprehensible by expressing them in terms of trips to the moon, although no interstate goes there. Thus, in 1970, vehicle miles traveled in the United States came to about two million round trips to the moon. Now cars do about three million round trips annually. That is even worse than it looks at first glance. As total mileage rises, emissions can rise even more steeply, because more of those miles are covered in stop-and-go traffic. Trends cut both ways: as the years go by, dirty cars from the pre-control days are replaced with clean new ones, but then the effectiveness of even the new models declines as the cars get older.
Americans are driving more miles than ever because of cheap gasoline, population growth and longer commutes that are often a consequence of housing costs. They also like to shop, visit and just plain drive; only about 35 percent of car miles are driven to get to work or as part of work, according to one Government survey. The result of all that driving, though, is not necessarily greater convenience but ever-denser traffic, ever-longer delays and ever-sicklier air.
Yet rather than giving up their cars, Americans have responded by transforming their rolling prisons into cocoons of comfort. The gear includes multispeaker stereos, orthopedically correct seats, car phones, air conditioners, heavy soundproofing, even laptop computers and fax machines. These days it's hard to find a car without FM stereo. All these comforts help motorists routinely endure a virtually unbearable environment, even as their idling engines make that environment worse by the minute.
Automobiles impose other costs, too, like the environmental damage that is caused by spills from all the oil tankers needed to feed American refineries, and the payments to foreigners for eight million barrels, about 40 million fill-ups, every day.
Against these facts of life, the new round of clean air proposals, said Terry F. Yosie, a pollution specialist at the American Petroleum Institute, is ''trying to find other means to stay even with the vehicle miles traveled, and get to the next increment of improvement beyond that, so we're not overtaken by events, as we were to some extent in the last decade.''
The Senate-White House compromise would delay until 1995 a new set of regulations on auto emissions and would require another phase to begin only if specicfied levels of improvement in air quality are not accomplished. The pre-deal Senate version would have required two rounds of emissions tightening, the first one in 1993.
The compromise would also delay stricter standards on utility smokestacks and other sources of pollution. Government officials are quick to point out that vehicles, or ''mobile sources,'' are not the only culprits that add to smog, deplete ozone in the stratosphere, where it helps shield the earth from damaging ultraviolet rays, or cause acid rain. The degree to which cars are culpable and the comparative ease of cleaning up tailpipes and smokestacks seem to vary according to factors like how many auto plants a Congressman has in his district.
But the car is the most democratic of these pollution sources; far more than emissions from paper manufacturing, say, or electrical generation, the pollution from cars comes down to millions of personal choices.
And those choices, environmentalists fear, will affect the whole planet, through the greenhouse effect. Carbon dioxide is believed to be a major contributor to global warming, and Americans' cars emit about as much carbon dioxide as all the sources in Japan do.
 
The Limits of Growth Are Hard to Reach
Technology can ameliorate some of these problems, through better fuel economy and cleaner tailpipes, but just treading water is a challenge. For a while rising gasoline mileage helped, but recent statistics from the Environmental Protection Agency run the other way.
Moreover, in 1970, people outnumbered cars by 2.5 to 1, but the cars reproduce faster. By 1988, there were just 1.7 people per car. The only limit seems to be that once there is one car for each driver, increases in the car population cannot increase pollution or gas consumption unless the cars learn to drive themselves.
The projection is for more of the same. At the Northeast States for Coordinated Air Use Management, a coalition comprising New Jersey, New York and the New England states that last year required the oil companies to produce less-polluting gasoline, Allan C. Van Arsdale, a staff analyst, said that in the next 10 to 15 years, vehicle miles traveled will jump an additional 25 to 40 percent.
Some experts say that center-city congestion is not much worse than it used to be. But wide-open roads of suburban counties are getting as bad as city streets. And while there have been some improvements like one-way streets and staggered timing of traffic signals, these are mostly one-time refinements; future efficiency gains will be harder to find.
At some point, simple congestion would seem to put limits on auto growth, but it is not clear where that limit is. ''Twenty years ago, if someone had told me that the average speed driving across Manhattan would be allowed to get down to 1.5 miles per hour, I would say, no, it'll never happen.'' said Michael Oppenheimer, a senior scientist at the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental group. ''But you don't know what people will stand for.''
And car manufacturers have found new ways to help them deal with their frustration. Christopher W. Cedergren, an analyst at J. D. Power and Associates, a Los Angeles consulting firm that measures customer satisfaction with cars, said the next item on the list of standard comforts is compact disc players, which will be in a majority of cars by the end of the decade.
Another accessory that is part of the solution is also part of the problem: the air conditioner. In 1970, 40 percent of cars had them; now 90 percent do, said Mr. Cedergren. That piece of equipment is a synergistic nightmare for environmentalists. Air conditioners do not just encourage people to drive; they also eat gas and are notorious leakers of a chlorofluorocarbon that is particularly dangerous to the atmosphere, encouraging the greenhouse effect and depleting stratospheric ozone.
While the ozone above 30,000 feet is being depleted, it is being created at ground level by the interaction of sunlight and auto emissions. Unfortunately, ground-level ozone does not replenish the ozone at high altitude. It instead turns into the smog that causes lung and nasal irritation and, scientists believe, may cause long-term lung damage. It is also damaging to plants and trees.
 
More Places to Go, And Cheaper, Too
All of this for a convenience that is becoming a home away from home. The most recent study, conducted by the Census Bureau in 1983, found that 30.1 percent of the miles traveled were logged getting to or from work, 13.4 percent were for shopping and 15.5 percent were for other personal business. Going to social and recreational activities accounted for 13.3 percent, education, religious and civic activities for 4.1 percent, and visiting friends and relatives for 13.6 percent. Leisure driving came to just 1 percent and vacations to 2.1 percent.
The energy consumption is vast. Moreover, the private car is not efficient. Mr. Oppenheimer and a co-author, Robert H. Boyle, point out in a book to be published later this year, ''Dead Heat: The Race Against the Greenhouse Effect,'' that only about one-seventh of the energy in gasoline moves the car forward. The rest goes out the tailpipe or the radiator.
But if Americans are doing more driving, it is not irrational from the driver's point of view, because the price of gasoline has gone down. According to the Department of Energy, on an inflation-adjusted basis, the price of gasoline at the end of 1989 was just below what it was in 1973 and 42 percent below its peak price, which was in 1980. The roads are already built, the car is in the driveway, and the additional cost of driving to a restaurant 40 miles away is too small to stop anyone.
''We have built a society that is dependent on personal mobility, and we are envied all over the world for that,'' said Michael R. Deland, the chairman of the Council on Environmental Quality and formerly the Environmental Protection Agency regional administrator in Boston. That mobility, he said, ''is consistent with our most cherished national values of independence. I don't think we're going to change that in the near future.''
But Mr. Deland believes, with most other experts, that the United States will have to cut its dependence on cars. As Kenneth T. Jackson, a Columbia University historian, put it in ''The Crabgrass Frontier,'' published in 1985, ''The United States is not only the world's first suburban nation, but it will also be its last.'' The earth cannot sustain many more economies like this one, he said.
If the American mass transit system is 140 million cars and 200 million people to drive them, what is the alternative?
One is public transportation, which usually means the bus. But, as the director of the E.P.A. Office of Mobile Sources, Dick Wilson, acknowledged: ''It's difficult to tell people they ought to leave the car home when they see the smoking diesel bus. We have to clean buses up so we can promote them with a straighter face.''
At the coalition of Northeastern states, Mr. Van Arsdale agreed that ''to get out of this rut we're going to have to provide a good alternative to the motor vehicle.''
But an effective public transit system requires concentrations of population, while each year since World War II has seen more dispersal. People travel from dispersed homes to dispersed workplaces, shopping malls, restaurants, theaters and schools. To make matters worse, the route maps would not be like simple lines or grids, but like a bowl of spaghetti.
 
One Suggestion: Undo the Suburbs
Until World War II, said Dr. Jackson of Columbia, land near transportation lines was valuable and land far away was not. Now, he said, the South Bronx, crossed by subway and train lines, is in ruins, while virgin land reachable by car over the George Washington Bridge in New Jersey is being converted to prime housing.
''Let's reverse what's been going on for the last 60 years,'' he said. A start, he said, would be a gasoline tax and an end to private transportation's public subsidies, a category into which he puts everything from road building to snow plowing to police protection of the highways.
Los Angeles is making preliminary moves to reduce the demand for travel. The South Coast Air Quality Management District and other government units there have drafted a plan that calls for using zoning to intersperse housing with employment centers.
It is a long-term solution that even proponents say will be difficult to bring about. Cleaner-burning gasoline and possibly some alternate fuels seem likely to come sooner. What else can be done to tie the web of modern life together without the automobile?
''There's not too much on the horizon right now,'' said Mr. Van Arsdale, ''other than, 'Beam me up, Scotty!' ''

Problem:
Travel from home in Haworth, N.J., to office in Newark, N.J., a distance of 20 miles, so as to arrive by 9 A.M. Some options:
 
The bus to eternity
Take 7:17 A.M. bus across the Hudson River to Port Authority terminal in Manhattan, arriving at 8:11. Then take 8:20 A.M. bus back across the river to New Jersey, arriving in Newark at 8:55 if all goes well. Minimum transit time 1 hour, 38 minutes.
 
Railroad three-step
Drive car to station in neighboring Oradell, take NJ Transit train to Hoboken, then the PATH tube to Newark. Choppy experience, but transit time is not much over an hour on a good day, and it's possible to read the paper.
 
By car
Insert lucky coffee mug in coffee-mug caddy. Buckle up. Blast off. Time on road maybe 40 minutes, depending on traffic.

LENGTH: 550 words

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
VISIONS OF AMERICAN PLENTY

 BODY:
A Soviet satirist, Mikhail Zhvanetsky, is a keen observer of life in his country and the United States. Following are excerpts from an essay he wrote for Literaturnaya Gazeta. It was reprinted in the February issue of Literary Gazette, an English-language version of the Soviet newspaper.
 
To understand what we are missing, to understand what human hands can do, to understand what the earth gives us, our people should tape a four-hour TV program in [an American] supermarket. We should stop playing imagination games and look at just what they sell in an American store. There's nothing special there - just everything. Absolutely everything that we know, heard, read somewhere, saw in pictures. That's half of it. And half is what we don't know, haven't seen or heard. And we should see it, to get the healthy spirit of competition going, so that we understand what the earth can provide, what water can provide, what the winter can provide, and what the summer can provide. . . .
[In the United States,] you can do this, you can do that, but someone is doing it all. Someone is working. Women come home with gray faces, India ink flowing down their cheeks, their hands full of ink. Salesmen run around with gray faces, and they aren't the least bit polite. Where does everything in the stores come from? After all, someone produces it. They pay, they pay a lot. . . .
You have to work unbelievably hard; smoke comes out of every part of your body. There is no time to read, no time to learn anything: ''I don't read books; I read the newspapers.'' ''I don't go to the theater.'' They talk about it with pride. ''There's a guy over there; he reads books. You can find everything out from him.'' ''I don't know what the name of this ocean is. There's a geographer; he knows.'' ''There's a mathematician; he knows.'' . . .
If we here, through many centuries of struggle, through deprivation and disasters, earned the sacred right to do absolutely nothing for 100 rubles a month, over there, on the other hand, to stand in place, you have to run. In order not to sink down, you have to work with your hands, legs and head. He wasn't at tennis once; another time he wasn't at the pool - and so the rumors begin. Already a rich client didn't go to him, and he, trying to be cheerful and smile, has already dropped one step lower, then lower, because, just like here, you go up only once. . . .
The boredom is excruciating, like the food. Like the businesslike women, the businesslike men, a Broadway show. Huge amounts of water flow, fires burn and there is plenty of nudity, and people crawl around like cats, . . . and over there they have everything, and they don't have anything else, and everything is broken up into types. Some read books, some make money, some are discovering new drugs, some are inventing airplanes, some just know what buttons to push, what to turn off. No one knows how anything is made. A few kids in Houston know; ask them.
You can buy pears. Or, after you pay, you can pick them for yourself, the best, the freshest, in someone else's orchard. Or, after you pay, you can pick wild strawberries, raspberries or vegetables. There is no one standing between the idea and the realization. . . .
Everybody uses you a little bit, but that's business.

LENGTH: 907 words

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
Can a Change In Rules Alter Young Lives?

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE

 BODY:
IN a crack-plagued Bronx neighborhood, public school students wear uniforms proudly. At a Bedford-Stuyvesant high school ringed by poverty, students know to leave their gold jewelry and the removable gold jackets for their teeth at home. And in a handful of New York City high schools, students routinely submit to metal-detector searches for weapons.
Increasingly, inner-city schools are focusing on their environments and how students perceive themselves. If the home and neighborhood are dysfunctional and chaotic, the thinking goes, the school must be a model of function and discipline. 
Besides campaigns to rid schools of graffiti and weapons, more and more schools are outfitting their students in uniforms or forbidding excessive gold jewelry or obviously expensive clothes as disruptive and emblematic of the drug culture. More than 50 districts nationwide, including those in Philadelphia, Miami and Houston, ban beepers in schools, mainly because of their association with drug dealers.
There is little research directly linking such regulations to academic progress, and experts say it would be nearly impossible to quantify any gains. But especially in inner-city schools, the measures are being tried nonetheless.
''The ghetto culture is not the culture of blacks anywhere in the world,'' said Dr. James Comer, Maurice Falk Professor of Psychiatry at the Yale University Child Study Center. ''The way these children behave is a function of economics, social experiences and generations of a caste system. Academic life is not meaningful or useful to them. Unless there is some understanding of the magnitude of the problem and why it occurs, there will be no progress in changing their behavior.''
Principals see children raw from the violence and pathology in their lives, whose lack of self-esteem hinders learning. They see their first charge as providing an environment that aids learning, and having students accept that environment and the demands of attendance and behavior it makes.
 
Closing the Gap
''The children in these schools typically have a variety of multiple and complex needs that for one reason or another are not being met by the family, the community or the private sector,'' said Michael Casserly, associate director of the Council of Great City Schools, a coalition of 45 large urban districts.
In ruling that it is wrong to bring weapons into a school or that there is a proper standard of dress, principals say they are closing the gap between the way the outside world presents itself and they way their students present themselves.
''You can be a pimp, you can be a prostitute, you can be a drug dealer with gold teeth,'' a principal in Brooklyn, Frank Mickens, told his students in banning gold jackets on teeth. ''You cannot go to Wall Street with gold teeth.''
Mr. Mickens has plastered the photographs of students all over Boys and Girls High School in Bedford-Stuyvesant to lift self-esteem. Citing statistics showing that almost one out of four black men in their 20's is in jail or on probation or parole, he has asked teachers to seat male students in the front of classrooms, where he believes they are more apt to participate actively.
 
A Measure of Success
Dr. Comer of Yale has worked with inner-city elementary-school children in New Haven, where classes included basic academics, social skills and artistic expression. He said attendance soared and standardized test scores began climbing after one year of the new curriculum. A follow-up of one group of students after they left the school showed that they were still performing ahead of students from neighboring schools.
G. Ben Dachs, the principal of Wingate High School in Brooklyn, said he initially was opposed to metal detectors at his school, and yielded because they were approved by parents and students weary and wary of the outside world. But he said test scores and attendance have risen since the advent of metal detectors and rewards for accomplishments like passing all courses.
''The culture of a school dictates whether a youngster will learn or not,'' Mr. Dachs said.
But Roland S. Barth, a senior lecturer on education at Harvard University and project director of the National Network of Principals' Centers, cautioned: ''To me, it raises the question about the usefulness of schools as we know them. If you have to create all over again the environment in which schools operate, maybe we need a different conception of packaging schools.''
Few students or parents have objected to non-academic regulations, although the American Civil Liberties Union has opposed bans on beepers in some cases. Among those who see the devastation wrought by crack, absent parents and inadequate housing, there is relief that standards are being set somewhere.
Aida Rosa, the principal of Public School 30 in the devastated South Bronx, said the parents in her district are increasingly holding two jobs or are involved in drugs. Some have abdicated authority, she said, but others just need help. When students were given the option of wearing uniforms, many accepted.
''With our uniforms we have created a sense of unity, a sense of feeling good about ourselves,'' said Ms. Rosa, whose school resounds with an almost palpable sense of good will. ''No matter what I do here I will never be one of the schools with the top reading scores. But I think the uniforms have made a tremendous difference.''

Yee; Sipa/Tony Savino; Beryl Goldberg)

LENGTH: 294 words

HEADLINE: Remember Panama?

 BODY:
Most Americans over age 10 still remember those dramatic televised reports. It was only 12 weeks ago that U.S. troops invaded Panama, in the largest military operation since the Vietnam War. President Bush's political stock soared when the assault brought the capture and removal to Miami of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, Panama's fallen strongman.
But 12 weeks can be a long time if you're trying to hold together a country whose army and police force have been shattered, and whose economy has been devastated by two years of U.S. sanctions and then a billion dollars of war damage.
Such is the crisis that now presses on President Guillermo Endara's new Government. Not surprisingly, Mr. Endara hopes that Washington will quickly approve promised aid and that funds in formerly blocked accounts will soon become available. But Mr. Bush's $500 million Panama aid package is meandering through Congress. Emergency funds are only now dribbling through the bureaucratic pipeline. A cumbersome process involving claims and counterclaims stalls release of back taxes owed to Panama by U.S. companies.
Meanwhile, Panama's 30 percent unemployment rate makes the Endara Government reluctant to pare down its reconstituted military force. Yet the presence of thousands of re-enlisted Noriega veterans could one day imperil democratic rule. Moreover, the force's unreliability prolongs the awkward role of American troops as a backstop for police operations on Panamanian soil.
Economic problems also make it harder for the Endara Government to consolidate popular support and renew its mandate with a fresh presidential vote. Panamanians who cheered U.S. troops last December never imagined that Washington could forget their desperate plight by March. Has it?

LENGTH: 2637 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL ISSUE;
Going Abroad Without Going Broke

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH; STEVEN PROKESCH is a business correspondent in the London bureau of The New York Times.

 BODY:
AMERICANS can still only hope for a return of the days when the mighty dollar made foreign travel a bargain. As a result of its relative weakness, imagination and careful planning will once again be a must for cash-constrained Americans intent upon spending their vacations strolling along the banks of the Seine, enjoying theater in the West End of London or sampling sushi in Tokyo.
But judging from the number of people now arranging for vacations this spring and summer, Americans are rising to the challenge.
It is, of course, too early to tell whether 1990 will surpass last year's record of nearly 6.5 million American visitors to Europe. But travel agents certainly sound upbeat. ''We're already having a good year,'' said Brian D. Robb, director of international product at the Carlson Travel Network (formerly Ask Mr. Foster) in Minneapolis, one of America's biggest agency chains. ''Concerns about the value of the dollar and terrorism seem to be on the back burner.'' 
Thomas Cook Travel, another big chain, also reports strong spring and summer bookings for foreign vacations, especially in Europe. ''The dollar is not great, but you have a combination of pent-up demand'' for vacations in Western Europe and ''a desire to explore Eastern Europe,'' said Marianne Toldalagi, senior vice president for marketing.
The value of the dollar against a weighted average of the world's major currencies is virtually unchanged from a year ago, according to separate calculations by the Federal Reserve Board and Morgan Guaranty Trust Company. But it is still one-third below where it stood five years ago.
Such general figures, though, do not tell you very much about a given place. For instance, the dollar is somewhat stronger in Australia, Israel and Egypt and is up sharply against the currencies of Mexico, Argentina, Kenya and Turkey. On the other hand, its value has fallen by 5 percent or more in Austria, France, Italy and the Netherlands.
Although the dollar has gained 5.7 percent against the British pound in the past year, Americans will not better off in Britain because prices in general have been rising at a 7.7 per cent annual rate. And a 21 percent rise in the dollar against the yen does not mean that Japan has suddenly become a bargain: Tokyo remains one of the world's most expensive cities.
But as even those on tight budgets will discover, there are still a number of places - including Mexico, Greece, Hungary, Czechoslovakia, Egypt and India - where the dollar wields a lot of buying power.
Just because a city is expensive does not mean everything is exorbitant. In many European cities, museums are free or inexpensive. A good seat at some of the most popular plays in London like ''Miss Saigon,'' ''Jeffrey Bernard Is Unwell'' or ''Les Liaisons Dangereuses'' costs only $20 to $25, and tickets for many fringe plays go for $10 or less.
While watermelons may cost $60 each in Tokyo, lunch without watermelon can actually be reasonable. Noodle shops charge $3 to $5 for a bowl of noodles. At most restaurants, a ''set'' or complete lunch - pronounced teh-sho-ku in Japanese - usually costs about $8. That might be sushi, a selection of yakitori (chicken on skewers), or some freshly fried tempura.
In Paris, antique lovers will find some bargains at the thrice weekly auctions at Hotel Drouot, the city's official auction house at 9 Rue Drouot in the ninth arrondissement.
Hotels may be expensive on average in West Germany, but the high standards for comfort and cleanliness mean you do not need to stay at a luxury hotel. A two- or three-star hotel that charges as little as $60 a night is usually acceptable.
Since the more expensive countries are eager to attract American tourists, many have tourist centers both at home and in the United States that have become increasingly helpful in suggesting ways Americans can stretch their dollars. This includes guidance on the least expensive times to come (avoid Passover in Israel and the World Cup matches that this year run from June 8 to July 8 in Italy) and on finding comfortable but less-expensive accommodations like bed and breakfasts.
So even though doubles at elegant London hotels like Claridge's, the Savoy and the Berkeley go for $297 to $429 a night, it is easy to find much more affordable places.
A British Tourist Authority brochure lists budget hotels in areas of London like Russell Square or Bayswater that cost $91 and under a night for a double. A service called Bed and Breakfast (GB) lists places in London that during peak season charge $26 to $66 a night per person, with breakfast (44-491-578-803). The Bulldog Club (44-1-622-6935) specializes in luxury bed and breakfasts in central London ($120 a night for a double with bathroom). And the Global Home Exchange and Travel Service will help you swap your house with that of a British family (44-1-852-1439).
The subway and bus systems are the key to getting around inexpensively in many areas of the world. For instance, in Tokyo clean, safe and efficient subways will get you almost anywhere in the central part of the city for 90 cents.
In London, using an exchange rate of $1.65 to the pound, a one-day pass costs $4.29 and a weekly pass is $32.50, for unlimited travel on subways and buses. The color-coded maps of the London Underground are excellent. In Paris a single Metro ticket costs 86 cents (at 5.8 francs to the dollar), but if you buy a packet of 10, called a carnet, at one time, it costs $5.38. A three-day ticket for unlimited travel, second-class, on Paris's subways and buses costs about $12, and for five days, $19. Frequent buses from the airport to downtown Stockholm cost about $6 versus $50 for a taxi.
SEVERAL countries also offer tourists special train passes, although they may require you to buy them in the United States before arriving. But make sure you are going to use them enough to make the purchase worthwhile.
In many countries, travelers can save money by avoiding peak seasons or holidays. ''In Europe in May, September and October, prices are down and the place looks the same,'' said Mr. Robb of Carlson Travel.
In Jerusalem, at the King David Hotel, the rate for a double is normally $170 with a street view and $227 with a view of the Old City, rises to $246 and $285, respectively, during the Passover season.
Of course, another option, no matter the time of year is to venture off the beaten path. The countryside just one hour from London is charming - as are the lower prices. Glasgow is the designated ''European City of Culture'' in 1990 and events are scheduled there throughout the year. The cost of a double room in Glasgow ranges from around $20 a night at a bed and breakfast to $161 at the four-star Holiday Inn.
Another way to save is to buy a package through a travel agent. Because tour companies buy in bulk, they often are able to offer savings of 15 percent or more. And packages are increasingly giving travelers more Flexibility in customizing a trip to their own liking. The land costs of an eight-night package of five Swiss cities sold by Thomas Cook, for instance, costs about $230 less, or 27 percent, than what you would pay on your own.
A good gauge for how much it will cost to stay in a given city is the State Department's per diem allowances for Federal employees traveling abroad. It covers moderately priced food and lodging as well as mandatory service charges and taxes, tips and the cost of expenses like laundry and dry cleaning.
At the upper end are Moscow ($218), Tokyo ($195) and Stockholm ($194). Next come Brussels, Madrid, Dublin, Rome, London and Paris, which range from $170 to $178. Those looking for more economical cities might chose Athens ($99), Nairobi ($94), Rio de Janeiro ($100), Mexico City ($102) and New Delhi ($103). Other daily allowances include $138 for Beijing, $150 for Sydney and $160 for Hong Kong.
Following are some specific tips for stretching your budget in a sampling of major international destinations.
 
France. While Paris is certainly expensive, it costs nothing to watch the sailboats in the Luxembourg Gardens, to go window shopping along Faubourg Saint-Honore or to listen to musicians on the Pont St.-Louis connecting Ile de la Cite and Ile St.-Louis.
It is easier to get an excellent $20 dinner in Paris than in New York. Try the hearty stews and crusty peasant breads at La Lozere, a folksy restaurant in the sixth arrondissement at 4 Rue Hautefeuille (43.54.26.64). If you really want to stretch your dollars, try one of the many North African restaurants in the Latin Quarter; a filling meal may cost less than $9. A way to try one of Paris's finest restaurants at nonstratospheric prices is to order one of the special fixed-price lunches that many of them offer.
There are still some good deals for hotels in Paris. A handsome, comfortable hotel overlooking the Pantheon is the Hotel des Grands Hommes (17 Place Pantheon, fifth arrondissement; 46.34.19.60), where you can obtain a double room with bath for $122 a night. A respectable but no-frills hotel, alongside the National Theatre of the Odeon is the Hotel Michelet Odeon (6 Place de l'Odeon, sixth; 46.34.27.80), where you can obtain a double room, with bath, for $68.
 
Italy. For those who want to combine a love for soccer and Italy, the World Cup '90 is offering special package trips that are available in most American cities. One way to save money is the Check Out Italy discount coupon program for popular spots like Rome, Milan, Venice, Florence, the Amalfi Coast and Sorrento. The 142 coupons that offer discounts for things like hotels, restaurants, beauty salons and shops, and a few gifts. (Send check or money order for $40 plus $4.95 for postage and handling to Check Out Italy, Post Office Box 36, Monte Rio, Calif. 95462; 800-462-0615 or 707-865-2797.) You may want to avoid Italy during the World Cup championship matches, when prices will probably be higher. Special events like art shows and concerts will not end with the games. They will run May to September.
A double room at a moderately priced hotel in Rome like the Hotel Locarno (22 Via della Penna; 3610841) costs about $130 a night, including breakfast. A luxury hotel like the Excelsior is about $330 for a double, without breakfast.
To save money, stay in smaller towns. Or try country-style lodgings similar to bed and breakfasts that practice what the Italians call agriturism. Prices in the less-explored southern regions are often one-third of those in the north.
 
Japan. It is true that tourists can easily spend $150 to $300 a head for dinner in Tokyo. But some restaurants charge $25 a person for a nice dinner and a glass or two of wine.
For lunch, great yakitori can be found under the elevated railroad tracks around the Yarakucho Station near the Ginza for less than $10. Or try the sushi shops near Tsukiji, the world's largest fish market, within walking distance of the Ginza.
For touring, some of the best sights, like shrines, are free or close to it. The area around Shinjuku Station is filled with bargain stores. Purchases in department stores are generally expensive, but an exception is the traditional Japanese lacquerware bowls.
Ordinary hotel rooms in Japan cost $125 to $500. But tourist offices in each town can put you in touch with minshiku, or the Japanese equivalent of bed and breakfasts, which often charge $50 a night or less.
 
Israel. The bargains seem few and far between. The Hilton in Tel Aviv charges $195 and several supposedly four-star hotels charge $100 to $125.
The major American rental firms charge $75 to $100 a day for what is called a full-sized car though is midsized by American standards, although local firms charge less. When taking a taxi, make sure that the cabbie has his meter on. While a group taxi, called a sherut, is cheaper for traveling between cities, making arrangements might be difficult if you speak no Hebrew.
Dinner at major tourist hotels can cost $40 to $50. But look for smaller restaurants that Israelis frequent near most of the hotels. The prices are lower and the menus are almost always in English. While the quality of beef is poor, the lamb can be quite good.
 
India. The dollar still goes a long way in India. A double room at Delhi's moderate Claridges Hotel is $69 a night, plus a 20 percent tax if paid in local currency. At the top-of-the-line Taj Mahal, it is $115.
Train and air fares are very low. Since many train trips are overnight, they save on hotel bills. Meals on trains are usually hot and fairly tasty in first- or air-conditioned class. A one-way overnight fare between Delhi and Calcutta runs from $35.52 on an ordinary, air-conditioned sleeper to $80 in a first-class compartment.
India continues to be one of the best places in the world for shoppers. To avoid phony goods in Delhi, go to Central Cottage Industries on Jan Path or the State Emporiums on Baba Karak Singh Marg off Connaught Place. The price of a heavy brass four-cup coffee pot is about $16. A floor-length woolen Kashmiri kaftan that is hand-embroidered goes for about $45, and cheaper models cost as little as $20. Colorful hand-painted Rajasthani jewelry boxes sell for $20 to $40. And you can pay from a few dollars to $500 for sari-length silk and hand-woven cottons.
 
China. With the devaluation of the yuan in December and a Government-imposed austerity program, the dollar now goes a lot further in China. And because tourists have generally stayed away after the upheaval last spring, most places have kept their prices down - although prices may rise because of the 11th Asian Games, which are scheduled for Sept. 22 to Oct. 7.
For lodging in Beijing, the best buys are Chinese hotels like the Huadu ($40 a night for a double) and the New Exhibition Center Hotel ($45). There is also a 10 percent service charge, but tipping is not allowed. The New Exhibition Hotel's rate includes breakfast and airport pickup but inform it in advance of arrival. The Jianguo Hotel charges what is considered a moderate $99 plus a 10 percent service fee. The Palace Hotel costs $160 a night plus a 15 percent charge. Both prices do not include breakfast.
Food, like Peking duck, is cheap and delicious. Local wines and those produced jointly with Remy Martin cost less than half the price of imports. Restaurants in moderately priced hotels and local restaurants catering to tourists are good choices.
Beijing has several joint-venture restaurants with foreign partners like Windows on the World, Dongfang, Ren Ren, Pearl and China Tea House that offer excellent dim sum lunches for less than $6 a person.
The cheapest way to get around is to rent a bike at 65 cents to $1 a day, plus a refundable $42 deposit. Taxis are reasonable, too: you can hire one for about $40 a day. For a guided tour of Beijing, try the City Bus Tour. A $4.25 ticket allows you to get off at a stop and resume the trip on another bus.
 
Kenya. Nairobi, the capital of Kenya, remains relatively reasonable. At the popular Carnivore Restaurant, which specializes in dishes like antelope, zebra and crocodile but also has vegetarian entrees, a meal for two with wine recently cost $39.
A basic room with two single beds costs $133 a night at the Norfolk Hotel, the most luxurious in town (telephone, from the United States, 254-2-335422). At the moderately priced Fairview (254-2-723211) - one mile from the city's center, with five acres of gardens - a double costs $42.85.
Camping trips are relatively inexpensive and can be arranged through any travel agent around town. In general, $250 a day a person will buy an individualized safari: a tented camp where your group will be the only guests, provisions for three meals a day and game rides in Range Rovers.

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By JOHN BRANNON ALBRIGHT

 BODY:

On Horseback in Alaska
Q. This summer I would like to go horseback riding in Alaska. Can you suggest places that offer trail rides? - G. S., New York, N.Y.
A. Alaska is so vast you would think there would be many places renting horses, but the state's Division of Tourism was hard put to find them. Here are three possibilities:
SeaHorse Riding Adventures, Post Office Box 122, Gustavus, Alaska 99826 (907-697-2266), has a stable of six horses and arranges rides for up to five people. All rides are guided, mostly along beaches in Glacier Bay National Park and on a few back roads. Gustavus, the gateway to Glacier Bay, is about 50 miles west of Juneau, accessible by air or water. 
Rides last one to four hours, and rates range from $25 for one hour to $75 for four hours ($20 to $65 for children). Although the company does not arrange overnight rides, Nate Borson, the vice president, said visitors could extend their trips by staying at an inn or bed and breakfast establishment and could go riding every day, take a kyacking trip or go fishing.
South Fork Outfit, Mile 110 Glenn Highway, HCO3 Box 8485, Palmer, Alaska 99645 (907-745-6323), has 20 horses and takes groups (minimum of 4; maximum, preferrably, of 10, although more can be accommodated) on trail rides of a day or more at $100 a person a day. The price includes horses, bedding and food. Overnight trips stop at cabins once used by trappers. The season is from the first of June to the end of October, according to Mark Meekin, son of the founder of the company, which started in 1945. An average ride lasts three to five days, but Mr. Meekin said he would custom-fit a trip to the visitor's wishes, offering among other things stream fishing, fossil hunting and wildlife photography. Palmer is about 115 miles northeast of Anchorage. South Fork Outfit will pick visitors up in Anchorage and provide room and board overnight at a lodge for $150 a person.
Matanuska Riding Stables, Post Office Box 3498, Palmer, Alaska 99645 (907-376-2946), has 29 horses and takes up to 20 riders on the trail at once. Day rides at $15 an hour for each horse until April 15, $20 an hour after April 15, are offered from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. every day year round. Overnight rides are $100 a person a day for a minimum of two people. Rates are for guide and horses only. Visitors must bring their own tents and sleeping bags and supply their own food.
Among attractions in the region used by both South Fork Outfit and Matanuska Riding Stables are glaciers, wildlife (moose, coyotes, rabbits) and the Wrangell Mountains, the Talkeetna Mountains and the Chugach Mountains. At times it is possible to see Mount McKinley.
A free vacation guide is offered by the State of Alaska; write Division of Tourism, Box E-529, Juneau, Alaska 99811 or phone 907-465-2010.
 
Van Rental in Portugal
Q. We are two couples leaving for Portugal on May 1 for 10 days. We want to rent a minivan (Ford Aerostar size) to hold four suitcases and four carry-on bags. Our travel agent says only nine-passenger vans are available and suggests we rent a Ford Orion. Would that be big enough? - B. S., Philadelphia
A. Officials of both Hertz and Avis say that a car the size of the Ford Orion (considered full size) should handle your luggage. The trunk space is 18 or so cubic feet, sufficient for four suitcases and at least some of the carry-on bags. The interior holds four or five passengers, so there would probably be room for some of the carry-on bags in the passenger compartment.
The Orion that Hertz offers has a manual transmission and gets about 32 miles to the gallon. The full-size car offered by Avis would probably be a VW or an Audi. Hertz quoted a weekly rate of $364, which pro rated for 10 days would be $520. Avis declined to quote a rate without knowing more particulars, such as pickup and dropoff spots.
The large van you mentioned is probably a Ford Transit (offered by Hertz) or a VW Transporter (offered by Avis). The Transit has automatic transmission, three doors, seats for nine passengers and room for five suitcases. Its mileage is rated at 20 miles to the gallon. The Hertz rate: $625 a week, $893 for 10 days.
A local agency, Europcar (24 Avenue Antonio Augusto Aguiar, 1097 Lisbon, Portugal; telephone from the United States: 011-351-1-524558), offers a seven-passenger Peugeot 505 station wagon that would undoubtedly meet your needs. A spokeswoman said the rates for May 1 would not be available until the end of March.
 
Flying Around the World
Q. Are there still round-the-world plane tickets? If so, who offers them and what restrictions apply? - E. B. E., New York, N.Y.
A. Many airlines, usually in conjunction with other carriers, offer round-the-world tickets - on two major routes: North Pacific and South Pacific. United Airlines, for example, has agreements with Air France, Air New Zealand, Alitalia, British Airways, Cathay Pacific, KLM, Lufthansa, Pan American, S.A.S. and Qantas. North Pacific fares are $2,204 in economy class, $3,102 in business class and $4,304 in first class. For the South Pacific: $2,784, $4,441 and $5,782, respectively. Northwest and Air France offer a North Pacific route in economy class only ($2,099).
Round-the-world tickets are good for a year from date of first use but must be purchased at least 21 days before that. Outside the United States, there is a wide choice of stopovers, but backtracking is not permitted. After setting an itinerary, you may make one change without penalty; subsequent changes cost $25.
Airline reservations representatives or a travel agent can work out details. British Airways, for example, maintains a round-the-world desk: 800-247-9297.
 
Tennis and Italy
Q. I plan to visit Milan in the fall. Could you give me a list of tennis resorts in northern Italy? F. W. B., Boseman, Mont.
A. Had you asked about golf, said a spokesman for the Italian Government Travel Office in New York, the task would be easy. The office publishes lists of golf courses but not tennis resorts because there are so many of them. Every town has at least one court. Many hotels have courts, and there are many private and public clubs.
The place to look is the telephone book. In the white pages they are listed under ''Tennis'' or ''Tennis Club.'' In the yellow pages, they are under ''Impianti Sportivi'' (sports establishments) and grouped with gymnastic clubs, horseback riding clubs and the like. In the white pages of the Milan phone book, for example, about 25 tennis clubs are listed.

HEADLINE: OLDER CHILDREN AND DIVORCE

 BODY:
It seems to me that Barbara S. Cain's article ''Older Children and Divorce'' (Feb. 18) does not add anything new to that tired subject. We all know that everyone suffers in a divorce. However, everyone suffers growing up. The young people mentioned in your article might have had different problems in nondivorcing families, but problems they would have had.
In the United States, we have allowed Hollywood to set our standards. We think we all should have ''perfect'' families like those in ''Leave It to Beaver'' and ''Father of the Bride.'' So we set ourselves up for disappointment.
Certainly, some of the marriages described in your article were better off ending in divorce. The real problem is with the state of marriage as defined in our society. It is an economic agreement endowed with all the false sentiments of a bad Grade B movie.
 
N.E. HALL
 New Canaan, Conn.

HEADLINE: The Politics of Pornography

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Donald Alexander Downs's so-called research on the politics of pornography is largely made up of the favorite fantasies and fabrications of its defenders. His ignorance of the realities of these politics is maintained by apparently talking to no one who wrote, sponsored, organized or testified for the ordinance against pornography that is his topic. The review by Franklin E. Zimring - another of pornography's defenders - of ''The New Politics of Pornography'' (Jan. 28) takes Mr. Downs's misrepresentations as fact. Both book and review might best be understood in the context of the public relations initiative - which cost upwards of a million dollars - by the Media Coalition, a group whose goal is to defend ''sexually explicit'' speech. One of its disinformation strategies is to put feminists who oppose pornography in bed with the right. 
Among the many legislators with whom we have worked on the ordinance, one is a political conservative. She was selected by the Mayor of Indianapolis to get the bill passed. We were honored to work with her. The ordinance was originally sponsored in Minneapolis by a progressive white Republican woman and a black Democratic man. Wherever it is introduced, liberals and conservatives vote both for it and against it. If the right supported the ordinance, we would have a lot more resources, credibility, money and votes. We have found most conservatives far more uncomfortable with sex equality than with pornography.
We did our best to influence former Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d's Commission on Pornography to listen to women, with some success. Our ''sin'' is in building a women's politics that is as indifferent to left and right as pornography's harm to women is. That is ''the new politics of pornography,'' but Mr. Downs misses it.
Mr. Zimring wonders what we have been doing the last five years. While pornography's defenders have got fat off the virtual academic cottage industry called ''the pornography issue,'' its opponents have been trying to survive in the face of being libeled, fired, evicted, impoverished, harassed, vilified, unemployed and unpublished. The erasure by Mr. Zimring of the role of the feminist writer Andrea Dworkin, who was co-author of the ordinance with me, is a part of this. And the lie that we are in bed with the right never stops, and never stops growing.
 
CATHARINE A. MACKINNON
New Haven

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:

Institutional Apartments
Question: Can institutions like schools and hospitals hold leases on rent-stabilized apartments and sublet them to teachers or nurses, or do leases have to be in the name of individuals to comply with the law? . . . M. S., Manhattan
Answer: According to Thomas R. Viola, a spokesman for the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, the Rent Stabilization Code has no prohibition against renting to an institution. However, the institution would have to conform to the normal rules of subletting. Those rules include obtaining the landlord's consent and limiting the sublet to two years out of four. But the code gives greater latitude to not-for-profit hospitals. Section 2525.6 (g) 1 of the code lets these institutions sublet to affiliated personnel without the landlord's consent and with no time limit. Schools, hospitals and other institutions that hold net leases on entire buildings are exempt from subletting rules as long as units are rented to affiliated personnel. 
 
From Co-op to Condo
Question: We wish to change our 11-family cooperative corporation into a condominium association. There would be no financial gain or loss for any of us. Is this possible and, if so, how do we go about it? . . . M. J., Monroe, N.Y.
Answer: According to a spokesman for the New York State Attorney General, a co-op can be converted to a condominium. The process requires filing an application for a tenant-sponsored condominium conversion plan with the Attorney General's Real Estate Financing Bureau. However, Stuart Saft, a lawyer who has guided a few co-ops through this process, suggested that you carefully consider the time and money involved.
''I can think of only one reason why this would be worth the effort,'' said Mr. Saft, ''and that would be to circumvent the 80-20 rule.'' This Internal Revenue Service regulation limits the commercial income of a residential co-op for such things as store rents to no more than 20 percent of its gross income. Mr. Saft said that before you convert, the shareholders would have to pay off the building's mortgage because condominiums do not have mortgages. Then all shareholders would have to convert shares to mortgages on their units.
Moreover, the condominium plan, Mr. Saft said, would have to meet the standards of such city agencies as the Departments of Buildings and Health. It would also have to include new architectural drawings, even if no new construction was involved. Mr. Saft said such a conversion would require a no-action letter from the Attorney General's office indicating that the co-op's plan did not involve the sale of units, as well as a private ruling letter from the Internal Revenue Service confirming that the transaction would be tax-free.
''Unless this co-op is facing a serious financial problem if they remain a co-op,'' he said, ''I would recommend against the conversion.''
 
Broken Leases
Question: I own a two-family house and rent the upstairs apartment. I have had problems with tenants who leave before leases are up or who use their security deposits as the last month's rent. Are the standard leases they sign binding? . . . R. T., Springfield, N.J.
Answer: Yes. According to David R. Smith, a lawyer who specializes in real estate matters, as long as the lease has been signed by both parties it is a legally binding contract. Security deposits are supposed to cover the cost or repair for any damage done over and above normal wear and tear on apartments.
''A landlord would have the right to sue,'' said Mr. Smith. ''But even if the chances of prevailing in court are good, the cost of litigation is often not worth it.''
