SECTION: Section 10; Page 1, Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 2498 words

HEADLINE: Development Slowdown Offers Planners a Breather

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
FOR the last five or six years local planning boards in the New York metropolitan area have been too busy wrangling with builders, worrying about the voters and wrestling with a host of new state environmental protection laws to think through a coherent new vision of the future of their communities.
But as the rush to build has slackened, some planning agencies are seizing the time they now have to assess where the boom of the 1980's has left them and to prepare for the next surge of development.
For the impression is widespread among both developers and planners that the current slowdown is just a dip in the building cycle - a pause to let demand catch up with an oversupply of houses and office space - rather than a long-term decline in the region's economy.
Indeed, some local officials say they are already seeing a new wave of applications for commercial, hotel and retail space being prepared by developers for the expected upturn. Many of the applications are prompted by the desire of developers to win approvals before environmental laws and zoning rules, already tightened during the boom, are tightened further. 
But with the slower pace of development offering a least a little slack time for planners and politicians, communities in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are looking for new solutions to old problems of congestion, high planning costs and environmental degredation.
Among these initiatives are making the builders of several neighboring projects jointly plan ways to mitigate the impact of traffic instead of making the municipality do it; seeking curbs on the growth of wasteful one-occupant commuter traffic on busy roads and moving to protect fragile wetlands from development before the market strengthens.
Lee E. Koppelman, executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board and the dean of regional planners, noted the odd juxtaposition of a slack market and an active development community.
''Interestingly enough, as far as Long Island is concerned,'' he said, ''we have a substantial irony in the fact that - despite the fact that development is in the doldrums and that in many areas there is a surplus of commercial office space - we have been getting applications for more commercial projects in a shorter time now than we've had before.''
Still, he said, the slump is clear for all to see, and with it a mandate for planners that is in some ways harder to achieve than when the market is jumping.
''When the economy is moving upwards, it is not the planners who create wealth, they only define objectives,'' he said. ''When the economy is in danger of sliding downhill, the planners have an even more important role - to make sure the slide doesn't ruin the quality of life they worked to achieve.''
Similar thoughts were expressed by planners in other parts of the region.
''IN the decade of the 80's the planning boards were subjected to a great deal of pressure from a flow of development applications that made the flaws in the system very apparent,'' said Samuel L. Hamill Jr., executive director of the Middlesex Somerset Mercer Regional Council, a nonprofit planning consulting group active in central New Jersey.
''The planning boards didn't really have time to deal with some of the more fundamental questions,'' he said, ''such as revisions in master plans and taking advantage of many of the new statutes that have come into effect in the 80's. Now that applications have dropped somewhat we have a little time to address ourselves to planning for the next boom.''
And a boom it has been. Northern and central New Jersey alone built 34 million square feet of commercial office space from the beginning of 1986 through 1989, outbuilding even Manhattan, which produced 24.2 million square feet in the same period. When commercial construction in Westchester and Fairfield Counties is included, the metropolitan area including Manhattan added 72.8 million square feet of commercial space during those four years of rapid growth.
New Jersey added nearly 180,000 new housing units, both detached houses and apartments, during the same period, with many of the new units rising in the suburbs of Atlantic City, which has been undergoing a gambling-driven development surge. Westchester County, meanwhile, saw some 12,000 new houses and apartments rise from 1986 to the end of last year, while for Fairfield County the number was 10,700.
For some planning departments, the slowdown that has followed this building frenzy has brought a welcome chance to catch up with demands neglected during the boom and to devise new strategies for coping with the next wave of development most municipalities believe is headed their way.
Some of the new departures follow:
* Lawrence Township, just outside Trenton and astride the Interstate 295-Route 1 highway network, is set to ask several major local corporations to draw up a joint traffic-impact plan on any new expansions in the area before approaching the town planning board. This means that corporate neighbors will have to talk to one another before separately seeking development approvals.
* The eight communities that make up Connecticut's South West Regional Planning Agency - an umbrella group composed of the Towns of Greenwich, Stamford, Darien, New Canaan, Wilton, Weston, Westport and Norwalk - have banded together to devise ways to reduce both interstate trucking and single-occupant commuter traffic on congested Interstate 95.
* On Long Island, environmental officials are mapping out new zones of protection for wetlands - an issue in all three states - before the next wave of office, housing and road building pushes makes the job of protecting fragile land areas more difficult.
For residents tired of growth and congestion, these initiatives may seem long overdue. But many developers believe that what the region needs now that there is a slump is not more, but fewer, planning constraints.
''The real estate sector has already been pummeled by public policy,'' said Pat O'Keefe, executive director of the New Jersey Builders Association. ''The question is no longer managing growth; the question confronting us now is getting some growth.''
Regional planners agree that many of the environmental quality-control laws that took effect in the 80's were enacted in response to the surge in development during the second half of the decade but were never fully integrated into local planning decisions because of the pace of work.
By all accounts, New Jersey has now taken the lead from Connecticut in state efforts to coordinate economic development planning and rational growth management. Starting with the 1979 act to protect the state's 1.1 million acres of pinelands from overdevelopment, the country's most densely populated state has since enacted several further measures to protect the environment.
These laws limit coastal development, set aside open space, regulate highway access, stringently protect wetlands and, under the 1985 State Planning Act, establish a ''cross-acceptance'' framework requiring municipalities, counties and state agencies to coordinate planning efforts.
Hartford's planning law, the State Plan for the Conservation and Development of Connecticut, dates from the early 70's. Although its rules largely govern actions by state agencies, it has inspired broad regional planning alliances in the state's urbanized southwest.
In New York, the State Environmental Quality Review Act, known as S.E.Q.R.A., was enacted in 1978. But it took full effect in the early 80's as a wetlands and water quality protection measure and has since been only modestly enlarged to cover historical and archeological sites.
''The thing about S.E.Q.R.A. is that its real potential is not really known yet, and this is true of all regulatory processes,'' said Hooper Brooks, who heads the environmental planning office at the Regional Plan Association, a nonprofit planning advisory group that covers the metropolitan region. ''You don't really get to see how good they are until you see what the courts do with them.''
In New Jersey, George Ververides, director of the Middlesex County Planning Board, recalled the economic slump, far more serious than today's, that followed the oil embargo of 1973 and 1974, prompting widespread predictions that suburban sprawl was at an end.
At the depths of the slump, he said, developers were still active along Route 1, the county's growth corridor, acquiring and assembling building sites for the upturn they seemed to know would come.
''They were buying up the land and putting large pieces together and we would not have had all the development here if they had not been out there, getting ready for the next boom,'' Mr. Ververides said.
''I feel this is a tremendous opportunity that has come to us because right at this moment the whole state plan is coming into play, and all of us now have a little time to pull away from the routine site plan work and think about what we're going to do in the county.''
Jerry Lenaz, a Princeton planning consultant for several central New Jersey township planning boards, said the breather in development has allowed some planning boards to consider sophisticated planning approaches.
One would be to apply project staging - a common requirement for big developments to be built out in phases according to a schedule - to small housing projects. The process allows planners to measure the impact of a project as it procedes and adjust environmental rules with the developer.
Massachussetts planning law now allows municipalities to build even small housing projects in phases to lessen sudden impacts on nearby communities, and Mr. Lenaz believes New Jersey townships should trythe same approach. This might be accomplished by tying permission to begin construction on one or two houses to the completion of road improvements, or limiting new houses to one or two per year to reduce the sudden impact on roads, sanitation and schools.
''SOME towns are taking this pause in the activity to update their master plans,'' Mr. Lenaz said. ''They're thinking, 'What do we have left, what's special about the remaining properties and how do we want to guide the remaining development in our community?' ''
One lesson of the boom years that several planners said would remain with them during the next upsurge in construction, assuming it comes, is the likelihood of increased pressures on developers to pay still more in impact fees to get approval of a project. Mr. Koppelman of the Long Island Regional Planning Board advanced another argument for vigilance during moments when the pace of development slows. Planning for development has two parts, he maintained, one designed to manage the ride to prosperity, and, once prosperity is achieved, to maintain that prosperity.
''Obviously you need careful planning when the market is active, but when things are slack there is an equal need,'' Mr. Koppleman said. ''Long Island has built to a crescendo where it has been defined in national surveys as one of the top communities in quality. So once you're there, the question becomes, how do you stay there?
''New York State has a budget crisis, Washington is pulling back, there's a softening in the real estate market, Long Island taxpayers are in revolt. The whole point of planning is not only to have stable growth, but to have the community remain stable at the level of quality that you've achieved.''
It would be easier for Long Island to protect its position today, Mr. Koppelman said, if it had listened to him earlier. In 1967, he said, Long Island planners had a blueprint for a ''perfect'' transportation system - electrifying all commuter rail lines, building separate grade crossings on all major highways and at least one bridge across the western Long Island Sound at Oyster Bay and providing high-speed ferry service to Connecticut farther east. The price was $2 billion, a figure that today would pay for the cross-Sound bridge and little more, considering the price of land.
''Real estate in Nassau County today is selling for $1 million an acre,'' Mr. Koppelman said. ''If you want to build a full cloverleaf intersection, that takes 100 acres, so you can see it immediately becomes impossible, and the best we can build are these diamond slip-offs.''
Mr. Koppleman described diamond slip-offs as a poor man's cloverleaf consisting of exit and entrance ramps, often controlled by traffic lights, and lacking the outer ramps of a cloverleaf that permit motorists to enter and exit an interchange without stopping.
Beyond the wall maps and bulging binders of the planner's office, meanwhile, many developers are already looking ahead to the next project.
Trammell Crow Residential Group of Dallas, a major housing developer nationwide, broke ground in November for Steward's Crossing, a 240-unit rental development built on land leased from Rider College in Lawrenceville, between Princeton and Trenton, in central New Jersey.
Why build now, at a time when the inventory of unsold houses in the area is high?
''I don't believe anybody's crystal ball is too good these days, but I do believe in the underlying demographics of central New Jersey,'' said Kevin Tucker, a principal in the project. Getting planning approvals is becoming more and more involved and time-consuming, he said, but once they have been achieved, logic argues in favor of going ahead, to have the project completed in time for the upturn. Mr. Tucker believes that will not come until well into next year.
ROBERT S. POWELL JR., president of DKM Properties, based in Lawrenceville, said that a project that took eight months to get approved five years ago now takes two or three years.
''It doesn't take any longer to get approval for a 60,000-square-foot office building standing alone than to get approval for 600,000 or 700,000 square feet in several buildings to be built out over seven years,'' he said. ''The problem is that it takes three years to approve a single building and one year to build it, so unless you have your approvals already lined up for other buildings, you can find yourself out of work.''
DKM Properties accordingly has applications before the state, which regulates wetlands, and Lawrence Township, which plans for Lawrenceville, to build 360,000 square feet of office space. It would be developed in three new buildings at Princeton Pike Corporate Center, at the intersection of Interstate 296 and Princeton Pike.
Mr. Powell believes the office market in central New Jersey is already recovering from a hard year of high vacancies, and he wants to be ready for the recovery.
''It really makes a lot of planning sense, if you're going to be in this business, to deal in projects that are long term,'' he said. ''That way you can address your planning issues up front and get your approvals in place, so when you find the market picking up you can move forward on your own schedule.''

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: A Theater Rescued;
Wreckers Foiled Again!

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. LYONS

 BODY:
The Lincoln Theater, a 65-year-old former playhouse in New Haven, has dodged the wrecker's ball and, in the best tradition of melodrama, has been revived - as the Little Theater on Lincoln Street.
In 1982, New Haven sought to demolish the 232-seat theater in the name of urban renewal and use its site for housing. But community groups mobilized to preserve the building, arguing successfully that it deserved to be saved because it was a true civic asset.
The theater had been erected in 1925 with money raised by residents who created the Little Theater Guild of New Haven. It showed films from 1935 to 1982. The preservationists said it would make little sense to tear it down since almost 100 local performing arts groups, lacking a proper theater, were then using church basements and high school auditoriums to stage their productions.
The building and its English Free Style facade was preserved, while the interior was updated with new sound and lighting equipment in a $1.2 million renovation paid for by the state. It is to be used as a theater by the Educational Center for the Arts, a regional high school for the artistically talented supported by 27 school districts in the New Haven area. The local Area Cooperative Educational Services will own the building, which also will be used by community arts groups.
A formal dedication is being planned in April.

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Columbia's Research Park;
A 'Spec' Building Planned for Audubon Theater Site

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
ITS purpose and location alone would make the Audubon Research Building noteworthy: a speculative commercial development in Washington Heights.
But because the six-story laboratory building, developed by Columbia University, would replace the abandoned Audubon Theater and Ballroom - where the black nationalist leader Malcolm X was assassinated in 1965 and where William Fox began building the entertainment empire that became 20th Century-Fox - the project has drawn not only attention but also criticism.
The critics believe that the theater is too valuable to be razed, given its significance to the civil-rights movement and its distinctive architecture. They also worry about the disposal of laboratory wastes.
Members of the City Planning Commission have also expressed some concern about the disposal question. For Columbia's project to proceed, the commission would have to rezone what is now a residential block to commercial, amend the Zoning Resolution to allow a ''scientific research and development facility'' in the commercial zone by special permit, approve a permit for the block in question - bounded by Broadway, St. Nicholas Avenue, 165th and 166th Street - and approve disposition of the city-owned property. The land-use review procedure has begun on the project and if the community board acts within 60 days, the matter will ultimately wind up at the Board of Estimate. 
The Audubon building would be the first element in what Columbia envisions as a four-block research park between 165th and 168th Streets, across Broadway from the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. The new complex, around Mitchel Park, would have three university laboratories, a doctors' office building and two garages.
It is the first phase, however, that may be the most unusual. ''What's new here is that this would be a speculative building,'' said H. Bernhard Haeckel, Columbia's director of office project development and coordination. ''I am not aware of a multitenant laboratory building in any university setting.''
More typically, a university leases land in its research park to a private company or developer, which puts up its own building.
Tenants in the Audubon building will probably be small companies doing research in cellular and molecular biophysics, genetics, immunology, cancer, biochemistry or microbiology. New York State, a partner in the project, has required that 40 percent of the space be leased to start-up companies.
City Councilman Stanley E. Michels, the Democrat who represents the area, said: ''I look at it as a chance to redevelop without displacing anybody, to fix up the general area - which has gotten into a depressed state - and to provide jobs.'' It is an opportunity for Washington Heights ''to break into the commercial end of things,'' he said.
The Audubon Research Building, 115 feet high, would have some 100,000 square feet. It would be faced in buff brick, with patterns echoing the modernist motifs of nearby architecture. At top would be a large metal-clad exhaust-fan housing, with ranks of stainless-steel stacks above. The architects are Perkins & Will, in association with Bond, Ryder and Associates, both of Manhattan.
THE new building would take up the north half of the theater site. The south half would be used as a parking lot, pending development of a 200,000-square-foot addition. The block is owned by the city and would be leased to Columbia for 99 years.
The $25 million cost would be met by Columbia University, with $4.5 million in equity and $2.5 million in borrowing; the city's Public Development Corporation, with $10 million and the state's Urban Development Corporation, with $8 million.
If the project returns less than 2 percent a year on the investment, 20 percent of any proceeds after expenses and debt service would go to Columbia, with 80 percent going to the city and state. For any return in excess of 2 percent a year, Columbia's share of the proceeds would rise to 25 percent.
''The P.D.C. and the U.D.C. see themselves as capital venturers in this enterprise,'' said Victor Marrero, of Brown & Wood of Manhattan, a lawyer for Columbia.
Among potential tenants, Mr. Haeckel said, are small, start-up companies; established companies that want a ''research lab outpost'' near the medical center and international companies that are ''eager to establish a foothold and view Columbia University as a prestigious institution with which to associate.''
Just being across Broadway would mean little if there were not some entree to the medical center. Mr. Haeckel said tenants would be able to use the library, attend some seminars and have other ''clearly defined amenities,'' some free, some for a fee.
One important service, he said, would be an environmental health and safety office to work with tenants, as they ''will have to comply with the large number of Federal, state and city regulations dealing with the use and disposal of hazardous materials.''
The disposal of biomedical waste was the focus of a preliminary discussion by the City Planning Commission last month. ''I think you're getting concern about the safety aspects,'' Denise M. Scheinberg, the acting chairwoman of the commission, told Columbia's representatives. ''This might be considered an unusual location for such a facility.'' There is another concern about the project: that it would require the demolition of the Audubon Theater, whose facade is filled with exuberant terra-cotta figures: foxes, griffins and an enormous sea-borne female figure before an ancient sailing ship.
''AT least some of it will be preserved and fit into the design of the interior of the building,'' said Lee Silberstein, vice president of the Public Development Corporation, about the terra-cotta work.
The Audubon Theater is not a landmark. The Landmarks Preservation Commission discussed it in the early 1980's but took no action, although its staff later called for salvaging of the terra cotta. Today, demolition seems all but inevitable. But Edward Kaufman, of the Municipal Art Society, said: ''We would really like to see some significant portion of the building preserved. And I don't mean fragments of terra cotta. I mean the exterior.''
Mr. Kaufman cited the building's role in the careers of William Fox and Thomas Lamb, one of the country's foremost theatrical architects. Even more important, he said, was its connection to Malcolm X, who was shot in the ballroom during a rally of his Organization of Afro-American Unity.
The Audubon's place in the ''martyrology of the civil-rights movement,'' he said, was equal to that of the Lorraine Motel in Memphis, where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated in 1968.
''It's a landmark that is uniquely representative of the African-American experience of struggle,'' said Michael Adams, a preservationist in upper Manhattan. ''There are few such landmarks one can identify as such in the city. If this building is allowed to go down, it will be a tragedy.''
Speaking for Councilwoman C. Virginia Fields, a Democrat whose district includes Harlem, Mr. Adams added, ''All too often, institutions like Columbia University and other interests offer vague promises of economic development and jobs at the expense of the community's cultural and architectural heritage.''
Mr. Haeckel, of Columbia, said ''the university is committed to provide a suitable, appropriate memorial to Malcolm X at that site,'' in addition to doubling an existing $250,000 Malcolm X scholarship.
Preservation of the theater was contemplated in Columbia's original plan. Since then, Mr. Haeckel said, it was determined that this would ''not be economically feasible within the limits of available funding.''
But Mr. Kaufman said: ''The public is putting in $18 million. If the public decides that saving the facades or even more of the building is a public purpose, for Columbia to say it's economically infeasible is just not relevant.''

HEADLINE: End Seen To Slump For Cars

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
AUTOMOBILE sales around Connecticut are still in a slump, but dealers say they are quietly optimistic that business will improve this spring.
''There's very guarded optimism that the spring and the summer will bring a renewed market,'' the executive vice president of the Connecticut Automotive Trades Association in Hartford, Stephen F. Gabriel, said last week. ''There's a lot of new models coming into the market which may attract new buyers. We still have rebate programs.'' 
Mr. Gabriel spoke one week after soft sales prompted a Norwalk auto dealer to file a voluntary bankruptcy petition in United States Bankruptcy Court in Bridgeport, the first such petition in Connecticut.
Bayer Cadillac-Oldsmobile, doing busines as Bayer Jeep Eagle, filed for protection from creditors on Feb. 28.
 
Depressed Market
''Automobile sales right now are very soft,'' the company's owner, Stephen Bayer, said in the filing. ''I have a large built-in overhead, which makes it very difficult to meet your obligations.''
Mr. Gabriel said he would not be surprised if other petitions were filed, given the market condition.
''It wouldn't be shocking if one or two more appeared,'' he said. ''The last year, year and a half, has been pretty much a continually depressed market, and depending on someone's economic condition going into such a long, depressed period, sometimes this is inevitable.''
Mr. Gabriel said sales in the state had been climbing since 1984, with a peak of 215,000 new cars and vans sold in 1986. But sales fell to 188,945 vehicles in 1988 and 164,983 last year.
 
Postponed Purchases
The establishment of 60-month financing kept people driving their cars longer, he said. ''Sometimes, even if they thought about trading it in halfway through that period, they felt they owed more money than the car was worth, so that would make them postpone their purchase a little bit longer,'' he said.
The 14-year-old Bayer company filed under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code, which allows it to reorganize while being protected from creditors. Stephen Bayer said in the petition he would use the filing ''to rid myself of some of my non-performing assets and get back into business.''
Mr. Gabriel said there are signs that the slump may have bottomed out, providing a better market. Nationwide, car and truck sales fell 4.7 percent last month, but sales usually pick up in March and April, when winter weather begins to break, and Americans hit the road.
A spokesman in the State Motor Vehicles Department, Andrew Nelson, said the showroom was packed with customers at Newman Lincoln-Mercury in East Hartford when he brought his car in for service on President's Day.
''We were pretty busy,'' said the general manager, Dick LaQuerre, whose dealership offered free service and maintenance deals that day. ''In fact, we found out in the last month we were the No. 1 Topaz volume dealer in the whole United States. We sold something like 63.''
Mr. LaQuerre said he was optimistic that business will pick up for dealers around Connecticut, ''provided everybody has some good values.''

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT Q&A: JAMES LEAHY;
Keeping Track of the Sound's Polluters

BYLINE: By ANDI RIERDEN

 BODY:
THE effort to save Long Island Sound demands more aggressive action by state and Federal environmental agencies as well as a commitment by industries to obey clean-water laws, says a study by the Connecticut Public Interest Research Group. The study, called the Campaign to Save Long Island Sound, found that 84 percent of Connecticut companies with permits to dump waste into state waterways violated the environmental laws, said James Leahy, the organization's executive director.
A review of the 121 companies involved showed that nearly 50 percent were routine violators, he said. Conducted by a team of scientists, engineers and environmental advocates, the five-month study examined Federal and state reports along with companies' self-monitoring reports.
The nonprofit organization, which has 45,000 members in Connecticut, conducts research and lobbies for environmental and consumer-protection regulations. Mr. Leahy, 27 years old, oversees campaigns for hazardous-waste cleanup, pesticide control and consumer rights. A Hartford resident, he previously served as the regional campaign director for the Public Interest Research Group's office in Washington. 
In an interview at his office in West Hartford, Mr. Leahy discussed the report and the group's proposals to toughen clean-water laws. Here are some excerpts from the conversation:
Q. What was the purpose of the Campaign to Save Long Island Sound?
A. We started in 1988 and focused our attention on assessing the whole problem of cleaning up the Sound instead of trying to solve it one part at a time. From our initial research, we found that there are significant levels of toxins in the Sound. But at the time, most of the attention from environmental groups pinpointed sewage-treatment overflow and urban runoff from highways and cities. However, we felt that it was necessary to focus on the underlying toxics problem that hadn't been looked at for several years in Connecticut. From there, we decided to focus on industries to see if they were complying with the Clean Water Act.
Q. How did you conduct your research?
A. We got our initial figures from the State Department of Environmental Protection and the National Oceanic and Atmosphere Administration, which examines water-quality trends in marine environments throughout the United States. Then we obtained discharge monitoring reports submitted by industries to the D.E.P. These record the amount of industrial pollutants that individual companies are allowed to dump in the waterways. The reports clearly indicated that an upseting number of companies had violated the permit parameters that had been set up for them.
Q. What did you find?
A. There were two studies. One dealt with the direct discharge of toxics into the waterways, and the second dealt with discharge into sewage-treatment plants. In both reports, we found between 80 and 90 percent of companies were either severe or chronic violators. We classified a severe violator as one that has exceeded its permit level by 50 percent or more, and a chronic violator as one who does it four times within six months - in other words, on a routine basis.
From the direct discharge reports, we found that 69 percent of the companies had severe violations, and close to 50 had chronic violations. Forty percent had both severe and chronic violations. We also found that 75 percent of companies that were discharging into local treatment plants had violated their permits.
Q. Who are some of the major violators?
A. One of our case studies was Circuit Wise in North Haven, which has had a series of violations over the course of several years and, as far as we're concerned, has shown no real good-faith effort to address those problems. The First Constitution Bank is now getting blasted because it is running the Save Our Sound campaign and giving loans to Circuit Wise.
Pfizer Pharmaceuticals in Groton is an example of a company that uses lots of chemicals but has made the effort to set up their plant so that its discharge processes work - though they have on occasion been careless. The worst companies in my view are the ones whose plants are running well, yet they don't make sure that they're staying within their standards. But when you get numbers that are saying 80 to 90 percent of companies are violating, it becomes too overwhelming to spotlight a few.
Q. What was the D.E.P.'s reaction to your findings?
A. They were incredibly cooperative throughout the whole process, and they helped make the study possible. They realize that they don't have the staff to enforce clean-water laws, and obviously industries realize that, too. The Water Compliance Bureau is taking significant cuts between now and 1994 because of Federal budget cuts. However, the D.E.P. did collect over $1 million in fines last year, more than they've ever collected.
Q. Does your organization have any alternative solutions to the D.E.P.'s staffing shortages?
A. The Council of Environmental Quality came out with a report that says that in order to fulfill the mandates that are required by the General Assembly, the D.E.P. would need an additional 350 positions, which amounts to a budget increase of $20 million. We have been trying to organize a lobbying effort to get the General Assembly to allow for the extra increase in staff.
We estimate that an extra $20 million in addition to the current D.E.P. budget would equal only 1 percent of the total state budget. We don't think that 1 percent is too much to ask to protect the environment. And from our canvassing efforts, we found that most of the people of Connecticut agree with us on that.
Q. Do fines serve as an effective deterrent?
A. The thing that drives industry is profit. Therefore, these violations have to affect the cost of doing business. Maybe companies are deciding that the fines are O.K. - it's cheaper to pay them than to install the proper pollution mechanisms. Companies are also pretty confident that, even if they report their violations, there's a big chance that they won't be brought to justice.
We've proposed legislation recommending that those fines be increased - that is, if you're a significant or chronic violator, then you should be issued a base fine of $25,000.
The second thing that drives industry is public relations. We'd like to see the D.E.P. put out a report of all companies that violate their permits so that people around the state will know who is protecting the environment and who isn't. If these companies are given a public relations problem, and that causes them to reduce their pollution, then I would say we're doing our job.
Q. How does this affect the Long Island Sound issue?
A. One of the problems of addressing Long Island Sound is that it's always been a coastal issue, with the people on the coast being the most concerned. But all pollution problems in Connecticut affect Long Island Sound, everything from runoff to the pollution of our rivers and streams.
We need to address all those things and realize that not only does everything in Connecticut affect Long Island Sound, but that Long Island Sound affects everything in Connecticut, including a good chunk of our economy, such as our fishing and tourism industries, which rely on the purity of our waterways.
What we're hoping to do with these findings is make Long Island Sound a statewide concern and end this division between the coastal part of the state and the interior part of the state. That way, I think the issue will be addressed more quickly.
Q. How does the environment compare to 1972, when the first Clean Water Act was passed?
A. It's much better. The problems in the 1970's were incredible in terms of the amount of pollution that was going unchecked into our rivers and streams and oceans. But even with these laws and the E.P.A. and D.E.P. in place, we've still got miles to go. These agencies were like slapping a gauze pad onto a bleeding wound to keep the patient from bleeding to death. Right now, we're in a situation where the wound is still open. It's no longer bleeding, but you have to watch it constantly and try your best to heal it.
Q. You grew up in Milford. Would you still swim in Long Island Sound?
A. I've swum in Long Island Sound all my life, and, yes, I would do so now. However, people don't always do what's best for them.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: March 11, 1990

SECTION: Section 8; Page 7, Column 1; Sports Desk

LENGTH: 1577 words

HEADLINE: BASEBALL NOTEBOOK;
Pay Cut Is Now a Seldom-Used Tool

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Rich Gedman, the Boston catcher who has forgotten how to hit, suffered the maximum 20 percent pay cut this year, his salary plummeting from $1.15 million to $920,000. Life wasn't always so cruel to Gedman. In 1988, he batted .231 and drove in 39 runs and got a raise, from $980,000 to $1.15 million.
The raise was more representative of today's salary practices than the 20 percent cut. The maximum cut is a seldom used economic weapon. Salary cuts of any dimension have had little use in recent years.
The relative absence of pay cuts is a curious development at a time when owners complain about escalating salaries, mushrooming payrolls and salary arbitration for more players. Clubs, for a variety of reasons, have eschewed the paycut as though, like the spitball, it had been banned from baseball. 
This year, for example, 162 players filed for salary arbitration, and only seven emerged with lower salaries than they had in 1989. Three of those players, including Gedman, have bonus provisions that, if they play often enough, could produce higher incomes than they had last year. Only a handful of other players have taken cuts, including Andy McGaffigan, a Montreal relief pitcher, who like Gedman, signed for 20 percent less.
They are the exceptions, however. Clubs simply don't cut salaries anymore, thus losing a chance to make some dent in their payrolls.
''We will tender a cut if it's a player who had a bad year,'' said Woody Woodward, general manager of the Seattle Mariners, speaking of the initial contracts sent to players in December. ''But we all wind up giving them, at worst, what they made the year before.''
Fred Claire, the Los Angeles Dodgers' general manager, said there were ''very few cases where a club wants to cut a player; it's just not something you want to do.'' In addition, he said, ''the escalation has been so great that going the other way becomes something that is almost out of the question. Everything is moving up so fast, if you can hold the line, you think you're accomplishing something.''
Claire cut one salary this winter. Last year John Shelby earned $550,000, but he batted .183, hit one home run and drove in 12 runs in 345 times at bat. He signed for $500,000, a 9 percent reduction.
The California Angels gave Mike Witt a contract for $90,000 less than the $1.4 million he earned last year after he compiled a 9-15 record and a 4.54 earned run average.
Some general managers are reluctant to cut a player's salary because they think it isn't worth the possible negative reaction the player might have and take on the field with him.
''I would hope you're dealing with someone more mature than that,'' Danny O'Brien, the Angels' senior vice president, said. ''When a guy is on a downswing for a couple of years, most recognize they should have a reduction. Then the problem becomes how much. Some guys say, 'Yeah, I deserve a cut, but don't hurt me.' ''
Jim Frey, the Chicago Cubs' general manager, noted that players who were released and signed with other clubs often signed for smaller salaries, but that was not the same circumstance as a player remaining with a club and accepting less money.
''That is not very likely to happen today,'' Frey said. ''I guess to some extent we're intimidated by the whole set of circumstances today.''
He referred to the options available to a player - salary arbitration after three years, free agency after six.
''If a club doesn't offer a player enough,'' Frey said, ''he goes to arbitration, and it's not likely an arbitrator would give a player less money than he made the year before.''
In the 15-year history of salary arbitration, only nine players have emerged from hearings with pay cuts. Joe Hesketh of Montreal became the ninth last month. Aurelio Lopez was the only player with a cut until 1987, and Orel Hershiser and Alejandro Pena were the only players to have gone the distance with a 20 percent cut.
But not many clubs go into arbitration seeking salary slashes. This year 133 players submitted figures for arbitration (the others settled before reaching that point). In only five instances did their clubs file salary figures lower than their 1989 salaries. Certainly there had to be more than five players in that group who had poor seasons.
General managers say the arbitration system makes it difficult for clubs to press a case for a cut. For example, they explain, if a player has a poor season, he uses his career to argue his case for a raise.
Yet if the clubs would expend as much energy on reinventing the paycut for deserving players as they have on resisting arbitration for a relatively few more players, they might stumble onto a cost-saving device they seemingly never knew existed.
 
Umpires Will Be Paid
Even though the season almost certainly will be delayed because of the owners' lockout, one group crucial to the season will not have their paychecks delayed. Richie Phillips, the umpires' lawyer, said his clients would receive their salaries for at least the first 75 days of the season even if the lockout continues.
That is what the umpires' labor contract provides, Phillips said. He added that the umpires might be entitled to pay beyond that time. Their salaries will cost the leagues a total of more than $25,000 a day, Phillips said.
Umpires do not receive their salaries for working spring exhibition games, but they receive bonuses. The leagues, Phillips said, have refused to pay the bonuses, and he plans to file a grievance seeking that money.
''We have no dispute with the owners,'' the Philadelphia lawyer said. ''They have no dispute with us. They have locked out the players and basically they have locked out the umpires. This is the absurdity of what these people do.''
Phillips did not say how much the umpires earn for working exhibition games.
 
High-Powered Public Relations
The owners' effort at a public-relations bonanza last Thursday was not a rousing success.
When some of baseball's public-relations people suggested moving the second part of the two-pronged news conference from a crammed tiny conference room in the baseball offices to the much more spacious press room at the Helmsley Palace, Howard Rubenstein vetoed the idea. When Howard Rubenstein decided that Charles O'Connor and Bud Selig had answered enough questions, he terminated the news conference.
Rubenstein is the high-powered New York public-relations man (he represents the Donald half of the Trump news media blitz) whom the Player Relations Committee hired last year to advise them on dealing with the news media. He had been working quietly behind the scenes until the owners decided to try to end their lockout with a no-strike pledge from the players.
A gaffe that even Rubenstein couldn't prevent:
The letter that Commissioner Fay Vincent wrote to Selig, the P.R.C. chairman, and Donald Fehr, the union leader, addressing it to both, asking for their mutual efforts to get baseball going, was not delivered to Fehr until the next day. Selig not only had his copy of the letter on time, but he also had his statement accepting the commissioner's request prepared before Vincent announced his offer at the first part of the news conference. Furthermore, when Mark Belanger, a union official, called O'Connor about half an hour before Vincent's news conference, O'Connor acknowledged the news conference, but said, ''It is not about lifting the lockout.''
 
'Go Home and Rest'
The most curious aspect of the stalled negotiations is the relationship between Vincent and Fehr. It almost appears that they should be on the same side of the bargaining table, not on opposite sides. In truth, they probably have more in common than Vincent has with the owners.
On the day of the Rubenstein news conference, Fehr heard that the commissioner looked exhausted and wasn't feeling good. They spoke briefly by telephone, after which Vincent said, ''Donald told me to go home and rest.''
Fehr also went out of his way that day and the next to avoid criticizing Vincent for his action in asking the union for a no-strike pledge. If Bowie Kuhn or Peter Ueberroth had done that, Fehr would have reacted angrily.
But when he was asked if the commissioner's announcement surprised him, Fehr said most mildly, ''In the world in which you work for people, there are political realities.'' In other words, he was saying, blame the owners, not the commissioner.
The next day, Fehr was referring to the letter he belatedly received, signed by Vincent, and said, ''There's nothing in this form letter, although I doubt seriously that Fay wrote it.''
So why can't they settle the dispute? Fred Off the Record Despite mediocre performances, or worse, players see their salaries rise steadily. Here are two examples (the salaries listed are what the players received the year after registering the record on the same line):

And Bear in Mind
 (Editor's choices of other recent books of particular interest.)
LONDON FIELDS, by Martin Amis. (Harmony, $19.95.) Set in the grimmest of possible worlds, (London in 1999, where a global catastrophe - called just "the Crisis" - impends. Mr. Amis's novel pursues its vivid characters through a rich and complicated picaresque tale of destruction and self-destruction.
FIRE & ICE: The Greenhouse Effect, Ozone Depletion and Nuclear Winter, by David E. Fisher. (Harper & Row, $19.95.)
THE NEXT ONE HUNDRED YEARS: Shaping the Fate of Our Living Earth, by Jonathan Weinter. (Bantam, $19.95.) There is, both authors assure us, a scientific consensus about global warming: it's coming. But something can be done, they believe, and these studies passionately and credibly urge attention to a threatening future that many of us seem to have despaired of in advance.
AFTERLIFE, by Paul Monette (Crown, $19.95.) A gallant, painful novel that concerns three "AIDS widowers" trying to reconstruct lives tenuously held in the wake of their lovers' deaths.
THE PARIS REVIEW ANTHOLOGY, edited by George Plimpton (Norton, $25.) THE WRITER'S CHAPBOOK: A Compendium of Fact, Opinion, Wit, and Advice from the 20th Century's Preeminent Writers, edited by George Plimpton (Viking, $19.95.) Much has changed since Mr. Plimpton conceived The Paris Review in 1952, and these volumes - the first in a collection of writing from the magazine, the second compendium from its interviews - are handy, entertaining and high-spirited guides to the last four decades by the engineers of change themselves.
THE QUINCUNX, by Charles Palliser. (Ballantine, $25.) Can you imagine a gigantic (788 pages) imitation of Dickens, abounding in wickedness, full of descriptive power, replete with plot and gratifyingly hard to put down? Mr. Palliser did!

LENGTH: 1906 words

HEADLINE: Groups Unite to Fight Airplane Noise

BYLINE: By BARBARA STURKEN

 BODY:
INCENSED by what they say is an intolerable level of jet noise over their homes, New Jersey residents in dozens of communities have banded together to draw the attention of politicians and government officials to the problem.
The New Jersey Coalition Against Aircraft Noise, organized in early January, is a collection of groups that sprang up to protest extensive rerouting of New York metropolitan region flights three years ago. The revised flight patterns inflicted jet noise for the first time upon areas 30 or 40 miles away from Newark International Airport. But despite a growing number of complaints, the roar of planes overhead continues, the group says.
The situation brings out deep-rooted suspicions held by many New Jerseyans that their state is taking more than its fair share of the New York region's ills. ''New Jersey - a dumping ground once again,'' is how the coalition describes the sentiment. Increased traffic at Kennedy International and La Guardia Airports contributed to the expansion of air lanes over their area, the coalition said. Its members also complain that governmental indifference to jet noise is part of a bigger problem: New Jersey's poor record on environmental issues. 
Kathleen Bergen, a spokeswoman for the Federal Aviation Administration, said that the agency has already modified the routing plan and felt it had already taken effective steps to deal with the noise problem. But she said that an increase in air traffic at Newark meant it would be impossible to go back to the old routes that avoided the areas that were now complaining. ''The system could not absorb the number of departures now scheduled at Newark,'' she said. ''It would be like having a one-lane road instead of a three-lane highway. The flight delays would be tremendous.''
Tomorrow night the coalition is scheduled to meet in the Bernards Township Municipal Building to vent its frustrations before a panel that is expected to include Representatives James A. Courter, Republican of Hackettstown; Marge S. Roukema, Republican of Ridgewood, and Dean A. Gallo, Republican of Parsippany-Troy Hills, as well as representatives from the staffs of Senators Bill Bradley and Frank R. Lautenberg.
''Different politicians are telling us to speak with one voice,'' said Craig Cantoni, president of the noise coalition, explaining the decision to form one citizens' group to fight aircraft noise. The main goal is to win passage of Congressional legislation to roll back the flight plan; the group has also proposed imposing flight curfews, requiring that airlines use quieter jets and expanding the use by commercial aircraft of airspace over the ocean now reserved for the military. Mr. Cantoni estimates that the coalition has a membership of about 3,000. Mr. Cantoni's experience is typical of many of the members of the coalition. A 43-year-old executive of a privately held industrial company, Mr. Cantoni and his wife moved into their home in Basking Ridge more than two years ago and did extensive landscaping in the backyard.
Last summer, he said, he went outside one day and was startled by a sound ''similar to never-ending thunder'' - the incessant drone of aircraft in the skies. He said that as a result, he spent the summer indoors with the air-conditioner on. ''We moved out here to hear the birds,'' not to listen to the ''ugly, obscene noise'' of jet engines, he said. The decibel level of the jets, he says, is similar to that of a vacuum cleaner 10 feet away.
Mr. Cantoni acknowledges that he is a frequent flyer but denies that his travels make him part of the problem he is trying to combat. ''We are not against economic growth of Newark Airport,'' he said. Saying that other communities in the United States have succeeded in curbing jet noise, he said, ''We can work out some kind of mutually agreeable plan'' with the relevant government authorities as well as the airline industry.
 
Layering of Noise
Protests have escalated since early 1987, when the Federal Aviation Administration implemented the Expanded East Coast Plan for the New York metropolitan region's air traffic. The plan was designed to reduce flight delays at Newark, La Guardia and Kennedy Airports by shifting routes over northern and western New Jersey. Many of the complaints that resulted focus on the low altitude of the aircraft, which apparently is caused by a ''layering'' of flights that allows jets destined for New York to fly directly above Newark-bound aircraft, the antinoise coalition said.
More than 1,000 square miles of New Jersey are covered by airline routes, the coalition said. Complaints have come from the northern communities of Boonton and Allendale and from central New Jersey towns like Colts Neck as well. Hunterdon and Somerset Counties have been especially affected, residents say. Communities closer to Newark Airport, like Newark's Ironbound district, which has experienced jet noise for years, are also joining in the antinoise effort.
Some members of the coalition have contended that planes occasionally fly so low that it is possible to read the airline's name on the fuselage. Residents also say that they are awakened in the middle of the night by air cargo flights, which usually use older, noisier aircraft.
Al Sidar, a pilot during World War II and a resident of Basking Ridge, said he had spotted planes ''not too far above the 3,000-foot level.'' And he said he has been frequently awakened at 2 or 3 A.M.
 
Port Authority Criticized
''No one here is of the mind that we shouldn't have any air traffic at all,'' he said. ''But what we are getting now is just intolerable.'' Not all residents of communities under the air lanes are bothered by the noise. Tim Deady, who lives five miles from Newark Airport, in Hillside, said that even though the planes go right over his house, it ''doesn't bother me that much.''
''I don't quite understand how people can get so upset,'' he said. ''The dogs barking in the street bother me much more than the aircraft overhead.''
The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which operates the three airports and has also come under fire from antinoise activists, defends the plan. ''The F.A.A. has been trying in good faith over the last couple of years to make adjustments in the plan to offer relief to those communities that have been affected by the noise,'' said William Cahill, a spokesman for the Port Authority. ''Changes have been made to try to arrive at a plan that would basically please the greatest number of people who have to live under the air routes. I don't know if it is possible to please everyone in this regard.''
Some of the changes made by the F.A.A. have merely shifted the noise from one community to the next, critics contend. Mary Jane Semcer of Far Hills has already moved once to escape ''unbearable'' jet noise, she said, only to find it followed her to her new home.
Her family lived in Short Hills and had built a deck onto their home when the jet noise arrived in 1987. ''The noise was so bad we couldn't even open the windows,'' she said. ''There wasn't any relief. At 2 or 3 in the morning, we'd see cargo planes right overhead. Their lights even shone in the windows.''
Mrs. Semcer and her family then moved to Far Hills. A few months later the aviation agency juggled the routes again, and the Semcers heard the sounds of the jets they thought they had left behind.
 
Highway in the Sky
''The quality of life has been destroyed by this,'' she said. ''I've got three children who have all gone to college out of the state, and when they talk about where they want to raise their children, it isn't here. They want to go to areas where there is more sensitivity to environmental concerns.''
Others are concerned that the noise in the sky is ruining their property values. ''Like a 12-lane highway through the center of town, the air routes will eventually affect everybody by making New Jersey and your community less desirable places to live,'' the coalition said in a bulletin. ''The routes can only make a bad housing market worse and reinforce New Jersey's sad stereotype as an environmental wasteland.''
Shirley Gazsi of Cranford, also active in the antinoise effort, said a chief complaint was that there was no warning of the plane rerouting. ''They did not do an environmental impact study,'' she said. ''It's not the same as someone moving into an area knowing that there's going to be noise. If you live close to the airport, you expect to hear it - but not if you live 20 or 30 miles away.''
Despite the fact that protests grew only when planes started flying over affluent communities, the coalition says theirs is not an upper-class cause. ''We represent thousands of people,'' Ms. Gazsi said, many of them living close to the airport. Curfews and use of quieter aircraft or newer models would improve life for people experiencing noise even before 1987, she said. The coalition also contends that noise is not the only form of pollution caused by aircraft and that New Jersey's air quality is also suffering.
 
Tremendous Growth
For its part, the aviation agency says that it must balance environmental concerns with the need for expanded air traffic. ''We know these people are not comfortable with the level of noise they are hearing but we are taking steps to mitigate that,'' said Ms. Bergen, the agency spokeswoman. ''Air traffic has grown tremendously since 1978'' when the industry was deregulated, she said, adding the ''aviation is a dynamic industry.'' In addition, she said, the agency determined that an environmental impact study was not necessary because the East Coast plan was for ''high altitude'' operations.
In response to complaints about night flights, the agency has in some cases reverted to the pre-1987 flight patterns for operations between 11 P.M. and 7 A.M., she said. But Ms. Bergen said that it would be ''just impossible'' to roll back the new flight system during normal business hours, because of the growth in the region's air traffic.
Several antinoise measures are pending both at the state and Federal level. A bill sponsored by Assemblywoman Maureen Ogden, Republican of Millburn, would require use of quieter aircraft; the measure lost by four votes in the Assembly last year but will be on the agenda again this session.
In the Congress, bills have been introduced by Mrs. Roukema and Mr. Courter. The coalition is pressing Gov. Jim Florio to file a suit against the aviation agency and may even proceed with its own litigation against the agency and the Port Authority.
Mr. Cantoni said the group wants nothing less than the restoration of the ''former tranquillity'' of the affected communities. Yet some coalition members concede that might be a tall order. ''Your opposition is the Federal Government,'' said Richard Coates of Far Hills, a coalition member, who said he felt as if he lived under a ''highway in the sky.''
The issue is not likely to die down. Just recently, Representive Matthew J. Rinaldo went home to Union for a visit and found that he had become yet another victim of the noise that has bothered many of his constituents for years. ''He was awakened in the wee hours by low flying aircraft,'' said John Arnold, an aide to the Republican from Union. ''It turned out that one of the most recent adjustments the F.A.A. made means that the planes are now flying over the Congressman's home.''

HEADLINE: FORUM;
East European Workers Will Need Incentives

BYLINE: By LEE SMITH and LEWIS KADEN; Lee Smith was director of the Cuomo Commission on Competitiveness. Lewis Kaden is a partner in the law firm of Davis, Polk & Wardell.

 BODY:
Many people think that laissez-faire capitalism will be a workable model for the redevelopment of the socialist economies of the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. Western advisers have consistently pushed for the creation of markets, free pricing and currency systems and an economy built on private enterprises. But the rush to markets, and the willingness to create economic insecurity, clearly carries with it a substantial risk of political turmoil. 
A safer path for Eastern Europe would lead to mixed economies that combine entrepreneurial qualities and efficiency with concern for economic security and equity.
There is much America can do to nurture the development of more effective enterprises. Joint ventures would bring managerial skills to underdeveloped Eastern European companies. In addition, the United States should encourage employee ownership and participation in enterprises in Eastern Europe. America is the world's leader in the legal, financial and organizational techniques needed to provide workers with equity in the enterprises in which they work. When properly structured and operated, the company with employee ownership, especially when combined with employee participation, offers the incentives needed to create higher productivity, wages and profits; just what state-owned enterprises need to combat their inertia, low morale, low productivity and lack of research and development.
In practical terms, the first step on the road to an employee-driven economy is for the governments of these countries to sell off divisions of their huge state-owned enterprises to the people who work in them. The very size of these enterprises has been an impediment to efficiency. The governments could finance the acquisitions by taking a note against the future earnings of the enterprises. The state in its role as a creditor can encourage the employees to put as much of their earnings as possible back into the enterprise.
The United States and Western Europe can encourage this process by making loans available to enterprises willing to undergo this transformation. It would be a mistake to insist that loans only be available to traditionally structured private companies or joint ventures with Western companies.
A mixed economy with a large number of employee-owned enterprises has economic and political benefits. Workers with a right to share in the wealth of an enterprise and a voice in the company have incentives to create wealth and can internalize a sense of responsibility, individual and collective.
Individual responsibility is fundamental to economic efficiency. And a sense of collective responsibility is needed to bridge the gulf between the individual's interests and society's needs. Fostering both values is important because the political and economic success of these societies will depend on how well their politics and their economics balance the rights of the individual and needs of the nation.
The irony is that if America wants to see state socialism transformed into a system that has a key feature of capitalism - the market - it will have to advocate one of the key concepts of the theory of socialism - worker ownership of the means of production.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: EUROPE (99%); UNITED STATES (95%); EASTERN EUROPE (93%); WESTERN EUROPE (79%); 

COMPANY: WESTERN COS (58%);

SECTION: Section 10; Page 9, Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1231 words

HEADLINE: FOCUS: California;
Market for Resale Houses Is Cooling Off

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN SHARP

DATELINE: SANTA BARBARA, CALIF.

 BODY:
LAST June, when California real estate prices were sizzling, John P. Forhan moved from a modest house into a larger, more attractive one about a mile away in a fashionable section of this city.
Mr. Forhan, a lawyer, and his wife, Carol, an accountant, paid $475,000 for the three-bedroom, one-and-a-half-bathroom house and put the old one on the market for $339,000 - the going price for properties in the lower section of the San Roque neighborhood. ''We thought the house would sell in a snap,'' said Mr. Forhan.
But at the end of summer, it was still on the market. The Forhans lowered the asking price 10 percent, to $305,000. In November, they lowered it again, to $297,000, and in December, they finally sold it at that price. 
''Things got very tense while we were paying two mortgages,'' said Mr. Forhan. ''It was tough.''
Like many coastal California homeowners, the Forhans got caught on the downside of the state's real estate cycle last year. After two years of price increases - in some cases as high as 30 percent a year -resales have cooled considerably.
But this cooling in no way signals a recession, according to California economists. ''It's a decline which is not dangerous and carries with it no expectations of a collapse,'' said Joseph Wahed, senior vice president and chief economist of Wells Fargo Bank.
Analysts outside the state have marked California as the next domino in the nation's tumbling real estate recession, following those in Texas, Arizona and New England, said Mr. Wahed.
James P. Antt Jr., president of the California Association of Realtors and a realtor in Bakersfield, said East Coast publications were predicting trouble for California - he cited an article in the Dec. 18, 1989, Barron's saying that in circumstances like California's ''panics can occur as home prices begin to falter.'' But ''we're not seeing what we are reading,'' he said, noting that the state's overheated market is just correcting itself by posting more moderate growth.
The median price of an existing home in California fell 7 percent in the last six months of 1989, to $188,000.
''The softening occurred in the move-up market, those houses priced at $250,000 to $400,000,'' said Andrew F. Kane, director of the real estate services group of Arthur Anderson, Western U.S., based in Los Angeles. ''People don't move into houses every year.''
The median resale price in 1989 was $196,521, a 17 percent increase over 1988. But although volume last June tumbled 24 percent, to an annual rate of 487,000 homes, in the whole year 538,770 homes went into contract, down only 4 percent from 1988, when a decade-high of 562,570 homes were sold.
''You just can't sustain double-digit price increases for long,'' said Leslie Appleton-Young, vice president of research and economics for the California Association of Realtors.
Several factors explain last year's slowdown. For one thing, workers' income growth has not kept pace with real estate appreciation. For example, in Santa Barbara, 120 miles northwest of Los Angeles, the median home price rose 19 percent, to $295,000, in 1988. At the same time, the average income grew only 2 percent, to $23,018, according to Mark Schniepp, economist at the University of California, Santa Barbara.
For the state, median home prices shot up 18 percent, to $168,556, while the average worker's income grew 6 percent, to $24,161, in 1988, the most recent year for which figures are available.
''The number of people who can afford a house is abysmal,'' said Mr. Schniepp.
ONLY 19 percent of California's households can afford a home. Assuming a 20-percent down payment on the $196,521 median-priced home, a California household needs at least $64,600 in annual income to qualify for a mortgage loan. A couple who qualify face monthly payments, including taxes and insurance, of $1,615. This is about 76 percent of the median income.
Nationally, 48 percent of households can afford to buy a median-priced home of $93,100. Assuming a 20-percent down payment, a household last year needed a minimum annual income of $30,600, less than half the amount needed by a Californian household, said Ms. Appleton-Young. Monthly payments totaled $765, again less than half the amount shouldered by Californians.
Because of the high cost of housing along the coast, many workers are buying homes inland. The most affordable region last year was Sacramento, where 39 percent of households could afford the median house price of $112,500. The least affordable region was the San Francisco Bay area, where only 11 percent of households could afford a median-priced home of $260,600.
That accounts for another factor cooling the increases of existing home sales: Many residents are moving farther from the ocean. ''The Central Valley markets have caught fire in recent months,'' said Mr. Wahed. The 600-mile-long valley accounts for 50 percent of the state's new construction permits, added Ms. Appleton-Young.
The migration inland is especially evident in the Riverside-San Bernardino area, where the median home sales price last year was $124,095. That is about half the price of a comparable home - priced at $245,262 - in Orange County, 15 miles away. As a result, many workers in Orange County commute a few hours every day to be able to own a home in the Riverside area.
''We're seeing a rebalancing in California's market to the interior,'' said Ms. Appleton-Young. The increased sales of lower-priced inland homes helps drag down the state's median.
Another factor cooling existing house-price increases is the condominium. As home prices continued to skyrocket out of reach for three-quarters of the state's households, condominiums became a popular second choice. In 1989, the median price of a condominium climbed 14 percent, to $139,299.
Deeper economic factors separate California's real estate market from troubled regions of the country, according to economists. For every person added to New England's population during the period 1984-88, two houses were built, Mr. Wahed said. The reverse was true in California. For every two people added to California's population, one house was added.
''The overbuilding in New England was the kiss of death,'' said Mr. Wahed.
THE biggest difference between New England and California is tied to population, according to Anthony Downs, senior fellow at the Brookings Institute. From 1980 to 1988, population gains in South California outstripped population gains of 21 states in the Northeast and Middle West combined. ''That puts a tremendous demand on housing in California,'' he said.
The demand will remain as long as the state's job market continues to post strong gains, as projected. Mr. Wahed projects that California will add 377,000 jobs in 1990, spread among industries as diverse as tourism, agribusiness, entertainment and international trade. That translates to 3 percent increase over 1989.
For 1990, Mr. Wahed projects median home prices will rise 7.5 percent; Ms. Appleton-Young forecasts a 9 percent increase, but an 11 percent drop in sales to 480,000 houses.
But for most California residents, the market slowdown is a moot point. ''I don't know anyone who can afford a house,'' said Lisa A. Baker, housing assistance supervisor for the County of Ventura, north of Los Angeles County. ''Everyone I know has terminal house-buying depression.''

COMPANY: WELLS FARGO & CO (56%); NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF REALTORS (59%); CALIFORNIA ASSOCIATION OF REALTORS (59%); NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF REALTORS (59%); CALIFORNIA ASSOCIATION OF REALTORS (59%);

PERSON: SHARP, KATHLEEN; FORHAM, JOHN P MICHAEL MCMAHON (52%); MICHAEL MCMAHON (52%);

HEADLINE: FOCUS;
Some Say Slip Is an Adjustment, Not a Downturn

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN SHARP
