SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 2038 words

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
For Gorbachev, an Uncertain Anniversary

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VILNIUS, Lithuania, March 11

 BODY:
Outside a polling place in Moscow last week, a voter framed the issue as a bitter joke: ''What is the difference between the Soviet Union and the United States?''
Answer: ''In the United States, Gorbachev would probably be elected President.''
The jibe was double-barreled. It took aim both at President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who today marks his fifth anniversary as Soviet leader, for failing to live up to his country's expectations, and at the West for worshiping too uncritically at the Gorbachev shrine.
 
A Danger of Not Keeping Up
For all his stature beyond his own borders, at home Mr. Gorbachev seems in danger of falling behind the major developments he set in motion: the surrender of the Communist monopoly, the remaking of the Soviet state, the disintegration of the empire, the fitful birth of a market. 
Critics, even among Mr. Gorbachev's devoted admirers, say that without another great leap of political imagination - something to bolster not his institutional power, but his popular authority - he stands little chance of leading his country through the coming period of sacrifice.
One such leap would be to step down as leader of the Communist Party, freeing himself from the obligation to clear his presidential decisions with the old men's club that runs the party.
Another would be to agree to submit to nationwide, multiparty elections, soon if not immediately.
Officials close to Mr. Gorbachev hint broadly that both of these are possible. But Mr. Gorbachev has not said so.
It is no longer news that Mr. Gorbachev's subjects grumble about the failed promises of his economic program, the rising prices and shrinking supplies. What is perhaps less understood is that the public is annoyed with Mr. Gorbachev for being too cautious in the cause of liberty, for failing to satisfy an appetite he himself stimulated.
Lionized abroad for liberating a totalitarian empire, he has never subjected himself to direct elections at home. Indeed, he is now preparing to accept a more powerful new executive presidency, again without giving the public a chance to pass judgment on his performance.
 
The Missing Element: Trust
Polls suggest that if Mr. Gorbachev did face a fair election, he would win by default - the public has not coalesced around an alternative leader - but his margin of support is declining fast, and with it his ability to motivate. Mr. Gorbachev has largely dispelled the fear that gripped his country, but he has not yet replaced it with trust.
Opinion surveys, election results, and man-in-the-street conversations all indicate that he has allowed an eclectic coalition of opposition forces to steal the slogans of reform.
''During the first stage of perestroika, it was rather reasonable for him to be in the middle of the road,'' said Sergei B. Stankevich, a street-smart young member of the loyal opposition in the Soviet Parliament.
''But now the potential of this middle-of-the-road policy is exhausted. Natural processes in politics, in the economy, are moving ahead much more quickly than Gorbachev, pursuing a middle-of-the-road policy, can react to them, and the society is developing much more quickly.''
To Westerners, the sense of disenchantment within the Soviet Union may be hard to fathom. These have been five years of breathtaking world change, with Mr. Gorbachev as catalyst.
If he did not exactly liberate Eastern Europe and singlehandedly end the cold war, he created the climate for the Europeans to liberate themselves by declining to prop up the tired old regimes and lending comfort to democratic alternatives.
Mr. Gorbachev's willingness to let one Communist tyrant after another fall without rattling a sword to defend them has made him the unlikely hero of dissidents throughout what used to be called the Soviet bloc. He did nothing to slow down democratization in Poland or in Hungary. Last fall, shortly after he met with Erich Honecker, the leader of East Germany was ousted, and this was soon followed by the opening of the Berlin wall and an accelerated exodus of East Germans to West Germany. The movement gave impetus to the drive toward German reunification, which Mr. Gorbachev has not opposed, although he has warned that it should be gradual. In Czechoslovakia, which Moscow invaded in 1968 to reinstall Communist orthodoxy, Mr. Gorbachev agreed to withdraw Soviet troops at the demand of the new, anti-Communist national leadership. Vaclav Havel, the dissident playwright turned president of Czechoslovakia, now tours the West appealing to capitalists to help keep Mr. Gorbachev in the Kremlin.
Mr. Gorbachev has acquiesced, so far, in the peaceful withdrawal of the Baltic republics - their creation of multiple political parties and private farming, their abandoning of Communism and their determination now to restore the independent statehood that existed between the two world wars.
The Soviet leader now faces the most serious test of his tolerance, as Lithuania's new, non-Communist parliament today declared its independence and called on Moscow to negotiate seriously the terms of disengagement.
Dissidents who were in prison when Mr. Gorbachev came to power are now in parliaments. The works they were jailed for writing or even possessing have been published in official magazines and newspapers.
Five million Soviet citizens now work in private ventures called cooperatives, and the Government has decreed an end to the state monopoly on industry and agriculture.
Political pluralism has become a reality, so far in the form of blocs and fractious alliances, but with a promise of full-fledged parties.
Perhaps most important, Mr. Gorbachev has begun the transfer of political power from the Communist Party to a law-based government, and from a fossilized center to more autonomous republics and local councils.
 
Amid Dazzling Tactics, Strategy Is Unclear
 Mr. Gorbachev has, through it all, been endlessly watchable. More surfer than swimmer, he rides the crest of events, barely keeping his balance by knowing when to lean forward, when to cut back, sometimes teetering precariously but never losing his sense of direction.
The Soviet leader's devotees have long maintained that he did indeed have a grand strategy, a sense of where the country was headed, but for tactical reasons - to keep the old guard off guard, to let the populace outgrow its conservative instincts - he could not be fully honest about his radical intentions.
The release of the colonies he could no longer afford or contain, the creation of a political and economic hybrid borrowing from both socialism and capitalism - those were in the master plan all along.
Short of a polygraph test, it is hard to be sure how much Mr. Gorbachev foresaw five years ago, and how much he learned along the way.
But unlike the new governments of Poland or Czechoslovakia, Mr. Gorbachev has never had a democratic mandate to do what he is doing.
The more the unfamiliar notion of democracy seeps into the public consciousness, and the more Soviet citizens follow events in Eastern Europe, the more irritated they seem that Mr. Gorbachev has limited their right to choose.
 
Can a Democracy Be Built by Decree?
 The issue is now focused on Mr. Gorbachev's proposal to create a new executive-style presidency with sweeping powers of decree and to diminish the authority of the parliament. Future presidents would be elected, but Mr. Gorbachev wants a five-year term given him by the 2,250 members of the Congress of People's Deputies, who are to converge on Moscow for a special session on Monday.
''I get hundreds of telegrams a day from citizens from all over the country, who are categorically against the election of the president at the congress,'' said Anatoly A. Sobchak, a popular lawyer-legislator from Leningrad. ''They say: 'You, the deputies, don't have any right to do this. We did not give you any such authorization when we voted for you. Only the people can elect the president.' ''
When they have been given a choice, the citizens have opted for candidates who distance themselves from Mr. Gorbachev and urge greater changes.
The big winner in local elections last Sunday was not Mr. Gorbachev, but a bloc of pro-democracy forces centered on the Interregional Deputies Group, the parliamentary opposition, which Mr. Gorbachev seems to view with suspicion bordering on hostility.
Members of the bloc understand Mr. Gorbachev's strategy of feinting right, then left, and ending up on his feet in the middle. But Mr. Gorbachev is now a centrist in a country with a shrinking center.
''The overwhelming majority of the leadership of the Interregional Group and most of the activists supporting it don't have any desire to remove Gorbachev from the first place on the political scene,'' said Vladimir O. Bokser, a strategist for the political bloc. ''We only want to move him over to the left.''
''But every move he makes seems designed to get more people fighting against him,'' Mr. Bokser continued. ''Maybe from the standpoint of high-level intrigues, everything he is doing makes sense, but the masses don't understand this.''
 
Unfamiliar Missteps In Public Relations
 Sometimes lately, Mr. Gorbachev's vaunted sense of timing and public relations have seemed to fail him.
On the night of the elections, he took up 12 minutes of the evening news with a rambling, disengaged interview at his polling place, repeating socialist homilies and dwelling on his longstanding devotion to the Communist Party even as party apparatchiks were being shunned by voters across the country. He seemed like a man out of touch. Even more stunning was his abrupt about-face on the issue of presidential power.
Paradoxically, the idea of an executive presidency was proposed last fall by opposition lawmakers, who argued this was the only way to free Mr. Gorbachev from the clutches of the Communist Party. Mr. Gorbachev passionately rejected it as contradicting his philosophy of decentralization.
Then last week, in a performance that seemed on television petulant and arrogant, he forced the proposal through the standing legislature in a rush, arguing that only a strong executive could cope with outbreaks of ethnic unrest and other crises.
Even those who favor a strong presidency were alarmed at the way Mr. Gorbachev lunged for it.
''I got really angry at the way he pushed through the law on the presidency,'' said Vasily S. Shakhnovsky, a young Moscow Communist who has been active in organizing a pro-democracy faction within the party. ''I just can't believe that a man for whom democracy is something inside him, something natural, could behave in such a way. I started having big doubts.''
Mr. Stankevich, who has won election both to the Soviet Parliament and to the Moscow City Council, contends that Mr. Gorbachev has allowed himself to be isolated by an inner circle of yes-men and misled by party and government apparatchiks who fear dramatic change.
''I see more and more signs that he is far from reality,'' Mr. Stankevich said. ''He is too slow to recognize reality.''
 
Does the West Really Understand?
 Perhaps Mr. Gorbachev is just waiting until the moment is right, until the public consensus is more clear, and then he will submit himself to a plebiscite or otherwise move to establish his public authority.
Or perhaps he has accepted the view of some around him that the country cannot, after all, move from totalitarian rule to democracy without a period of benign autocracy to force through unpopular changes.
What annoys the political newcomers trying to take Mr. Gorbachev up on his promise of democracy is how readily the West seems to accept that Mr. Gorbachev himself is the main thing.
Ilya I. Zaslavsky, a young member of the parliament who is one of the most popular political figures in Moscow, said it is condescending for Westerners to think of Mr. Gorbachev as a benign paterfamilias, and to dismiss his more radical critics as somehow destabilizing.
''When people are elected in non-democratic ways, and then play the democrats, as Gorbachev has done, then that's not democracy either,'' Mr. Zaslavsky said. ''It is just another form of the same old thing.''

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
PARLIAMENT IN LITHUANIA, 124-0, DECLARES NATION INDEPENDENT

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

 BODY:
VILNIUS, Lithuania, March 11 -Lithuania tonight proclaimed itself a sovereign state, legally free of the Soviet Union, and named the leaders of a non-Communist government to negotiate their future relations with Moscow.
The Lithuanian parliament voted 124 to 0, with 9 abstentions and absentees, to restore the independent statehood ended by Soviet annexation 50 years ago. The Lithuanian Communist Party, which won only a minority of seats in parliamentary elections last month, joined the non-Communist majority in the vote, and in an outburst of songs and embraces that followed.
''Expressing the will of the people, the Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian Republic declares and solemnly proclaims the restoration of the exercise of sovereign powers of the Lithuanian state, which were annulled by an alien power in 1940,'' said a resolution passed late tonight. ''From now on, Lithuania is once again an independent state.'' 
 
Full Implications Unclear
It was not immediately clear what the full implications of the Lithuanian action were. According to Lithuanian leaders, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet President, has indicated a willingness to negotiate the conditions of independence. But there was no immediate reaction to the declaration of independence either from Mr. Gorbachev or the Soviet Government.
Tass, the Soviet press agency, issued a factual report of the Lithuanian action without comment. Reports on national television were similar. [The Bush Administration urged the Soviet Union to respect the Lithuanian move, but stopped short of an explicit statement of recognition of the newly declared government. Noting instead that the United States never recognized Soviet authority over the Baltic republics, officials urged nonviolence and said that only through talks with Moscow, not unilateral action, would Lithuanians achieve what they want. Page A11.] Hundreds of Lithuanians gathered outside the parliament building, singing national hymns and chanting independence slogans, as the legislators changed the name of the Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic to simply the Lithuanian Republic and ordered the hammer and sickle replaced by the old Lithuanian coat of arms.
At one point, people in the crowd outside used screwdrivers to pry the copper Soviet insignia from the front of the building, to a roar of approval.
But behind the united front, many legislators and ordinary citizens voiced deep worry about how Moscow would respond to this precedent-setting breach in the union. The most common fear was a wave of economic repraisals that could produce fuel shortages and unemployment, threatening the state with chaos.
Other legislators worried that such a dramatic act of defiance, especially on the eve of an important Soviet congressional gathering, would weaken President Gorbachev, who has so far generally acquiesced to Lithuania's drive for freedom.
Before approving the law completing the political break with Moscow, the parliament elected as Lithuania's new president Vytautas Landsbergis, a soft-spoken music professor who led the pro-independence movement called Sajudis from an eclectic band of dissidents to a legislative majority.
By a vote of 91 to 38, the Sajudis-dominated legislature elected Mr. Landsbergis over Algirdas Brazauskas, the Lithuanian Communist Party leader, whose personal popularity has soared since his party broke with the Soviet Communist Party in December, but not enough to overcome the Communists' association with decades of occupation.
 
New Leader Urges Calm
Mr. Landsbergis urged the 3.7 million citizens of the republic to be calm and united as they enter a period of tense negotiations aimed at persuading Moscow to treat them as a friendly neighbor. On Monday the parliament is to consider an appeal to Mr. Gorbachev asking for withdrawal of the more than 30,000 Soviet troops based in Lithuania and the speedy repatriation of Lithuanian men serving in the Soviet Army.
''We cannot ignore the interests of our neighbors, particularly our neighbors to the east,'' the new Lithuanian president said. ''But we will not be asking for permission to take this or that step.''
Mr. Brazauskas is an economist by training, and supporters said the Communist leader would be a more reassuring presence at the bargaining table where details of the disengagement are to be worked out. But Mr. Landsbergis represented a clean break with the 50-year period that Lithuanians regard as an armed occupation.
The neighboring Baltic republics, Latvia and Estonia, are also moving toward secession.
''It will be contagious for other republics,'' said Mr. Brazauskas, who voted for today's decision but had earlier argued for a more gradual separation. ''Perhaps some will follow our example. But a great state like the Soviet Union will not collapse easily.''
Although the Communists here voted for the declaration of independence, Mr. Brazauskas declined an offer to be vice president, and other party members said they were not interested in prominent positions in the new government.
 
Other Officials Named
Mr. Landsbergis appointed three deputies, one a Communist and two who have quit the party, and named as prime minister a market-oriented economist, Kazimiera Prunskiene, who has announced her plans to leave the party.
Ustas J. Paleckis, the Communist party ideology chief, said that the Communists were persuaded that Sajudis did not want to share power on a more equal basis and that some party officials had decided they would remain aloof from the government and let Sajudis take responsibility for the consequences.
In the corridors outside the parliamentary chamber, Mr. Brazauskas's Communists - about one third of the 133 legislators - and some non-Communists wondered aloud about the wisdom of moving so quickly to declare independence.
''Probably a third of the deputies think it is crazy to rush into this,'' said a local journalist sympathetic to Sajudis. ''But anyone who speaks against it is sure to be branded a traitor.''
No representatives of Moscow were evident in the hall.
 
Rights Advocate Applauds
Though there was no official reaction from the Kremlin, members of the parliamentary opposition in Moscow sent a message of congratulations, and Sergei Kovalyov, a human rights advocate and former political prisoner recently elected to the Russian republic's parliament, came here to applaud Lithuania's move.
''A lot of Russians will say, ''We liberated you from the Germans, we helped you industrialilze,' '' Mr. Kovalyov said in a brief address to the parliament. ''None of them will say that we deported half of the Lithuanian people to Siberia.''
In recent days Mr. Gorbachev and other Soviet officials served notice that Moscow would make billions of rubles in financial claims on Lithuania if it secedes, and challenged Lithuania's boundaries, including its right to the Baltic seaport of Klaipeda, also called Memel. Mr. Gorbachev has also repeatedly cited security risks for Moscow in the loss of the republic, and promised to defend the rights of the republic's non-Lithuanian minority, 20 percent of the population.
There have already been some signs of stepped-up pressure, including a freeze by the Soviet Government-controlled banks on the assets of Lithuanian savings banks, that have led leaders of the republic to speculate about a possible economic blockade.
 
What Moscow Could Do
Annual trade between Lithuania and other Soviet republics is estimated at $24 billion at the official rate of exchange, including almost all of Lithuania's subsidized oil supplies.
Another fear is that Moscow could shut down centrally run industrial enterprises, throwing half a million Russian blue-collar workers out of jobs and raising ethnic tensions.
''My fear is that if we do not understand the progressive forces in Moscow, we can bring them a lot of danger,'' Mr. Paleckis added. ''And it will be danger for us as well. If Mr. Gorbachev loses, our declaration of independence will make moral sense, but. . .''
Mr. Landsbergis replied that ''the people of Lithuania are not naive. Even after listening to frequent warnings about how difficult it was going to be, they voted all the same for the Sajudis platform. We consider that a kind of referendum.'' Mr. Landsbergis said he hoped for prompt recognition from foreign countries, including the United States, which has never formally acknowledged the annexation of the three Baltic republics but has been wary of undermining Mr. Gorbachev.
The vote was the climax of a campaign that began gathering momentum less than two years ago, with the creation of the Sajudis initiative group in June, 1988.
A year ago, the alliance proved its strength by capturing most of the republic's seats in a new Soviet Parliament.
Mr. Landsbergis and several other lawmakers said they would no longer participate as voting members of the Soviet Parliament, although they might come to Moscow as observers or as members of a bargaining team to work out the details of secession. LITHUANIA'S PARLIAMENT VOTES INDEPENDENCE OF MOSCOW RULE LITHUANIA'S PARLIAMENT, 124-0, DECLARES COUNTRY INDEPENDENT

HEADLINE: Panama's New Leader Fasts To Dramatize Need for Aid

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PANAMA, March 11

 BODY:
Nearly three months after American forces invaded Panama, the Panamanian economy is in ruins and $1 billion in emergency aid remains stalled in the United States Congress. At the Metropolitan Cathedral here, President Guillermo Endara has devised an unusual but apt way to dramatize the plight of a country starved for money: he has gone on an indefinite hunger strike.
''It is an act of commiseration,'' he said. ''This is a fast to remind all Panamanians of good will that there is suffering in our country and that this suffering consumes flesh, bones and stomachs of beings as human as those of us gathered here.''
Mr. Endara, a rotund man whose normal weight runs well above 200 pounds, began his fast on Feb. 28, Ash Wednesday, in what he described as an expression of Lenten religious sentiment ''that has absolutely nothing to do with American aid.'' But he acknowledged that he probably would not have had to undertake his campaign at all if his friends in Washington had been quicker to help him reconstruct his country. 
 
A Gesture of Solidarity
The Panamanian economy, Mr. Endara said, is now in even worse condition than before the American invasion that overthrew Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega on Dec. 20. Unemployment is above 30 percent, many people are going hungry and businesses are in ruins.
Mr. Endara said he felt that only by relinquishing the air-conditioned quarters of the Presidential Palace and its ''excellent cuisine, a first-class cook, and all the food I want'' could he show ''solidarity with my fellow citizens who are suffering from malnutrition and poverty.''
''Something must be done for these people,'' he said. ''Unfortunately, I cannot do anything, because all the plans we have to help them require money that we don't have.''
''It's hard for the President, with all the comforts of the presidency, to go to the people and say 'I am suffering with you,' '' Mr. Endara continued. ''The people are going to say, 'That fat guy is full of it. It's nothing but talk.' ''
 
Life in a Rocking Chair
The President, whose reputation here is that of a good-natured bon vivant, said he does not intend to continue his fast through the entire 40 days of Lent, but would not say when he would begin eating again. His staff said that Mr. Endara is consuming only liquids, and though he appeared more pale and somewhat slimmer than normal, he is good spirits and lucid, even presiding over Cabinet meetings in the cathedral and at the Presidential Palace.
''When I see I can no longer continue with my Government chores and that I am debilitated, I will suspend my fast,'' he said.
Mr. Endara is spending most of his time in a rocking chair in a corner of the cathedral, a large electric fan at his side and a cot on which he sleeps at night just behind him. A few feet away, beneath a large statue of Mary cradling a crucified Jesus in her arms, aides answer telephones and try to conduct normal Government business.
The United States Ambassador, Deane R. Hinton, has gone to the cathedral to confer with Mr. Endara several times during the fast, as has Michael G. Kozak, a Panama expert in the State Department in Washington, and various other American officials and bankers. But there is also a steady stream of poor and humble Panamanians, who take up positions behind a red rope to watch Mr. Endara with hopes of catching his attention and perhaps asking a favor.
 
'We Are All Hungry'
''I am here because I sympathize with the President,'' said Elisa Lam, a peasant woman visiting the capital from the interior. ''I want Mr. Bush to let go of that money, because we are all hungry here and there is no work. If we get the money we've been promised, things can start moving again.''
Mr. Endara's hunger strke has been widely publicized throughout Latin America, where it is seen as an example of American abandonment of a faithful client. In nearby Nicaragua, the Sandinista Front is already predicting that President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro will be left in the lurch by a penny-pinching Bush Administration, Washington's promises of generous assistance notwithstanding.
''If the United States doesn't even have the political vision and pragmatism to understand that it is necessary to put some money into Panama in order to strengthen Panama, what can we other Latin Americans expect besides congratulations and messages?'' President Daniel Ortega Saavedra asked mockingly this week. ''With congratulations and messages, you cannot resolve the grave economic problems that affect our countries.''
Mr. Endara's Government originally requested $1.5 billion in American aid after evaluating the damage done by the invasion and two years of American efforts to strangle the Panamanian economy through sanctions. Late in January, the Bush Administration responded with a package of $1 billion in loans, grants, credits, investment guarantees and other aid, in Mr. Bush's words ''as instant a relief as we can hope for.''
 
Aid Package Stalled
But the package has run into problems in Congress. It recently approved the first $500 million installment, but it provided only $42 million in direct emergency aid money with the balance made up of loan guarantees, credits and other similar aid measures.
The second $500 million component remains stalled while the Bush Administration and lawmakers debate the size of the package, how the funds should be spent and where to cut the Federal budget to pay for the increased aid.
Senator Patrick J. Leahy, the Vermont Democrat who heads the Senate Appropriations Subcommittee on Foreign Operations, said the Panama package raised broader questions over how to expand foreign aid funds to newly emerging democracies when the United States is experiencing its own serious budget problems. The Administration, he said, is ''telling the Panamanians that the check is in the mail, but there's no balance in the checkbook and no checks.''
In response to such arguments, Mr. Endara said he remembered ''when economic sanctions were imposed during the Noriega dictatorship, numerous Congressmen, Senators and State Department officials came here.
''When we reminded them of the damage being done to the economy, all of them said: 'Don't worry. When Panama becomes a democracy, we will help reconstruct your economy.' '' Mr. Endara said. ''These promises must be kept.''
 
'It's Our Money'
Mr. Endara said he was particularly distressed that more than $200 million of Panamanian Government funds in Washington's hands had not yet been released to his Government. That money, including payments from the Panama Canal, was frozen by Washington in 1988 and 1989 as part of the sanctions imposed on the Noriega regime.
''Part of the money that is being held back in the United States is ours,'' he said sadly. ''It's not aid from the U.S. It's our money that was being held by the U.S. against Noriega. Now it's being held up by some sort of bureaucratic problem and hasn't got to us for reasons that are still unexplained.''
The Panamanian President, who went on a hunger strike last September as part of a civil disobedence campaign against the Noriega regime, also finds himself wondering if Capitol Hill's reluctance to authorize the aid package is related to Washington's desire to see his Government take a tougher stand against the laundering of drug money here.

HEADLINE: Four Oil >Spills Turn Spotlight On New York's Vital Straits

BYLINE: By ALLAN R. GOLD

 BODY:
Before four spills dumped hundreds of thousands of gallons of oil into the Arthur Kill and the connecting Kill Van Kull this year, the two waterways were hardly known outside maritime circles, even though they carry more traffic than the Panama Canal. But the 16-mile channel winding between northern New Jersy and Staten Island is an important contributor to the economic vitality of the Northeast.
The area's rich history of heavy industry goes back more than 100 years, most of which passed without concern for the surrounding flora and fauna.
The kills, as the Dutch settlers named them, became a convenient industrial dump, as well as sewer system for nearby communities. Today small, unpublicized oil spills occur regularly, and runoff from urban life also fouls the water.
Still, in the last 15 years this degraded environment has been making a comeback, most visibly heralded now by the return each spring of hundreds of graceful, long-legged wading birds. 
''It's an incredible phenomenon,'' said Dr. Katharine Parsons, director of the Harbor Herons Project, a study of wildlife habitat in the kills. But conservationists say the recovery could be stymied by the amount of oil that has spilled recently.
Until now, economics have prevailed. Nearly two billion gallons of oil products can be stored in the hundreds of tanks on the New Jersey side of the kills, and tankers, barges and container ships plying these waters carry the most shipping tonnage of any port in the nation.
Each day an average of 100 commercial vessels pass through the Kill Van Kull, which separates Bayonne from Staten Island. In a vivid demonstration of the strait's value, when it was reopened after 24,000 gallons of heating oil spilled on Feb. 28, 500 commercial and pleasure vessels passed through it in 48 hours, the Coast Guard said.
From the air or ground, the sprawling fields of oil tank farms and smoke-spewing, malodorous refineries are grim industrial eyesores. But their presence has established the area as the Northeast's distribution hub for gasoline and home heating oil.
Three-quarters of the 70 daily oil-related vessel movements in the Port of New York are through the kills.
Three of the other recent spills involved vessels loading in the waterway, including the explosion of a barge last week that dumped more than 100,000 gallons of oil into the Arthur Kill. In by far the largest incident, a faulty Exxon pipeline poured 567,000 gallons of oil into the Arthur Kill on Jan. 1.
An extraordinary collection of more than 200 businesses are assembled along the Arthur Kill and the Kill Van Kull, accounting for thousands of jobs in New Jersey and New York, although the numbers have been declining. The most visible presence is the oil and chemical complex, represented by many of the industry's major companies.
Some have been there for years: American Cyanimid, Du Pont, GAF and Exxon or their corporate forerunners all had operations in Linden, N.J., by 1920.
Besides the petrochemical complex, the Arthur Kill is home to two electric power plants, a sewage treatment plant on the New Jersey side and a power plant on the Staten Island shore.
 
Pollution by Landfill
Also, the world's largest landfill -now 150 feet high and rising - sits at Fresh Kills, S.I., along the Arthur Kill. Sixteen to 20 trash-laden barges make their way daily from New York City's four other boroughs down the Arthur Kill to the New York City landfill.
In use since the late 1940's - it was supposed to be temporary - the landfill is hardly a benign neighbor. It illegally discharges millions of gallons a day of toxic liquid, leached from the trash, into the Arthur Kill. New York City is making efforts to seal the fill.
The landfill and industry have occasionally been the source of interstate disputes. In the mid-1980's, Staten Island residents complained about the horrible smell that wafted through their neighborhoods. It surely must be New Jersey and all those factories, they asserted.
Perhaps not, according to a consultant's study paid for by the Chemical Industry Council of New Jersey. Much of the odor came from the Fresh Kills landfill, the study concluded, as well as a sewage treatment plant along the Arthur Kill on the New Jersey side.
The Arthur Kill and the Kill Van Kull have had chronic pollution problems since the petroleum industry settled in the area in the 1880's. Before then, local waters were a vibrant fishery. Oyster beds flourished in nearby Newark Bay and even provided seeding for beds in the much better-known oyster centers of New England and Chesapeake Bay, said Andrew Willner, a researcher with the American Littoral Society, an environmental group in Sandy Hook, N.J.
 
Rockefeller a Trailblazer
Among the earliest petroleum businesses to settle in the kills area was John D. Rockefeller's Standard Oil Company. He persuaded Bayonne's City Council in 1880 to let Standard lay an oil pipeline through the streets. Five years later the company, Exxon's forerunner, opened a refinery in Bayonne.
In the late 1880's, spills from Newark Bay refineries reduced catches of fish and shellfish. What was left became unmarketable because the products tasted like kerosene.
People continued to fish and swim in the kills through World War II, despite the great growth in industry along their banks. As children, ''we used to go crabbing and fishing in that area,'' said George Hudak, the 55-year-old former Mayor of Linden.
''You know how you go down the shore and it smells like the ocean?'' said Robert Watkoskey, 57, who grew up in Bayonne and is district director of the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers International Union. ''That's the way it used to smell.'' Mr. Watkoskey said he and his father, who worked for Exxon, crabbed in Newark Bay in the 1940's.
 
Damaging Effects of War
The factories went all out during World War II, without much regard to the health of the Arthur Kill, Mr. Hudak said. At the war's end, he recalled, he went down to the kill for a swim in Linden's Tremley Point neighborhood and sank six or seven inches into oily residue at the shore.
''That's when we stopped swimming,'' said Mr. Hudak, a State Assemblyman.
In any case, local residents did not care much about the pollution because the companies provided good jobs, Mr. Hudak said.
The story is told in the area about the time in 1940 when President Franklin D. Roosevelt took his campaign for a third term through Perth Amboy. The economy was sluggish, and an upbeat city councilman introducing the President told the enthusiastic crowd of several thousand, ''If F.D.R. is re-elected, the skies over Perth Amboy will be black again.'' His audience is said to have cheered lustily.
 
Focus on Economic Gains
Polluting industry also did not make much of an impact on Bertha Matuska, a 97-year-old resident of Linden who went there at the age of 14 from Czechoslovakia. Mrs. Matuska said she ran a Tremley Point restaurant that catered to workers from plants like the American Cyanimid operation.
Joseph Kuban has lived all of his 34 years in Linden within view, and scent, of the Exxon Bayway plant. ''What do you want me to say?'' Mr. Kuban asked with a shrug. ''When you live here, you don't really notice that stuff.'' His father worked at a nearby Cities Service operation.
Few paid much attention to the ecological condition of the kills until the late 1960's. In a study by the Federal Government in 1967, cages containing blue crabs, clams and minnow-like killifish were lowered into the Arthur Kill. Several days later the cages were withdrawn and the fish were dead, said Dr. Parsons, of the Harbor Herons Project.
A major culprit was the raw sewage that had been dumped into the kill through the years and had robbed the water of oxygen. But laws like the Clean Water Act of 1972 required municipalities to clean up such discharges. Environmentalists credit curtailed sewage dumping with the revival of wildlife in the Arthur Kill.
 
Return of Water Birds
As food sources were restored, wading birds found a new home. In 1974, birders discovered nesting by snowy and cattle egrets and black-crowned night herons on Shooters Island in Kill Van Kull. In 1978, egrets were found on Pralls Island in Arthur Kill.
''Nowhere does such important wildlife exist in such immediate juxtaposition with a highly industrialized urban area,'' said Dr. Donald McCrimmon, former president of the Colonial Waterbird Society, in a report on the value of the kills as a wildlife habitat.
The report, to be released today by the Trust for Public Land and the New York City Audubon Society, proposes wetlands preservation measures on Staten Island to protect animal habitat. It suggests that the intensity of industry along the kills has helped keep people away from remaining wetlands and has led to an ecological revival.
''Just because we label something industrial, that doesn't mean we should just write it off,'' said Dr. Royal Nadeau, a member of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency's environmental response team based in Edison, N.J.
But one environmentalist, Gary Ott, a science support coordinator from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, could not help but notice the impact of years of chronic pollution on Pralls Island.
So many oil products have found their way into the water that Mr. Ott calls the goo surrounding the island ''Pralls Boulevard.''

HEADLINE: Two Years Temper Hopes in Baltimore

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BALTIMORE, March 7

 BODY:
A little more than two years ago, when Kurt L. Schmoke took over as Mayor of Baltimore, expectations soared that he would get this troubled old port city moving in a new direction. Time has tempered those hopes. An athletic Rhodes scholar who had managed to become the first black elected to the job, Mr. Schmoke took office with a splash of national publicity. Soft-spoken, introspective, even a little shy, he had a far different agenda from that of his blunt-spoken, relentlessly political predecessor, William Donald Schaefer.
He talked of rejuvenating Baltimore's spreading slums and of educating the poor youngsters living in them. He wanted Baltimore to be known as ''the city that reads,'' not as the city of glittering waterfront hotels and packed restaurants serving tasty crab cakes. 
Mr. Schmoke is still a politician to be watched. But getting Baltimore moving in a new direction, away from business district development toward solutions to serious problems of poverty, education and public health, has proved to be much more difficult than he initially calculated, though he says momentum is shifting toward him.
 
Creating His Own Roadblocks
''It's been tough, a learning experience,'' he replied when asked to assess the first half of his four-year term. ''But the good days have begun to outnumber the bad days.
''I'm in office at a time when Baltimore has some very difficult problems to solve,'' he added. ''I'm confident we can do it.''
While the major barrier is money, many of Mr. Schmoke's detractors, as well as some supporters, say he has created roadblocks of his own.
They credit him with pushing much-needed initiatives in education and housing. But in their judgment he has also been guilty of ill-considered personnel changes, foot-dragging, tangled lines of communication and political naivete, including one instance in which he was widely criticized for suggesting that some drugs be legalized because the nation's drug epidemic was more a health problem than a crime problem.
''The Mayor and everybody else knows by now what the city's problems are,'' said Michael C. Middleton, executive vice president of MNC Financial Inc., a major bank here. ''So it's time the Mayor sat down and stopped just studying things and scattering projects around. He needs to really lay out a game plan, make decisions and get things moving. People are more than willing to work with him.''
For all that was achieved during the 15-year tenure of Mr. Schaefer, who gave up the mayor's job to make a successful run for Governor, Mr. Schmoke inherited a city with some daunting unfinished business. There is much more, or less, to Baltimore than its bustling downtown business district and waterfront, nationally acclaimed examples of urban rejuvenation.
 
City's Greatest Cheerleader
As Mayor, Mr. Schaefer was perhaps the greatest cheerleader the city ever had. He achieved national stature by endlessly coming up with ways to promote his town. He was a tough political act to follow, especially for a self-effacing politician like Mr. Schmoke, whose instincts are to make common cause with the downtrodden, particularly the blacks who now account for more than half the city's 780,000 residents, and to study a problem at length before taking action.
Though Mr. Schaefer now lives in Annapolis, he obviously left his heart in Baltimore. Several times when Mr. Schmoke has seemed to him to be reacting too slowly, as when a musicians' strike dragged on, the Governor has shown up to push a solution.
Mr. Schmoke is not easily given to such aggressive politicking. But he has made high-profile appearances at major fires and pointedly toured a school supply office when a textbook shortage became a major issue. He has also streamlined his staff to speed the flow of ideas and has begun to publicly chastise city officials, including his own appointees, for shortcomings.
The Mayor is especially concerned about the city's schools because the illiteracy and dropout rates are among the highest in the country. Some employers are having trouble finding qualified workers and have joined Mr. Schmoke in a drive to fashion corrective programs, some of them offering job and college incentives to students who graduate.
Other city statistics and municipal failings also deeply concern the Mayor.
The rate of illegitimate births is one of the nation's highest, and the city's AIDS epidemic is one of the worst.
 
Block After Block of Slums
Within walking distance of the Baltimore's waterfront restaurants and boutiques are block after block of slums, with the number of abandoned houses and apartments steadily outstripping rehabilitation efforts in most places.
Property taxes, a main source of city revenue, are among the highest in the state and have driven many middle-class families to the suburbs.
The port, once the city's main reason for existence, is plagued by labor trouble and competition from other ports, particularly Hampton Roads, Va., at the mouth of the Chesapeake Bay.
As things now stand, the city will not have enough money this year to maintain basic services, like fire and police protection, let alone start new programs to solve old problems. A shortage of about $50 million, out of a budget of $1.6 billion, is anticipated.
City law requires that the budget be balanced, so city officials are pressing the Maryland Legislature for aid and are preparing to lay off as many as 1,000 of the city's 29,000 employees to save still more money.
 
Feeling Effects of Reagan Era
''Some people are going to have to go,'' said Mary Pat Clarke, the President of the City Council. ''The transition from the Schaefer years to the Schmoke years has been difficult, just in terms of style, but it has been doubly difficult because the effect of the Reagan years has been to drastically cut Federal aid to cities.''
Delegate Charles Ryan, the chairman of the Appropriations Committee in the State House of Representatives, said Mr. Schmoke's standing in Annapolis is good enough to win the city ''maybe $20 million'' to help close the $50 million spending gap.
''He's been very effective during his visits with us,'' Mr. Ryan said. ''We are sympathetic. We're going to try to take over some city expenditures that are really expenditures for the whole state, such as money for the zoo and for some law-enforcement functions.''
Mr. Schmoke takes heart from such news. He called it proof that Baltimore is moving forward, that new headings are being set, that the city and its Mayor are solving their problems.

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
Nations Widen Role of Bank for East-Bloc Aid

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, March 11

 BODY:
A dispute over the role of a new international development bank to help Eastern Europe has been resolved with a decision that the bank will provide loans not only to the private sector, but also to public-sector projects like road building, European officials said today.
Jacques Attali, the French official who headed a meeting this weekend of 39 nations to lay the groundwork for the bank, said a consensus had developed on the issue, despite the reluctance at first of the United States and Britain to allow loans to public-sector projects in Eastern Europe.
Mr. Attali, a senior adviser to President Francois Mitterrand of France, said the group had also agreed that the capital of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development should amount to about $12 billion. 
Officials at the two-day meeting said this would make the bank the most important international financial institution to be set up since the World Bank and International Monetary Fund were established after World War II.
 
Roads and Communications
The bank aims to help revive the economies of Poland, Hungary, Czechoslovakia, East Germany and other Eastern European nations.
Many Eastern European officials had argued that public-sector investment was needed in areas like roads and telecommunications to help the private sector grow. Under one proposal, a maximum of 40 percent of the bank's loans could go toward public-sector infrastructure.
Asserting that major progress had been made at the meeting, Mr. Attali said he hoped that the documents to establish the bank could be signed at a meeting on April 9 in Paris. He expressed confidence that the bank could begin lending money late this year or early next year.
Officials at the meeting said a consensus was forming that the Soviet Union should not only be allowed to be a member of the new bank, but should also be able to receive loans. American officials had originally opposed loans to the Soviet Union on the ground that Moscow has not moved as far toward democracy as many other Eastern European nations. #6 Percent From Moscow They also argued that the bank would be unable to meet the Soviet Union's considerable financial needs and grant enough money to Eastern European nations as well.
One official said there was tentative agreement that the Soviet Union would contribute 6 percent of the bank's capital and be limited to receiving 6 percent of the loans.
For Soviet officials, membership in the bank is important because it would give them a role in an institution that is expected to play a wide role in shaping the future of Eastern Europe.
Mr. Attali said it was also agreed that 51 percent of the bank's capital would come from the 12 nations of the European Community, from the community itself and from the European Investment Bank, a community development bank.
Still subject to debate, Mr. Attali said, are the exact shares contributed by the other nations participating and by two community institutions. Nor has it been decided who should sit on the bank's board of directors, he added.
The bank's members will include the United States, Canada, Japan and most European nations. Liechtenstein, South Korea, Israel, Egypt and Morocco all sent representatives to the meeting and plan eventually to join.
The two announced candidates to head the bank are Mr. Attali and Onno Ruding, a former Dutch Finance Minister. After first supporting Strasbourg, France, as a potential headquarters for the bank, French officials proposed this weekend that it be based in Paris.
Officials said other cities on the list includedLondon, Prague and Budapest.

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
Romanians' Lives Quickly Improve

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUCHAREST, Romania, March 11

 BODY:
There was a birthday party here last week for Dana Madolciu, who turned 34, and in a number of ways it illustrated the remarkable changes that have taken place in Romanian households since the overthrow of President Nicolae Ceausescu in December.
There were 100-watt bulbs in the chandelier instead of the 40-watt bulbs demanded by the Communist dictator in his last years and enforced by street patrols. There were the plates piled high with pork schnitzels, fried fish, pate, olives, cheese and three kinds of chocolate cake - all of which were either in short supply or unavailable in the shops of Bucharest only three months ago.
Cristian Madolciu, Dana's husband, said food stores for the most part get daily deliveries in the afternoon now, when most of the 10 million employed Romanians are at their workplaces. They are quickly sold out. ''We still have queues, but then most of them are our older relatives buying for us while we are working,'' Mr. Madolciu said. 
 
Food Donated From Abroad
Much of the food now on the store shelves is from foreign donations sent here after the Ceausescu regime was toppled. The cheese on the Madolciu table, for instance, came from the Netherlands in a box stamped, ''Best Eaten Before February 1990.''
Gaiety marked the evening after the 11 guests sang ''La Multi Ani,'' the Romanian version of ''Happy Birthday,'' to Mrs. Madolciu, a slender woman smartly turned out in an acid-washed miniskirt.
Her two daughters, joined by two young cousins, engaged in mock combat over who would get precedence to blow out the single birthday candle on the first cake after it had been re-lit for them. The children then presented their own idea of a lambada for their mother to the accompaniment of a tin drum and a tambourine.
The television set was on the whole evening, and there was elation around 10:30 P.M. when it showed the Romanian national handball team eking out a one-goal victory over the world champion team from Sweden.
During the Ceausescu reign, Romanians were subjected nightly to an hour or more of the daily doings of the dictator and his wife, Elena, followed at best by a Czechoslovak detective series.
No sports events were shown even when it was certain that Romanian athletes would be the winners. The sole exception was the Los Angeles Olympic Games, where Romania was the only Soviet bloc participant, which suited the Ceausescu foreign policy.
 
Crime Also Increases
Other signs of liberty in the Romanian capital today include an increase in crime, strikes and forms of free enterprise.
While the Ceausescu regime did not publicize crime statistics, Jean Moldoveanu, the Deputy Minister of Interior, said in an interview this week in the newspaper Dimineata that there had definitely been an increase in crime since the revolution.
He said there were 311 assaults in January and 380 in February across the country. Over those two months, there were 128 murders, 74 attempted murders and 28 cases of manslaughter, he said. Many of these cases were attributable to ''excessive consumption of alcohol,'' he added.
Although not as omnipresent as during the dictatorship, blue-uniformed policemen, formerly called militiamen, are still a visible presence in the streets of Bucharest.
This did not prevent a thug from robbing a French television cameraman one night recently in front of the Intercontinental Hotel and then beating him so severely that he had to be flown to Paris for medical treatment.
 
Strike in Subway System
On the strike front, employees stopped the capital's new subway system, one of the few giant projects of the Ceausescu era that has popular approval, for several days last week to underscore their demands for higher pay and better conditions. The strike caused Bucharest's first traffic jams on thoroughfares in recent memory.
Above ground on Nicolae Balcescu Boulevard, two shepherds from the mountains of Transylvania maintained a hunger strike through the weekend, saying they wanted the new Government to give them the 315 sheep, 30 goats and 3 donkeys that they said had been taken from them by ''the dictator's regime'' last November.
Waving his crook, one of the shepherds, clad in the shaggy sheepskin cloak and pink lambswool hat of his trade, told passers-by: ''The law is for all. We want our flock back!''
 
'Exclusive Sensation' Offered
A new twist in Romanian free enterprise occurred on Wednesday, when an official of a state enterprise called an acquaintance who works for a foreign newspaper at 8 A.M. and offered him ''an exclusive sensation - the last sculpture of Ceausescu.''
Meeting four hours later, the official produced photographs and a video cassette of a huge-looking modernistic victory monument, at the base of which was a tall frieze plainly depicting Mr. Ceausescu and his wife. The official said the work was 42 meters tall and added, ''We made it.'' The sculpture is on a list for demolition.
Asked where it was situated, he said: ''That is a secret, but it is standing within 200 kilometers of Bucharest. It was a gift from Ceausescu to his son Nicu.'' Nicu Ceausescu, the former Communist Party chief in Sidiu County, is in prison awaiting a military trial.
The official asked, ''How much will you offer me for the photograph and cassette?''
His face fell when he was told to seek out an illustrated magazine or a television company.

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
U.S. Advises Moscow To 'Respect' Lithuania

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 11

 BODY:
The Bush Administration urged the Soviet Union today to respect the decision of the Lithuanian parliament to restore its sovereignty, but stopped short of an explicit statement of recognition of the newly declared government.
Noting instead that the United States had never recognized Soviet authority over Lithuania or the two other Baltic republics, officials urged nonviolence and said that only through negotiations with Moscow, not through unilateral action, would Lithuanians achieve what they want.
''The United States would urge the Soviet Government to respect the will of the citizens of Lithuania,'' the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said in a statement.
He added: ''We have consistently supported the Baltic people's inalienable right to peaceful self-determination. We call upon the Soviet Government to address its concerns and interests through immediate constructive negotiations with the government of Lithuania. We hope that all parties will continue to avoid any initiation or encouragement of violence.'' 
 
Avoiding Trouble for Gorbachev
Explaining the Administration's position, a senior official said it grows partly from the view that only through talks will the Lithuanians truly achieve their aims, and partly from the view that there is no reason to make matters worse for President Mikhail S. Gorbachev with defiant statements of support for the Baltics when the Soviet leader appears to be moving in the direction of setting them free anyway.
''Gorbachev has to accept the principle that the Baltic states are going to become independent and the Balts have to accept a process through which this independence can be peacefully and gradually negotiated,'' said an Administration official. ''This is not an issue we intend to take the lead on. We will only get involved if invited by both sides.''
The staff at the Lithuanian legation in Washington, sustained for years by Lithuanian gold reserves hidden in the United States, greeted today's news with unexpectedly mixed emotions.
To be sure, there was the triumphant clink of champagne glasses. But beneath the heady jubilation there was an undercurrent of sobriety - natural for a people who know Soviet power well enough not to celebrate as though today's vote were the end of the story.
 
'We Went Through a Desert'
''We went through a desert for so many years, no one ever believed in us, and now we have reached the oasis,'' said Stasys Lozoraitis Jr., the charge d'affaires who has been representing a government that existed only in his peoples' memory for 50 years.
The United States first recognized an independent Republic of Lithuania in 1922 and never stopped recognizing it, despite the Soviet occupation in 1940.
Being a diplomat without a country is neither easy nor much fun, as evidenced by the dented Oldsmobile Omega that serves as Mr. Lozoraitis's official car. It was no surprise to hear him exude, ''I am happy, very happy.''
He was also quick to add: ''But the story is not over. You see, I am a European. I know the Communists well. I know that the situation has changed radically - but, but, but. There are still many buts. Gorbachev could be replaced tomorrow. The Soviet economy is in horrible shape. We will have to negotiate with some very serious people in Moscow. We still don't control the banks, the police, the railway system. We don't even control the electricity yet. We will see now how the big brother reacts.''
 
Saving the Best Champagne
In some ways those mixed emotions seemed to be displayed in the repast the legation laid out for today's reception: a single bottle of California Winemaster champagne, nestled between jugs of diet soda and surrounded by a few cookies, cakes and miniature yellow, green and red Lithuanian flags. Celebratory, but not too celebratory. The best champagne will wait. Mr. Lozoraitis said today's statement by the White House met with his legation's approval for the moment. He said that ''as soon as the Soviets hear the Americans declaring their support for our independence they will realize that if they try to stop it they will be going against the United States.''
That the White House statement did not include overt recognition of the new government was also calculated, explained Lithuanian diplomats; they said their countrymen want to make sure that the new government is allowed by Moscow to take over the reins of power before they aggressively seek world recognition.
Asked whether the United States would establish diplomatic ties with Lithuania, the State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, said: ''We recognized the independent state of Lithuania in 1922, and United States practice has been to establish formal relations with the lawful government of any state - once that government is in effective control of its territory and capable of entering into, and fulfilling, international obligations. When we are satisfied that the Lithuanian government can meet these requirements, we will establish formal diplomatic relations.''

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
Gorbachev Seeks Party Overhaul but Not Open Election of Congress

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, March 11

 BODY:
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today proposed a basic overhaul of the troubled Communist Party, but stopped short of demanding competitive secret-ballot participation by all 19 million Communists in the election of the 5,000 delegates to the approaching party congress.
Party insurgents seeking emergency doses of democratization had been urging direct competitive elections of congress delegates as their best chance for rapidly opening the party up to pluralism and stave off the collapse Communism has suffered in Eastern Europe.
Mr. Gorbachev, however, beginning a difficult week in his strategy to de-emphasize the party's position and seek a greatly enhanced role as national President, proposed a crucial compromise that would let local party organizations decide the precise details of electing delegates to the convention, which is due to open in July and debate retreating from the party's traditional monopoly of national power.
The Soviet leader made his proposals at a closed meeting of the party's Central Committee. A tightly limited account of the meeting was offered by Tass, the official press agency. 
At the meeting, Mr. Gorbachev urged that democratization be used to make ''the focus of party life'' the individual party members, who have in the past been treated as passive followers in the affairs of the traditionally oligarchic party.
 
Sweeping Changes Uncertain
But it was far from clear that his long list of proposals offered in the name of decentralizing and democratizing the party machinery would effect sweeping changes in the party congress, whose meeting would begin July 2 under Mr. Gorbachev's plan.
The proposals to overhaul the party that he did offer included several that were expected, including ending the General Secretary's role and installing more of a shared-authority party system relying on a chairman assisted by deputies. He also proposed a two-term limit on party official posts, and a sharing of the central party members' dues with local party groups.
These and other measures appeared secondary to the proposal that local party organizations retain control over the selection of party congress delegates, although in some otherwise unspecified ''elective'' process. This is a move likely to invite less, not more democratization as entrenched machines protect their patronage from insurgents' challenge.
The next step in Mr. Gorbachev's double-edged move to switch his executive focus from party to Government will begin on Monday, when the party hierarchy he addressed today goes into recess and the nation's elected Parliament takes center stage to consider Mr. Gorbachev's proposal for a more powerful governmental presidency who eventually would be popularly elected.
With considerable prodding from the Soviet leader, this ''super presidency'' proposal already has been approved by the Supreme Soviet, Parliament's standing chamber. The other chamber, the Congress of People's Deputies, will take up the issue Monday, with 1,500 of the 2,250 votes needed for approval.
 
First Elected by Congress
Under the Gorbachev proposal, the first five-year term of the strengthened presidency would initially be filled not by popular election but by a vote among the congressional deputies. Critics in the Congress's nascent minority opposition already have denounced this provision, saying it weakens the idea of popular democracy, even though many of them concede that Mr. Gorbachev is now the only figure with the standing to take up emergency powers to deal with the deepening economic and political crises.
Critics have been complaining as well that the rush to institute such a powerful post would be accomplished without benefit of the constitutional changes promised by Mr. Gorbachev as a basic part of his program for national renewal. Opponents fear the Gorbachev proposal will permanently weaken the legislature's fledgling role in national affairs and end all chances of an effective system of checks and balances.
The presidency bill would increase Mr. Gorbachev's present powers to rule by decree under a cabinet system. He would also have veto power over parliamentary actions, subject to the Supreme Soviet's overrule by two-thirds of its members. Even then, Mr. Gorbachev could appeal the overrule directly to the people's deputies.
There was some expectation that the closed meeting today of the 250-member party hierarchy, the Central Committee, might be the first to annoint the formality of Mr. Gorbachev's candidacy for the superpresidency. But no mention of this was made in the Tass report.
 
Two Separate Spheres
In effect, Mr. Gorbachev is acting this week in two ever more separate spheres, easing the party from its position of dominance while using his control of the Congress to create the larger presidency he would use to execute national changes without the usual repeated need for persuading and cajoling a panel of party doubters.
The decision to give local party machines the crucial say in how to elect the party congress delegates underlined once again Mr. Gorbachev's centrist predilection for displaying compromise and gradualism in easing the party from its dominance even as events rush the process forward at an ever-increasing rate.
Politically, through five years of popular strategems and hierarchy prunings, the Soviet leader already has assumed many of the party's prerogatives himself or begun sharing them with the legislature. But the vast patronage machinery that controls government and business institutions across the nation has remained largely inert in the face of his demands for change, and this is one of the targets of his dual political and governmental activity this week.

HEADLINE: Elected President Replaces Pinochet

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VALPARAISO, Chile, March 11

 BODY:
The long and often bitter era of military rule came to an end in Chile today with the installation of Patricio Aylwin, a genial Christian Democrat and longtime political figure, as the elected successor to Gen. Augusto Pinochet.
Hours later, returning in triumph to Santiago, the capital, after his inauguration in the unfinished new Congress building in this Pacific port city, President Aylwin promised to do everything possible to establish the truth about the repression of the Pinochet period.
Declaring that Chile ''doesn't want violence or war, it wants peace,'' he said he would ''build the country we dream of.''
The passions and controversies that surrounded General Pinochet throughout his 16 1/2 years in power followed him into the plenary hall of the Congress for the ceremony. 
A small group of people threw tomatoes and other objects at the general when he approached the Congress in a black limousine convertible, but nothing appeared to have hit him.
Chants of ''Pin-o-chet, Pin-o-chet!'' and ''A-se-si-no, a-se-si-no!'' - meaning ''Assassin!'' - came from his supporters and opponents as he climbed the steps to the soaring portico looking out toward the Pacific Ocean. The same competing chants resounded inside the hall. Mr. Aylwin and General Pinochet stood side by side as Sen. Gabriel Valdes, elected president of the new Senate earlier in the day, swore in Mr. Aylwin in a brief ceremony without speeches.
 
A Broad Coalition
Mr. Aylwin embraced Mr. Valdes, a fellow Christian Democrat, and shook hands with General Pinochet, who then left the hall with his wife and ministers, stopping along the way to shake hands with Mrs. Aylwin.
Mr. Aylwin swore in a 20-man Cabinet that reflected the broad coalition from center to left that brought him to power, then departed in a 1962 black Ford convertible that had been used by Eduardo Frei, the only previous Christian Democratic President of Chile.
Back in Santiago, 75 miles southeast of here, tens of thousands of people lined the city's main thoroughfare, the Alameda Bernardo O'Higgins, as Mr. Aylwin arrived at La Moneda, the presidential palace. Half-destroyed by bombing in the Sept. 11, 1973, coup against President Salvador Allende Gossens, it has since been restored and refurbished. Even though the new legislative complex is being built in Valparaiso, the executive branch will remain in Santiago.
General Pinochet, who called free elections after losing a plebiscite to extend his rule by eight years, urged Chileans in a television address on Saturday night to ''unite in one fraternal embrace'' and show a ''responsible attitude'' toward their new leader.
 
A Short Guest List
The international isolation that the Pinochet Government faced manifested itself to the end, with only three foreign Presidents - those of Argentina, Uruguay and Brazil - arriving while General Pinochet was still in power and, therefore, in time to take part in the formal inauguration.
Eight other national leaders, including Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez of Spain and President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua, deliberately planned their arrivals for a few hours after the new Government had taken power. They were invited to take part in celebrations in honor of President Aylwin tonight, and some will remain for events on Monday and Tuesday.
Vice President Dan Quayle, leading a delegation that included Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, arrived late Saturday and paid a courtesy call on General Pinochet this morning before the inauguration. General Pinochet had said that no delegation leader could attend the inauguration without first presenting credentials to him.
Several hundred supporters of General Pinochet were massed outside his residence, and as Mr. Quayle's caravan pulled away they beat and kicked the Vice President's bulletproof Cadillac and other vehicles. Mr. Quayle said he had told General Pinochet that if the transfer of power went peacefully, ''the 1990's will write the history of President Pinochet as much as the years in the past.''
 
Keeping Command
Even though he has given up the Presidency, the 74-year-old general is allowed by the Constitution to continue as army commander, a fact that has led to concerns among many people that he will try to function as a parallel power.
But Mr. Aylwin has said he can work with General Pinochet as long as the general stays within his constitutional role, which means he is not supposed to interfere in politics. Mr. Aylwin, a 71-year-old lawyer and former senator who supported the 1973 coup, has harmonious relations with leaders of the air force, the navy and national police.
The main reason General Pinochet has given for holding onto his army command in the face of Mr. Aylwin's request two months ago that he step aside is that he feels he must be there to protect members of the army from possible prosecution for the political killings, disappearances and torture of prisoners that occurred under his rule.
The new President has said he will not intentionally set out to persecute General Pinochet or anyone under him but that neither will he block congressional or judicial investigations that might lead to charges.
 
A List of Abuses
Abuses attributed to the Pinochet Government fall into three categories. First, an unknown number of people, possibly as many as 1,000, died in the days and weeks immediately after the coup, many in executions and many others in shootouts between troops and members of the Communist Party and armed groups of the far left. Second, nearly 700 people disappeared in the 1974-77 period after being detained by the intelligence police. Finally, countless others have been reported tortured while in detention.
With Chile's economy the healthiest in South America, it is the human rights issue that will probably be the toughest challenge for Mr. Aylwin in his first months in office. He has to find a way to avoid confrontation with General Pinochet and the army while responding to demands for justice from victims and their families.
About 400 people are currently imprisoned on charges that human rights groups say are political.

HEADLINE: No Advantage for Disadvantaged Found in a 60's Military Program

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 11

 BODY:
A Vietnam-era program intended to give poor youths and those with low aptitudes a ''leg up'' on life by lowering standards for entry into the military was a failure, a new study says.
Allowing those people to enter military service did not improve their lot later in civilian life, said the study, conducted for the Defense Department by the Human Resources Research Organization of Alexandria, Va.
''In fact,'' it added, ''in terms of employment status, educational achievement and income, those who never served were better off than those who had been in the military.'' 
''These data provide no evidence to support the hypothesis that military service offers a 'leg up' to low-aptitude and disadvantaged youth as they seek to overcome their cognitive and skill deficits and compete successfully in the civilian world,'' the study said.
About 300,000 entered the service under the program from 1966 to 1971, with nearly two-thirds entering the Army. Fifty-four percent were volunteers, and 46 percent were draftees.
 
Named by McNamara
Janice H. Laurence, a social scientist with Human Resources Research, told the House Veterans Affairs Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations last month that the project's ''social promises were not kept.''
Under the program, advanced by Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara, the military was viewed as a steppingstone for social advancement.
The study raises questions about current proposals to encourage the use of the military to some help youths overcome social and educational disadvantages.
Under the program, ''low-aptitude recruits'' - those scoring below a normal cutoff on the Armed Forces Qualification Test - entered the service with promises of traditional and remedial skill training.
Half the those who entered the program came from the South. More than 40 percent were from minority groups, and the average reading ability was at the sixth-grade level.
Most went to combat or to jobs like food service, supply, wire communications, motor transport and automotive repair.
Flaws in the enlistment test allowed another group of about 300,000 people - also lacking the traditional qualifications - to enter the military from 1976 to 1980, the study said.
 
Lagging Behind in Life
According to the study, veterans of the project wound up earning $5,000 to $7,000 less per year than their nonveteran counterparts. Veterans were more likely to be unemployed, less likely to be married and more likely to have been divorced.
The low-aptitude veterans who served from 1976 to 1980 were not found to be better off economically, educationally or socially than their non-veteran counterparts. There were no significant differences regarding employment status, occupational category or average income, the report said.
But the veterans had less formal education, had higher divorce rates and were more likely to be dissatisfied with their jobs.
Ms. Laurence offered no reasons, but gave some theories: employers may be biased against veterans; time away from ''mainstream civilian activities and pursuits'' may be damaging, and the transition to civilian life is particularly hard for those of low aptitude.
