LENGTH: 1065 words

HEADLINE: New Land Panel Has Trouble Gearing Up

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
The way New York City governs land, perhaps its most precious commodity, is in quiet turmoil these days, with the Dinkins administration behind schedule in putting in place changes under the new City Charter and developers rushing to act on big projects before the system changes.
Eleven days after the charter requires Mayor David N. Dinkins and other city officials to have appointed a chairman and all the members of a new 13-member City Planning Commission, none have been named. The existing 7-member commission, which will review projects until the end of June, has two vacancies.
The City Council, which after Sept. 1 will have final power for the first time over zoning changes and where to build city projects like jails and homeless shelters, does not yet know how often its committee on land use will meet, what its rules will be or just how it will divide its work. 
''It's sort of natural, because you have the old system rapidly ending, and the new system which is a mystery to everyone, and you have a gap where people don't know quite what to do,'' said City Council President Andrew J. Stein. ''It's a funny period.''
So far, no projects have been delayed by the slowness in naming the new commission because it is not to begin reviewing projects until July 1. Among the many problems to be resolved are new guidelines governing the ''fair-share distribution'' among communities of city projects from sanitation garages to libraries. The Mayor is to propose such rules by July 1, and the staff of the city planning department is working on them. But officials there say only so much can be done without a new chairman in place.
''It's all extremely important,'' said Jeannette D. Kahlenberg, executive director of the Citizens Union, a civic group that supported the new charter last year. ''This is a land city and that's the most important new area the Council has taken over. If things are behind now, what's going to happen in the future?''
So sensitive is the subject that several lawyers, business executives and lobbyists for major developers declined to comment on the record, for fear of alienating the new Mayor or council members who will have power over their projects. But a number said they receive constant inquiries about the changes and uncertainties.
''You've got a client and you want to take them to talk to somebody,'' said one former city official who is now a lawyer in private practice. ''You can't do it, because the people you need to talk to either aren't there yet or aren't sure themselves how things will work.''
And while Mr. Dinkins voted for many major projects as Manhattan borough president, some developers fear that he will not be as sympathetic to their wishes as the former mayor, Edward I. Koch. Two weeks ago, in what some saw as an important test, the developer of the huge Riverwalk project on the East Side withdrew the proposal after the administration let it be known it would oppose it.
Mr. Dinkins had spoken out against the plan in the past, but it was supported by Mr. Koch and the city's Public Development Corporation, which was a co-applicant with the developer.
 
Changes Were Extensive
Mr. Dinkins's deputy mayor for planning and development, Barbara J. Fife, began negotiating changes to make the project more acceptable. Then city planners said such changes would be so extensive as to require the project to begin the review process all over again, and Mr. Dinkins's First Deputy Mayor, Norman Steisel, and Mrs. Fife decided simply to oppose it.
Mrs. Fife said the Mayor was working on choosing a planning commission chairman but could not say when one would be appointed.
Among the names that have been mentioned as possible candidates are Edward L. Sadowsky, a lawyer and former Councilman, Edward Wallace, a former Councilman and aide to former City Council President Carol Bellamy and Linda Davidoff, head of the Parks Council, a nonprofit civic group.
Mayoral aides said the other six mayoral appointees to the new commission were being held up because of delays by the city's screening panel and delays in background checks.
Mr. Stein and each of the five borough presidents must also appoint one member to the commission, and some of them have set up screening panels of their own. Several of these elected officials said they also wanted to see who the Mayor named to the commission before making their own appointments.
 
Ruled Unconstitutional
Now, the six-month Uniform Land Use Review Process, known as Ulurp, that virtually all major projects must undergo is geared to the twice monthly meetings of the Board of Estimate, which has the final say. Consideration of projects begins with a 60-day advisory review by the local community board, 60 days at the Planning Commission and another 60 days at the estimate board.
But the board was ruled unconstitutional last year, and voters approved a new charter that redistributes its powers, which are being phased out.
In recent weeks, developers have pressed to have a number of major projects certified by the city planning department as ready for review, so they will still be considered by the Board of Estimate.
Among these proposed projects are a major biotechnology building by Columbia University in Washington Heights and a major commercial residential development along the Queens waterfront in Long Island City known as Hunter's Point.
 
'Knowing What Buttons to Push'
''There's a sense of knowing what buttons to push when you go to the Board of Estimate,'' Mrs. Fife said, ''in the other case, there's uncertainty. It's a case of the devil you know versus the devil you don't.''
Any big project for which the formal review process has not already begun, is virtually certain to end up at the Council. One of the first major plans that is expected to go through the new process is the huge Trump City proposal for the Upper West Side.
Council members themselves say they are conscious of the responsibilities that are about to fall on them.
''It hasn't yet reached the point where people start to come to your door to talk about it,'' said Councilman Walter L. McCaffrey of Queens, chairman of the land-use committee's subcommittee on franchises. ''My concern is that suddenly on a Monday morning my staff is going to hand me seven messages from seven different people, all wanting to talk with me at once.''

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Japanese Work To Link Business To Philanthropy

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
Last fall, five days before the Mitsubishi Estate Company of Tokyo bought control of the Rockefeller Group, which owns Rockefeller Center, Mitsubishi's sister companies made another New York investment.
This one was considerably smaller and generated less publicity than the Rockefeller Center deal, but its implications could be nearly as profound: Several Mitsubishi companies and other Japanese corporations underwrote the first United States tour by the Takarazuka Revue dance troupe. In its debut at Radio City Music Hall, the troupe raised $100,000 in a benefit for the United Way of New York City.
The Rockefeller Center deal was among the most dramatic examples of Japan's appetite for American companies - it even prompted some Japanese to caution against acquisitions with such symbolic value. (In New York, the Japanese represent the largest contingent among foreign-owned banks; they are second among foreign companies in commercial real-estate holdings and third in hotel space). 
The investment in United Way was emblematic of another trend: a broadening embrace by Japanese-owned companies of the American tradition of corporate philanthropy.
Hisao Kondo, president of Mitsui & Company (U.S.A.), Inc., has become what the New York City Chamber of Commerce hails as the first foreign national to be elected a director of the chamber in more than two centuries. About 60 of the chamber's 1,500 member companies are Japanese owned.
Mr. Kondo and Minoru Makihara, president of the Mitsubishi International Corporation, have also been elected partners of the New York City Partnership, the chamber's sister organization, which promotes corporate social responsiblity. Last fall, Mr. Kondo, who is president of the Japanese Chamber of Commerce and Industry of New York, joined the board of United Way. Sam Kusomoto, president of the Minolta Corporation in the United States, sits on United Way's board in Bergen County, N.J.
The emerging spirit of volunteerism marks a profound strategic shift. Underlying earlier reticence was the short tenure of many Japanese nationals in this country and, more fundamentally, a culture gap: ''Good corporate citizenship is not second nature to the Japanese,'' said John K. Wheeler, vice president of the Japan Society in New York. In Japan there has been little private involvement in public affairs.
When Ronald K. Shelp, president of the New York City Partnership, tried to explain to Japanese executives the role of private industry in addressing social problems, one businessman interjected: ''Which branch of government did you say you work for?''
But in 1988, the Keidanren - the Japanese business federation - said the lack of philanthropy by Japanese concerns abroad ''would be detrimental to their harmonious integration into host communities and would also invite unfavorable impacts and friction.''
Last month, the Japanese Foreign Ministry proposed to offer Japanese companies tax deductions for philanthropy in this country. Next month, the Keidanren is sending another study mission here to explore community service.
Philanthropy and volunteerism represent a vehicle for improving recruiting, enhancing government relations, providing tax deductions and for ''gaining acceptance and thereby improving American community perception of the Japanese transplant company,'' says a ''call to action'' just issued by the Japanese Chamber of Commerce of New York.
''All of this comes down to the bottom line: community involvement and volunteer programs are ultimately good for business,'' the chamber's guide concludes.
Early Japanese versions of involvement were largely limited to endowing professorships, subsidizing research and giving money but remaining disengaged. More recently, volunteerism has manifested itself in more direct efforts, ranging from Hitachi America Ltd.'s commitment to Tarrytown's schools and hospitals to participation in the New York City Partnership's summer-jobs program by Mitsui and the Japanese Chamber of Commerce.
Increasingly, Japanese companies are being courted by potential beneficiaries of partnerships, which are viewed as one means of ameliorating economic conflict between the two countries. Moreover, community involvement conforms to a more familiar Japanese tradition of creating long-term relationships.
''If Japan is going to be investing as a partner they feel it's essential to become part of the community,'' said Penelope Benson-Wright, director of the New York-Japan Initiative, founded by the New York Chamber and Partnership.
''We think the future of the city depends on their active involvement,'' Mr. Shelp said.

HEADLINE: Last Cast of 'Chorus Line' Wonders About Taking Its Next Steps

BYLINE: By MERVYN ROTHSTEIN

 BODY:
For 25-year-old Jack Noseworthy, singing and dancing in ''A Chorus Line'' was always the stuff of dreams. Last month, Mr. Noseworthy's dreams came true. He was offered, and he accepted, a role in the Michael Bennett musical, the longest-running show in Broadway history. And then came the afternoon of Feb. 21.
''That day, the day they announced the closing of the show, was my opening-night performance,'' Mr. Noseworthy recalls with a shrug while sitting in a dressing room at the Shubert Theater, where the musical has been playing since July 25, 1975. ''I left 'Jerome Robbins's Broadway' to come here. And my immediate thought was that I'm going to be out of a job.''
Joseph Papp, head of the New York Shakespeare Festival, the musical's producer, announced on Feb. 21 that the 15-year run of ''A Chorus Line'' would end on March 31, after 6,104 performances. The 32 cast members, including Mr. Noseworthy, would all be out of work, most of them facing the painful prospect of going from audition to audition in search of a job. 
It was a case of life imitating art, because ''A Chorus Line'' is about the thoughts, fears and frustrations of chorus dancers looking for work. In the show, 17 performers take part in an audition, competing for 8 jobs in a Broadway musical. ''I really need this job,'' they sing. ''I hope I get it. How many people does he need?''
 
The Real Job
They talk, dance and sing about the trials and tribulations they are willing to put up with, the long periods of unemployment many of them accept out of their love for what they do, their need to get on a stage in front of a thousand or more faces in a darkened theater and grab their moment in the spotlight. To get there, they accept the often demeaning process of audition and rejection until some director decides they are just the right ones for what he has in mind.
''It's unquestionably a tough life,'' Mr. Papp says. ''But there's an essential quality I have found in all the dancers. There's a kind of courage there and a lack of self-pity. There's a strong sense of affirmation. They just keep going and they still manage to smile.''
As one veteran cast member, Angelique Ilo, who plays Judy Turner, the somewhat daffy dancer from El Paso, Tex., says: ''A performer's job is looking for a job. And if you don't come to terms with that, you're in the wrong business.''
Many cast members, however, have not had to endure long periods of unemployment in the last decade. They have had the security of ''A Chorus Line,'' a show they could leave for other shows and return to when the other shows closed. But now that security is gone, and for some, it is time for making decisions.
 
The Old and the Young
Some say the moment has come to weigh whether they are finally too old to continue dancing - though none can agree on precisely what the words ''too old'' mean. There are thoughts of leaving the business, as at least one did when unemployment became too tough to bear. Where to go, though, is a tough question. For a few there is the possibility of moving from dancing to choreography, or becoming stage managers.
Many, however, are quite young and have been lucky and talented enough to get fairly steady work in their first few years in the business. But even they worry that perhaps their time of unemployment, the word they have heard so much about, has come.
Mr. Noseworthy, who had been in ''Jerome Robbins's Broadway'' for a year and a half, says he does not regret making the move. ''This month is going to be exciting, and I think only positive things can come of it,'' he says of his role as Mark, the youngest dancer at the audition, fresh off the bus from Tempe, Ariz. ''I had seen 'A Chorus Line' 10 years ago, and what always attracted me about the show was its history. And now I'm going to be a part of that history.''
He has worked for pretty much all his three-and-a-half years in the business. Now, he says, he will ''audition for whatever there is to audition for.''
''I'm a little neurotic, though, and I'm hoping that it won't be too long that I'm unemployed, because I haven't experienced that feeling and I don't know what to expect,'' he says. There is the possibility of returning to ''Jerome Robbins's Broadway,'' he adds, ''but there has to be an appropriate opening; if the tall, blond girl on the left leaves, they're not going to hire me.''
 
An Actress in 5 Roles
Laurie Gamache, 30, has the major role of Cassie, the former star who is trying to make a comeback and is willing to take a job in the chorus. Ms. Gamache has been with the show since 1980, when she was hired during an audition in Iowa, her home state, just after graduating from college. She has played the roles of Sheila, Kristine, Judy and Bebe, as well as Cassie, on Broadway, in the national and international companies, on the bus-and-truck tour and on tours of Japan, Europe and Canada. She is part of a singing group called Blue Avenue, which also includes two present members and one former member of the company, and all are hoping to develop the group further as a cabaret act.
After all these years, she says, auditioning will be strange, but she is not worried. ''There are a lot of places around the country where I can work,'' she says. ''Whether or not I will be the lead in a Broadway show again is a different question. It's a pretty big dream to think about getting my picture outside in front of a theater again.''
 
The Only Original
Robert LuPone, 43, is the only member of the original cast now in the show. In 1975 and 1976, he played Zach, the director who decides which performers will make it into the chorus; he was away for 12 years, and then in 1988 he became Zach again. In between his two stints, he says, he did ''films, television and theater, and I formed my own theater company, the Manhattan Class Company.''
When the show folds, he says, he plans to ''continue doing films, television and theater.''
''I'm a working actor, and I will continue to be one,'' he says. ''If not, I'll do something else. If all else fails, I have my own company.''
Michael Gruber, 25, plays the role of Mike, who studied tap when he was young because his sister was taking lessons. Mr. Gruber already has another job: He leaves May 1 for the Vienna company of ''42d Street.'' ''A Chorus Line'' is his first Broadway show. He has been in the business only about two years, and he has been in ''A Chorus Line'' since January 1989. ''I've really only been out of work three months tops,'' he says, ''but then I haven't been in the business long.''
William Mead, on the other hand, is very familiar with the long periods of unemployment the show speaks about. ''I've left the theater several times because of them,'' he says. ''Once I didn't dance for almost seven years. It was when I went to see 'A Chorus Line' that I decided I wanted to dance again.''
Mr. Mead understudies four roles in the musical and has been a dancer for 30 years. He has been with ''A Chorus Line'' on and off for four years, including the last two and a half. Now, he says, he is trying to put together a solo act, and he will start auditioning, ''for summer stock, I guess.''
 
A Month Off to Decide
Fraser Ellis, 33, is an understudy and assistant stage manager who joined the bus-and-truck company in 1981 and has been with ''A Chorus Line'' for eight and a half years. ''The closing is sad for me because it represents getting older,'' he says, ''and that's always hard to come to terms with. You always think, 'What am I going to do when I can't dance anymore?' and now it's a reality.''
He is a member of Blue Avenue. He is also ''toying with the idea that I might make a career move to something else,'' though he is not sure what. ''I'm not worrying about surviving, but I've been out of the mainstream of auditioning for a long time. It may be time to stop dancing. That's why I'm taking a month off to decide what to do.''
Troy Garza, another member of Blue Avenue, also has a decision to make. Mr. Garza, who will be 36 this year, is the dance captain. He was in the original London company in 1976, spent 20 months on the road and came into the New York production late in 1977, more than 12 years ago.
''Being out of work is a bummer,'' he says. ''I thought I would want to take two months off, but now that there's a visible end in sight I would rather keep working. I have a choice of whether I want to stick to captaining or get into choreographing. But I find that I do like performing a lot more than I thought I did.''
Gordon Owens, 31, plays Richie, who gave up the idea of teaching for the glamour and risk of the stage. Mr. Owens has been in the show off and on for 10 years. ''This time it's been a year,'' he says. ''I joined in 1980, quit, did 'Dreamgirls,' came back, did 'Starlight Express' and came back for the third time.''
Now, he says, he is working on a couple of plays in development, including one that is to have a staged reading and that he hopes will turn into a full-scale production. He has also written a screenplay - ''and I am determined to fight for it until it gets done.''
 
The Reason for Dancing
Doug Friedman, 26, plays Greg, the former Sidney Kenneth Beckenstein, who is the most experienced of the dancers. He has been with the show only four months, but those four months have meant a great deal to him. ''This is why I became a dancer,'' he says. ''I saw this show with my junior high school class when I was 13 years old, and once I saw it, I decided I wanted to be a dancer. I wanted to be in 'A Chorus Line.' ''
In the eight years he has been in show business, he has done the national tour of ''Cabaret,'' ''A Chorus Line'' in Europe and on the road, and a revival of ''Mack and Mabel'' that was supposed to go to Broadway but didn't. And, he says, he has performed on ''cruise ships and things like that.''
''There was a time, about a year and a half, when I couldn't get a job,'' he says. ''You just wind up at unemployment. I waited tables, and that was fun sometimes. And then I started performing, and for two years it's been good. Like a miser, I saved my money. I wanted to buy a co-op.'' Now, he says, he has begun auditioning again. And he's also doing something else: ''I'm closing on my co-op.''
Finally, there is Ms. Ilo, who is one of those who has thought about the words ''too old.'' She has spent 5 of the last 10 years in the show, and at one point played Cassie. ''I came back as Judy after I had two babies,'' she says.
''I've been in show business since I was 17 - I won't tell you my age,'' she says. ''And at times I think, 'Aren't you getting a little old for this?' I don't know. I don't think you ever get too old to do it. So I think I'll audition for anything I think I'm right for. And I think I'm going to keep on auditioning until they tell me I'm getting too old to do this.''
She laughs. ''And maybe even then I won't believe them,'' she says. ''After all, as long as I can keep kicking. . . . ''

HEADLINE: Christie's Reverses Stand on Price Guarantees

BYLINE: By RITA REIF

 BODY:
Christie's, one of the world's two major auction houses, has abruptly reversed a longstanding policy and has guaranteed a minimum price for a collection of artworks it is to auction in May.
''During the last 12 months or so, we have in certain cases found it difficult to compete without offering guarantees,'' Christopher Davidge, the managing director of Christie's International, said late last week by telephone from London. ''It is a recognition with executors and trustees that we have to be competitive.''
Mr. Davidge cited an increased demand for guarantees over the last year in announcing that his auction house has guaranteed five paintings to be sold for heirs of Robert Lehman, the financier, at Christie's in New York on May 15. The presale estimate for the collection is $40 million to $60 million. Mr. Davidge would not say what the guarantee figure was, other than to say it was between the high and low estimates. 
 
A Lure for Sellers
In the high-flying and increasingly lucrative business of fine-art auctions, the guaranteed price has become a powerful magnet for houses to attract sellers. As prices skyrocketed into millions of dollars, the demand for financial devices strongly increased.
Adherents say price guarantees are a perfectly reasonable way of bringing in new business and of lifting the burden of risk from sellers. Both adherents and detractors agree that guarantees have brought art to the auction market that would otherwise have passed through galleries or remained unsold. But the detractors contend that guarantees have served to inflate prices and, in giving the house a greater financial stake in the work of art, have provided further reason for buyers to beware.
No auction house has used the device more effectively in recent years than Sotheby's, the archrival of Christie's. In fact, Christie's has frequently been critical of the use of guarantees by Sotheby's.
When told that Christie's would now use guarantees, Diana D. Brooks, the president of Sotheby's in North America, said: ''I find it hypocritical after the public criticism Christie's has leveled at us for our practice of giving guarantees.''
Mr. Davidge, who controls Christie's policy worldwide, declined to say how often, under what terms and where Christie's would offer guarantees to clients in the future.
 
Competition for Consignment
Mr. Lehman, the financier, was chairman of the Metropolitan Museum of Art at his death in 1969. He left the paintings - an 1888 self-portrait by Vincent van Gogh and studies of women by Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec, Amedeo Modigliani, Pierre Auguste Renoir and Kees van Dongen -to the children (there were two and are now three) of his son, Robert Owen (Robin) Lehman, a film maker. Robin Lehman decided recently that the artworks should now be auctioned and with the trustees of the estate went to court to get permission to sell the five paintings.
Christie's had stiff competition in winning the Lehman collection from Sotheby's, which offered a guarantee, and from Acquavella Galleries, which offered to buy the collection for an undisclosed price. The prize painting of the group, the most valuable announced thus far for the May auction sales, is the van Gogh, which is expected to bring $20 million to $30 million.
''Guarantees are a very potent kind of lure,'' said David P. Tunick, a major New York art dealer. ''A guarantee is money in the bank. However, if a guarantee is not disclosed, the whole question of conflict of interest does arise. Once a guarantee is made, it means the auction house has equity in the object that is going to be sold.''
Mr. Tunick said this weekend that he was not surprised that Christie's had guaranteed the Lehman paintings. ''It is very clear that Christie's has caved in to the demands of the marketplace,'' he said. ''They have thrown their ideals to the wind. They took such a strong stand, and now it is a 180-degree reversal. I don't blame them. I think it is a very competitive situation.''
Sotheby's has used the guarantee to win consignments from museums, estates and owners of major artworks. Under a guarantee, the auction house and the seller agree on a minimum price, either for an individual work or for an entire lot, and the house must pay the seller at least that much, whether or not the art is sold.
The fate of any amount the house brings in over the guarantee depends on the individual deal. It may go to the seller, or it may be split with the auction house. The auction house becomes the owner of any unsold art.
 
Failure Could Bring Ruin
Sotheby's was not alone in offering guarantees. At least three other auction houses - Butterfield & Butterfield of San Francisco and Los Angeles, Habsburg, Feldman of Geneva and New York, and William Doyle Galleries of New York - offered them, too, but they have nowhere near the financial impact on the market of Sotheby's.
Until now, Christie's shunned guarantees, at least guarantees for which it would be responsible. For the last year or so, Christie's has said it would help clients to arrange third-party guarantees, possibly with a merchant bank in London, an offer on which there were no takers.
''We want to remain at arm's length on a transaction,'' the president of Christie's in New York, Christopher Burge, said in late January. ''If a guarantee goes wrong in a down market, it could destroy the business. In the long run, it could be fantastically dangerous to the business itself.''
Mr. Burge said Saturday, ''I am happy to stand by what I said earlier.''
Mr. Davidge said he still agrees with Mr. Burge that the failure of an expensive guaranteed work or collection to sell could ruin Christie's.
''We stand by what we have always said,'' Mr. Davidge said. ''Guarantees are not the proper business of the auction process. As far as I am concerned, we do not like guarantees. We do not believe they should be offered. However, we do have an ability to give a guarantee and still maintain a professional standard that people seek from us.''
Mrs. Brooks of Sotheby's said, ''I find it hard to believe they are going to be giving guarantees if they don't believe they should be doing it.''
 
Demand Is Increasing
The detractors of guarantees, art dealers being among the most vocal, have had some effect. Sotheby's announced early this year that it would fully disclose what works or collection had guarantees and mark them prominently in its sale catalogues, eliminating what to some extent had been guesswork for potential buyers.
During the first four months of the auction season, which began in September, the sum of Sotheby's guarantees represented 10 percent of its $1.5 billion in international sales - more than three times the value in guarantees of any comparable period in the past.
''Guarantees seem to be more in demand,'' Mrs. Brooks said. ''We did increase our market share in 1989.'' She added that in the fall period Sotheby's market share, which was 55 percent in 1988, rose to 58 percent. ''The guarantee definitely helped that.''
Sotheby's May sales are to offer numerous guarantees, the largest of which is the early 20th-century art holdings from the estate of Lydia Winston Malbin, valued at $65 million to $85 million. A lawyer for the Malbin estate, Ralph E. Lerner, said Sotheby's price guarantee was the crucial factor. No Longer Impartial? Dealers have criticized Sotheby's role as potential owner, saying it compromised the house's function as an impartial agent for both the seller and buyer by serving as a banker for the seller. Dealers say that buyers should be wary because guaranteed works may be overestimated or overpublicized, but no specific incidents have been cited. They have also questioned Sotheby's wording - or absence of it - on guaranteed offerings in its catalogues. In New York sales through December, Sotheby's identified guaranteed lots as properties in which the auction house ''has an interest,'' without saying which of several forms of interest it was. In London, guarantees have not been identified at all.
Last fall, the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs, responding to inquiries from the press, informally looked into Sotheby's policies on disclosure of guarantees but said it found no violations of regulations. Because of the widespread discussion in the press about financing and guarantees, though, Sotheby's reviewed its programs and said it would make some changes anyway. These were announced in January. ''We are going to disclose guarantees in our sales all over the world,'' Mrs. Brooks said. Any individual property or collection auctioned with a guarantee, she added, is to be identified with bold graphics - probably a circle - and an explanation of the guarantee is to be included in the front of all its catalogues. The changes are to apply not just in New York, but to Sotheby's auctions worldwide as well. Mr. Davidge said the guarantee on the Lehman artworks would be noted in the catalogue.
Mrs. Brooks said Sotheby's would continue to guarantee some major individual artworks but would focus more on larger properties, preferably collections or groups of three or more items, ''to mimimize our risk by spreading it over many objects.''
When asked whether it is by design that individual works guaranteed are among the highest-priced, running to seven figures, Mrs. Brooks said: ''We have never established a minimum value of the collections or properties we will guarantee. We would do it on something valued at $100,000 if we really wanted it for sale.''
 
An Ambitious Guarantee
Probably the most ambitious guaranteed deal involved the sale at Sotheby's in October of the art and antiques collection of John T. Dorrance Jr., an heir to the Campbell Soup fortune; the sale totaled $131.3 million. The transaction was criticized because Sotheby's refused to acknowledge until December that it had guaranteed the collection.
Mrs. Brooks said Sotheby's guarantee was ''less than $100 million.'' However much it was, it was sufficient for Sotheby's to win the competition for the collection against Christie's and against Acquavella, the New York dealer, which offered $100 million for the artworks alone.
David Grimbley, of the London brokers UBS Phillips & Drew, said guarantees were a factor in Sotheby's success in the fall season. ''It is something that got them more business,'' he said. ''I think that Dorrance - historically a client of Christie's - went to Sotheby's because of the guarantee.''
Guarantees could present other problems, he said. ''The most dangerous situation for the art market would be if both companies offered guarantees - because then they would bid each other up.'' He said overly aggressive estimates on guaranteed artworks might result, spurring further inflation in the art market.
 
Revival of a Past Practice
The guarantee has been a source of dispute since it was secretly introduced at Sotheby's in New York. David J. Nash, who heads fine art sales at Sotheby's in New York, recalled the short but lively life of the guarantees after he and Peregrine Pollen, who was president of Sotheby's in New York when it was still known as Parke-Bernet Galleries, began them in 1972 or 1973 at a time when selling at auction, instead of through a dealer, was viewed as risky. The guarantee worked, wooing owners of major artworks like Norton Simon, the California industrialist; Arnold Maremont, a New York businessman, and the estate of the art dealer Edith Halpert and the contents of her Downtown Gallery.
The Arab oil embargo ended the art boom by mid-1974, and in 1975 the Department of Consumer Affairs changed its regulations, requiring auction houses to disclose any financial interests in their catalogues. When the art market heated up again in 1986, guarantees were revived.
Richard L. Feigen, a prominent New York dealer, is a frequent critic of guarantees, but that has not stopped him from negotiating four guarantees with Sotheby's, one of them for a painting he personally consigned and three for paintings he consigned for clients. Two of these paintings were sold for prices below the guarantee; one brought more than the guaranteed minimum, and one did not sell.
Mr. Feigen has criticized the guarantee as ''definitely inflationary.'' ''Free market forces are not allowed to go work,'' he said.
As for his using a device he condemns, he said: ''I used the guarantee in instances where we were agents for the vendor, where I am obligated to get the best possible terms for those vendors. That's my job.''

HEADLINE: Realty Hurts American Express

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 11

 BODY:
The American Express Company's dabble into real estate in the 1980's is proving to be one of its biggest blunders.
Now the company faces a difficult decision of whether to unload its primary real estate subsidiary. Such a move would please shareholders but infuriate thousands of people who bought partnership interests in real estate through Shearson Lehman Hutton, American Express's stumbling brokerage subsidiary.
In 1982 when it acquired the Balcor group, a leading seller of real estate partnerships, American Express hoped the new division would pick up the slack if business weakened at its brokerage subsidiary.
Balcor, which is based in Skokie, Ill., outside Chicago, sponsored partnerships that would invest in mid-size office buildings, shopping centers and apartment complexes. But most of the 153 realty partnerships that Balcor sponsored between 1982 and 1989 invested heavily in the Southwest and have stumbled badly during the economic slump in that region, unable to achieve the occupancy levels or rents that had been forecast, Balcor officials say. 
 
Paying the Banks
The partnerships have been forced to renegotiate or refinance scores of bank loans they obtained to buy property, and American Express has advanced nearly $250 million in loans and loan guarantees to keep the most troubled partnerships from defaulting.
Making matters worse is that another of Balcor's core businesses -real estate finance - is also not doing as well as American Express had hoped. Under Stephen Silverstein, Balcor's 41-year-old chief executive, Balcor accelerated a program of lending against commercial properties nationwide. By last November, the company had $1.1 billion in such loans, but repayment of $114 million has been listed as late. While Balcor has estimated that losses on those loans will not exceed $10 million, analysts are not nearly so optimistic.
Organizationally, Balcor is a part of Shearson, and its problems will show up in the brokerage's results. ''You're going to see Shearson take a big charge for Balcor in the first quarter,'' said Michael Blumstein, the brokerage analyst at the First Boston Corporation. ''A couple-hundred-million-dollar reserve for those Balcor loans wouldn't surprise me.''
 
Favoring a Sale
At American Express headquarters in New York, top company officials are understood to favor unloading Balcor. They think - and analysts agree - that selling Balcor would help American Express's stock, which has fallen in recent months in good part because of Balcor's problems as well as problems in the rest of Shearson Lehman Hutton.
But their decision is complicated by the fact that a sale would make it virtually certain that American Express would lose the $250 million it has sunk into the troubled Balcor partnerships. Even more important, given American Express's willingness to stick with the partnerships until now, a sale would probably provoke a furor among the hundreds of Shearson stockbrokers who sold interests in the partnerships and the 400,000 investors who invested in Balcor partnerships. While Balcor itself reported a profit last year because of its other businesses, many of the partnership investors face losses.
 
Keeping Investors at Bay
''There is a desire to keep investors at bay and Shearson stockbrokers at bay,'' said Michael Kirby, a principal at Green Street Advisers, a Newport Beach, Calif., firm that monitors real estate companies. ''Imagine what would happen if suddenly you had thousands of Shearson customers pounding on their brokers' doors, complaining about real estate partnerships that had gone bad. The brokers would then be screaming bloody murder to New York.''
Balcor investors have reason to be upset. An information circular distributed earlier this year under a Shearson recapitalization plan disclosed that some of the partnerships had halted interest payments to lenders while others had defaulted on loans and had their properties seized. As for the nearly $250 million that American Express has spent to keep the most troubled partnerships afloat, the information circular says that $32 million will probably never be recovered.
In an immediate financial sense, the risk to American Express or Balcor appears minimal because neither American Express nor Balcor guaranteed the partnerships' bank loans. But if the partnership investors incur big losses when their properties are sold - the outcome most outside experts expect - the reputation of Shearson's sales force could be sullied badly. That could be of much longer-term consequence than Balcor's bad loans.
 
Perspective on Revenue
In 1989 Balcor contributed revenue of $260 million to Shearson, which had total revenue of $12.5 billion, while the parent company had revenue $25.05 billion.
Balcor was founded in the early 1970's by Jerry Reinsdorf, a wealthy Chicagoan who is best known as the principal owner of the Chicago White Sox and the Chicago Bulls. Mr. Reinsdorf saw a niche for Balcor: sponsoring partnerships that would invest in mid-sized office buildings and apartment complexes.
His idea was a huge hit. Exploiting holes in the law permitting partnership shareholders to claim tax deductions well above their investments, Mr. Reinsdorf attracted money from individuals nationwide. In 1982, after he sold Balcor to American Express, money poured in as interests in Balcor partnerships were sold through Shearson offices around the country. Balcor raised $582 million in 1983, $630 million in 1984 and $835 milllion in 1985, making it the leading sponsor of realty partnerships for three consecutive years. At its peak, Balcor controlled properties worth more than $4 billion.
In January 1985, Mr. Reinsdorf turned over his duties at Balcor as chief executive to Mr. Silverstein, a former top finance executive at Playboy Enterprises Inc. who had been hired by Mr. Reinsdorf several months before. No sooner had the change in command taken place than did problems that had been brewing begin to surface.
 
Started to Realize
''When I came in, we started to realize that some of the properties were already not performing as planned,'' Mr. Silverstein said in an interview.
What no one had apparently realized, or acted on, was that Mr. Reinsdorf had sent the Balcor partnerships down a dangerous path, concentrating their investments in Dallas, Houston, San Antonio and other cities that depend on the oil and gas business. Balcor officials say a majority of the investments were in apartment complexes and smaller office buildings precisely the type of properties that have since fared the worst in the current oil recession.
''Jerry felt that the Sun Belt was the place to be investing,'' Mr. Silverstein said. ''If oil had gone to $100 a barrel, everyone would say we were the smartest guys in the world.''
Whether Shearson executives knew what was going on at Balcor during this period is unclear.
 
'All Over the Country'
Reached while traveling on Friday, Mr. Reinsdorf disputed Balcor's contention that Balcorps concentrated its holdings in Texas. ''Balcor was invested all over the country,'' he said. ''Texas was a state where we had a substantial stake, but so were Florida, Georgia, Nevada, California and Michigan. I don't think anybody would have foreseen that oil prices would fall off the table.''
As for American Express's involvement with Balcor, Mr. Reinsdorf said, ''We were autonomous, and they were not involved in the investment process. It would have been foolish, because that was not their expertise.
Mr. Silverstein, who had been on the job barely six months, then made a critical decision. Rather than let the partnerships collapse, he would attempt to renegotiate their bank loans and lease their buildings as fully as he could. He also persuaded American Express to begin making loans to partnerships most desperate for cash.
Mr. Silverstein's idea was simple: If the partnerships could be kept afloat there was at least a chance that their buildings could regain lost value.
 
A Doomed Business
Meanwhile, sensing that a pending tax-law change would doom Balcor's mainstay tax-shelter business, Mr. Silverstein immediately began moving Balcor away from partnerships and into lending.
As it turns out, Mr. Silverstein's strategy has been successful - to a limited extent.
Balcor's troubled loans notwithstanding, the lending operation has generated millions of dollars in interest income. The efforts to keep the partnerships alive have also been fruitful, reducing investors losses.
Working with Thomas Meador, Balcor's 42-year-old president, Mr. Silverstein has been able to stanch the cash-flow deficits that had been moving the partnerships closer to insolvency. At the same time, with the Southwest economy beginning to recover, he has been able to raise rents on certain partnership buildings, and the value of a number of the buildings has increased.
 
'Under Control'
''Right now, our feeling is that we have the situation under control,'' Mr. Silverstein said.
The problem is that Balcor investors want more than that. And as things now stand, Balcor officials acknowledge, it could be years, if ever, before investors get all their money back, let alone a return.
''Investors will get some of their money back to most of their money back,'' Mr. Meador said. ''But given the declines in the market, it's unlikely that you will get all of your money back plus a return.''
For Balcor investors, the story will have an painful epilogue. Because many of the investors claimed big tax deductions in the early years of their investment, they will face hefty capital-gains taxes when the properties are sold.

HEADLINE: Venezuela and Banks Near Agreement on Debt Relief

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Venezuela and its commercial bankers are moving toward a debt agreement that is expected to include a provision for substantial, but temporary, debt relief.
The relief would come in the form of a large reduction in the interest rates that Venezuela pays on its $21 billion of loans from commercial banks. These rates, now around 10 percent, could be reduced by several percentage points. If economic conditions improve over the next several years, the interest rates would return toward their present level. 
Commercial bankers and officials in the negotiations, which have been going on and off for more than a year, said the proposal was necessary because the bankers believe that Venezuela, unlike Mexico and Brazil, does not need debt reduction.
 
Political Motives Cited
The country's push for it, they argue, is politically motivated to help the Government win support for the difficult economic changes it put through to fight inflation. Those changes include the privatizing of state-owned industries and opening the economy to foreign investment. The restructuring has pushed the country into a deep recession, with the economy declining by at least 8 percent over the last year.
If an agreement is reached that contains the temporary reduction, it would be the latest under the Brady Plan, the Bush Administration's strategy to ease third world debt, named for Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady. Mexico was the first to reach an agreement under the Brady plan, which was announced a year ago. The Philippines and Costa Rica have also reached agreements.
''We are certainly moving very nicely in a very good atmosphere toward an agreement,'' said one banker about the Venezuela negotiations. ''In the next couple of weeks we could be there.'' Like others commenting on the negotiations, he asked not to be identified.
Miguel Rodriguez, the Minister of Economic Development and head of the Venezuelan negotiating team, was in New York last week to meet with the banks' advisory committee, led by the Chase Manhattan Bank.
 
Several Options
In a final plan, a temporary debt-reduction provision would be one of several options. Bankers and officials said the plan also contains an option to buy back debt, with Venezuela purchasing some existing debt at a discount below the face value that would be based on bids from banks.
It also contains an option, comparable to one in the Mexican agreement, that would set a specific level of debt reduction. It was 35 percent in the Mexican plan.
In Venezuela's case, the banks would exchange existing debt for securities with a lower face value or a lower interest rate. These securities would come with guarantees that would cover the principal and interest payments. The money for these so-called enhancements would be provided by the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and other countries, probably including Japan.
There is still intense discussion over the temporary debt-reduction proposal, bankers and officials said. In debt terminology, the provision is called recapture. While there were recapture provisions in the Mexican agreement, bankers involved in both sets of talks said the banks were unlikely to regain anything under the Mexican agreement because they were not very stringent.
''They are looking for something better, but I don't know if they are going to get it,'' one Bush Administration official said.
 
Advantage of Temporary Cut
Several bankers said a temporary debt-reduction option would probably offer a larger cut in interest rates than a proposal in which the level of debt reduction is set by agreement.
Another issue is the contention of some bankers that regardless of the debt reduction and loan options agreed upon, there is also a need to redefine the terms and conditions of Venezuela's existing debt. Bankers will also want Venezuela to keep current on interest payments. It has begun to pay some interest on its existing debt, bankers said, but is still behind on a payment that was due at the beginning of the year.
Venezuela's new President, Carlos Andres Perez, said when he took office a year ago that he wanted a 50 percent reduction in the country's existing debt to commerical banks, but bankers refused, saying no debt reduction was justified. In September, Mr. Rodriquez, the lead negotiator, proposed an approach that included the current list of options and backed away from the 50 perecnt demand.

LENGTH: 1699 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
A Freer, but Shrinking, Market

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUDAPEST, March 6

 BODY:
In Eastern Europe, Hungary is leading the way in shifting trade away from the Soviet Union and toward the West. The abrupt about-face has jolted many Hungarian companies that grew fat and happy relying on the huge Soviet market.
At Ikarus, one of the world's largest bus manufacturers, 11,000 workers are fuming over a Government order to cut exports to the Soviet Union by 1,000 buses this year. As a result, managers at Ikarus, where layoffs were long taboo, have for the first time announced a temporary ''forced holiday.'' More than 5,000 people have been idled for a month at the company's grimy jumble of hangar-like buildings.
Hungary is pressuring Ikarus and hundreds of other manufacturers, many of them state-owned, to export less to the Soviet Union. That is because Moscow still owes almost a billion rubles for all the buses, machinery and other Hungarian products it imported last year. 
 
Trade With West
Equally important, Hungary's Government wants to force the companies to sell more to Western Europe and the United States. This effort will push Hungary's inefficient enterprises to upgrade their products and production to Western standards. It will also provide the Government with much-needed hard currency -money like francs, marks and dollars that can be converted into other currencies - to make payments on its large foreign debt.
''This trade policy is part of the process of de-Sovietization,'' said Laszlo Lang, deputy director of the Hungarian Institute for Foreign Relations. ''We're seeing it not only in economics, but also in politics, defense and culture.''
Hungary's efforts to slash exports to the Soviet Union - whose appetite for imports is far larger than its ability to pay for them - are part of the huge economic changes sweeping through Eastern Europe as the region hurtles toward capitalism. Many economists predict that Czechoslovakia, Poland and other Eastern European nations will soon follow Hungary in pursuing a wrenching reorientation of their trade relations.
One of Hungary's aims is to reform or replace Comecon, the creaking Soviet-led trading group, with Western-style trading based on hard currency and world prices.
Such a move would at first be bitter medicine for Hungary. Its industry will be under severe pressure to become more competitive, because Comecon customers, long accustomed to barter trade, may decide that if they are paying hard currency, they might as well buy Western goods.
Some economists say a move toward hard-currency trading could cut trade among the Comecon countries by 50 percent and cause huge layoffs in many industries. At the same time, it could create huge opportunities for Western companies seeking to increase sales to Eastern Europe.
 
Bankruptcy Chain Feared
Industry is so rattled by the shock therapy that some economists fear a chain of bankruptcies, with Ikarus going under and pulling many of its suppliers down with it. Ikarus is widely viewed as the hardest-hit company because it historically exported more than 80 percent of its annual production of 12,000 buses to the Soviet bloc.
''We're in a difficult situation,'' said Zoltan Vadnai, the director of Ikarus's assembly plants. ''If Ikarus goes into the soup, all of Hungary is going to go with it.''
Some days Ikarus's management seems to spend more time lobbying Government officials for permission to export more to the Soviet Union than figuring out how to manage a scaled-down company. Last year, Ikarus exported 5,500 buses under an agreement between Budapest and Moscow. In January, the Trade Ministry reduced that to just 4,500 buses. Ikarus exported more than 3,000 buses last year to other Soviet bloc nations, but the Hungarian Government has ordered a freeze on exports to those nations. Another 1,000 buses went to the Soviet Union through barter agreements that Ikarus arranged itself.
''Things are very uncertain for us now,'' said Gyula Siska, a mechanic, as he labored on a red-and-white bus that had been destined for Czechoslovakia. Ikarus officials are now looking for another country to take these buses.
''Work is so slow nowadays that even those of us not on temporary layoff don't know how long we will be around,'' Mr. Siska said.
 
Better Buses for the West
The biggest shock has come at the assembly plant that makes buses destined for other Eastern European countries. There workers, many of them in their teens, toil at half speed on no-frills buses that use nongalvanized steel and low-horsepower engines based on 45-year-old designs.
Next door, at the plant for buses going to the West, the workers are older and more experienced. The buses are made with rust-resistant steel, often have powerful engines imported from the West, and are given a slick, shiny paint job that puts the Comecon buses to shame. The fully equipped versions for the West cost $150,000, more than five times what the Comecon buses go for.
Mr. Vadnai, the Ikarus manager, expects bus shipments to the East bloc to fall to about 6,000 this year from about 10,000 last year. By putting more energy in selling to the West, he expects hard-currency exports to double this year to about 2,000, which includes sales to Houston and Jacksonville, Fla.
But sales to the West will not come close to taking up the slack. ''It's not so easy to sell more buses to the West, which is already a very competitive market,'' said Mr. Vadnai. ''For us to concentrate on that market, someone would have to close down Mercedes-Benz and Daf,'' two of Western Europe's leading bus manufacturers.
Hungarian officials acknowledge that their tough policies will mean layoffs and other strains for a year or two, but they are confident their strategy will ultimately produce a more competitive, healthier economy. These officials have grown impatient with the Comecon system, which relies heavily on primitive barter. Not only that, they complain that Comecon's insular trading system promotes laxness by keeping inefficient companies alive as long as they feed the hungry Soviet market.
''The Soviet Union is much easier to sell to than any other market,'' said Sandor Richter, an economist and trade expert. ''Their technical requirements are much less than those of industrial nations. The Soviet Union buys a lot of goods that couldn't be sold elsewhere.''
 
Meaningless Trade Surplus
In 1989, Hungary ran up a trade surplus of 1.6 billion rubles with other Soviet bloc countries, but in the topsy-turvy world of Communist economics, a trade surplus is the last thing Government officials want. Under Comecon rules, a country with a surplus gets a i.o.u. that does not bear interest from its Socialist trading partners. So Hungary has received nothing in return for its surplus, which amounted to almost 3 percent of its economic output last year.
Hungarian officials have sought to reduce their trade reliance on the Soviet bloc, which takes about half of Hungary's exports, for three years, and in January, they stepped up their efforts. First, they froze all export licenses for the Soviet Union. Then they issued new permits, but at far lower levels than before. Machinery exports to the Soviet Union will be slashed by a third.
''A lot of people on the production line think what we are doing is madness,'' said Deputy Trade Minister Piroska Apro. ''But there is no other solution. We want to end this crazy system of barter within Comecon.''
Hungary is slashing exports to the Soviet Union because it is afraid of creating another huge trade surplus this year and wants Moscow to step up its exports to offset Hungary's 1989 trade surplus. The Soviet Union provides Hungary with oil, natural gas, chemicals, textiles and other raw materials, but Moscow's economic woes have caused its Comecon exports to dip.
Hungary is in a bind because the Soviet economic crisis has made it hard for Moscow to provide enough products for domestic consumers. Whatever products the Soviet Union can spare for export it would much prefer selling for hard currency than shipping to Hungary.
The Soviet Union and Hungary have agreed in principle that next year they will start carrying out their bilateral trade on a hard-currency basis at world prices. Surpluses at the end of the year would, in theory, be settled by a clearing in hard currency. This would replace a system using negotiated prices, unresolved surpluses and ''transfer rubles,'' a Comecon accounting unit.
Comecon's members are debating among themselves whether to follow Hungary's lead in moving toward hard-currency trade, something that would shake up all of Eastern Europe.
''The basic problem is that only part of the products exported to Comecon can be redirected to the West, the third world or the domestic market,'' said Bela Kadar, director of Hungary's Institute of Economic Planning. ''Many of these enterprises stuck to their comfortable market as long as they could.''
 
Marketing and Capital Needed
Now these enterprises need to learn to market to the West, and many of them will need Western capital, often through joint ventures, to upgrade their products and production.
But Mr. Vadnai, the Ikarus manager, and many Government officials say it is important not to shun the Soviet market. Mr. Vadnai said Ikarus has established a spare parts system, maintenance system and sales network throughout the Soviet Union, which gives his company a leg up on its competitors. ''We have the experience there, and if we start to ignore the market, then I'm sure Western companies will be eager to step in,'' he said.
Under the current trend, some experts say that Ikarus's annual production could fall to 6,000 buses within a few years and that its work force should be cut in half.
Still, the company has been reluctant to dismiss employees, trimming only 400 Polish and Czechoslovak guest workers. Ikarus officials say they hope the new Government that will be installed after elections later this month and next month will soften the hard-nosed policies.
In response, Mr. Apro, the Deputy Trade Minister, said, ''It's much easier for Ikarus's management to bring its demands to the Government than to put its own house in order.''

HEADLINE: Rostenkowski Presents Plan to Cut Deficit

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 11

 BODY:
In what he described as a budget challenge to his own party and the Bush Administration, the Democratic chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee today called for a combination of tax increases and spending cuts, including a one-year freeze on increases in Social Security benefits.
The chairman, Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, offered the proposals as a blueprint for reducing the Federal deficit by $511.6 billion over the next five years without what he called the ''smoke and mirrors'' and ''feel-good promises'' that have characterized past efforts at paring the deficit.
Mr. Rostenkowski's committee, one of the most powerful in the Congress, is responsible for writing tax legislation as well as for overseeing entitlement programs like Social Security and Medicare.
 
Challenge Issued
''Here's my challenge: adopt my plan to fix the deficit or come up with a better one,'' he said in an opinion article published today in The Washington Post.
He elaborated on his views this morning in a television interview on the CBS News program ''Face The Nation,'' saying he expected ''a verbal hazing'' from Democrats and Republicans over his call for a one-year freeze in Social Security cost-of-living increases. 
Judging by the polite, noncommittal responses from other lawmakers and Administration officials, there was little immediate indication that Mr. Rostenkowski could succeed in altering either the terms or the substance of the debate of fiscal policy.
Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House Democratic majority leader who was in California this weekend, declined to comment. A spokesman for Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who heads the Senate Finance Committee, said the Senator would have no immediate comment.
In a statement, Representative Leon E. Panetta, the California Democrat who heads the House Budget Committee, said, ''It has always been clear that tough choices have to be made on defense, entitlements and taxes if we are going to confront the deficit head on.''
White House officials did not respond publicly.
 
Catalyst for Talks
Avoiding any pointed criticism of President Bush, whom he describes as a close friend, Mr. Rostenkowski made clear he would like his plan to be the catalyst for high-level budget negotiations between Congress and the White House.
His aides said he had discussed the general outlines of the plan last week with the White House chief of staff, John Sununu, and the director of the Office of Management and Budget, Richard G. Darman.
Efforts by Mr. Rostenkowski to broker a similarly broad tax and budget package last year ended in his embarrassment and political isolation.
Mindful of Walter F. Mondale's stinging defeat in the 1984 Presidential election, in which he bluntly called for tax increases, Mr. Rostenkowski has always insisted that any broad tax increase plan would have to be endorsed by the White House. The Ways and Means panel will not begin its tax deliberations for at least another two months, and aides to the chairman said that if the White House is unresponsive to Mr. Rostenkowski's plan, he would abandon it.
In addition to taking aim at the politically sensitive Social Security program, Mr. Rostenkowski's proposal categorically rejects the Social Security tax cut suggested by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, and the reduction of the capital gains tax sought by President Bush and supported by a majority of the members of Mr. Rostenkowski's committee.
Instead, he proposed raising taxes on tobacco, alcohol, gasoline and pollutants; raising the Federal income tax rate that the highest income earners pay 33 percent, from the current 28 percent; freezing spending on domestic programs at current levels for one year, except for programs that cover the poorest citizens; eliminating for one year the tax provisions that automatically adjust tax brackets for inflation, and cutting the military budget by 3 percent from this year's spending level.
 
Candidates for Increases
Mr. Rostenkowski's plan envisions doubling the current tax of 16 cents a pack on cigarettes and doubling the taxes on beer and wine. The last time beer and wine taxes were raised was 1951 and 1955, respectively. All three categories are regarded as prime candidates for higher taxes this year, regardless of the fate of Mr. Rostenkowski's proposal.
The proposed 3 percent reduction in military spending would cut $10 billion from the Pentagon budget in 1991 and $150 billion over five years. All these cuts, he said, should be used to reduce the deficit rather than to fund other programs.
Mr. Rostenkowski also called for repeal of the 1987 Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget-balancing law.
''Gramm-Rudman is a crutch, a collective confession of our inability to lead and our unwillingness to face up to our responsibilities,'' he said in the article in The Washington Post. He added that his other proposals would cut the deficit to the point where the budget-balancing law would be irrelevant.
 
Detailed Tax Proposal
Although Mr. Rostenkowski has frequently spoken about the need for tax increases, the proposal he advanced today marks the first time he has laid out his views in so detailed and comprehensive a fashion.
While Mr. Rostenkowski's budget prescription draws on suggestions that have been advanced at various times by other lawmakers in both parties, it comes at a time when Democrats are deeply divided on how to respond politically or substantively to President Bush's unyielding opposition to tax increases and his go-slow approach to reductions in military spending.
Several major elements of his plan are at odds with the policy statements and proposals from other Democratic leaders, notably Mr. Gephardt and Mr. Bentsen.
Only last week, when asked by reporters whether the Democratic Party wanted to raise taxes, Mr. Gephardt replied: ''It is not the position of the Democratic Party to raise taxes.'' Mr. Bentsen has been urging a plan that would amount to a modest tax cut for middle-income taxpayers by expanding the limited deductions currently available for contributions to Individual Retirement Accounts.
But Mr. Rostenkowski's proposal rejects that approach as well as the Administration's variation on it, arguing that the measures are costly and unlikely to encourage more saving by Americans. Mr. Rostenkowski's long-held view that gasoline taxes should be increased has some support among Democrats and Republicans, but Mr. Bentsen, like most politicians from the Western and Southwestern states, is a vocal opponent.
 
Fairness of Tax Rates
The one element of the Rostenkowski blueprint that comes the closest to reflecting a consensus among Democrats is an effort to address the issue of tax fairness. In recent weeks, Congressional Democrats have produced a series of studies aimed at showing that tax changes over the last 15 years have resulted in a system that favors the wealthiest taxpayers.
Mr. Rostenkowski's proposal would address that issue in two ways: by raising the tax rate for the highest income earners and by allowing rebates on the gasoline tax for lower-income taxpayers.
Under an anomaly in the current tax system, people with taxable incomes of $47,050 to $109,00 and families with incomes of $78,400 to $185,730 pay a top tax rate of 33 percent. But taxpayers whose incomes exceed those amounts pay a top rate of 28 percent. Mr. Rostenkowski's plan would eliminate this so-called bubble in the tax code so that the top rate would be 33 percent for the wealthier as well.
When House Democratic leaders advanced a similar plan to change the top tax rate last year in an effort to counter Mr. Bush's capital gains tax cut proposal, they were deserted by 64 members of their party and suffered a humiliating defeat on the House floor. At that time, Mr. Rostenkowski was at best a lukewarm supporter of the leadership's proposal.
 
A Political Club
The last time that either party took a serious look at freezing cost-of-living adjustments in Social Security benefits was in 1982, when Senate Republicans got President Reagan to agree to it in principle as part of a broader deficit reduction package. But Democrats were quick to use the propsoal as a political club against Republicans, and Mr. Reagan altered his course.
Even suggesting a reduction in Social Security benefits has been virtually taboo ever since, although many lawmakers in both parties are willing to say privately that any serious proposal for dealing with the Federal defict must address the issue. Senator Moynihan said he would oppose a freeze on Social Security cost-of-living adjustments as a matter of principle, even though he agreed with many of the other suggestions in Mr. Rostenkowski's proposal.
''I think he's got a lot of votes in the cloakroom, and he would get a lot of votes on the floor if the Administration is willing to join him,'' Mr. Moynihan said of the overall plan.
But the Senator rejected Mr. Rostenkowski's contention that Democrats are engaged in a bidding war with Republicans over tax cuts by considering a reduction in Social Security payroll taxes. The problem both parties have on the question of Social Security, he said, is a failure to distinguish between general tax revenues and the money paid into the Social Security trust funds through worker and employer payroll contirbutions.
Mr. Moynihan has argued that the current surplus in the Social Security trust funds, intended to finance the benefits of the baby boom generation that will reach retirement age early in the next century, is instead improperly being used to help offset the current Federal budget deficit. As a result, he has urged that Social Security payroll taxes be reduced.

HEADLINE: Business Scene;
High Technology In Plants Abroad

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

 BODY:
WITH an energy not seen since the heyday of the multinationals 20 years ago, American companies are building factories overseas, buying companies and getting into all sorts of joint ventures. But while they expand their production abroad, they are somehow managing to do it without hiring a lot of foreign workers.
The hiring hold-down is a badge of the new global corporation, and a revealing one. Hiring is not robust because the overseas plants are increasingly as high-tech, automated and labor-saving as those back home. And the mix of what American companies own abroad is changing. They are losing interest in the labor-intensive ventures that were past favorites, among them the manufacture of clothing and other consumer products now purchased increasingly from foreign suppliers. 
The shift to high-tech production has shown up vividly in Mexico, where General Motors, Ford Motor and Chrysler - and also Nissan and Volkswagen - have built state-of-the-art auto engine plants since 1985, staffing them with people drawn from that country's plentiful supply of labor. ''In two or three years, these workers have achieved U.S. quality and productivity levels at less than $3 an hour,'' said Rudiger Dornbusch, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
The success of these ventures is helping to erode the old idea that the big industrial powers have a corner on high-tech, state-of-the-art production because only their technicians and workers have the necessary skills. True, the auto-engine technology comes from the industrial world, but the combination of foreign capital and efficient, inexpensive Mexican workers is making that country a big producer of the engines. ''What we are looking at here is offshore automation by American companies, and not the return of sophisticated production to the United States,'' said Harley Shaiken, an economist at the University of California at San Diego.
Perhaps no company illustrates better than General Electric the phenomenon of booming investments abroad carried out with a shrinking work force. G.E. is spending huge amounts to build plastics factories in Japan, Singapore, Spain and South Korea. A stove factory is earmarked for Mexico and G.E. has purchased control of a Hungarian light bulb company.
But with all this activity, G.E.'s employment abroad dropped to 49,000 last year (including 500 Americans), from more than 60,000 in 1984. The reason is plain: G.E. has shed two labor-intensive operations. Utah International, an overseas mining subsidiary, was sold in 1984 and G.E.'s consumer-electronics division was purchased by Thomson S.A., a French company, in 1987.
In partial payment from Thomson, G.E. received a company that makes high-tech medical diagnostic equipment, but with far fewer workers than the old electronics factories it used to own. While the new plastics factories are beginning to add workers to G.E.'s overseas payroll, these modern operations are not big users of labor. And the work force at the Hungarian light bulb company, acquired this year, is to be shrunk. ''Our foreign investment today is more sophisticated,'' said Walter Joelson, G.E.'s chief economist.
The activity of American corporations abroad is not well documented. The Commerce Department collects data on investment and employment, but with a two-year lag. The latest numbers, for 1987, show that while net investment has been rising since 1985, employment overseas declined through the 1980's to 6.2 million in 1987. The figures cover operations in which an American company had at least a 10 percent stake. Two-thirds of the employment was in Europe, Canada, Japan and Australia. But Mexico, Brazil and the Far East accounted for more than a million of the workers, demonstrating the enduring allure of low wages.
Almost certainly, the 1988 and 1989 numbers will show an upturn in employment, one that reflects the robust overseas investment reported in the last two years by numerous executives and business organizations. The Conference Board, for example, last week released the results of a survey of 1,000 American manufacturers. It showed 217 new investments overseas in 1989, a rise of 20 percent from 1988. Most were in Western Europe.
The global company, however, is not likely to be a big generator of jobs, whether it is an American corporation expanding abroad or the British and Japanese setting up in the United States. But small as the job pie might turn out to be, the American worker appears to be getting a share. Foreign companies operating in the United States employed 3.1 million people in 1987, nearly 3 percent of the American work force. That was a 30 percent rise from the 2.4 million in 1982, and the figures for 1988 and 1989 are likely to show similar increases.

HEADLINE: Trade Negotiations Create an Uproar in Japan

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 11

 BODY:
The proper number of knotholes in a sheet of plywood does not constitute anyone's definition of subject matter fit for review by the leaders of Japan and the United States.
But a flood of questions about how specifically Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu and President Bush discussed trade problems at their meeting earlier this month has created a furor in Japan's Parliament and underscored the sensitivity of trade talks between Tokyo and Washington.
''This is an extremely trivial matter, and we would prefer to see the focus placed elsewhere,'' said an American official, referring to the latest trade controversy between the countries. A Japanese official echoed the view that the commotion was ''ridiculous.'' 
 
What the President Said
Knotholes were apparently not discussed at the meeting between Mr. Bush and Mr. Kaifu in Palm Springs, Calif., although they have been a matter of contention in some trade talks between the United States and Canada, as well as talks with Japan. Washington has argued that these nations place limits on the size of knotholes in plywood in a way that discriminates against American goods.
Mr. Bush did say afterward that he pressed the Prime Minister to have Japan import more forestry products.
In a speech on Wednesday, the President also said he had pressed for more imports of satellites, supercomputers, semiconductors and telecommunications products, which like forestry products are the focus of American threats to retaliate if Japan is not more forthcoming.
By mentioning these items, however, Mr. Bush was seen here as having violated what Japanese officials say is an unwritten rule of meetings between heads of state. Nobody denies that American pressure is important to get Japan to change its ways, but it is considered impolite to say so publicly.
Trade disputes are at the heart of growing tensions between the two economic superpowers. But the Japanese sensitivity also reflected the view that it would have been demeaning for Mr. Kaifu to agree to take action on any particular demands by Mr. Bush.
 
Carrying Out the Ritual
The ritual of trade negotiations is such, Japanese officials say, that if Mr. Kaifu had been specific about what steps Japan might take, he would be seen as catering to his patron in Washington and would not be able to carry anything out.
By the end of this week, the trade talks between Washington and Tokyo had thus become overshadowed by a sudden rush of statements, denials and clarifications from Japan's Foreign Ministry, the Prime Minister's office and the White House, all to carry out the ritual.
When Mr. Kaifu returned from the Palm Springs meeting last Sunday, he was asked in the Parliament if he had responded positively to any specific demands by Mr. Bush that Japan make structural changes that would open Japan up to more American imports. He said no.
Then it was reported in the United States that Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, had said that Mr. Bush had pressed the Prime Minister to increase spending on public works, eliminate anticompetitive business practices and make it easier for big discount stores to flourish in Japan.
 
'Forcefully Tackle' Problems
Mr. Kaifu's office then said that even if Mr. Bush had raised these matters, Mr. Kaifu did not respond except to say, in a general way, that Japan would ''forcefully tackle'' these problems.
This assertion quieted protests from the opposition in Parliament.
But then came reports of a speech by Mr. Bush, asserting that he and the Japanese Prime Minister had specifically discussed American efforts to increase exports of forestry products and other items.
The Bush speech brought yet another clarification by Misoji Sakamoto, the chief Cabinet secretary. Even though these items were mentioned, he said, they were not elaborated on. He added that no commitment had been made beyond an agreement by both countries to ''do their utmost'' to solve their problems.
Michael H. Armacost, the United States Ambassador in Tokyo, who was with Mr. Bush and Mr. Kaifu in Palm Springs, then stepped in, directing the American Embassy here to issue a clarification. It said the President ''did not raise any specific structual issues'' in the meetings.
