HEADLINE: Ortega Sees Quayle and Reaffirms A Transfer of Power in Nicaragua

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SANTIAGO, Chile, March 12

 BODY:
Backing away from an earlier threat, President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua assured Vice President Dan Quayle today that he would surrender control of the military and the security police to the new Nicaraguan government next month.
Mr. Ortega and Mr. Quayle talked for more than 90 minutes during a lunch in La Moneda, the presidential palace in Santiago. The meeting was the highest-level Nicaraguan-American contact in a decade. Mr. Ortega, in remarks to reporters after the session, said, ''I guaranteed to him that the process of the transfer of power was going to take place with the utmost normality.''
 
Disbanding of Rebels Preferred
Mr. Ortega said ''the best thing for that purpose would be that the contras cease to exist by April 25,'' when he and the governing Sandinista Front are scheduled to hand over power to an opposition coalition led by Violeta Barrios de Chamorro. 
But he also said that the transition ''will go forward with or without the contras.'' He said there are ''no conditions'' attached to the transfer of power. [Administration officials in Washington said President Bush would ask Congress for $300 million in special aid to Nicaragua. Page A7.] Mr. Ortega's comments were in contrast to recent statements by Sandinista leaders demanding continued control of Nicaragua's 65,000-member army and security forces and warning that armed citizens might rise up if the contras were not demobilized. Negotiating Tactic? Those statements, in a speech to supporters in Managua last Thursday night, were interpreted by many diplomats as an attempt to gain leverage in negotiations over the transfer of power. Mr. Ortega said that Nicaragua was experiencing ''the calm before a storm'' and warned that he could not guarantee a peaceful exchange of power if the contra army remained intact.
Such statements were combined with Sandinista-sponsored legislation that would protect departing officials from prosecution and give away large amounts of state property before the turnover of power on April 25. They were also backed by the widespread distribution of automatic weapons to Sandinista supporters.
International and diplomatic criticism of such steps apparently encouraged Mr. Ortega to moderate his stand just before his departure from Nicaragua on Saturday, when he delivered a conciliatory message promising that the transition of power would be peaceful.
Administration officials said that in his remarks today, Mr. Ortega was emphatic that the transfer of power would be peaceful.
''He guaranteed me two things,'' Mr. Quayle told reporters before he left Santiago for Asuncion, Paraguay. ''One, on April 25, he will turn over his presidency to Violeta Chamorro, and two, he guaranteed to me that Violeta Chamorro will appoint all of the ministries, including the Defense Ministry and the Interior Ministry.''
 
What U.S. Wants
The United States has been seeking guarantees that the Sandinistas would turn over these ministries, which control the army and the police.
Administration officials said Mr. Ortega also expressed a willingness to accept an American plan to use United Nations peacekeeping forces to insure the security of the contras when they disband and to keep track of the government transition in Nicaragua.
Asked if he accepted Mr. Ortega's promises, Mr. Quayle said, ''We're going to work with him and others to make this happen. I believe it will happen.''
But officials with Mr. Quayle cautioned that some negotiations remain to be concluded, and said the transition could not be conducted on Mr. Ortega's guarantees alone.
Administration officials said Mr. Ortega asked Mr. Quayle to lift all the economic sanctions imposed against his country. They said Mr. Quayle replied that Mrs. Chamorro had already made such a request and ''it was being actively considered.''
 
Quayle's Journey
Mr. Quayle, in the midst of a weeklong swing through Latin America, met with Mr. Ortega three times today. In the first encounter this morning, they shook hands and chatted briefly before a service at the Metropolitan Cathedral. Mr. Quayle said he ''congratulated him for the way he has conducted himself, especially his statement that democracy has won and will be implemented in Nicaragua.''
A second, 10-minute meeting took place at the Chilean presidential palace, where the new President, Patricio Aylwin, was host at a lunch for visiting officials.
Administration officials said that in that encounter, Mr. Quayle complained about what he said were military attacks on rebel units and ''intimidation'' of supporters of Mrs. Chamorro by pro-Sandinista mobs, and he pressed Mr. Ortega to accept international monitoring and guarantees of the transfer of power in Nicaragua, they said.
The officials also said Mr. Quayle assured Mr. Ortega that the United States was ''willing to work on a process'' that would lead to dismantling the contra army, and they described the meeting as ''quite cordial.'' One official said the two men ''expressed their common goal as well-being and a democracy in Nicaragua.''
 
Closer Proximity
The third, 90-minute meeting came during lunch, after Mr. Ortega persuaded President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica to change seats so that he could sit next to Mr. Quayle.
That Mr. Quayle held the meeting with Mr. Ortega reflected both the inevitable shift in Washington's policy after the Sandinista Front's loss in the Feb. 25 elections and the urgency Mr. Bush has assigned to the effort to arrange a peaceful transition of power.
The issue dominated Mr. Quayle's meeting in Macuto, Venezuela, on Friday with President Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela and Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez of Spain, both of whom have sought to act as coordinators of the international effort to arrange the Nicaraguan transition.
Mr. Ortega flew to Chile on Sunday night with Mr. Gonzalez, Mr. Perez, Mr. Arias and President Rafael Leonardo Callejas of Honduras. Mr. Arias said today that the leaders had agreed to hold a meeting of Central American officials on March 30 and 31 to discuss the transition. Both Mr. Ortega and Mrs. Chamorro would be invited, he said.
 
MRS. CHAMORRO IN TEXAS
 HOUSTON, March 12 (AP) -Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, the Nicaraguan President-elect, has returned to Houston for the removal of a brace from her knee.
She fell and broke her kneecap on New Year's Eve and underwent surgery in Houston on Jan. 4. She returned to Nicaragua on Jan. 16 and campaigned on crutches in the successful effort to defeat the Sandinistas.
Last Thursday, she came back to Houston, and an orthopedic surgeon, Dr. Malcolm W. Granberry, removed her brace on Friday.

HEADLINE: White House Sees 'Room to Talk' In Democrat's Plan on the Deficit

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12

 BODY:
The Bush Administration signaled interest today in Representative Dan Rostenkowski's plan to raise certain taxes and freeze domestic spending, while Democratic colleagues of the House Ways and Means Committee chairman responded with far more caution.
The reactions underscored the political maneuvering set off by Mr. Rostenkowski's exhortation to both parties to get serious about reducing the Federal budget deficit. On Sunday, Mr. Rostenkowski had outlined a package intended to reduce the deficit by more than $500 billion over five years and establish a basis for negotiations between Congress and the Administration.
The White House moved quickly to project an appearance of reasonableness while affirming - in more polite language than usual - President Bush's opposition to tax increases. But Democratic leaders were holding back, in part out of fear that the White House might be preparing a trap that would leave them in the position of calling for unpopular tax increases and cuts in Social Security benefits. 
It was clear that with his plan Mr. Rostenkowski had upstaged the House and Senate Budget Committee chairmen and the Democratic leadership. And compared with the cautious reaction of many Democrats, the cordial response of the Bush Administration appeared almost enthusiastic.
The White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, told reporters: ''We think there's some room to talk. We don't want to pour cold water on a plan we may want to swim around in for a while.''
Richard G. Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, praised the plan as ''courageous and serious,'' pointedly saying it was the first the Administration had seen from Congressional Democrats that it considered worthy of discussion.
''We've said all along that we were prepared to discuss any reasonable proposal on its merits,'' Mr. Darman said in an interview on public television's ''MacNeil/Lehrer Newshour.''
But Mr. Darman acknowledged that the Administration opposed the two key elements of the plan by the House Ways and Means Committee chairman: the tax increases and a one-year freeze on cost-of-living adjustments to Social Security recipients.
''We do have some very fundamental objections to parts of it,'' Mr. Darman said.
The proposal is to increase excise taxes on gasoline, alcohol and tobacco and to raise the income tax rate of the wealthiest taxpayers to 33 percent, from 28 percent, while freezing all Federal spending for a year and cutting military spending by $150 billion over five years.
The House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley, Democrat of Washington, called Mr. Rostenkowski's plan ''a very interesting suggestion,'' but repeated his longstanding view that tax increases had little chance of approval without President Bush's support. While Mr. Darman offered nothing to suggest that the President had altered his opposition to tax increases, the budget director's comments on the tax issue were considerably less strident than those generally offered by Administration officials.
''We think the whole reason to get into deficit reduction is to enhance economic growth, not to have tax increases that hinder it,'' he said. Mr. Rostenkowski's plan would result in a $30 billion increase in taxes for the 1991 fiscal year, he said, and ''we think that's too heavy.''
The Democratic leadership seemed wary of embracing either the Rostenkowski plan or the immediate possibility of budget talks with the Administration. Rank-and-file Democrats avoided endorsing any of the specifics in the plan, and House Democrats were especially cautious.
President Bush has repeatedly said he opposes any tax increases, and Mr. Fitzwater insisted that the Administration's willingness to discuss Mr. Rostenkowski's plan did not indicate a change in that position.
''I'm not signaling any action on our part, except to say this gives us a basis for discussion,'' Mr. Fitzwater said. He added, ''Once you get into specifics, we're going to be negative.''
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader and a senior member of the Senate Finance Committee, said he was also willing to explore the issues outlined by Mr. Rostenkowski in an article on the Op-Ed page of the Washington Post. Mr. Dole had previously endorsed an increase in gasoline taxes if the revenues were earmarked for highway and bridge repair.
He praised the Ways and Means chairman in particular for urging that any ''peace dividend'' achieved from cuts in military spending be used to reduce the budget deficit rather than pay for new programs.
''His proposal could be the wake-up call we've been waiting for,'' Mr. Dole said. ''We'll see who answers it.'' He pointedly noted the lack of enthusiasm from Democratic Congressional leaders.
Senator Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas who heads the Senate Finance Committee, who is traveling on the West Coast, issued a statement praising Mr. Rostenkowski for demonstrating leadership. Mr. Benstsen called the proposal ''a good starting point'' for debate on reducing the deficit and said he was willing to give Mr. Rostenkowski's ideas ''my full attention.''
''It's sort of like, 'Let a hundred flowers bloom,' '' said one House Democratic aide, who described the Rostenkowski plan as simply one element to be considered as the party struggles to reach a consensus this year on tax and budget policy.
 
Seeking Response to Moynihan
 Democratic leaders in both houses have been trying for more than a month to develop a unified response to a proposal by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, for a cut in Social Security taxes.
Representative Charles E. Schumer, the Brooklyn Democrat who serves on the House Budget Committee, noted that many Democrats were uneasy about any budget negotiations with the Administration. ''The White House will let us walk out on this plank only to saw it off at an opportune moment,'' he said.
Despite the restrained reactions of Mr. Rostenkowski's colleagues, tobacco, liquor and trucking lobbies are taking the committee chairman's proposals for higher excise taxes seriously and are preparing campaigns to oppose any increases. The Ways and Means Committee is expected to begin its deliberations on a tax bill in May.

HEADLINE: The Big Bailout
A special report.;
U.S. HAS TROUBLE COPING WITH ITS SAVINGS EMPIRE

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12

 BODY:
Seven months after President Bush signed into law the largest Federal bailout in history, savings and loan regulators are mired in bureaucratic bickering and frustrated by their inability to sell off hundreds of sick savings institutions quickly.
With few buyers stepping forward, private analysts now say the cost of rescuing the industry's problem institutions could exceed $200 billion over 10 years, far higher than originally projected. And for the short run, the Congressional Budget Office said last week that in the next two or three years alone, the cost of the bailout could rise $25 billion to $30 billion over the $50 billion anticipated earlier.
 
The Failures Continue
The costly, slow-moving Federal rescue package could prove a political liability for the Bush Administration. Bob Dole, the Senate Republican leader, warned today that his party could face a political backlash unless work was speeded up on the savings bailout. ''This thing could be an albatross in 1992, which happens to be an election year,'' Mr. Dole said. 
Hundreds of savings and loans ran into trouble after Federal regulations were relaxed in the 1980's. They plunged into a wide range of speculative investments, ranging from real estate ventures to ''junk bonds.''
The bailout legislation assumed that the Government would end up taking over about 400 institutions. But more continue to fail, and regulators fear that the number could go as high as 800 institutions, with almost one-third of the assets in the industry. All these institutions are expected to become insolvent by mid-1992; they will have to be liquidated or sold to investors.
Accordingly, some banking experts predict that what began as a Federal rescue could turn into a de facto nationalization of a large segment of the savings industry, with the Government having to run hundreds of hobbled institutions for years to come.
The cost of the bailout to the American public was initially put at $159 billion over 10 years. But the total rises by almost $12 million a day, or more than $4 billion a year, as troubled savings institutions that have not been closed continue to lose money.
''The United States Government is now the single largest operator of financial institutions, dwarfing Citibank, and yet we are doing little more than marking time,'' said Richard Pratt, a former chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board and now chairman of Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.
Few dispute the difficulty of the task. The Resolution Trust Corporation, established by the law to manage the bailout, could eventually bring under its control institutions with assets of more than $450 billion, an amount that exceeds the largest banking company in the world, the Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank of Tokyo, which just surpassed $400 billion in assets at the end of last year. A large portion of the assets controlled by the Government are loans that are not being paid back. In addition almost all of the institutions that have been seized are involved in an array of lawsuits.
This empire will make the trust corporation the largest financial institution in the world, the largest single owner of real estate, the largest liquidation company and the largest auction firm.
 
Criticism And Praise
 While President Bush was widely praised for tackling the savings industry's problems as soon as he took office, Democrats and even some Republicans are now taking the Administration to task.
They complain that Treasury officials have unduly meddled with the trust corporation while the White House has looked the other way, and they say such interference has prompted the resignation of key administrators of the bailout.
''President Bush's great promises are drowning in a sea of indecision, inaction and infighting,'' said Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, the Texas Democrat who is chairman of the House Banking Committee.
But not everyone is so gloomy in assessing the trust corporation and its Oversight Board.
''I think they deserve a break; they have not been doing that horribly,'' said Preston Martin, a former vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board and chairman of WSGP Financial Management Inc. in San Francisco, which runs a number of savings institutions with assets of $10.3 billion. ''They have a huge task that will take time to get running smoothly.''
In Congressional testimony last month, L. William Seidman, chairman of both the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the trust corporation, acknowledged that he was getting defensive.
Mr. Seidman presented the lawmakers with a list of accomplishments: The agency has hired 2,300 people, established four regional offices, developed a strategic plan as well as bidding guidelines, initiated the sale of 60 institutions, and published an inventory of 30,000 properties for sale.
The agency's supporters, including Mr. Martin, say the trust corporation has made considerable progress since it came into existence in September. As of late last week, it had taken over 393 sick savings associations with assets of $193 billion. Of that number it has liquidated or sold to private investors 51.
 
Restrictions In the Law
 Among the greatest hurdles, the regulators have found, are the provisions in the bailout legislation that greatly restrict investment opportunities for potential buyers while increasing the underlying costs of running an institution - even though these measures were intended to curb the freewheeling business practices that contributed to the industry's troubles.
The law requires savings institutions to have at least 70 percent of their assets in mortgage-related loans, up from 60 percent. Another provision restricts institutions from entering the real estate development business and bars them entirely from holding ''junk bonds.''
But many investors contend that it is getting harder and harder to make money in mortgage lending, unless an institution is very large and has vast economies of scale. And they complain that higher deposit insurance premiums and capital requirements have discouraged them.
As a result, few institutions other than banks, which are interested in the branch networks of defunct institutions, have been willing to buy from the Resolution Trust Corporation.
''The bailout so changed the rules of the game that it cut deeply into the future profitability,'' said Jamie Jackson, president of Oak Tree Capital, a real estate investment banking firm in Washington. ''This certainly changed the opinion of investors.''
 
Conflicts In the Bureaucracy
 Frictions within the bureaucracy were considered inevitable when the Bush Administration insisted that it have the ultimate responsibility for the spending of billions of dollars in taxpayers' money. But the frictions have been greater than expected.
The White House insisted that Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady head the Oversight Board that was created to manage the trust corporation. The top administrators of the board found they had to clear policies and actions with the Treasury, and tensions developed over delays in getting policies approved by the Treasury, which was worried about potential criticism if the approach was too favorable to investors.
Investors note that those tensions seem to have come to the surface in the difficulty the agencies have had in formulating rules for bidding.
At first, the Oversight Board required that anyone seeking financing from the Government to buy property put up 25 percent of the purchase value in cash. Then after a multitude of complaints it has begun liberalizing many policies. For example, the cash requirement for financing was reduced to 15 percent recently.
And on several occasions, the board put ailing institutions up for bids, then pulled them off the market at the last minute. The board took that step because it expected to change the bidding rules and also feared a shortage of bidders.
But its decision angered some would-be buyers who had already spent time and money.
''We had people with airline tickets, hotel reservations, who at that last moment had to call it off,'' said Robert S. Boyd of the Secura Group, referring to a recent bidders conference called off at the last minute.
Insiders say that when Daniel P. Kearney resigned on Feb. 9 as president of the Oversight Board, he blamed the Treasury for ''micromanaging'' the board. Publicly Mr. Kearney has said he did not have sufficient authority at the agency.
Soon after, two senior aides to Mr. Kearney also left.
''The organizational chart speaks for itself,'' said Fred Alt, Mr. Kearney's deputy and one of the aides who left. ''Anything with that many parties involved is extremely difficult for people to work with.''
The organizational problems have made it hard for the Bush Administration to fill key posts. Two remain vacant on the Overight Board.
And only late last week, more than three months after M. Danny Wall announced that he would step down as director of the Office of Thrift Supervision, the nation's top savings and loan regulator, did the Treasury come up with his replacement. He is T. Timothy Ryan Jr., a Washington lawyer who was a counsel to the Bush for President committee. He has no formal training in banking and the savings industry but is regarded as a strong manager and tough enforcer.
Mr. Ryan's selection is a sign that the Administration could not persuaded a well-known figure in the savings or banking industries to take the post.
Until Mr. Ryan is confirmed by the Senate, Salvatore R. Martoche, the former Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for enforcement, is running the savings office.
 
Faith That The System Works
 But some banking lawyers and experts, though still a minority, believe that the situation could turn around soon. The Treasury seems to have backed off somewhat, allowing Mr. Kearney's temporary replacement, William Taylor, the Federal Reserve Board's director of banking regulation, more autonomy.
Less intervention by the Treasury is also likely to make for a smoother relationship between Mr. Taylor and Mr. Seidman. If they work well together, the bailout will have a better chance of success.
Last last month, the Oversight Board also extended the time during which a buyer can return assets it deems worthless to the Government to one year, from six months. And besides reducing the 25 percent cash requirement, the board is considering several other measures to make sick savings institutions more attractive.
''Over time the R.T.C. will probably work itself out,'' said Gerald P. Carmen, the former head of the Federal Asset Disposition Association, which managed troubled savings institutions' assets for the Government before the bailout. ''The public tends to look at the short term, and in that sense we haven't done very well. But from my government experience, somehow over a 10-year period, bureaucracies muddle through and get the job done.'' But he added, ''The costs are still enormous.''

HEADLINE: No Matter How You Measure It, We're Not Saving Enough

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Though right in some particulars, Prof. Robert Eisner's ''Low U.S. Saving Rate: A Myth'' (Op-Ed, March 1) is mischievously misleading.
Professor Eisner is right when he says that many kinds of public spending in the United States that the statistics treat as consumption (for example, spending on infrastructure, education, and research and development) will increase the future productive capacity of the economy and should therefore be counted as investment. He is also right that, so adjusted, the net national saving rate turns out somewhat higher than appears from the conventional figures. 
What he fails to say, however, is that no matter what reasonable measure one uses, the share of net national saving in gross national product between 1982 and 1989 has been a fraction of what it was from 1950 to 1979. Taken together, personal and public consumption, and the replacement investment needed to offset depreciation have absorbed a much larger share of G.N.P. recently than in the past.
Professor Eisner says that it is not surprising that ''Rapidly growing nations have to save more.'' But that is just the point. To make real potential national income (and thus our stagnant real wages) grow faster - indeed to avoid risking a further slowdown -we must sharply increase national saving - the combined total of private saving and Government saving. The only reliable method for doing that is to increase Federal Government saving. That means gradually shifting the Government's structural operating budget - what the budget would be at high employment, including Social Security, but excluding Federal civilian investment - from a large deficit to a large surplus.
Professor Eisner is right that, by itself, tightening the budget would mainly reduce personal consumption and Government purchases, thus freeing resources: labor and plant capacity. Drawing those resources into producing investment goods and exports - and that is the objective -would require timely Federal Reserve action to drive down interest rates and more public investment.
But at least in an economy that is operating near its inflation-safe capacity - and barring a large spontaneous increase in private saving -tightening the Government's operating budget is a necessary though not sufficient action. If, that is, we want to restore public and private investment.
 
FRANCIS BATOR
CHARLES SCHULTZE, ROBERT SOLOW
Cambridge, Mass., March 2, 1990
 
The writers are respectively, a Ford Foundation Professor at the Kennedy School, Harvard; senior fellow at the Brookings Institution; Institute Professor at M.I.T. and a Nobel laureate.

HEADLINE: Fighting the Deficit Too Bravely

 BODY:
''I've participated in the binge of irresponsibility,'' says Representative Dan Rostenkowski. ''But, no more,'' vows the blunt chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee. Writing in The Washington Post, Mr. Rostenkowski outlines a bold plan to attack the Federal budget deficit with a combination of new taxes and spending cuts. 
The plan, which includes unpopular measures like suspending next year's Social Security raise, deserves high marks for honesty and courage. He has even prompted a glimmer of interest from the White House. The chairman is right to offer a responsible attack on the deficit, especially with two irresponsible tax cut plans hurtling down the Congressional railroad track.
But in execution, the Rostenkowski plan risks causing more pain than it would relieve. It contains good ideas, but also bad and unnecessary ones.
Huge Federal deficits siphon money out of private capital markets. The threat is a long-term erosion of the nation's capital stock. The solution is for Congress to stop spending more than it collects in taxes. Resolving this imbalance requires permanent changes, not merely one-shot tax hikes and spending cuts. Mr. Rostenkowski's plan turns on some of both:
The Good: The proposed permanent tax hikes on gasoline, alcohol and tobacco are sound. These would raise tens of billions each year while helping to clean up the environment and lower health-care costs. These changes should be part of any long-term budget plan. The Bad: The core of the Rostenkowski plan is a package of one-year fixes. He proposes, for instance, to freeze spending that is not targeted on the poor and to suspend indexation of the tax code. These changes will cause pain, despite his commendable proposal to expand the earned income tax credit that benefits the working poor. The elderly would lose some Social Security benefits; low-income families would pay more tax.
And Mr. Rostenkowski's plan would renege on commitments made during reform of the tax code and Social Security. Breaking commitments could be justified in times of severe crisis. But the deficit presents no such short-term threat.
Mr. Rostenkowski recommends repeal of the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings deficit targets because, he argues, they would be superfluous under his plan. Not true. Without those targets, Congress would be free to offset his measures with a new round of tax cuts and spending hikes. Gramm-Rudman remains a regrettable but useful straitjacket.
The Unnecessary: Deficit reduction is one, but only one, way to promote economic growth. Investment in the nation's disadvantaged children and dilapidated infrastructure is at least as important. The deficit needs to be reduced substantially, but how much should depend on case-by-case evaluation of public investments.
Mr. Rostenkowski challenges his colleagues to adopt his plan or improve on it. It's a welcome challenge to those attracted by reckless reductions in the Social Security tax or in the capital gains tax rate. The test now is whether Washington can turn his one-shot fixes into permanent remedies.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: EDITORIAL

HEADLINE: Replacement Workers: Management's Big Gun

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12

 BODY:
To keep operating in a strike, more and more companies have been deploying a weapon they long shunned -hiring permanent replacements for workers who are on the picket lines.
When 6,300 drivers for the Greyhound Corporation abandoned their buses 10 days ago, management had 700 new recruits on hand to drive its fleet and 900 more in training. Thousands of new pilots, mechanics and flight attendants who have been assured careers with Eastern are keeping the airline aloft. And long after the end of the strikes in which they were hired, thousands of new workers remain on the job at the International Paper Company, the Boise Cascade Corporation, the Phelps Dodge Corporation and at Continental Airlines. 
The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations has made prohibition of replacement workers its No. 1 labor law goal this year. But legislation in Congress prohibiting such workers, introduced last month by Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum of Ohio and Representative William L. Clay of Missouri, both Democrats, faces tough going and a probable veto by President Bush if Congress should pass the bills.
Meanwhile, the Supreme Court has agreed to decide a case that could strengthen management's hand in using replacement workers to thwart unions. The case involves a request by a small company in Texas that the National Labor Relations Board presume that permanent replacement workers oppose unions, thus expediting the company's effort to banish the union.
 
'The Balance Has Shifted'
Labor experts maintain that management's wide use of permanent replacements has upset the symmetry that has been a tradition of labor disputes. On the one hand, management has said it has a right to lock workers out at the risk of losing profits; on the other, labor has said it can withhold its services at the risk of losing income.
''The balance has shifted,'' said Mark A. de Bernardo, director of the Labor Law Action Center at the United States Chamber of Commerce here. ''Labor's trump card in a dispute, the strike, is no longer trump.''
Robert M. Baptiste, a Washington attorney for labor unions, said that in a strike ''there was always a sense that people would eventually say, 'Enough, let's sit down and get serious.' '' But he added, ''Now, companies just want to get rid of unions.''
One reason that companies now think that goal is possible is the lesson they drew from the illegal strike of 11,500 Federal air traffic controllers in August 1981, seven months into Ronald Reagan's first term as President. After the controllers defied a back-to-work order, Mr. Reagan dismissed them, filled their ranks with permanent replacements, and the union collapsed.
 
'A Signal to Other Employers'
The Government's success in keeping the air traffic system working impressed many unionized companies.''Reagan made it respectable to bust unions,'' Mr. Baptiste said.
Gary Burtless, a labor economist at the Brookings Institution, said Mr. Reagan emboldened management to risk the strain to its business of taking on less experienced workers. ''The fact that the President was able to keep the air traffic system going indicated that there was a lot more scope for replacing workers than people imagined,'' Mr. Burtless said. ''If you can replace air traffic controllers you can certainly replace bus drivers.''
The permanent replacements, often recruited from the ranks of the unemployed or from low-paid employees of other businesses, are a variation on the temporary substitutes vilified by trade unionists as ''scabs'' or ''strikebreakers'' but nevertheless regarded as a part of management's legitimate arsenal. Temporary replacements leave at the end of a strike, but permanent replacements are assured the strikers' jobs. After a strike, the law allows strikers first claim on their old jobs, but only if replacements vacate them.
 
Risk of Permanent Replacements
Many companies still shun permanent replacements, in part because they run some risk in using them. Even if they decide they can get by without the expertise of skilled workers, companies must weigh the potential costs of incurring the wrath of workers who are not involved in the strike and of losing customers because of consumer doubts about the quality of the service provided by replacement workers.
This change in management's attitude has occurred along with a change in workers' loyalties, both to their unions and to their companies, which makes it harder for unions to sustain strikes and easier for management to persuade workers to move into the strikers' jobs.
Workers no longer think unions can deliver the gains in wages and benefits that made blue-collar members the world's best paid workers. For several years, union workers in private industry have been winning smaller wage increases than nonunion workers, and trade union membership as a part of the national work force has declined from 30 percent in the 1970's to 16.4 percent in 1989.
And for all that attention that recent strikes at companies like Greyhound, Eastern, the Pittston Coal Group Inc., Boeing and the Nynex Corporation have received, unions are increasingly wary of using their ultimate weapon, the strike, and risking both their members' jobs and the embarrassment of failing to win concessions from management. In the 1970's the Bureau of Labor Statistics recorded an average of 289 strikes a year involving 1,000 or more workers. In the last five years the average was 52.
 
The Seeds of Acrimony
Furthermore, some companies have found it easier than they expected to find replacement workers.
That is what happened in an especially vitriolic strike in 1987 and 1988 involving three International Paper mills in Jay, Me. The company proposed eliminating premium pay for work on Sundays and holidays, and the paperworkers union walked out. The company started bringing in permanent replacements just 13 days later, planting the seeds of acrimony that local officials say will persist for years.
''It's something you do only as a last resort,'' said James W. Gilliland, the company's director of employee relations. ''It's not fun for anybody.''
In Jay, he said, the company has reduced its work force from 1,250 to 1,062, and 80 percent of the employees are permanent replacements. They started at $9 to $10 an hour, about $4 less than the strikers, Mr. Gilliland said, and premium pay was abolished.
Once the company decided to proceed, Mr. Gilliland said it found a surprisingly large pool of candidates for the strikers' jobs despite the nation's relatively low unemployment rate.
''As more and more young people have entered the labor market, they have found fewer and fewer high-paying industrial jobs,'' he said. ''So when an industrial company enters the market to hire permanent replacements, it has no trouble whatever.''

HEADLINE: Aide Differs With Cheney on the Soviet Threat

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12

 BODY:
Differing with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, a top Pentagon expert on Soviet affairs has endorsed the assessment of William H. Webster, the Director of Central Intelligence, that there is little chance of renewed Soviet dominance over Eastern Europe if President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is ousted by hard-liners.
The official, Phillip A. Petersen, a specialist on Europe and the Soviet Union for the Pentagon's policy planning staff, also said that the Warsaw Pact has already ceased to exist as an effective military organization and will be maintained largely as a political ''fiction'' in the future.
Mr. Petersen's conclusions in a unclassified research paper have drawn attention because they come after a dispute between Mr. Webster and Defense Secretary Cheney over the future Soviet military threat.
Critics of Mr. Cheney on Capitol Hill have argued that the Defense Secretary is increasingly the odd man out in the policy debate in Washington. The emergence of Mr. Petersen's unclassified study has provided ammunition to detractors who argued that the Defense Secretary is even out of tune with some specialists within his agency. 
The Pentagon demonstrated unusual sensitivity to the political implications of Mr. Petersen's analysis.
A Pentagon spokeman read a statement asserting that Mr. Petersen's study is a ''research paper for input into the policy process, and is intended to neither draw policy conclusions nor make policy recommendations.'' Requests to interview Mr. Petersen about his research paper were rejected by the Defense Department.
The dispute over the Soviet military threat came to the fore two weeks ago when Mr. Webster, in Congressional testimony, said that the economic pressures on Moscow are so severe that even a new hard-line regime would be unlikely to begin a major military buildup or to try to revive the Warsaw Pact.
Mr. Webster's analysis undercut one of the main arguments that Mr. Cheney has used to win support for his military spending request: the threat that a reversal of Mr. Gorbachev's policies could rejuvenate the Soviet military.
Mr. Cheney has struck different notes. He has said that he believes Moscow is likely to completely withdraw its forces from Eastern Europe. But he has also stessed caution; in his January report to Congress he said changes in Soviet foreign and military policy ''are only just beginning to be implemented and are still relatively easy to reverse.''
A new classified assessment by the Joint Chiefs of Staff also allows for the possibility that Soviet foreign and domestic policy may be reversed, but plays down the likelihood of this.
The Joint Chiefs' assessment says that the transformation of Soviet foreign and domestic policy is not complete and adds that there are some imaginable circumstances under which the policies might be reversed. But the Chiefs' assessment adds that there is widespead agreement that Soviet leaders have decided to abandon a two-decade-long policy of military growth.
Mr. Petersen's paper centers on his thesis that Soviet leaders, starting with Yuri V. Andropov, have developed a new view of European security that emphasizes economic rather than military relations.
While the paper does not directly address the debate between the Defense Secretary and the C.I.A. Director, Mr. Petersen cites approvingly Mr. Webster's statement that there is little chance that ''Soviet hegemony could be restored in Eastern Europe'' because even hard-line successors to Mr. Gorbachev would be under severe economic and political pressures that would deter them from engaging in a military buildup and taking a confrontational stance toward Washington.
Taking note of Soviet statements of the need to maintain the Eastern and Western military alliances, Mr. Petersen writes that the Warsaw Pact has essentially ceased to exist as ''an integrated military command.''
Mr. Petersen attributes the new view of Soviet security to Mr. Andropov, who he says placed like-minded officials in important positions before he died.

HEADLINE: Bush to Seek $300 Million in Funds for Chamorro

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12

 BODY:
President Bush will ask Congress this week to provide the newly elected government of Nicaragua with $300 million in assistance to rehabilitate the country's war-ravaged economy, Administration officials said tonight.
They said Mr. Bush would ask Congress to appropriate the money before April 25, when President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro is scheduled to be inaugurated.
That would require extraordinarily fast action by Congress. Administration officials said they wanted Congress to vote for the aid, if possible, before lawmakers leave town for an Easter recess that runs from April 6 through 17. 
White House officials said that Mr. Bush would probably make a televised appeal for the aid to Nicaragua in the next day or two. A State Department official said: ''This aid package absolutely has to be on a fast track. If it's not, it will be too late.''
Battered by more than a decade of war, Nicaragua is in the midst of an economic crisis, with high inflation, high unemployment and shortages of basic commodities. Agricultural output and export earnings have fallen as a result of the war and a trade embargo imposed by the United States.
Administration officials said they might ask Congress to provide Nicaraguan aid beyond the $300 million, for the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1.
Mrs. Chamorro's office said today that her Government was seeking a total of $500 million in emergency assistance from Washington, Reuters reported. She is hoping that Managua will receive $300 million shortly after she takes office and the remaining $200 million in the course of the year, the statement from her office said.
Mr. Bush is also expected to announce this week that he will lift economic sanctions imposed on Nicaragua by President Reagan in May 1985. The sanctions prohibit the import of Nicaraguan goods into the United States, forbid the export of most products from this country to Nicaragua and bar Nicaraguan air carriers from the United States.
Of the $300 million aid package, $30 million is earmarked for demobilization and repatriation of Nicaraguan guerrillas camped in Honduras, White House officials said. The United States has been providing food, clothing, shelter and medical supplies to the contras and has also been urging them to return to Nicaragua.
Mrs. Chamorro's chief economic adviser, Francisco Mayorga Balladares, visited Washington last week and outlined her ''agenda for economic recovery.'' He said that the plan would include economic incentives for the contras to return to Nicaragua.
The incentives could include small plots of land and ''starter kits'' containing farm tools, seeds and fertilizer, Administration officials said.
Mrs. Chamorro led a 14-party alliance that crushed the Sandinistas in elections on Feb. 25. Many Nicaraguans cited dissatisfaction with the state of the economy as a reason to vote for her. About two-thirds of the $300 million in Mr. Bush's request is for oil and for agricultural commodities like seeds and fertilizer.
 
Year's Supply of Oil Gone
Administration officials said that the Sandinistas had somehow disposed of a full year's supply of Soviet oil in the last three months. The Sandinistas either used or sold most of the oil, they said. Nicaragua used to get large amounts of oil from Mexico and Venezuela, but the supplies were cut off because Managua did not keep up with its payments, the Administration said.
Paul S. Reichler, a Washington lawyer who has represented the Sandinista Government of Nicaragua since 1979, said that in recent years Managua has been getting most of its oil at little or no charge from the Soviet Union.
Mr. Reichler said that the President of Nicaragua, Daniel Ortega Saavedra, ''supports U.S. aid for Nicaragua and will cooperate in efforts to expedite delivery of such aid.''
''I have been instructed by the Nicaraguan Government to lend my support to lobbying efforts to get U.S. economic assistance for Nicaragua and to collaborate with Mrs. Chamorro's people in these efforts,'' Mr. Reichler said.

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Shadow Cast By Dukakis Over Cuomo

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 12

 BODY:
He's a Northeastern, liberal Governor with a Mediterranean heritage. He used to brag about his state's prosperity but now is beset by financial difficulties. And as New York's budget problems mount, politicians here are posing the inevitable question: Is Mario Cuomo at risk of becoming the next Michael Dukakis?
Most political analysts say Mr. Cuomo's fiery style is so unlike Mr. Dukakis's lukewarm manner that the differences between the two overwhelm the similarities. But Republicans, hoping to damage the Governor, have already begun raising the analogy as Mr. Cuomo heads into a gubernatorial campaign. And even Democrats acknowledge that the comparison could be a liability if he decides to run for President. 
 
Sentences With Both Names
''To the extent that we always try to avoid the mistakes of the last campaign, a Northeast liberal Governor with fiscal trouble is not what the doctor ordered, given the campaign we've just gone through,'' said Tony Podesta, a Democratic political consultant. ''People who would like him not to run will surely be using a lot of sentences that contain both the words Dukakis and Cuomo.''
In most lines of work, it would seem too early to ask questions about events that, like the 1992 Presidential election, are two years away. Not in politics. Maneuvering for the Presidential campaign is already under way, and many politicians long ago started to handicap the race.
Mr. Cuomo, who is considered a favorite among potential Democratic candidates, has yet to indicate if he intends to run in 1992. With President Bush's popularity so high, it would seem that the biggest factor in his decision would be whether he wants to tackle a strong incumbent.
But the state of New York State is also bound to play a crucial role in Mr. Cuomo's decision whether to run for President. And right now the economic indicators suggest that the state's financial problems will grow worse over the next two years, rather than better, meaning that the state budget will probably continue to plague Mr. Cuomo through 1992.
''If the budget begins to hurt Cuomo in New York, it will hurt him in the rest of the country, just like we saw it in Massachusetts,'' said Al From, head of the Democratic Leadership Council in Washington.
 
The 'Miracle' That Ended
In Massachusetts, the end of the economic boom that Mr. Dukakis labeled the ''Massachusetts miracle'' has left that state with a $500 million budget deficit. Together with Louisiana, it has the worst credit rating in the nation. Reports surfacing toward the end of the 1988 campaign that Massachusetts's finances were falling into disarray weakened Mr. Dukakis's already faltering campaign and helped undermine the image he had fostered as a tough manager.
In New York, economic troubles have all but consumed the state government in recent months, and although Mr. Cuomo insists the problems are not so bad as in Massachusetts, every week seems to bring more bad news. Just today, for example, the State Comptroller said the state's budget gap had grown to $1.5 billion, almost three times what Governor Cuomo estimated last month.
Mr. Cuomo, always coy when it comes to discussing his ambitions, insists he is not worried about how New York's ballooning budget problems play politically and is certainly not interested in how they play nationally. ''It's not our concern,'' he said. Point-by-Point Rebuttal But this indifference is belied by a point-by-point rebuttal the Governor has devised to respond to charges about the state budget that Republicans have yet to level.
In this rebuttal, outlined by the Governor in a recent speech in Washington and in subsequent interviews, he raises the kind of criticism that a Republican Presidential opponent might be expected to raise and then disputes it, dismissing assertions that New York taxes too much, that it spends too much and that its budget problems are its own fault.
If anyone should be faulted on management skills, Mr. Cuomo says, it is the Republicans, who have presided over the largest deficit in the nation's history. ''National Republicans are the last people in the universe who should try to criticize us because once they start it, they'd be dead,'' he said.
Far from shirking comparisons between the Republican Administration in Washington and his own administration in Albany, Mr. Cuomo in recent months has often used New York's budget problems as an opportunity to attack Federal policies.
''While we got into trouble, we were spending generously on people problems,'' the Governor said recently. ''They cut back on people problems like education, drugs, roads and bridges. And part of our problem, everybody knows, is the national economy.''
But Mr. Cuomo appears to be sensitive to the notion that on the national scene he is already being compared to Mr. Dukakis, and in a recent interview he raised the analogy himself. ''What are you going to talk to Cuomo about?'' he asked, referring to his Republican critics. ''You're going to say, 'You guys are Massachusetts?' If we're Massachusetts, you're Massachusetts squared.''
 
National Economic Slowdown
Many economists and even many Republican politicians acknowledge that New York's budget problems cannot be viewed separately from a national economic slowdown that has left many states reeling. But they also point out that during Mr. Cuomo's tenure, state spending has grown by almost 80 percent while inflation increased prices by only 30 percent.
Republicans like Roger Ailes, the media consultant who directed Mr. Bush's 1988 campaign advertising, call Mr. Cuomo's attacks on the White House an effort to avoid blame for the problems in New York.
''This man's never taken responsibility for anything in his life,'' Mr. Ailes said of the Governor. ''He'll blame things on Mother Teresa before he'll take responsibility.''
So far, there is little evidence that the state's budget problems have affected Mr. Cuomo's popularity in New York, where he is expected to run for a third term as Governor in November. The most recent survey by the Marist Institute for Public Opinion, a Poughkeepsie group does frequent polling on state issues, shows Mr. Cuomo with a comfortable 64 percent approval rating.
 
No Republican Challenger
Politicians here say it is not surprising that the budget has not yet translated into problems for Mr. Cuomo. After all, they say, he does not yet have a Republican opponent in the gubernatorial race. This has left criticism of the state's fiscal policies to a chorus of Republican legislators, whose charges that the Governor taxes and spends too much rarely reach beyond the State Capitol.
''I think Cuomo has the potential to skate through his problems for lack of an opponent,'' said Roger Stone, a Republican political consultant. ''You can't beat somebody with nobody.''
Just how much of a liability New York's fiscal problems would prove to a Governor-turned-Presidential-candidate would depend, analysts say, on the forcefulness with which Mr. Cuomo deals with the problem.
''If Cuomo is able to manage the problem and deal with it effectively, it won't even be a blip on the radar screen,'' Mr. From of the Democratic council said. ''If it gets out of hand, it could really be problem.''

HEADLINE: Medicaid Help for AIDS Patients Proposed

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 12

 BODY:
Unemployed New Yorkers with AIDS would have private health insurance premiums paid for through Medicaid, under legislation proposed today by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. 
If the program is carried out, Governor Cuomo estimated it would help 1,800 people with AIDS and cost the state $2 million and local governments another $2 million.
AIDS patients at 185 percent of the Federal poverty level or below would be eligible.
Local social service commissioners can authorize Medicaid payments of health insurance premiums for AIDS patients. But, for example, a single person would have to be making $5,700 annually or less to qualify, said Pamela Rehak, the Governor's assistant secretary for human services.

PUB-DATE: March 13, 1990

SECTION: Section C; Page 15, Column 1; Cultural Desk

LENGTH: 1444 words

HEADLINE: Review/Art;
Landscapes Show Rembrandt's Peaceful Side

BYLINE: By MICHAEL BRENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
''Rembrandt's Landscapes: Drawings and Prints,'' which opened Sunday at the National Gallery of Art, will give pleasure to anyone who likes Rembrandt and anyone who likes prints and drawings. What the exhibition will not do is provide a way of coming to terms with the polemics that have thrown almost everything about Rembrandt into question. These 99 works on paper seem as removed from the turmoil of recent Rembrandt scholarship as they seem untouched by the emotional swells and dramatic turbulence of Rembrandt's painting.
The exhibition is unaffected by the Rembrandt Research Project in Amsterdam because that group of five Dutch scholars has been involved in a 21-year effort to establish a secure corpus of Rembrandt's paintings, not of his work on paper. The project has disattributed or reattributed many paintings. There is a sense that no work is safe from the machinery of re-evaluation, not even Rembrandt favorites like ''The Polish Rider,'' from 1657, in the Frick Collection in New York. 
The show also offers little or no response to revisionist art historians like Gary Schwartz, who has raged against what he sees as a misguided view of Rembrandt as a totally independent genius whose work is the embodiment of the noblest human values. In ''Rembrandt: His Life, His Paintings,'' published in 1986, Mr. Schwartz, an American living in the Netherlands, concentrates on patronage and argues that Rembrandt gave his Dutch clients exactly what they wanted and that far from being a prince of a human being he was manipulative, arrogant, greedy and ruthless.
On the surface, this show is as peaceful as its art. It includes sketches, studies and finished drawings, as well as all 26 of Rembrandt's landscape prints. There are etchings made from life and etchings no bigger than matchboxes. There are a few works in which Rembrandt aimed for a monumental statement, including the overblown ''Three Trees,'' in which Dutch farmland is transformed into a heroic theater.
All the works are intimate in scale. There is a feeling both for the rapid, almost Zenlike gesture and for detail so fine that you almost need a magnifying glass to see it. No matter how expansive the vista, the works have to be seen up close, like pages in a book. The drawings appeal to the eye in their demand for keen visual observation; they appeal viscerally in the darting immediacy with which stumpy and flowing lines seem to impose themselves upon the paper.
In all the works there is a sense of the artist as an outsider, as a city boy in nature. Rembrandt was interested in cultivated, not untamed, land. In all the works there is a sense of detachment. Although Rembrandt felt entirely at ease with what he drew or etched, he never identified himself with landscape as did van Gogh, a Dutchman influenced by Rembrandt's expanses of fields and trees and artistic license with what he saw. Although Rembrandt is widely perceived as a romantic, these are really not romantic works.
The tone of the work is puzzling, and a clear indication that questions raised by the revisionist scholars need to be addressed. The combination of nonchalance and self-consciousness, calculation and conviction, has an odd, almost modernist edge. It is hard to know to what degree Rembrandt cared personally about what he was drawing, and to what degree his scenes of stable, down-to-earth rural life were intended to please patrons.
One of the most instructive aspects of the show is the insight it provides into Rembrandt's relationship with other artists. Titian's ''Mountainous Landscape With Riderless Horse Emerging From a Lake'' is shown alongside Rembrandt's copy of it. The copy is close to the original but freer, and it suggests both tribute and competition.
Centuries before Robert Rauschenberg struggled to erase an actual drawing by Willem de Kooning in a famous Pop Art gesture of generational assertion and rebellion, Rembrandt took a print by Hercules Seghers, an artist a generation older than he, and burnished away the right-hand section, transforming a scene of ''Tobias and the Angel'' into a ''Flight Into Egypt.''
In the catalogue, Cynthia P. Schneider, an assistant professor of art history at Georgetown University and the curator of the exhibition, writes that Rembrandt's action was ''truly a labor of love.'' ''Rembrandt,'' she writes, ''could not have expressed his respect and admiration for Seghers more eloquently than by reaching across time to work together with him as he did in the 'Flight into Egypt.' '' It does not make a lot of sense, however, to interpret an artist erasing the work of another artist as a declaration of love.
The catalogue does not challenge any deeply held view of Rembrandt. Some of its caution is understandable. Few of the works on paper are dated, and Ms. Schneider writes, ''no documentation exists regarding Rembrandt's working process from landscape.'' The installation is not chronological but thematic. It is divided into five sections: farmhouses and cottages (by far the largest), imaginary landscapes (including the works after Seghers and Titian), architecture and town views, along the Amstel and IJ Rivers, and panoramas.
It is also hard to know how Rembrandt perceived these works. He was a figure painter for whom history painting was the key to art heaven. Landscape became an established genre only in his lifetime (he died in 1669 at the age of 63). Ms. Schneider writes that Rembrandt's landscape paintings ''number no more than eight'' and that they were executed between 1637 and 1647. Most of the landscapes on paper span 30 years and were made, Ms. Schneider thinks, after the landscape paintings, in the 1640's and early 1650's.
The catalogue avoids speculation. It offers no comprehensive overview. While the entries provide a great deal of information and an essay by the Dutch art historian Boudewijn Bakker offers new documentation about routes Rembrandt followed on his walks and the two kinds of farms he depicted, the show makes no statement or argument about the place of these landscapes in Rembrandt's oeuvre.
What, then, are these works, and what was Rembrandt trying to do in them?
They can be seen as an attempt by the artist to establish some distance from the politics of the rough and tumble art world in Amsterdam and from the kind of emotional involvement required in his commissions.
The landscapes are economical and often quick. In many of them there is a feeling for space and light that contrasts sharply with the dense and often darkish paintings. In ''A House in Sunlight,'' the brown ink seems to set off the glare of the sun concealed within the paper; the feeling for ink or pencil is almost Chinese. In ''Winter Landscape'' Rembrandt manages in a few dark lines to make blank paper seem like snow.
The works are also about continuity. The Netherlands does not have the artistic and architectural history of Italy or France. In some of the best 17th-century Dutch landscape painting, there is a sense that the country's true wealth and tradition lay in its rivers, fields and trees.
The relationship between the flatlands and trees in the northwestern Netherlands has an elemental purity to which Rembrandt responded long before Piet Mondrian found in it an inspiration for the vertical and horizontal grids of his abstract painting.
Rembrandt's farmhouses are enduring and accessible, and they suggest community. They also seem as organic as the trees that grow beside them. In a drawing like ''Three Cottages Along a Road,'' the ramshackle farmhouses suggest a link between the 17th century and mud huts of prehistory.
Rembrandt also seems to have truly enjoyed working outdoors. In a number of drawings, a man, sometimes barely visible, is alone in the fields, drawing or, like a monk in Chinese painting, sitting in contemplation before a village, field or tree. Although Rembrandt may always have been considering the market, and he was ambitious enough that he probably wanted to show landscape painters that he could outdo them without trying, he really seems to have loved the Dutch landscape and to have found in it an anchor. This might help explain why these drawings are unsearching and untroubled.
But there is still invariably this sense of shrewdness and distance that makes one wonder. How much did Rembrandt tap this unsearching and untroubled air for himself, and how much did he draw it into his paper because he thought it was what the good burghers of Amsterdam wanted to breathe?
 
 *
 ''Rembrandt's Landscapes: Drawings and Prints'' will remain at the National Gallery of Art through May 20. The show will not travel.

HEADLINE: Big Effort Is Begun To Reverse Decline Of Turtles

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
Turtles crawled the earth and swam in its waters before the dinosaurs appeared. Now they are facing the first broad-scale threat to their future in 200 million years, and some of the world's leading conservation organizations are gearing up to combat it.
The campaign goes far beyond, and is separate from, a much-publicized effort to preserve six species of sea turtles whose numbers are being reduced by fishermen and shrimpers. The broader effort encompasses about 300 species of land and freshwater turtles on every continent.
They are afflicted by an accelerating decline, according to a comprehensive survey by the World Conservation Union, with about a third of the species requiring conservation attention. ''That's a very high percentage for a group of vertebrates,'' said Michael W. Klemens, a herpetologist at the American Museum of Natural History in New York, who is the director of the worldwide conservation effort now beginning. 
The problem is that the pace of modern change has placed many kinds of turtles in an evolutionary bind. Over the eons, they have owed their success and their survival to what Dr. Klemens calls a ''conservative'' adaptive strategy. That is, they have relied on longevity - some turtles live more than 100 years - to insure that their species survives.
They lay a relatively small number of eggs, and there is a high mortality rate among hatchlings. ''The one thing they have going for them is that they live a long time,'' said Dr. Klemens. ''Once a turtle reaches adulthood, it can reproduce for 30, 40, 50 years. The individual adult turtle is very important.''
For this strategy to work an undisturbed and unfragmented habitat is required. Now the development activities of another well-adapted species, Homo sapiens, are disrupting many turtle habitats. This affects turtle populations in two ways: eliminating adults who wander out of their truncated home range and are killed, and cutting breeding populations off from each other, thereby reducing the number of eggs and surviving hatchlings.
 
Fewer Reproducing Adults
 On top of this, many turtle species around the world are exploited for food and other uses, further reducing adult populations.
The special danger faced by many species of turtles is that with reduced numbers of reproducing adults and fewer breeding opportunities, not enough young turtles are being produced to replace the adults.
''In Asia, in Africa, even in the New York metropolitan area, some populations are made up almost entirely of aged adults, and juveniles are just not present,'' said Dr. Klemens. ''Once they're gone, that's the ball game; or extinction may proceed over several generations. But that's the pattern.''
The effort to head off this decline is being undertaken jointly by the World Conservation Union, the American Museum of Natural History and the Durrell Institute of Conservation and Ecology in Canterbury, England. Nearly 50 projects are being undertaken, with a projected budget of $2 million to be contributed by a number of conservation organizations.
The goal is to help declining populations through tactics like breeding turtles under controlled conditionsand releasing them into the wild and erecting fences around eggs in natural breeding areas to keep predators away. A few programs of this kind are already under way. In Madagascar, for example, threatened tortoises are being bred in pens. The program employs people from local villages, and the fruits and vegetables that the tortoises eat are purchased locally. ''Local people have to see a real economic incentive to preserve these animals,'' said Dr. Klemens.
One incentive is the need to maintain an important source of protein, which turtles provide in many areas of the world. In Southeast Asia and Latin America, river turtles in some places are under heavy pressure from people who hunt them for food. In other places, tortoises are kept in village pens for food and as a source of hatchlings that, according to the World Conservation Union, fetch high prices and are easily smuggled.
As an example of how habitat fragmentation endangers some species, Dr. Klemens cites studies of the common wood turtle of North America. Its relatively flat, brownish shell and orange legs are familiar in the Northeastern United States. It lives in streams in the fall and spring, but travels overland in the summer over a home range extending for several miles.
''But there's no place in Westchester or Fairfield County that's more than a mile from a road,'' said Dr. Klemens, who has studied the problem. Some adult wood turtles are killed crossing roads, and adults are often prevented from reaching each other to mate. While adults still live in those two counties, they have essentially stopped reproducing. ''They are the last remnants of that population,'' Dr. Klemens said. ''Once they die, that's it.'' Wood turtles, he said, are now ''functionally extinct'' in those two counties.
 
Long Life, High-Domed Shell
 The wood turtle is not to be confused with the common box turtle, an even more familiar sight in the Northeast. Its hallmark is a high-domed brown and yellow shell. With a life span exceeding 120 years, it is the longest-lived vertebrate in North America. Because its home range is much smaller than that of the wood turtle, it is one species not affected by habitat fragmentation.
Of the species not getting conservation attention but in a decline judged serious enough to warrant it, 39 are known to be declining and threatened over a substantial part of their range, according to a scientific study carried out by the World Conservation Union.The seriousness of their plight has not been clearly established, however. These species include, for example, the alligator snapping turtle of the Southeastern United States; the bog turtle and Blandings turtle of New York State; the Mexican mud turtle; the Egyptian tortoise; the red-footed tortoise of South America, which is particularly exploited as food during Holy Week, and the big-headed turtle of Southeast Asia, heavily exploited by the pet trade.
Fifty-two species have been identified as being threatened because they are restricted to just a few bodies of water or drainage basins or are limited to a small, specific habitat. Disruption of those habitats could cause extinction of a species. Among these are the Burmese star tortoise, the Berger's tortoise of Namibia and the Bolson tortoise of Mexico.
A third category, including 16 species, is considered badly threatened or heavily exploited. Among those identified as heavily exploited are several varieties of river turtle in Madagascar, Southeast Asia and Latin America. Those considered badly threatened include the western swamp turtle of Australia, some species of Galapagos turtles and the plowshare tortoise of Madagascar, of which only about 15 specimens remain. These, said Dr. Klemens, ''are really on the edge.''
