HEADLINE: Efforts to Halt Wetland Loss Turn Their Attention Inland

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
A new and contentious phase has opened in the struggle over the future of the millions of acres of marshes, swamps, bogs, prairie potholes and bottom lands that not only provide an irreplaceable habitat for wildlife but also help replenish the nation's water supplies and control its floods.
Despite longtime efforts by the Federal Government to arrest the steady shrinkage of this natural resource, an estimated 200,000 to 400,000 acres of wetlands continue to vanish each year, most in freshwater drainages in inland areas, where 95 percent of all wetlands lie. Largely untouched by Federal and state regulatory efforts, millions of acres of these freshwater wetlands have disappeared since the mid-1950's, overwhelmingly because farmers converted them to cropland.
Efforts to preserve wetlands have focused mainly on coastal areas, but now environmentalists, politicians and regulators are engaged in a campaign to control the attrition of inland wetlands for the first time and ultimately to reverse it. They have declared their near-term objective to be no net loss of wetlands. 
Under the no-net-loss principle, conversion of wetlands would be permitted only if the user restored previously converted wetlands or created new ones. President Bush has embraced it, and two Federal agencies and some state governments are requiring it. Congress is holding hearings about whether it should be Federal law.
But despite widespread acceptance of the basic principle, early attempts to put it into practice have encountered stiff and angry resistance. It comes especially from farmers who see regulatory efforts as a confiscation of their assets. ''I bought my farm, and if the Government wants it, they should acquire it the good old American way -buy it,'' Rick McGown, a Missouri farmer, said in handwritten testimony that he presented to Congress two weeks ago.
And on Maryland's Eastern Shore, where most non-tidal wetlands lie on farms and the issue has become especially heated, enforcement of the no-net-loss policy has discouraged banks from lending money to farmers because of the uncertain status of their lands. It has also stopped development by preventing farmers from selling excess lands to developers, a move many had counted on to provide for their retirement.
''The farmers are very upset,'' said Samuel Q. Johnson, an Eastern Shore legislator who is a member of the Maryland House of Delegates' committee on the environment. ''And not only the farmer. This thing is spreading to the banking community, to the real estate community. I know people who have been turned down on loans for land. It has nothing at all to do with their credit or ability to pay. It is simply the unknown factor about whether this was non-tidal wetlands.''
Two real-estate developments worth $22 million together have shut down because of uncertainty over the situation, he said.
Most non-tidal wetlands are on private property, and as the wetlands debate heats up, policy-makers are searching for ways to head off conflict and confrontation, allay concern and safeguard both public and private interests while making the no-net-loss principle a reality. Proposals are emerging in Congress, for instance, to offer tax incentives for wetlands conservation and even to pay farmers to reconvert land, which could then be placed in a wetlands conservation bank.
Underlying the action and argument is a shift in perception about wetlands. Through most of American history, they have been considered wastelands to be eliminated and converted to productive use. ''For a long time, we regarded swamps as sources of pestilence that should be filled in as quickly as possible,'' says James Leape, a wetlands expert at the Conservation Foundation, a Washington-based organization that sponsored an influential national study of wetlands loss.
 
Study Shapes New Debate
 The study was carried out by the National Wetlands Policy Forum, a broadly based group that included environmentalists, industrialists, government officials, developers and farmers. Its report, issued in late 1988, first proposed the no-net-loss goal. The report has largely shaped the renewed argument and is the focus of the Congressional hearings.
Wetlands today are seen increasingly not as nuisances, but as an invaluable resource. Scientists say that they protect shorelines from erosion by ocean waves and storms and reduce the severity of inland floods by slowing and storing flood waters. They remove pollution from waters that flow through them and recharge underground aquifers. They store water in the wettest parts of the year and release it at a constant rate to maintain regular stream flows.
They provide critical breeding and nesting habitats for a wide array of fish and wildlife, including migratory waterfowl. They support many commercial fisheries, provide an array of commercial products from cranberries and timber to fish and shellfish and offer widespread opportunities for hunting, fishing, boating, nature study and photography. And because of the gases they emit and absorb, like methane, nitrogen and carbon dioxide, they help maintain the planet's atmospheric balance.
 
From Marshes to Tundra
 Wetlands include marshes extending across thousands of acres to wet spots smaller than a room and from the vast Okefenokee Swamp in Georgia to the squishy borders of inland rivers and lakes. They include not only Alaskan tundra but also the Everglades and the bottom lands of the Mississippi Delta.
Ecologically speaking, the loss of wetlands can be disastrous. In one example, the conversion of prairie potholes of the upper Midwest to agricultural use has been ''extremely devastating'' to certain species of ducks, said Joseph S. Larson, an expert on wetlands who is the chairman of the department of forestry and wildlife at the University of Massachusetts.
The potholes, large depressions in the prairie created when huge chunks of ice were buried in the last ice age and then melted, are the nesting grounds for ''probably 80 percent of the ducks in North America,'' said Dr. Larson. But so many of the potholes have been converted from wetlands to wheat fields, he said, that there has been a tremendous loss of habitat, and species like the redhead and canvasback ducks are in serious decline as a result.
In addition, a number of communities have experienced serious flooding after wetlands were drained and replaced by streets, parking lots and other surfaces that allow water to run off more freely.
Of more than 200 million acres of wetlands that existed in the contiguous 48 states when Europeans arrived in North America, an estimated 95 million remain, according to the Environmental Protection Agency. They are found across the country but are concentrated especially in the Southeast, the upper Midwest and the Northeastern coastal states. Another 200 million acres remain in Alaska in the form of tundra, which is frozen wetland.
Government studies by the Fish and Wildlife Service have calculated that from the mid-1950's to the mid-1970's, 11 million acres of wetlands vanished, a net loss of about 550,000 acres a year, in the contiguous 48 states. About 80 percent of the loss resulted from the draining and clearing of inland wetlands by farmers. The remainder was attributed to such activities as urban and suburban development, which accounted for about 6 percent, dredging, mining and the discharge of pollution. Natural phenomena like erosion, storms and subsidence accounted for about 5 percent of the loss.
 
Losses Are Being Disputed
 How much additional loss has occurred in the last 15 years is a matter of sharp contention. The Congressional Office of Technology Assessment estimated in 1984 that the rate was about 240,000 to 360,000 acres a year.
Whatever the scope of the problem, spokesmen for farmers and developers minimize their constituents' contribution to it. ''I don't think agriculture has played that much of a part'' in the last 10 years, said Mark Maslyn, an official of the American Farm Bureau Federation, who took part in the Wetlands Policy Forum study. ''I think that was just a time and point in history that passed.''
 
Losing Wetlands by Increments
 But environmentalists and some government officials insist that interests like agriculture and real estate are responsible for the continuing attrition. ''We're losing wetlands by small increments,'' says Hope Babcock, general counsel for the National Audubon Society, who also took part in the Wetlands Policy Forum study, ''and when you start nibbling away, pretty soon you're destroying a whole ecosystem.''
Last month, the struggle over the issued sharpened as the no-net-loss principle was incorporated into an agreement between the Environmental Protection Agency and the Army Corps of Engineers over the enforcement of wetlands protection under Section 404 of the Clean Water Act. This section, which regulates the filling of wetlands, is considered by environmentalists the most important tool available for controlling wetlands loss.
Some environmentalists say that the authority of the Corps of Engineers in some ways does not extend far enough because it does not apply to the excavation, clearing or draining of wetlands. Such activities are responsible for most wetlands loss, especially inland. While coastal wetlands are reasonably well protected, said the 1984 report by the technology assessment office, freshwater wetlands away from the coasts ''are generally poorly protected.''
In an attempt to help plug this gap, Congress in 1985 prohibited farmers from growing crops on any tracts converted from wetlands after that year. If they do, they are supposed to lose all their Federal farm program benefits, including subsidized loans, crop insurance and price supports.
A number of states are embracing the no-net-loss principle and expanding it beyond filling-in of wetlands. Maryland has adopted one of the most far-reaching state laws incorporating the no-net-loss principle, and the Legislature is in a hot battle about approving the new regulations to complete the law. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York has espoused no net loss. Among states besides Maryland that have enacted the principle into law is New Jersey, and other states, including Washington and South Carolina, are considering it.
 
Looking to Economic Solutions
 In the end, many conservationists and officials are convinced, wetlands protection will have to look beyond regulation to economic solutions. ''It's unrealstic to expect private land owners to do what's good for society just out of the goodness of their hearts,'' said Ralph Heimlich, an analyst in the Economic Research Service of the Agriculture Department who has studied the wetlands issue extensively.
Outright purchases of land for a wetlands conservation bank is one strategy being pursued in Florida, where officials plan to buy and restore more than 100,000 acres of freshwater marshland that were drained and converted into orange groves and truck farms.
Other strategies being proposed involve economic aid for not developing or otherwise converting ecologically important wetlands, as well as tax breaks for donating them to a conservation reserve.
''You have to begin to tilt the economic playing field,'' said Ms. Babcock.

HEADLINE: For Macy, a Bitter Pill to Swallow

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
Afflicted by continuing high debt and costly competitive pressures, R. H. Macy & Company has been carefully preparing its investors, lenders, employees and suppliers for another bitter pill to swallow on quarterly losses.
Today, New York's biggest retailer is expected to report steeper losses for its second fiscal quarter, ended Jan. 27, compared with a loss of $33.1 million for its first quarter, ended Oct. 28. It would be Macy's fourth consecutive quarterly loss, one of the retailer's biggest and hardly what Macy's has been hoping for. In a recent letter to investors, Macy's management said: ''We don't expect that you will be pleased with the results of our most recent quarter. We certainly will not be.'' 
The latest results, which include the important Christmas season, are also expected to show a decline of more than a percentage point in gross profit margins from a year ago.
 
Reports Produce Caution
Yet, the warnings and bad-news meetings with bankers, investors and suppliers have produced more caution than consternation among them, indicating that the admonitions may be having a calculated effect. ''We hear the numbers to be reported are terrible,'' one supplier said. ''But the effect will depend much on the P.R. job they do before the losses come out.''
Some bankers and financiers said they had lost none of their enthusiasm for the skills of Edward S. Finkelstein, Macy's chairman and chief executive, and his team of 350 associates who led a leveraged buyout of the company in July 1986.
But others insist that Macy's management has lost its way by concentrating on raising cash flow to pay its merger debt, has unfairly blamed the price-cutting competition of Federated/Allied stores for its problems and needs a new strategy.
 
Employee Morale a Concern
If Macy's has successfully prepared outsiders for dismay, internally it has not been as successful. Concerned about employee morale, senior executives have held meetings with middle and junior managers to convince them that the company is doing fine, with lots of liquidity and good cash flow. But worry and fear over the losses and exhortations to work harder have affected some in the buyout group, as well as many employees.
''There seems to be definite concern among Macy's executives about the state of their business,'' said Robert E. Kerson, president of Walter Levy/Robert Kerson Associates, a retail-marketing and recruiting company in New York. ''We are seeing more executives willing to leave Macy than ever before.''
''Many of these,'' he added, are in the leveraged-buyout group, ''which suggests there are some nonbelievers.'' He continued, ''They feel the rewards predicted for them may not develop or will take longer than they expected, and the multiples promised for the return of their investment seem to be fading away.''
 
Meetings With Banks
Macy's has met several times in recent weeks with its main bank lenders. The executive of one, who asked not to be identified, said yesterday: ''We are concerned about the retail industry as a whole and about Macy's, too. Though they are highly leveraged, they have done a good job of bringing their debt down. We know their news is not great.''
But, the bank executive continued, Macy's officials had given assurances that they had taken steps to cut back store inventories, which some analysts had criticized as too high. The banker also said Macy's planned to keep pace with competitors ''without taking too much of a bath in markdowns.'' He added, ''Their sales are better.''
Mark G. Solow, senior managing director of acquisition finance for the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company's investment banking sector, declared: ''I have an awful lot of confidence in Ed Finkelstein and his team. I have been through two financings with them. But I believe that anyone who expects every year to be better with our present economic situation must be naive. The economy is going through a cycle that we have known was coming. I have a number of deals that I've worked on and some I've been concerned about. But not this one.''
 
The Strain Is Showing
Macy's, taken private by Mr. Finkelstein in 1986, has debt of more than $4.7 billion left from the buyout he led and from the company's acquisition of the Bullock's and I. Magnin chains in 1988. Macy's has taken steps to cut expenses, combine operations and lay off some people. The company denies reports of large layoffs, but others insist that the dimissals are growing.
Under the surface, the strain is showing within Macy's, creating some dissension.
Some executives have bristled at Mr. Finkelstein's urgings that they work Saturdays to achieve better results. ''If we've been doing such a lousy job in five days, it could be even worse in six days,'' one executive told his supervisor, according to a story making the rounds at the company. ''Maybe we need a new game plan instead.''
 
Effect of a Recent Appointment
The recent appointment of Myron E. Ullman, a former executive of Wharf Holdings, as Macy's corporate executive vice president and chief financial officer has caused what is described by insiders as a power play and some confusion among other top executives in the New York corporate headquarters and in the divisions in California and Atlanta.
For years, Mark S. Handler, president and chief operating officer, has functioned as Macy's No. 2 executive under Mr. Finkelstein. Now, apparently with the chief executive's approval, divisional presidents who reported to Mr. Handler are reporting to Mr. Ullman. ''Ed has handed Mike Ullman the responsibility for the daily operations,'' a Macy executive said.
While convinced that ''Macy's continues to be an excellent retailer,'' Walter F. Loeb, a retail consultant, said: ''Suppliers are nervous about Macy partly because they've been sensitized by the losses and bankruptcy at Campeau's Federated/ Allied Stores. Finkelstein has done a good job of keeping the suppliers warned about continuing losses, unlike Campeau, where there were unpleasant surprises. But I think that the critical year will be 1991, which could be very damaging to Macy if it doesn't turn around by then.''
Meanwhile, Macy and Pittsburgh City Center, a new shopping mall in Pittsburgh, said that Macy's had agreed to open a 250,000-square-foot department store in the mall in spring 1993. It will be the first big department store opened in the city in 65 years. The store is one of eight new ones Macy's plans to open in the next few years, although none is planned for the 1990 fiscal year, which began July 30, 1989. Macy, R. H.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Posts Sharp Climb Against Yen

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar surged yesterday to its highest level in two and a half years against the Japanese yen and rose against the West German mark, buoyed by the market's negative sentiment toward the two foreign currencies.
The dollar closed at 152.63 against the yen, despite overnight efforts by the Bank of Japan to halt the rise. It closed at 151.27 Friday. 
The United States currency has not been higher since July 1987, when it traded at 153.45 yen.
Against the mark, the dollar rose to 1.7135, from Friday's 1.7035. Some dealers said the dollar would have risen further except for anxiety over the possibility that the West German central bank would intervene to sell dollars if the exchange rate rose much above 1.71 marks.
The volatile Tokyo stock market, where share prices have fallen sharply this year, and worries about Japanese interest rates have combined to weaken the yen. Tokyo's key Nikkei index fell 624.89 points Monday, a loss of 1.84 percent, to close at 33,368.23.
The dollar has marched higher since last month despite repeated sales of the currency by the Bank of Japan and other central banks trying to halt its rise.
''We've busted through the 152-yen area,'' said Francoise Soares-Kemp, a vice president at Credit Suisse. ''The dollar-yen situation is pretty clear.''
The dollar initially overcame the barrier in Tokyo as investors and speculators bet the United States currency would move higher still. The rise carried over into trading in New York.
Traders said that the dollar jumped further in late trading on rumors that Japan's Prime Minister might be replaced this spring. Smick Medley International, an influential Washington consulting firm, said in a report that there is a better than even chance that Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu will step down, possibly by the end of May, because of problems with the budget and the economy.
Traders remain wary of central bank intervention but that was not enough to prevent the sharp dollar rally yesterday.
''Bit by bit, the market is chiseling away at the central banks, while the central banks are trying to chisel away at the market,'' said Alexis Egan, a corporate dealer for Banque Indosuez in New York.
Traders said that only the Bank of Japan intervened yesterday, selling an estimated $100 million to $200 million for yen.
They added that the dollar is likely to continue appreciating gradually unless officials from the seven wealthiest industrial nations adjust their monetary policies to push the United States currency lower.
Psychology is bearish for the mark due to worries that Eastern Europe's political and economic liberalization will cause higher West German inflation.
In other currency action yesterday, the British pound fell to $1.6115 from Friday's finish at $1.6160. The dollar ended at 1.5265 Swiss francs, up from 1.5105 Friday and at $1.1795 Canadian, down slightly from Friday's $1.1800 Canadian.
Gold prices finished unchanged to slightly lower in New York after rising overseas. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery, on the expiring March contract settled unchanged at $399.80 an ounce. The active April contract was off 50 cents an ounce, to $401.10.
Gold was bid at $400.65 an ounce late in London, up from $399.05 on Friday. The late bid in Zurich was $401.10 an ounce, up from $399.50. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold closed at $400.55 an ounce, down from $400.65.
Silver bullion traded late in London at a bid of $5.13 an ounce, up from $5.11. On New York's Comex, silver for current delivery settled at $5.042 an ounce, down from $5.095 late Friday.

HEADLINE: Business and Health;
Research Outlays To Aid the Aging

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim

 BODY:
MEDICAL experts and their supporters in the business community are putting pressure on Congress to spend more for basic research on a number of illnesses that make life miserable and expensive for millions of elderly Americans.
They argue that in the long run the best way to slow spiraling health-care costs is by devising better treatments for Alzheimer's disease, osteoporosis, incontinence and other conditions that force millions of the elderly into nursing homes.
Advancing their case, the Pepper Commission, a bipartisan Congressional advisory group named for the late Representative Claude Pepper, Democrat of Florida, recently recommended that annual Congressional appropriations for research into diseases of the elderly be gradually raised to $1 billion from the $380 million appropriated last year.
The $380 million includes spending by the National Institute on Aging and the other institutes studying heart, cancer and neurological diseases, said Daniel Perry, executive director of the Alliance for Aging Research, an advocacy group supported by foundations and businesses. In all, basic health research got $7.6 billion. 
The research outlay is minor compared with the cost of care for people aged 65 and over, which absorbed $180 billion of the nation's health-care spending last year. The amount is expected to grow rapidly as the population ages. The number of Amerians over 85, those most likely to enter nursing homes, may quadruple by the year 2030.
''If we don't make the investment in research, we will pay dearly later on,'' said Dr. Robert N. Butler, chairman of geriatrics at the Mount Sinai Medical Center's School of Medicine in New York. He said promising studies already under way could save enormous amounts in medical costs. For example, studies of hormonal treatments for enlarged prostates in older men may produce a far less costly alternative to the 400,000 prostate operations done each year.
Dr. T. Franklin Williams, director of the National Institute on Aging, said a simple skin biopsy to diagnose Alzheimer's, the memory-loss disease, might ''save $1 billion right up front in diagnostic tests,'' which are largely paid for by Medicare.
Dr. Alan M. Garber, an economist and assistant professor of medicine at Stanford University, said such medical advances would mean longer and better lives - ''80 good years instead of 70'' for many people. But he questioned whether overall health care costs would be reduced. ''More people will survive longer, which may even increase their costs,'' a Congressional aide said.
The major drug companies are spending $3.6 billion this year to find new treatments for the elderly. Merck & Company, for example, said it is spending ''a very substantial part'' of the $855 million it has allotted to research and development on illnesses that are common in older people. A growing share of industry research budgets is going to basic research in laboratories. ''But the National Institute on Aging helps to set priorities and to publicize those priorities,'' said Dr. John F. Beary 3d, a senior vice president with the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, an industry group.
Some financial service companies are also supporting Federal research to help the aging. The nation will have to try to reduce the number of elderly who lose their independence ''or the 11 percent of gross national product going to health care will inevitably go up,'' said F. Peter Libassi, a senior vice president with the Travelers Corporation, which manages health benefits and sells long-term-care insurance.
John L. Steffens, president of Merrill Lynch Consumer Markets and chairman of the Alliance for Aging Research, said business people had several concerns. They include paying the health costs of their retirees, the level of Government spending, and the financial implications for individuals who will face ''25 to 30 percent of their lives in retirement'' as life expectancy lengthens. ''If we begin to plan for some of these eventualities of changing demographics now, we can solve these problems,'' he said. ''I don't think we're going to ration health care.''
The Bush Administration's budget calls for a 4.7 percent increase in the budget for the National Institutes of Health, to $7.9 billion, next year. Congress usually adds a few percentage points to Administration requests for health research, Congressional aides said. Alzheimer's research, which has been gaining national support, is likely to get some added money, they said.
Representative Mary Rose Oakar, Democrat of Ohio, said she would urge the House Appropriations Committee to increase spending for research to help the aging. ''We are very pennywise and pound foolish,'' she said.

HEADLINE: JAPAN INVESTMENT IN U.S. PROPERTY OFF

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 12

 BODY:
Japanese purchases of United States real estate fell 10.7 percent in 1989, with investment shifting from office buildings to hotels and resort properties, the real estate accounting firm Kenneth Leventhal & Company said today.
The Japanese spent $14.8 billion on real estate in the United States last year, compared with $16.5 billion in 1988, the company's report said.
Purchases of office properties fell about 60 percent to $3.3 billion in 1989 from $8.31 billion in 1988. Investment in hotel-resort properties rose to $4.16 billion last year, from $3.58 billion in 1988, a 16 percent increase. 
Over all, offices remain the favorite target of Japanese investors, said Jack Barthell, a Leventhal partner. Of the total $5.7 billion that the firm's data show as invested in United States real estate, 44 percent is in offices.
The Japanese appear to be backing away from purchases of ''trophy properties,'' like Rockefeller Center, the study found. Mitsubishi Estate Company last year announced it was spending $846 million for a controlling interest in the compnay that owns Rockefeller Center, the New York office and cultural center.
The study also noted that the Japanese still own just 2 percent of United States commercial real estate, far less than European investers.
California was the leading state for the second year in a row, with 36 percent of the 1989 investment. Forty percent of the purchases were concentrated in the greater Los Angeles area.
Hawaii was second and New York third, but interest among Japanese buyers in New York properties appears to be waning.
''Most attractive properties have already been acquired, and the cost of acquisitions in Manhattan may cause investors to divert funds to other markets,'' Mr. Barthell said.
The top three states accounted ofr 81 percent of the Japanese investment.
Among the findings, investment in residential property jumped to 15 percent, triple the amount invested in 1988. Nearly two-thirds of that was in California, and 28 percnet in Hawaii.
Leventhal said the size of Japanese deals is getting smaller as investment moves into smaller American cities, and that Japan's largest institutional investors are turning attention to Europe leading up to economic unification in 1992.
Leventhal defines investment as both equity investment and convertible debt secured by United States real estate.

LENGTH: 1759 words

HEADLINE: Honda Blurs Line Between American and Foreign

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MARYSVILLE, Ohio

 BODY:
When the Honda Accord became the best-selling car model in the United States last year - the first foreign car ever to do so - not everyone viewed the event as simply another sign of American industrial decline at the hands of Japan.
A reason is that the Honda Motor Company, which once offered only cars imported from Japan, has in some ways become as American an auto maker as Ford or General Motors. And that is spurring a growing debate about whether a company like Honda, despite its foreign ownership, should not be nourished as a national asset rather than lumped in with companies that simply flood American markets with products manufactured abroad.
The debate affects a host of issues, including when to apply curbs on imports of autos or auto parts, and which companies' products the United States should champion in world markets. It involves not only automobile manufacturing but also other industries from consumer electronics to machine tools. 
More than any other foreign auto maker, Honda is blurring the distinction between foreign and American. The proof is Honda's huge plant here, which assembled 363,668 Honda Accords and Civics last year, more cars than any other single auto plant in the United States.
When the plant opened eight years ago, American workers, like many at Japanese-owned factories in this country, were mainly used to assemble parts mostly imported from Japan, to build cars designed by Japanese engineers. The engines, for example, were built in Japan and shipped so that they could simply be dropped into place.
But now, Honda is sharing skills and ideas with its American work force at levels from the assembly line to the design office, and it has increasingly relied on those workers for more than just relatively simple labor. Honda has begun to use its American engineers in Ohio and California to design cars for the United States market, the company's largest, and to improve the tools and processes used to build them.
''We're not here as puppets,'' said Dan Smith, 31 years old, a manager who supervises engineers involved in testing cars at the Marysville plant. Mr. Smith was once an engineer with the Cummins Engine Company.
The percentage of imported parts used at the Marysville plant has fallen significantly; the number of parts suppliers based in the United States has risen to 194, from 27, since the plant opened. (That group includes American companies, Japanese companies based in this country and joint ventures.) And the engines are now being built from scratch at a new plant near Marysville.
 
A Hybrid Vehicle
The Accord itself is now a hybrid, built by workers in both Japan and the United States and exported from both countries. Honda engineers here have designed a two-door version that is now being exported to Japan. An Accord station wagon and all the machinery needed to build it will also be designed at Marysville, and that car will be exported to the European market as well.
''Eventually, we will be able to create full and original vehicle models here, but we have to learn gradually the way Honda wants it done; you have to learn by doing,'' said John Adams, who supervises 150 engineers who build machines and tools for manufacturing the vehicles.
Honda's strategy is to develop and build cars in the main areas where they are sold - Japan, North America and Europe - and even export them, said Scott Whitlock, Honda's executive vice president for United States manufacturing and a former lawyer from Columbus, Ohio.
Viewed in this light, Honda may seem far less threatening to American economic interests than the stereotypical Japanese company.
 
Helping U.S. Competitiveness
Indeed, rather than undermining American competitiveness, the cross-pollination at Honda actually increases it, a number of experts say. They argue that Honda, one of the standard-setters in manufacturing and engineering cars, is helping Americans improve an essential product. The improvements will soon spread to other manufacturers trying to stay even, the theory goes.
For example, the Ford Motor Company last month became the first American auto maker to switch to the production of a new model without stopping the assembly line for more than a day, a practice Japanese auto makers, including Honda in Marysville, have used for some time to increase productivity.
Normally, a plant might stop work for four or five weeks to install new tools. But at Honda, by constructing reprogrammable machines that move on tracks, engineers can slow the production line and quickly shift from the old model to the new one.
As another example, Honda has shown its American supplier, the Inland Steel Company, how to remove tiny imperfections in its steel that hindered the effectiveness of a corrosion-resistant coating, said Matthew Lofton, Inland's general sales manager. Inland later signed up the Chrysler Corporation as a customer for the corrosion-resistant steel.
 
New Management Philosophies
''Plants like this force everyone else to put on their track shoes,'' said David Cole, head of transportation studies at the University of Michigan and an auto industry consultant. He said Honda's Marysville plant enhances American industrial competitiveness ''by introducing new management philosophies and becoming a model for other U.S. firms.''
Such arguments have been voiced passionately by Robert B. Reich, a professor at the John F. Kennedy School of Public Policy at Harvard University. Professor Reich argues that foreign-owned corporations that invest heavily in American operations can sometimes contribute more to American competitiveness than their American-owned counterparts. He says the United States must stop favoring companies simply because they ''fly the U.S. flag.''
As Professor Reich sees it, although profits from Honda go to Japan, that sum accounts for little when compared with the company's outlays for salaries, materials, research and training in the United States. Moreover, world securities markets allow American investors to buy shares in Honda.
Hence, Professor Reich contends that the nation should develop policies governing foreign investment, trade, antitrust and research and development that encourage ''any global corporation that invests in the American work force,'' like Honda.
 
New Spirit in Trade Matters
Specifically, he argues, the United States should work to open foreign markets to goods built by Americans, even if they work for Honda, rather than just to companies with headquarters in the United States, which might be assembling products abroad. He opposes import quotas or retaliatory tariffs, protectionist measures suggested by some American automotive concerns.
In the spirit of Professor Reich's arguments, United States trade officials seem in some ways to be accepting Honda and other Japanese car makers as among their own, despite frequent criticism of Japan. Last month, the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, strongly warned the European Community that this country would protest any attempt in Europe to restrict imports of cars built by Japanese companies in the United States. France and Italy are pressing hard for restrictions.
''We would be remiss if we didn't stress how strongly we feel that a Japanese nameplate car made in our country is an American car,'' Mrs. Hills told a press briefing.
But many in the United States auto industry disagree. They have urged the Government to take a hard line against Japanese auto makers.
 
Auto Workers' Position
The United Automobile Workers union, for example, argues that cars produced at plants like Marysville should be considered imports and counted toward the import quotas voluntarily adopted by Japan. That would mean that Honda and other Japanese auto makers would sell fewer cars in the United States, possibly making it uneconomical to manufacture here. Such a move could reduce the sales of individual models to the point that their American plants might no longer have the production volume to justify the capital expense.
Other proposals, while not specifically aimed at Honda or the auto industry, could restrict imports of engines or components the Japanese auto makers deem vital. The Automotive Parts and Accessories Association, an American trade group, has asked the Senate to tighten restrictions on imported auto parts used by Japanese car makers in this country. The group contends that American auto-parts makers are being excluded from Japanese markets.
American auto executives also criticize the rules and customs hampering American entry into the Japanese market, like the expensive requirement of building exclusive dealerships rather than selling through multi-brand dealerships as permitted in the United States.
The attitude of American auto executives toward the Japanese is complex. Each of the Big Three car makers owns stakes in Japanese auto makers and has joint ventures with them. But they also feel threatened by the stunning success of their Japanese counterparts.
 
'Adversarial Trade'
''I'm uneasy at this stage by the process of Asian ownership,'' said Donald E. Petersen, who recently retired as chairman of Ford. ''It's what Peter Drucker calls adversarial trade, rather than competitive trade. Their objective is to eliminate the competition.''
Don Hilty, chief economist for the Chrysler Corporation, said Professor Reich's argument did not hold up. For one thing, Mr. Hilty said, Honda carries out very little research or development work here. Moreover, as he sees it, the Honda Accord Coupe, which is made exclusively in this country, is no more than ''a derivative, strictly a P.R. exercise.''
Frank Joyce, a spokesman for the United Automobile Workers, criticizes Japanese car makers for paying less than union wages and benefits at American plants like Honda's. The union, anticipating a defeat, called off a vote at the Honda plant on recognizing the U.A.W. as bargaining agent.
Like Honda, other Japanese auto makers have increasingly been obtaining parts and components in the United States while giving American engineers, designers and managers additional responsibility. Nissan, Toyota and Mazda have opened American research and development centers.
 
Honda's Edge at Marysville
Honda management argues, however, that the Marysville plant is the farthest ahead in bringing in Americans at all stages of the process.
Honda workers make many engine parts, assemble engines, turn steel sheet into parts and certify cars for export to Japan.

HEADLINE: Civilian Sworn In as Haiti's President

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, March 13

 BODY:
Ertha Pascal-Trouillot, the only woman on Haiti's Supreme Court, became Provisional President of Haiti today, and the chief of the army declared, with a snappy salute, that his forces were ''at your command.''
''The army will stay in the barracks,'' Maj. Gen. Herard Abraham, its chief, said in a ceremony before hundreds of Haitians and foreign diplomats at the gleaming white presidential palace. The army has dominated the country for the last four years, since the three-decade dictatorship of the Duvalier family was overthrown.
Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot, who was appointed to the high court four years ago, broke an impasse by accepting the presidency after civilian political leaders rejected the chief justice, who was designated by the constitution to succeed Lieut. Gen. Prosper Avril when he stepped down as head of a military Government over the weekend. 
In a brief speech, Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot said that her principal task would be to lead the country to early elections.
 
'No Other Ambition' but Service
''I have no other ambition,'' she said, ''but for the singular service of my country. My Government will be what you want it to be, constantly animated by the breath of your aspirations and your invincible hopes.''
Thousands of Haitians crowded the boulevard and plazas in front of the palace, cheering and waving green branches from trees and shrubs, a symbol here of peace and freedom, as the new President, in a white linen suit, General Abraham, in an olive dress uniform, and his wife, Maryse, stood on the palace steps while the army band played the presidential anthem. Later, the crowd surged behind Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot's motorcade.
There was no violence in the vicinity of the palace, but scattered incidents were reported elsewhere in the capital.
The ceremony, in which the chief of the army and the entire high command indivdually pledged loyalty to a civilian President, was an emotional milestone in a country that since the fall of the Duvalier dictatorship in 1986 has repeatedly been frustrated and battered by military commanders seeking to perpetuate their own power.
Also present in the chandeliered palace chamber were the civilian political leaders who had struggled for the departure of General Avril and had selected Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot as President. Despite their triumph, the civilian political leaders still face street violence, severe economic problems, vast political differences, fierce rivalries and a paucity of political experience.
 
Civilians Outflank Military
Nevertheless, for the first time since President Jean-Claude Duvalier fled to exile in France in 1986, civilians have outflanked the military, taken power for themselves and selected the country's temporary leader from their own ranks.
''It's certainly a great day for this country, a great day for democracy,'' said Alvin P. Adams, the United States Ambassador here, shortly before lifting a glass of champagne to the new President.
One concern of many Haitians is whether the army will try to disarm the hundreds of former members of the Duvaliers' Tontons Macoutes civilian security forces and, if so, whether they will succeed. One senior officer said he thought the former Tontons Macoutes might ''keep quiet'' if they were left alone. ''They would like to live in peace like everyone else in this new situation,'' the officer said.
 
Job Is Seen as Limited
Late this afternoon, the 12 political leaders who were instrumental in bringing about the latest changes met with the new president in her first formal meeting in the palace.
Most of the political leaders say they see the job of the provisional goverment as extremely limited and in her acceptance speech Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot, who has written several books on law, seemed to agree. She said she expected to oversee ''the normal functioning of the administration'' without undertaking ''profound initiatives.''
Francois Latortue, a former Minister of Justice who appointed Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot to the high court in 1986, said that contrary to widespread reports on Monday she was not the only woman serving as a judge in Haiti. He estimated that about 10 women serve on various courts, adding that most are justices of the peace and deal with misdemeanor crimes.

GRAPHIC: Photo: As Ertha Pascal-Trouillot was sworn in as Provisional President of Haiti yesterday, soldiers held back a crowd in front of the National Palace in Port-au-Prince, where the inauguration ceremony took place. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Aid Hanoi on Boat People, U.N. Official Urges

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GENEVA, March 13

 BODY:
Faced with continuing United States opposition to the forced repatriation of boat people from Hong Kong to Vietnam, a leading United Nations official appealed today for a sharp increase in international aid to Vietnam. The aim of the aid would be to stop the boat people from fleeing Vietnam in the first place.
But the official, Thorvald Stoltenberg, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, told a meeting of representatives from about 25 countries here today that he expected the impasse on the issue of the boat people to continue. 
Last January, an international meeting here came close to an agreement to start forcibly repatriating boat people in Southeast Asia determined to be economic migrants, next July. But the agreement fell through when the United States said it would not accept any forced returns until the beginning of next year.
The meeting asked the High Commissioner to mediate, but today her reported that the United States had not shown any willingness to compromise on the length of the moratorium before deportations could begin.
In response, Mr. Stoltenberg ''made a plea for more economic assistance for Vietnam to deal with those pockets of poverty where many boat people come from'' said a spokesman of the agency, Raymond Hall.
 
Most Are Fleeing Poverty
The agency is so eager to attack the root causes contributing to the outflow that it is prepared to play the unusual role of ''catalyst and coordinator'' of aid to Vietnam, Mr. Hall said.
Mr. Stoltenberg, a former Norwegian Foreign Minister who took over the United Nations job in January, told the meeting that 50 percent of the boat people come from four impoverished coastal districts of Quang Ninh province in the north, near Haiphong.
Since the Communist victory there in 1975, the United States has been at the forefront of efforts to stop foreign aid from reaching that country.
A Western diplomat at today's meeting said ''it's definitely true.''
''If you want to lure people back you have to offer them something,'' the diplomat said.
But donor countries have so far pledged only $18 million of the $108 million that the High Commissioner's office has appealed for this year to care for the boat people and help voluntary returnees readapt to Vietnamese life.

HEADLINE: Khomeini's Son Urges No Concessions on Hostages

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, March 13

 BODY:
Two leading militants in the Iranian leadership have issued statements strongly opposing the release of Western hostages taken in Lebanon by pro-Iranian militias, stating that Iran should refrain from talks with the United States on the issue.
The remarks, by Ahmed Khomeini, the son of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, who died last June, and former Interior Minister Ali Akbar Mohtashemi, indicate that President Hashemi Rafsanjani has been unable to achieve a consensus in the Iranian leadership on the release of the hostages.
Arab and Western diplomats who are experts in Iranian affairs said that until a yearlong power struggle within the ranks of Iran's leadership is resolved, no action can be expected on the hostage issue.
President Rafsanjani and other Iranian officials have suggested over the last two weeks that Teheran was willing to mediate the release of the Western hostages in Lebanon in return for a resumption of economic, diplomatic and technical aid from the West. 
But Mr. Khomeini asserted in a speech to police officers on Monday that ''the United States will never see the day when the Islamic Republic will make concessions to Washington.''
 
U.S. Is 'Wasting Its Time'
Mr. Khomeini, who denied that Iran is directly implicated in the holding of hostages, said ''the United States is wasting its time'' if it is trying to open channels to Iran.
Ayatollah Khomeini's son is not a member of Parliament or of the Rafsanjani Government, but he continues to influence policy in Iran through a large network of allies in powerful posts in the Revolutionary Guards militia, several state-owned financial institutions, the Interior Ministry and the Iranian intelligence apparatus.
Hojatolislam Mohtashemi, a member of the Iranian Parliament, wrote in an editorial in the Teheran daily Kayhan on Saturday that ''freedom for the hostages means breaking the chains of bloodthirsty wolves.''
Arab intelligence officials and Western diplomats say Hojatolislam Mohtashemi played the major role in building up the Party of God militia in Lebanon as a fighting force. Groups attached to the Party of God are presumed to hold at least 16 Western hostages.
Experts on Iran say that a competition has been raging among factions in Iran over the control of the militias aligned with the Party of God. In the last few months, President Rafsanjani has tried to reassert his control over the militias' financing and supplies.
While this effort is believed to have been somewhat successful, a considerable segment of the assistance to the militias continues to come from other factions in Iran, notably those connected with Mr. Mohtashemi and presumably Mr. Khomeini. Arab experts on Iranian affairs noted that the militias encourage this competition within Iran, since they benefit from it.
Iran's spiritual leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, appeared to call for an end to the infighting within the country by suggesting that it gives an impression of weakness. He accused the Western press of encouraging the notion that Iran is seeking help from the West because the country has been ''finally brought to its knees.''
 
Iran Seeks $27 Billion
The latest Iranian contact with the West, made public only on Monday, was a visit in late February by an International Monetary Fund delegation at Iran's request. The negotiations in Teheran were the first talks between the I.M.F. and Iran in 10 years.
Iran is seeking $27 billion to repair its economy and increase production of oil and petrochemicals, industries that are vital to earning foreign currency but that were wrecked by the long war with Iraq that ended in 1988.
But Western officials say no loans can happen without approval from the I.M.F. and Western financial groups - which is unlikely as long as Western hostages are held in Lebanon.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From President's News Session on Foreign and Domestic Issues

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Bush's news conference in Washington yesterday, as transcribed by The New York Times:
 
OPENING STATEMENT
Today I want to speak about how we can best help two democracies in our hemisphere, Panama and Nicaragua. These nations need our help to heal deep wounds inflicted by years of strife and oppression, years of loss and deprivation. . . . I've taken an important step today. As a demonstration of our resolve to be part of the process of reconciliation, I just signed an executive order to end the economic embargo against Nicaragua. . . . And next, I'm asking the Congress and the American people to join me in crafting a bipartisan agreement to help both countries. . . .
I'm proposing the creation of a Fund for Democracy to assist in the reconstruction and development of these two countries, and I'm requesting the Congress to approve, by April 5th, a package of assistance of $800 million for these two countries, using funds from the defense budget. This package consists of $500 million for Panama - already requested in that Jan. 25th proposal to Congress, along with $70 million for refugees, and an additional $300 million for Nicaragua. . . .
In addition, under existing authorities I'm initiating immediate action to provide $21 million of previously appropriated economic aid, principally for food and - and humanitarian assistance. I also will be sending to the Congress in the future a budget amendment for an additional $200 million in fiscal '91 for Nicaragua, consistent with the approach that we've taken this year. . . . 
I am prepared because of the dire need for these funds to ask for a waiver of the Budget Act to allow this critical program to proceed on a required timetable.
 
Quick Action Is Urged
I urge the Congress to move quickly, and also urge in the strongest terms that it not add any extraneous requests - items to this request. . . . Our help is needed swiftly to bring about demilitarization and advance the whole Central American peace process. . . .
Let me . . . give you the three broad categories of assistance: aid for democracy, for development and for demilitarization. . . .
Development and demilitarization, they go hand in hand. They start when we provide textbooks for children, when we create thousands of new jobs, when the hand that held a gun guides a plow. In short, as we demobilize the military we must mobilize the market. This is a great and historic task, but we are inspired by the courage of our neighbors. We're close - very, very close - to a hemisphere that is completely democratic, a compass of freedom that spans half the world, from Alaska to Argentina. . . .
And now I'd be glad to respond to questions. And, Helen, I believe you have the first one.
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
 
Taxes and the Deficit
Q. Your warm reception of the Rostenkowski plan - does that mean you are ready to negotiate tax increases and a freeze on Social Security benefits, things you have never gone for in the past?
A. No, it doesn't. The answer is no. . .
Q. You're not willing to negotiate, or what is your --
A. Overall feeling? Look, I think he, without rancour, without a lot of rhetoric, made a very broad proposal. We've made a proposal, the Administration. We now would like to hear from the budget process on the Hill what their proposal is, and then we'll talk.
But I . . . was being receptive through not knocking the things in it we don't like - and there are plenty. . . .
Q. You're not saying that you would go for a tax increase or --
A. No, I'm not for a tax --
Q. You don't want a freeze on Social Security --
A. Well, there's a lot of things I'm not for that are in his proposal. A lot, including taxes.
 
Recognition of Lithuania
Q. Mr. President, the United States has never recognized the forced incorporation of Lithuania into the Soviet Union. Now that Lithuania has declared its independence, the United States seems to be moving tentatively toward full recognition. Is that because we're afraid of offending Mr. Gorbachev or don't want to alienate him?
A. It's because we want to see the evolution of the control of the territory there. And also we want to see peaceful resolution to this question.
Q. Well, do we still regard Lithuania as a captive nation, along with the --
A. We might not use the word, but we never have regarded Lithuania as incorporated into the Soviet Union. That's been our policy. . .
 
Disbanding the Contras
Q. Mr. President, are you concerned about the apparent reluctance of the contras to disband, and what can you do about it?
A. Yes, I am concerned about it . . . and I'm also concerned about certain military action by the Sandinistas. But I'm also encouraged, Britt, because yesterday I talked to Dan Quayle and he told me of his visit with Ortega, where Ortega seemed concerned about -seemed willing to transfer the Defense Ministry, seemed willing to transfer the Interior Ministry, and was open about the discussion of reducing - I want to be careful here I don't overstate it - but reducing military action on both sides.
So I can't say I'm not concerned, but I am encouraged the way it's going so far.
 
U.S. Policy on Israel
Q. Mr. President, do you regret the other day raising the issue of settlements in East Jerusalem?
A. No, I don't regret it. I think all the speculation and commentary of the last 10 days have blown things way out of proportion. What I was doing was reiterating United States policy. But let me say this: right now in Israel there is internal developments taking place in the political scene there, and I do not want to look in any way like we're trying to mingle into the internal affairs of Israel, as they're going through this difficult political problem right now. And so I will answer no more on it.
 
The Situation in China
Q. Mr. President, you opened your comments today by saying that the day of the dictator was over . . . and yet the exception to that rule is the situation in China. . . . Do you have any second thoughts about the approach that you took . . . and your sending of your high-level envoys there, and any thoughts that this policy must now change because of the lack of response from the Chinese?
A. No. But I'm not happy with the evolution of reform in China but I have no regrets about that. And I'm reinforced by - by a lot of expert opinion that feels that the approach I took, accomplishing something by executive order that the Congress wanted to do dramatically later on through legislation, was the proper approach. And I - so I hope - hope our policy will bear more fruit. But no, I am not happy with the status quo.
Q. Well, Mr. President, if you're not happy with the status quo, why not change your policy now to take a tougher line toward the Chinese regime?
A. Because I'm familiar with China and I think we're on the right track. And I hope that we'll see a - an evolution of more reform. And that's exactly why not change it now.
 
Reaction to Gephardt
Q. Why does Gephardt get under your skin so much? You've got a - I don't know, 80 percent approval rating. He makes a speech attacking you and --
A. Well, what have I said? Now what would make you think that he gets under my skin?
Q. He says you're not a strong leader, and want people around the White House --
A. Oh, I know, I know, that's so discouraging. But why do you think he gets under my skin? The honest answer is - I know you won't believe this - it doesn't. It doesn't. I think we're going in the right direction, we're taking substance in policy. I think the -many in the Congress think that we are being responsive. But look, I expect that, I expect that kind of political criticism.
But I think if you want to talk about the substance of his ideas, do I think it's a good idea to loan money to the Soviet Union today? No. We have no request for food aid to the Soviet Union; do you just want to put it on a ship and send it over there? No, I don't think that's a particularly brilliant idea. But I don't want to knock the man, maybe he'll come on a good idea one of these days.
 
Concern Over the Hostages
Q. Mr. President, last week you were so concerned about the hostages that you were willing to take a questionable call, and it might have been from the Iranian President and then, of course, you found out it wasn't. In response, Rafsanjani made a statement saying that you had been trying to get ahold of him for a month. Did you actually then try to place a call to the real person, or could you clarify --
A. I don't know where he got that. I saw that statement, and it was - there was no truth in it. . . . I think the bottom line is you have to say: would you do it again based on the information you had? And I'd say, yes, I probably would. . . .
But what's wrong with reaching out and touching someone when the hostages are at stake? The hostages are at stake here. And what's wrong with trying? And I, look, I feel this all the time. I've talked about this, that I will go the extra mile. And when the whole story comes out on this, you all are going to be very, very fascinated with the details.
Q. Tell us.
A. Very fascinated. But I'm just telling you that it is important - it is very important to run down every avenue in terms of these hostages. And I would be remiss if I didn't. . . .
Q. Can I follow up, Mr. President?
A. Yes.
Q. If you didn't try to reach him for a month, can you say whether you or anyone acting on your behalf did try to reach him at all?
A. Have we been trying to reach Rafsanjani?
Q. Have you tried, yes?
A. No, other than this one, one phone call that turns out to be a hoax.
Q. So as far as what you can tell, what he was saying just didn't make any sense.
A. Yes. It's very much like the rhetoric that they use from time to time. He's got some political problems at home, and we understand that. The main thing is can we move forward and get the hostages out. And I'll repeat, good will begets good will. . . .
 
Soviet Political System
Q. Mr. President, I understand that Tass is reporting this morning that the Soviet Parliament has granted President Gorbachev the expanded powers he wants and has been requesting. I'm interested, sir, if you side with those within the Soviet Union who fear that there are not sufficient checks and balances on this new Presidential system, that it could result in a more totalitarian Soviet Union? How you feel this might affect your dealings with Gorbachev, and whether you envision extending this Fund for Democracy perhaps one day to the Soviet Union itself?
A. I answer that by saying I stay out of the internal affairs and deliberations of the Soviet Union. And they are going through a process of reform which we support in broad terms, perestroika. They're going through a process of glasnost, which is openness, which we support. And it would be very inappropriate for the President of the United States to start passing judgment as that process of perestroika, democratization if you will, moves forward.
And so, yes, the Soviets have created a new post of president, I hear. But that's their business, and we will work with the - in this instance President Gorbachev. As you know, I think we have a reasonably good relationship there, a respectful one. And I'm going to continue to work with him.
Q. Well, can you say, sir, whether you think that as you continue to work with him, that will be affected in any way by these changes that have taken place? . . . And would you see involving the Soviet Union in this Fund for Democracy?
A. I think the answer is to help in a technical way as best we can for moving - helping the Soviets move toward a market economies and free markets and those kinds of considerations. . . . You know, there's discussion of an Eastern development bank. The question is out there whether the Soviets should be members of that bank or not. And as a matter of fact, we have some deliberations going on as to what the U.S. position should be right now. I'm not prepared to state it, but I've been spending some time on this question. . . .
 
U.S.-Japan Issues
Q. Mr. President, after your meeting in Palm Springs with Prime Minister Kaifu, he took a real beating in the Japanese Diet. And I wonder in retrospect were there any misunderstandings in your conversations? . . .
A. You know what? I think those reports just highlight the sensitivity of the situation in Japan. And I think the - as far as I'm concerned, the talk, the talks were very good.
Q. Just one follow-up. You said in a speech the day after you got back to the Electronics Association that you had discussed telecommunications with him. And that apparently came as a surprise to some people in Japan. Was that a brief discussion, a lengthy one?
A. A broad, a broad discussion of several categories. . . . We left the details of all of these categories that are so well known as differences between the U.S. and Japan to the experts.
 
Priority on Foreign Aid
Q. Mr. President, your opening statement - in your opening statement you appealed to Congress to pass your aid program, but you did not appeal to the American people. And one of the problems a lot of Congressmen say they're having is that foreign aid at this time is not a high priority for a lot of people. What do you - do you think an appeal, first of all, to ordinary Americans is necessary, and what do you say to people who think that perhaps what may be seen as the first part of a peace dividend is going overseas?
A. I think you put your finger on a good point. However, I believe that both Nicaragua and Panama have strong support from the American people. . . . And I am convinced that when the American people understand what we're talking about offsetting proposals in defense - in other words, not going in there and costing them more, or taking it away from some other program - that it will have strong support.
 
Cheney-Webster Differences
Q. What about the differences reported between Secretary Cheney and C.I.A. Director Webster over the threat assessment --
A. Just a minute --
Q. -- in the event that Gorbachev is thrown out of power.
A. One minute on that one. As I've said before, I don't see any real disagreement here. No. I tried to answer that yesterday and I expect I didn't, didn't lay it to rest. But I don't think anybody believes, including Cheney, that the Soviet system is going to go back to where it was in, in, you know, before 1980 and the middle of the 80's. But there are differences. When you go to try to predict with accuracy, based on intentions.
And so I, I've talked to them now and I, I feel that they're pretty close together and I -it's difficult when you have a fast-changing world and yet you take a position like I do. We must retain a credible defense. And you get into a big debate - well, what is credible? And I think that's what you're seeing here. So I can tell you - I mean, talk to these gentlemen. I don't think that there is this enormous difference between the intelligence community . . . and and the Secretary. I think we've come up with a prudent, well-thought out defense plan. And there will be changes, I'm sure, after our cooperation with and consultation with Congress. But believe me, there - these are not diametrically different views that you're reading about.
Thank you all very much.

HEADLINE: President of Panama Ends His 13-Day Fast

DATELINE: PANAMA, March 13

 BODY:
President Guillermo Endara of Panama today ended a 13-day fast begun as ''an act of commiseration with a suffering people'' and as a protest against his country's worsening economic situation.
The President left the Metropolitan Cathedral here late this morning, at approximately the time President Bush said in Washington that the United States ''must act and act soon'' on aid to Nicaragua and Panama. The Bush Administration has promised $1 billion in aid and credits to Panama's new civilian Government, but the proposal is stalled in Congress.
Mr. Endara had no immediate comment on Mr. Bush's pledge of a renewed effort to get the aid package approved. But he said ''the messages of solidarity received from inside and outside Panama, including from leaders of brother countries, fill me with satisfaction and faith in my people.''
The President said he was ending his hunger strike because his conscience had told him ''the moment has come'' to return to his daily work routine.
The Associated Press reported that Mr. Endara began the fast weighing 240 pounds and lost 16 pounds.
He expressed hope that his ''personal and individual gesture'' would inspire others to help him end the country's economic crisis.

HEADLINE: Nicaraguans on Both Sides Praise Embargo's End

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, March 13

 BODY:
After five years of deepening economic hardship, much of it attributable to United States sanctions, Sandinista officials and opposition business leaders today applauded President Bush's decision to end the American embargo on trade with Nicaragua.
''The lifting of the economic embargo against Nicaragua is an act of justice that has been delayed for too long,'' said Vice President Sergio Ramirez Mercado. ''The economic embargo, the financial boycott, the closing of source of credits for all these years was not an act of injustice against the Sandinista Front as the party in power, but against the entire Nicaraguan nation, against all our people.''
Relief over Mr. Bush's decision, which also includes proposals for $300 million in new economic aid, was expressed not only by the Sandinista Government, which was the target of the sanctions, but also by anti-Sandinista leaders, some of whom had come to oppose the embargo as an excessively blunt and destructive political instrument. 
''It is extremely positive for Nicaragua in all respects,'' said Ramiro Gurdian Ortiz, an influential opposition business leader, referring to today's announcement. ''This opens up for us the biggest market in the world: the American market.''
 
The Timing Wins Praise
The Vice President, Mr. Ramirez, said the new package announced by Mr. Bush would not directly benefit his Government, which was defeated in national elections by the United States-backed National Opposition Union last month and is scheduled to leave power April 25.
But he described the decision as an important step toward rebuilding the nation's battered economy. And he praised its timing, interpreting it as an effort to end a decade of conflict between the United States and the Sandinista leadership.
''This could have been done perfectly well on the 25th of April,'' Mr. Ramirez said. ''I interpret it as a positive gesture from President Bush to President Ortega.''
This afternoon, the Nicaraguan Foreign Ministry formally invited the Bush Administration to send a delegation to study the economic situation here ''so that the economic aid can reach the Nicaraguan people as soon as possible.''
In a further softening of his Government's public statements on the coming transition of power, Mr. Ramirez emphasized that the Sandinista leaders would respect the right of the President-elect, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, to name the senior officials of the Sandinista People's Army and the Ministry of the Interior, which controls the security police.
''Mrs. Chamorro has the constitutional and legal powers, and we are going to respect them,'' Mr. Ramirez said.
 
A Denial on Arms Handout
Commenting on widespread evidence that Government officials had been handing out automatic weapons to Sandinista supporters in urban neighborhoods and in the countryside, Mr. Ramirez denied that the Government had a policy of arming civilians, and said efforts were being made to control such activity.
In many areas of the country, Sandinista supporters have spoken openly of receiving arms from the Government in the days since its electoral defeat, and some senior Sandinista officials, insisting on anonymity, have defended the step as an effort to prevent persecution of Sandinista militants by the incoming government.
But Mr. Ramirez asserted that any such reports were of isolated incidents and did not reflect a Government decision.
''We are not pursuing any Government policy of handing out weapons,'' Mr. Ramirez said in an interview. ''The Chief of Staff of the army convened a meeting of the military commanders of all the regions today to analyze the current situation and take the measures necessary to control any abnormal situations that might have been raised in this sense despite the Government's policy.''
 
Harsh Stand Is Softened
Mr. Ramirez's remarks appeared to represent a further shift away from the harsh posture assumed last week by Sandinista leaders in support of demands for demobilization of the contra rebels and preservation of the Sandinista-controlled army and Ministry of the Interior.
That defiant position was most vividly expressed in a speech last Thursday by President Daniel Ortega Saavedra suggesting that the country was now in a ''calm before the storm.'' And it was buttressed by Sandinista efforts to pass sweeping new laws granting immunity from prosecution for any crimes committed during Sandinista rule, and granting full, permanent property rights to any person or institution occupying government property.
Speaking today, Mr. Ramirez defended the legislation, which has been condemned by opposition leaders, describing it as a necessary step to prevent ''revanchism and revenge'' after the transition of power. But he acknowledged that the early versions of the laws had been poorly drafted, and said that the Sandinista-controlled National Assembly had recognized the need for important changes during floor debate.
The law granting immunity from prosecution, he noted, had been heavily amended before being approved Saturday in a form that would specifically give amnesty to combatants on both sides of the country's long contra war. In addition, he said, the law was amended again this morning to put it into effect immediately so as to remove the possibility that it could be used to pardon crimes that have not yet been committed.
''It was an error to send to the Assembly a law that wasn't properly scrutinized,'' he said. ''The first law of amnesty was really a bad law because it would have erased the penalty for all crimes, including common crimes. That is terrible, and for that reason we changed it immediately.''

HEADLINE: INDIA RE-EXAMINES ITS FOREIGN POLICY

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MADRAS, India, March 10

 BODY:
In India, where a special relationship with Moscow has brought diplomatic and trade benefits for decades, the tumultuous collapse of European Communism and changes in the Soviet Union itself are forcing the most fundamental rethinking of New Delhi's foreign policies since independence in 1947.
The turmoil in the Soviet bloc has been a blow to Indian intellectuals, many of whom have become apologists for authoritarian Communist governments while living in a democratic nation professing to be nonaligned. Indian socialists have played large roles in making foreign and domestic policies.
''The deep alienation in Eastern Europe came as a big shock to many here,'' said N. Ram, editor of the liberal Madras-based national newspaper The Hindu. ''Nobody really knew the extent of it. It destroyed many impressions and delusions.'' 
India's Foreign Minister, Inder Kumar Gujral, said in an interview that the lesson of the last few months was that ''successful socialism needs democratic party participation.''
 
Redefining Issue of Alliances
As for nonalignment with the United States or the Soviet Union, a movement in which India has taken a leading role, he said it was made ''irrelevant'' by recent events and would have to be redefined.
Mr. Gujral, a former Ambassador to Moscow, said that the most welcome recent event from the viewpoint of the developing world was the collapse of the spheres of influence that developed after World War II.
''Spheres of influence was another name for covert imperialism,'' he said. In place of this division of the world, he said that regional cooperation was growing, replacing nationalism and altering the meaning of patriotism. He referred to the prospects of a united Europe as a lesson to other regions including this one, where a South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation has made little headway.
While there is general agreement here that relations with neighboring nations - Pakistan excepted - have improved, there are new questions about how much New Delhi can depend on traditional Soviet support. India has enjoyed generous trade concessions, including the ability to pay for goods and services in rupees, which are useless to Moscow except in return trade.
 
Moscow's Support Uncertain
Moscow frequently backed India in world organizations, using its veto at the United Nations to block action on Kashmir, which India partly controls in contravention of United Nations resolutions. New Delhi's troops are trying to crush a separatist movement there.
Nikhil Chakravarty, editor of the leftist magazine Mainstream, said that on a recent visit to Moscow he was left with the impression that the Soviet Union would not use its veto, which he called ''a cold war ploy,'' on the Kashmir issue again.
He added, however, that Moscow was firm in insisting that Kashmir was a matter to be settled between India and Pakistan. But he also said that ''anything the Russians do today they do in consultation with Mr. Baker,'' the United States Secretary of State.
Mr. Chakravarty was one of the few Indian journalists to visit Eastern Europe during the revolutionary changes there, and not until January. Only in the last few weeks have analyses by him and others begun to appear in intellectual journals and newsmagazines.
 
Slow to Debate 1989 Change
India's two Communist parties, in whose offices portraits of Stalin can still be found, have shied away from official comment altogether.
The debate on India's response to the remaking of Europe was slow to begin in this country for several reasons.
Neither newspapers nor the national television network had correspondents at the momentous events of 1989.
Second, India was also changing its government in December after a bitterly fought election. There was little time for a general foreign policy debate in the new administration as Prime Minister Singh and Mr. Gujral were forced to concentrate first on Kashmir.
A third explanation lies in the general lack of public discussion of foreign affairs, a topic largely kept out of the political arena by India's powerful and secretive Ministry of External Affairs.
Officials and former members of the foreign policy establishment insist that there has been been complete public consensus on the two guiding principles of Indian policy, which they do not see as contradictory: no formal alliance with either superpower bloc and close ties to Moscow, cemented in a 1971 friendship treaty. A corollary to this is a belief that the United States has always misunderstood and been hostile to India.
''If you were to have referendum in India today - or if you had taken it ten years ago, 20 years ago, 30 years ago -and you asked the question: Which country does an Indian admire most?'' said A. P. Venkateswaran, a writer on international affairs and former director of the foreign ministry, ''the answer would always have been the United States.''
''But if you asked the question: Which country has stood by India in her time of the need, the U.S.S.R. would always come first,'' he added. ''Maybe today it would still come first.''
Government officials say that relations with the United States began to improve even before India's November election or the changes in Europe.
