HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East;
Lithuanian-Americans React With Joy After 50-Year Wait

BYLINE: By SUZANNE DALEY

 BODY:
A party in Chicago for a local Lithuanian-language radio program on Sunday erupted into a more spontaneous celebration. Just minutes earlier, Lithuania had proclaimed itself free of the Soviet Union.
''People started applauding and, almost as if on cue, they stood up and started singing the Lithuanian national anthem,'' said Daiva Meile, who was among the guests. ''There was euphoria - such a sense of pride.'' 
By yesterday, Ms. Meile said, much of the elation in Chicago's large Lithuanian community had cooled to concern, as the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, struck a stern note, calling Lithuania's declaration of independence ''illegitimate and invalid.'' The concerns of Chicago's Lithuanians were echoed in several of the country's other Lithuanian communities.
Ms. Meile, a spokeswoman for the American Lithuanian Council, a group founded in 1940 to seek Lithuania's independence, said many Lithuanian-Americans were begining to realize that there would probably be difficult times ahead for their motherland.
 
'Not Going to Be Easy'
''We've begun to sense that it is not going to be easy,'' Ms. Meile said. ''We do not doubt that it will happen. But it's going to take years of negotiating with the Soviet Union - hopefully negotiating.''
''More than anything, I think people are worried about the possibility of economic sanctions,'' she said, adding that almost all of Lithuania's electricity, gas and coal in Lithuania comes from the Soviet Union. ''To cut that off would be really a hardship.''
The nationalist spirit that has motivated Lithuania to be the first among the states of the Soviet Union to declare independence has been nurtured by a number of factors, experts on Baltic affairs say. Among them are a homogenous population, a strong Roman Catholic faith and a long history of rebellion against foreign rule.
''In the 19th century under the oppression of the czars, Lithuanians were not even allowed to speak their own language,'' said Asta Banionis, the director of governmental affairs for the Lithuanian-American Community Inc., a group that seeks to foster and maintain Lithuania's heritage and culture. ''There developed a whole underground for books.''
 
Differences With Baltic Neighbors
Others point to a number of distinctions between Lithuania and its Baltic neighbors to the north, Estonia and Latvia.
After 50 years of domination by the Soviet Union, both Estonia and Latvia now have large numbers of Russians and others of non-Baltic descent, who were attracted by industrialization and better living in the Baltics or sent there by Moscow, or both.
But Lithuania, with a population larger than that of its two Baltic neighbors, has a higher percentage of people of Lithuanian descent - about 80 percent, compared with a population about 60 percent Estonian in Estonia and around 50 percent Latvian in Latvia.
Also, the Catholic church also never lost its grip on the population, experts say. It operated in secret for years, providing a framework for rebellion.
 
Church 'Gave Them Strength'
''It gave, throughout, a structure and a moral basis to hold together some sort of political alienation,'' said Martha Olcott, a professor at Colgate University who is an expert on the region. ''The church is part of their lives; they maintained secret churches. It gave them strength.''
Some Lithuanian-Americans expressed disappointment with the Bush Administration, saying they wished the President would take a more aggressive stance in the matter.
In the East New York section of Brooklyn yesterday, Cornelius Bucnys, the editor of a Lithuanian-language weekly, Darbininkas, was preparing today's issue. In it he calls for Lithuanian-Americans to write to Congress and to President Bush, urging that they strongly support Lithuanian independence.

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East;
Cash-Starved Parties Introduce Voters in Hungary to the Fund-Raiser

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUDAPEST, March 11

 BODY:
Democracy has its price, as Hungary's new political parties are learning now that they must pay the bill for the posters, leaflets, 30-second television spots, lapel pins, cigarette lighters, helicopters, hot-air balloons and other props of this country's first full-fledged electoral campaign in 40 years.
To come up with money to get their message across, the parties are looking for help at home and abroad to supplement the fixed sum they get from the Government. Like-minded foreign political parties have been tapped for contributions in cash and in kind, and Hungary's aspiring entrepreneurial class is being wooed from all sides.
But fund-raising, in the style that Americans are used to, is still an undeveloped art in Hungary. ''It doesn't work here,'' said Anna Petrosovits, president of the Social Democratic Party of Hungary. ''We tried to invite people to coffees and teas, but there was no - how shall I put it - outcome.'' 
The Alliance for Free Democrats recently sent an invitation to foreign entrepreneurs in Budapest, written in English in gold letters, for a ''fund-raiser art exhibition and champagne reception.'' Several dozen business people showed up and joined in a vigorous discussion about Hungary's economic future, but few made any move toward the clear plastic contribution box.
''This wasn't really a fund-raiser,'' said Tibor Vidos, executive director of the Free Democrats, ''because we haven't raised any funds.''
 
Too Direct an Approach
Like door-to-door campaigning, asking people for money is simply not done at this stage of Hungarian democracy. In both cases, the approach is too direct and too intrusive and would rub people the wrong way, political strategists say.
So the parties resort to more indirect methods - like a series of balls sponsored by the Hungarian Democratic Forum, described as modest but elegant by one leader. After expenses, the balls brought in about 30,000 forints, or $5,000 at the official exchange rate, according to Attila Kollar, the party's general accountant.
''You have to handle these things very carefully,'' Mr. Kollar said. ''Hungary is still a poor country, and we don't have these traditions. Even spending too much money on posters can cause disapproval among the silent majority.''
As negotiated between the departing Communist Government and the opposition parties, Hungarian electoral law does not require the parties to report where they get their money or how they spend it until 30 days after the elections. Contributors of more than 50,000 forints have to be identified, and the only prohibition is against donations from foreign governments and state-owned companies.
The opposition parties say they deliberately left the door open for contributions from foreign political parties as a way to counterbalance the weight and wealth of the ruling Socialist Party, as the majority wing of the former Communist Party is now called. For the same reason, they mostly decline to say exactly how much they have received, saying it would only lay them open to political accusations.
 
Rumors Fill the Void
In the absence of hard information, rumors have filled the void, rumors so widespread that spokesmen for several parties denied them, even before they were asked. Thus, the Free Democrats said they had not received any help from the Soros Foundation, headed by the New York financier George Soros, and the Social Democrats scoffed at reports that they had received $4 million from the Socialist International.
But the Social Democrats confirm that they do receive considerable help from Western European social democratic parties. The Democratic Forum said it had received money and equipment from Christian Democratic parties from West Germany and elsewhere, while the Free Democrats said a significant sum had been contributed by the West German Free Democrats.
Most of the parties complain that they have had to raise their budgets sharply since the campaign got under way. The estimated costs range from $500,000 for the Democratic Forum to $1 million for the Social Democrats. Almost every party said that to meet its goal, it had to take out a loan.
To people's amazement, combined with bemusement, even the Socialist Party, which after 40 years in power has considerable institutional holdings, is claiming poverty. At a news conference last week, the president of the party, Rezso Nyers, said it had to take out a loan to pay for its campaign. While he would not say how much, he commented acidly that it was ''no more than what the Free Democrats get from abroad.'' A party spokesman later said the campaign budget was close to $833,000.
 
TV Time Is Limited
Because of a rule limiting paid political advertising on television to six minutes a day - distributed in 30-second spots to the 12 national parties -television time does not consume the money here that it does in the West. The cost of 30 seconds on the two state-controlled channels ranges from $1,000 to $20,000, depending on the time slots, which are distributed by lot.
Since no one party can mount a television blitz, the competition for the voters' attention is taking place elsewhere, with each party staking out its speciality. The Social Democrats are planning to drop leaflets from helicopters.
The Democratic Forum has a balloon it uses above provincial cities. The Socialists have a near-monopoly on Budapest's lampposts with thousands of banners, hung by a Spanish-Hungarian joint venture at a cost of $50 apiece.
The most graphically striking poster of the campaign is one distributed by the Democratic Forum, a mock film poster for ''Comrades,'' showing a Soviet officer, his beefy neck viewed from the back, with the words, ''The End'' written at the top in Russian.

HEADLINE: Fiscal Fire in New York

 BODY:
New York State has fallen into serious financial trouble. Gov. Mario Cuomo's proposed budget, just two months old, is already way out of balance. The outlook is so bad that the bond rating agencies have sounded the alarm. There's a fiscal fire. Where are the firefighters? 
Edward Regan, a Republican and the State Comptroller, says the budget gap has grown to $1.5 billion in just two months. Yet Mr. Cuomo has not come up with a plan to close that gap. Only he has the standing and strength to galvanize support for what have to be tough decisions. He is the Governor. The question reverberates: Where is the Governor?
The Senate Republicans, led by Ralph Marino of Long Island, continue to ignore reality in the face of Mr. Regan's credible findings. Assembly leader Mel Miller, a Democrat, recognizes the grave reality but lacks the political leverage of a governor. If Mr. Cuomo means to put the state back on a sound fiscal footing, he'll have to reach out to the public and the business community fast. The new budget should be in place in 17 days.
An economic slump now deprives New York and other Northeastern states of anticipated tax revenues. States cannot control such profound economic trends but they do control how they react to economic swings. Years of sloppy fiscal management in Albany mean a downturn can quickly become a crisis.
The state has consistently overestimated revenues. It has cut taxes without restraining spending. It has operated at a deficit and doesn't hesitate to roll debt from one year into the next. It has allowed short-term borrowing to mushroom to an all-time high of nearly $5 billion. And Mr. Cuomo's budgets, with the Legislature's concurrence, have relied too heavily on one-shot revenues and raids on the reserves of authorities and trust funds.
Now, with the economy slowing, the state is running out of options. Mr. Cuomo's January budget proposed a package of new fees and taxes, some spending cuts and increases. He urges holding off the next phase of the personal income tax cut, which could add about $400 million in revenue next year, and more than $1.5 billion the year after that. With remarkable irresponsibility, Senate Republicans continue to balk, but even if they ultimately agree, the budget will be out of balance because of the revenue shortfall.
Mr. Cuomo and the Legislature will ultimately balance the budget on paper. If recent history is any guide, they will probably come up with a patchwork of cuts and taxes for 1991 that will leave the structural problems to bite again in 1992. The most solid proposal - increasing the state's 8-cent-a-gallon gasoline tax - would provide a much-needed revenue stream.
But the state needs fiscal reform as well.
A comprehensive plan for reform would include adoption of the same strict budget procedures the state long ago imposed on New York City. The state has to reduce short-term borrowing, eliminate the accumulated deficit and reduce the cost of state spending, which has grown 80 percent during Mr. Cuomo's tenure. Its costly Medicaid program needs examination, as does education spending, up 84 percent in seven years.
''We need more discipline,'' the Governor acknowledged when he proposed his budget. ''Everybody knows it. This is an opportunity to develop that strength.'' Right, and what the state needs now is a leader who will do just that.

LENGTH: 791 words

HEADLINE: Single-Room Housing Won't End Homelessness

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In ''The Homelessness Test'' (editorial, March 1), you recognize that the loss in single room occupancy housing, or S.R.O.'s, has had a serious effect on the numbers of people living on the streets and in shelters. Mental health research on the homeless confirms that this housing shortage is more critical than ''deinstitutionalization'' and other mental health problems among the homeless.
Unfortunately, you assume that most of the homeless are mentally ill or older people who once lived in S.R.O. housing. You argue that the mentally ill homeless were deinstitutionalized, moved into S.R.O. housing, and when this housing was transferred to other uses, they and many other S.R.O. residents became homeless - a plausible sequence. However, my own research, and data from surveys of the homeless across the nation, suggest that for most of the homeless the sequence of events has been very different. 
Most of the homeless are young adults, under age 45. Most have never lived in S.R.O. housing. Fewer than 15 percent have been hospitalized for mental disorders. And more than half the homeless population is homeless for less than six months.
You dismiss the causal role of deinstitutionalization in the 1960's and 70's because of its distance in time from the increasing homeless population of the 80's, but you fail to recognize that much of the loss in S.R.O. housing also took place before the 1980's. Though some people undoubtedly became homeless because of S.R.O. conversions - a deed that should be redressed - the evidence does not suggest the loss of S.R.O.'s as a widespread, direct source of homelessness. The real impact of lost S.R.O.'s on homelessness is that when a new segment of people became residentially unstable in the 1980's, they did not have this stock of cheap rooms to fall back on. What might have been hidden in the old problem of skid row homelessness became a new problem of emergency shelter homelessness.
That most of the homeless are young adults, not mentally ill and have never lived in S.R.O. housing suggests wider causes of the homeless problem and more ambitious solutions than increasing the number of S.R.O. units. Poor, urban, young adults have seen two decades in which growth industries have favored better educated suburban populations and where the jobs available to unskilled workers have paid wages that have steadily declined against inflation (the value of the minimum wage declined 31 percent between 1980 and 1988).
Across the country, people who rely on public assistance have likewise seen the value of benefits deteriorate against inflation, nearly 50 percent since the early 1970's. Compounding declines in income among young, urban adults has been a sharp rise in the cost of housing. S.R.O.'s have disappeared, and standard rental apartments consume nearly 65 percent of the average poor household's income. This dramatic combination of forces pushed a new generation into residential instability and, ultimately, homelessness. Given the intense competition for resources in impoverished communities, it is no surprise that the disabled, the defiant and the deviant were the first and most likely to be squeezed out or forced to choose out.
How can we best understand this new group of people from whom the majority of the homeless comes? They are people who cannot afford to form new households. They are adults who are not settling new families or living in their own apartments at the rate their parents did.
While more S.R.O.'s would provide an option for them, do we want to institutionalize a new skid row? More important, is that what most homeless people want? Before the boom in emergency shelters in the 1980's, residents of S.R.O.'s used to be considered ''homeless.''
What really needs to be addressed is the marginal housing and income status of a generation of young and poor adults. The homeless represent a small segment of a much larger problem of poverty and restricted opportunity reflected in the rapid turnover of the homeless population, in the increase in urban crime, in prison overcrowding and in the countless victims of the drug economy.
S.R.O.'s might be the solution for some people, including the older and disabled homeless, but many others, including the masses of near-homeless (and soon-to-be-homeless), await a more imaginative solution that gives them a chance at stable household formation, adequately compensated labor, social protection from disability and unemployment, and that supports more diverse and mixed household arrangements than is represented in the proposed S.R.O. solution.
 
DENNIS P. CULHANE
Needham, Mass., March 1, 1990
 The writer has completed a doctoral dissertation on homelessness.

HEADLINE: School Boards Said to Pad Their Payrolls

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
Two Brooklyn school superintendents said yesterday that their school boards had hired a total of 150 unneeded people to patrol cafeterias and perform clerical chores at a cost of almost $2 million a year.
The revelations, made at a news conference called by the Joint Commission on Integrity in the Public Schools, lent support to the contention of the commission's chairman, James F. Gill, that many of the city's public schools are ''patronage troughs'' for political leaders and aspiring politicians.
Commission officials said later that perhaps half of the city's 32 elected school boards were hiring people for unneeded jobs to enhance their members' political support. In the process they are squandering many millions of dollars, the officials said. 
 
'Vulnerable to Corruption'
The commission's findings were bolstered yesterday afternoon when Michael P. Sofarelli, the Board of Education's Inspector General, issued a report describing the practice of hiring paraprofessionals and school aides as ''peculiarly vulnerable to corruption.''
The personnel officers who do most of the hiring, he said, serve at the pleasure of the boards and are subject to ''undue pressure'' to hire ''based on political considerations.'' The districts are spending $110 million a year for such positions, he said.
Mr. Gill said the new disclosures suggested that the state's decentralization law, which gives 32 local boards authority over elementary and junior high schools, ''needs a lot of repair work.'' In part, he blamed the inspector general's office, which investigates improper acts by school employees. It ''does not enjoy the confidence of people in the system,'' he said, suggesting that it be replaced by an entity outside the jurisdiction of the Board of Education.
At the news conference, both Brooklyn superintendents - Levander Lilly of District 19 in East New York and Marco Hernandez of District 32 in Bushwick - said they had sought to dismiss unneeded school aides who were hired before they took office. Board members, they said, threatened not to renew their contracts or to block their budgets and programs.
Mr. Lilly wore a concealed tape recorder for the commission to record conversations with board members, but commission officials said he was not able to obtain any evidence to corroborate his own statements. The officials speculated that the board members had been alerted by news accounts of previous use by the commission of a tape recorder and were cautious in what they said.
Nevertheless, Mr. Gill said, testimony provided in closed commission sessions by Mr. Lilly and Mr. Hernandez has been turned over to the Brooklyn district attorney's office.
 
Reward 'If I Played Ball'
''I was told by these board members,'' Mr. Lilly said, ''that if I played ball and did certain things they would like me to do, I would have no problem with my contract.''
He said that fewer than 100 of the 189 school aides in his district were needed. ''Anybody who wanted a job could walk in and get a job,'' he said. But when he protested to board members, he said, he was told, ''These are community people, and they deserve to work.''
Mr. Lilly said the board members seemed exclusively concerned with jobs they could parcel out and trips to conferences that they could take at public expense.
''The board has not mentioned children and education and what's good for children five times since I have been there,'' he said.
 
Threats 'to Get Me Out' Cited
Mr. Hernandez told a similar story. Half of his district's 120 school aides, he said, serve no legitimate purpose and should be dismissed. But he had difficulty trying to do this, he said.
''I was confronted by board members who have single-handedly told me, because I do not comply with their political ambitions and protect them, they will get me out of the superintendency,'' Mr. Hernandez said.
Both Mr. Lilly and Mr. Hernandez, superintendents since 1987, have been told that their contracts will not be renewed after June 30.
Last October the Gill commission presented dramatic conversations taped by Colman Genn, the superintendent of District 27 in Queens, suggesting that school board members were hiring firends and supporters as paraprofessionals and school aides. Yesterday's news conference, Mr. Gill said, was called to demonstrate that Mr. Genn's testimony was ''not an isolated case.''
 
'Without Reference to Merit'
''Hiring is being done without reference to merit, without reference to education, and you have nepotism and cronyism running rampant,'' Mr. Gill said.
The 13,000 paraprofessionals in the city's schools, who must have high school diplomas, assist teachers in classrooms and are paid up to $16,520 a year. The 6,000 school aides, who do not need high school diplomas, are paid $8.15 an hour for patrolling cafeterias, watching doorways and filing records. The Gill Commission said aides are paid an average of $12,000 a year.
Corinna Grant, president of the Community School Board 19, could not be reached last night for comment, but in past interviews she has denied that any hiring in the district is politically motivated. Repeated calls were made to John A. Battaglia, president of School Board 32, but he could not be reached.
Tito Velez, a member of School Board 31 and former chairman, said last night that Mr. Hernandez's comments were ''not true.'' Seven of the board's nine members were newly elected last July 1, he said, and Mr. Hernandez ''never recommended that we fire any school aides.''
Mr. Velez said Mr. Hernandez's contract was not being renewed because he had ''run up a deficit of $600,000 in the fiscal year that ended July 30.'' In the past, he said, the district either had a surplus or a deficit of no more than $100,000.
Edward Handman, a spokesman for District Council 37, the union that represents the school aides, said, ''The problem with the schools can hardly be laid at the feet of $8-an-hour part-time workers.''
 
'It Is Sinful'
Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez was briefed by Mr. Gill yesterday afternoon about the revelations and said that ''in the current economic climate, it is sinful'' to pad payrolls.
Yesterday's allegations of wasteful hiring were not confined to jobs as school aides. In an interview, Mr. Lilly said that to get his budget passed, he was forced to create four community coordinator positions each paying $40,000 a year. Three of the jobs, he said, were not needed.
He tried to insulate the appointments from politics, he said, but school board members went ''behind my back'' and pressured district officials to hire friends of board members.

HEADLINE: EDUCATION: About Education

BYLINE: By Fred M. Hechinger

 BODY:
Even more tragic than the fate of students who drop out of school is that of half a million children who drop in irregularly or not at all. They are not truants; they may not lack the desire to learn. What they lack is a home from which to register as regulars for school.
The children of the homeless, often shunted from one shelter or school district to another, are in danger of being lost to education. 
Fortunately, some educators make it their business to seek these children out, then try to make them comfortable in school and to make school a substitute home.
Terrence Quinn, principal of Public School 225 in Rockaway, Queens, kept a diary about his work with homeless children, which was published in The Executive Educator, a magazine of the National School Boards Association.
In an interview, he said that last year some 50 of his students came from a squalid shelter hotel. They were not the same 50 each month because the hotels have a maximum stay of 28 days, adding to the instability of the children's lives. This year, he said, the number has declined as permanent housing has been provided for some families. But whatever the numbers, the youngsters that Mr. Quinn tries to serve come from families who, he said, have ''fallen off the economic ladder'' and for whom ''the school is the only place that offers warmth, stability and hope.''
Mr. Quinn and some other principals have established after-school programs for homeless children. These youngsters are given a supply kit that includes a clock, calculator, pens, notebooks and other supplies.
They receive special tutoring, a daily snack and instruction in the arts, crafts and athletics. They can eat, play and do their homework at school until dark. Two nonprofit groups - the Studio in the School Association and the New York City School Volunteers - provide these and other services. Teachers and paraprofessionals help with homework and provide computer instruction. Mr. Quinn wants to see the centers expanded to accept all children who want to come.
He and some colleagues in other schools have learned that getting homeless children to come to school is not a matter of just opening the doors. ''They don't come out on their own as much as we'd like,'' he said. ''There is a shyness. We have to go to them. And there has to be a bus service to bring the children to school.''
He and the school's social worker went out to the Rockaway Park hotel and invited parents to a breakfast in the hotel lobby - the only available social space. About 20 mothers appeared at the first breakfast, and, said Mr. Quinn, they were ''decent, down-to-earth folks who truly care and want more for their children than a single 10-foot-by-12-foot room.''
The cards are stacked against homeless children: they have no quiet place to study or to rest; they don't know where their next shelter will be; they are surrounded by drugs and often by violence. Still, Mr. Quinn noted, there are some rewards for those who refuse to give up. He tells of one youngster from a shelter who was chosen to deliver the valedictory address at her graduation.
Donna Harrington-Lueker, an associate editor of The Executive Educator, said, ''Terrence Quinn isn't the only school executive who walks the corridors of a welfare hotel.''
''All over the United States,'' she said, ''scrappy educators and advocates for the homeless are teaming up to address the educational needs of the some 500,000 youngsters for whom home is a cardboard box, a welfare hotel, a car, or a concrete slab underneath an overpass.''
She quoted a study by the United States Conference of Mayors showing that families with children make up 34 percent of the country's homeless. As many as 43 percent of the homeless children, it is estimated, do not attend school regularly.
The Stewart B. McKinney Homeless Assistance Act of 1987 requires that homeless children be given the same schooling as other youngsters, including special programs when needed. But implementation has been spotty and slow, with the bulk of financing left to states and local districts to provide.
Mr. Quinn worries about the schooling of all poor children, not just those who are homeless. He is raising money to send 30 to 50 youngsters to summer camp. He is proud of Project Giant Step, which helps 3- and 4-year-olds attend school for half a day.
Mr. Quinn, 42 years old and a principal for five years, said, ''I'm blessed.'' He celebrates his work in ''beautiful downtown Rockaway with an ocean view'' and takes his inspiration from the old advice to light a candle instead of cursing the darkness.

SECTION: Section B; Page 9, Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 1053 words

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
An Insider Looks, Optimistically, at the University

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
Henry Rosovsky is that unfashionable thing these days: an optimist about higher education.
The university's critics are legion. They denounce tuitions that soar above the inflation rate, courses that either neglect Western intellectual traditions or exclude non-Western cultures, and a tenure system that allows professors to spend too much time off campus.
Mr. Rosovsky, the former dean of Harvard University's faculty of arts and sciences, who is now a senior professor, disagrees. He makes his case in a down-to-earth, provocative book, ''The University: An Owner's Manual,'' published this year by W. W. Norton & Company. 
Many groups believe they ''own'' the university - alumni, students, faculty, administrators. His book will probably anger some of them, as he is well aware. ''I have the sense,'' he writes at the outset, ''that every group will approve what is said about others.'' Is Nostalgia Misplaced? Mr. Rosovsky argues that many of the current debates about higher education stem from a misplaced nostalgia for a time when it might have seemed possible to define a common learning and heritage.
''Forty years ago, there may have been more of a common denominator for people,'' he said. ''Universities were generally white and male. There were very few blacks. Jews were carefully controlled. In those circumstances, it was easier to achieve a consensus. But most institutions I know are far better today than they were 40 years ago.''
His book eschews ideology, as befits a man who proudly labels himself a pragmatist and whom Joseph S. Nye Jr., a Harvard professor of Government, calls ''conservative with a small c.'' Like the man, the book is practical but also idealistic, focusing on the issues Mr. Rosovsky considers crucial for the future of the research university: recruiting top-notch faculty and breeding a new generation of scholars. And it is opinionated, with flashes of sarcasm directed at those who strike him as shrill, self-important or unreasonable.
He tells undergraduates that they are not at the center of a university, as they might be at a small college. But he tells them they can benefit from the university anyway because their teachers, if sometimes remote, are breaking new scholarly ground. He describes professors' enviable freedom and perquisites, but warns that they cheat students and the university if they schedule too much outside consulting and too little teaching.
 
Danger in Democracy
He holds that in running a university, more democracy is not always best - a position that has already prompted accusations of elitism, arrogance and excessive devotion to the status quo.
''The people who say universities have not changed enough - what they mean to say is, 'The change I want hasn't taken place,' '' he said. ''I think a school is a place where people who have more knowledge should have more voice.
''I would give students a great deal of latitude in governing their own lives. But in academic things, I feel too much democracy led to disaster. In Europe, Japan, Korea, you get all sorts of parity structures, and they paralyze universities. Our structure is why the American university has been able to change more creatively than universities elsewhere in the world.''
Mr. Rosovsky's 11-year tenure as dean, from 1973 to 1984, was a time of relative political quiescence. Rather than cope with students occupying university buildings and professors dividing into hostile camps, he devoted his energies to bringing the university's budget under control and negotiating Harvard's biggest curricular overhaul in decades, the Core Curriculum.
 
The Lines Are Drawn
The Core does not require certain courses or books, but exposure to the differences in the way scholars in different fields think.
Curricular debates continue to rage at American universities, with lines drawn between those who want a common curriculum based on Western thought to those who see the traditional curriculum as racist and exclusive and would require students to learn about non-European traditions. While Mr. Rosovsky says he does not think Harvard's course should be a model, he thinks it neatly sidesteps these issues.
''The curriculum committee was struck with the rapid growth of knowledge,'' he said. ''The idea was training minds in modes of thought and critical thinking. Given the diversity of the Harvard student body and faculty, the 'Great Books' format is too confining. And with all these ridiculous debates about Western, non-Western - we had none of that, because for us, who could question the need for a foreign culture requirement?''
Mr. Rosovsky acknowledges that some will see his views as too positive. A day of conversations with students and junior faculty at Harvard, in fact, turned up familiar and persistent complaints - student isolation from senior professors busy with their own research and government or business commitments, alienation of assistant professors who know their chances of tenure are slim, overworked graduate students uncertain of the rewards of scholarship, the dearth of women and minority teachers on Harvard's faculty, disputes about Harvard's South African holdings.
 
'This Is the Real World'
''The university is not a little paradise, a Shangri-La,'' Mr. Rosovsky said. ''This is the real world. Everything that happens in society happens here.''
While Mr. Rosovsky believes that students exaggerate professors' inaccessiblity, he does think senior professors should teach more undergraduates, while younger teachers concentrate on graduate students. Junior faculty should get more time for the research that determines their futures. Isolated graduate students should be able to find sympathetic faculty mentors.
True to his calling as an economist, Mr. Rosovsky proposes incentives -exactly what they should be he is still considering - to help persuade tenured professors to spend more time on campus and on teaching.
But Mr. Rosovsky continues to believe that some of the criticisms stem from unrealistic expectations of the university. ''A lot of these exaggerated expectations is society passing the buck,'' he said. ''We teach, we do research. Don't think of us as being the principal institution of social change. Our capacity to raise questions is far better than to answer them.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Henry Rosovsky, a senior professor at Harvard University, who has written a provocative book, ''The University: An Owner's Manual.'' (NYT/Rick Friedman)

HEADLINE: EATING WELL;
Nutrition Labeling: To Be or Not to Be?

BYLINE: By MARIAN BURROS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12

 BODY:
Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter appears to be out of step with the rest of the Bush Administration on mandatory nutrition labeling. The day after the Secretary of Health and Human Services, Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, announced the Administration's proposals to require labeling on most packaged foods, Mr. Yeutter told the same audience that such regulations might be just another example of ''the heavy hand of government in the activities of Americans.''
Mr. Yeutter, speaking to the National Food Policy Conference here, said the Agriculture Department didn't necessarily disagree that packaged foods should carry nutrition information. But he said the nation might be moving the wrong way.
''When we have a lot of people in Eastern Europe trying to throw off the yoke of central government,'' he said, this might not be the moment for the Government to become more centralized. ''How much government do you want?'' he asked. 
Where food labeling is concerned, consumers seem to answer, ''More.'' In a nationwide telephone survey of 1,006 households, conducted for the National Food Processors Association, 83 percent of the respondents said ingredient and nutrition information had ''a great deal'' or ''some'' influence on what they purchased.
Asked to choose among five kinds of nutrition labels, they overwhelmingly chose one with more information on key nutrients than labels now carry, and more about daily dietary recommendations. The margin of error for the survey, conducted in September by the Opinion Research Corporation of Princeton, N.J., was plus or minus three percentage points.
The proposals would make label information more uniform, closer to the truth and more useful. The changes described by Dr. Sullivan would apply only to products that the Food and Drug Administration is responsible for; everything, that is, but meat and poultry, which are under the Agriculture Department.
Mr. Yeutter's statements reflect rivalries between the F.D.A. and the Agriculture Department over food regulations and offer a glimpse of how politics affects the food supply.
Even the food industry, which has opposed mandatory nutrition labeling as too expensive and too complicated, has now endorsed such labeling as long as Federal law pre-empts state law. And bills in both houses of Congress are similar in most ways to the proposal outlined by Dr. Sullivan.
Last Thursday Dr. Sullivan announced that the F.D.A. would make big changes in food labeling. He said it would publish proposals by midyear on mandatory labeling and on revisions in nutrition labeling. There will be a final proposal on health messages by next year, he said.
Many labels now list calories, protein, carbohydrates, fat, protein and certain vitamins and minerals, but the labeling has been voluntary since it began in 1973. Two exceptions exist: if a nutritional claim is made for a product or if it contains added vitamins or minerals, it must carry a nutrition label. About 60 percent of the processed food under F.D.A. jurisdiction lists nutrition information.
Under the F.D.A. proposals and bills that are expected to be reported out of committee to both houses of Congress within two months, the labels not only would be mandatory but would show the amount of saturated and unsaturated fat, not just total fat, and cholesterol, fiber, sodium and potassium. In F.D.A. hearings last year and in the survey for the food processors, consumers indicated a keen interest in such information.
The F.D.A has also proposed that B vitamins not be listed or that they be made optional because concerns about disease from nutritional deficiences have declined. But the survey for the food processors found that consumers did not want any information deleted.
The revised regulations would also set standards for terms like ''high fiber,'' ''no cholesterol'' and ''low cholesterol.'' Manufacturers can now call a product ''high fiber'' whether it has four grams in a serving or eight.
''The problem is all those snappy slogans don't mean a damn thing,'' Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio, said on Thursday at the conference. ''For more than 10 years F.D.A. has been trying to come up with a definition of 'low cholesterol.' '' He is sponsoring a bill to bar use of ''no cholesterol,'' which frequently appears on food packages, if a product is high in saturated fat.
''People ought to be secure in the knowledge that a boldface health claim on the front label won't be contradicted by the fine print on the back panel,'' the Senator said. Like dietary cholesterol, saturated fat can raise blood cholesterol.
The regulations and bills would also require uniformity in the serving sizes for which nutrition information is given. Many food companies have simply listed more servings without making the package bigger, to make it appear, for instance, that there are fewer calories or grams of sodium per serving. One company's 10-ounce can of soup, for example, once provided two servings, then two and a half, and now two and three-quarters.
In its hearings the F.D.A. also learned that consumers didn't like ''either/or'' labeling, which permits the manufacturer to use the cheapest available oil (for example, a label can presently say, ''contains corn oil and/or sunflower oil and/or coconut oil''). Certain fats, like corn and sunflower oil, are unsaturated; others, like coconut and palm oil, are highly saturated. People who want less saturated fat and those who are allergic to a food, like corn, want to know what the ingredients are, not what they might be.
The F.D.A. said the industry wanted to retain the current system for economic reasons. The agency has suggested a plan to get around the issue; it would require the label to list the amount of saturated and unsaturated fat, preventing manufacturers from changing the ratio of fats unless they revise the label.
The F.D.A. also wants to allow more flexibility in the labeling of more healthful foods, so that, for example, a cheese made with less fat than a standard cheese could be called low-fat cheese instead of cheese substitute.
The thorniest matter - health messages - is addressed in all the proposals. The Administration and Congress agree that labels claiming a health benefit should be honest and supported by scientific evidence. But how to attain that goal is elusive. The F.D.A. is proposing that health claims be permitted in six areas: fiber and cancer; fiber and heart disease; fats and cancer; fats and heart disease; sodium and high blood pressure; calcium and osteoporosis.
In commenting on health labeling, the Acting F.D.A. Commissioner, James S. Benson, said that one criterion would be ''whether the good attributes of the food outweigh the bad.'' But the difficulty of determining that was evident in his response to a question from a reporter about whether a health claim would be allowed for the calcium in whole milk, which is high in fat. He said he couldn't answer.
The F.D.A. said it would also consider a new format for the nutrition information, to make it easy to compare the nutritional profile of a serving with the United States Recommended Daily Allowance. The survey for the food processors found that consumers wanted to be able to make that comparison quickly and easily.
Dr. Sullivan said he expected speedy action on the F.D.A.'s proposals, but others were less confident. Ellen Haas, the executive director of Public Voice for Food and Health Policy, a consumer group in Washington that co-sponsored the conference last week with the food processors, said the agency had been working on nutrition labeling regulations for 10 years. ''The Secretary should be announcing at this point what the agency is doing, not what they are proposing,'' Ms. Haas said. ''This is deja vu all over again.''
While the F.D.A. has the authority to make such regulations, consumer advocates and health professionals maintain that legislation would push the agency to speed the process.
The Congressional and Administration plans differ on one significant point. The Congressional proposals would keep states from enforcing different standards for labeling, which is the industry's preference, too.
''We would accept mandatory labeling, provided there is strong Federal pre-emption,'' said Roger Coleman, speaking for the National Food Processors Association. ''We don't want a bunch of state regulations.''
The Agriculture Secretary is also in favor of Federal pre-emption, but Dr. Sullivan said that under the Adminstration's proposal ''states would be able to add to the information required, but they will not be able to subtract from the bedrock information mandated by the regulation.''
All the work that has gone into the labeling bills and proposals could go up in smoke over pre-emption. Senator Metzenbaum's legislative assistant, Joel Johnson, said that when the food labeling bill goes to the Senate, an effort will be made to amend it to pre-empt state laws regulating the use of pesticides. Because environmental groups oppose such an amendment, some Senators who would otherwise vote for the nutrition bill might not.
So despite a basic agreement among the public, producers, Congress and the Administration that better nutritional labeling is needed, the matter of Federal pre-emption may undo the nutrition-labeling proposals of 1990.
 
What Labels Might Say
IF the sweeping changes recommended by the Food and Drug Administration and by legislation that is making its way through Congress become law, the labels that shoppers find on food will be very different. But no changes are likely for at least two years. Here are some of the proposals:
Mandatory Labels: Just about every packaged food under the jurisdiction of the F.D.A. - that is, everything but meat and poultry -would carry nutrition labeling. The following information now printed on some labels would be retained: serving size; the number of servings in the container; the calories, protein, carbohydrates and fat in a serving, and the percentage of the Federal Recommended Daily Allowances for vitamins A and C and calcium and iron. The percentage of protein, thiamine, riboflavin and niacin would either be deleted or become optional.
New Data: The new information would include the amount of saturated and unsaturated fat, fiber, cholesterol, calories from fat, sodium and perhaps potassium. Serving sizes would be standardized. A nutritional profile of the product might be included: the amount of calories, fat, saturated fat, cholesterol and sodium in a serving, compared with the Recommended Daily Allowances.
Labels might have to show the percentage of key ingredients.
Terminology: Definitions would be required for terms like ''low fat'' and ''high fiber.'' Products with reduced amounts of fat might be allowed to describe themselves as ''low fat'' rather than ''substitute'' or some fanciful name.
All sugars in a product might be grouped together, rather than being included among the ingredients listed in order of predominance.
Health Benefits: Regulations would say how and when health benefits could be cited on labels.

HEADLINE: Bonn Sets Mark Rate On Savings

BYLINE: By FERDINAND PROTZMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WEST BERLIN, March 13

 BODY:
Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany said today that East Germans would be able to exchange their personal savings at a one-to-one rate for West German marks, but that this rate would not apply to East German marks held by businesses or other institutions.
Though the plan has been mentioned before by Bonn officials, today was the first time Mr. Kohl has specifically said the rate would be one-to-one for savers. Coming five days before East Germany's first free elections on Sunday, Mr. Kohl's comments were clearly political in nature, intended to sway the large number of undecided East German voters toward the conservative Alliance for Germany and to slow the flow of East German emigrants to West Germany.
''We want savers to know that when the change in currency comes, it will be at one-to-one for them,'' Mr. Kohl said in a speech at a rally for conservative political parties held in Cottbus, a city in southern East Germany not far from the Polish border. 
 
'Crucial' Support
''This will be valid for small savers but not for the whole currency,'' Mr. Kohl added. ''It is crucial that those who deserve our support and solidarity should not be disadvantaged.''
The exchange-rate plan for establishing a single German currency is a crucial step in the economic unification of the two Germanys. Mr. Kohl did not say when or how currency union would be realized nor did he specify a rate for the billions of East German marks in circulation. He also did not address the dangers, such as sharp rises in inflation and interest rates, that many economists say a one-to-one rate carries.
Western financial markets focused on the inflationary potential of the one-to-one rate. In New York, Treasury bond prices dropped, based on the view that higher inflation in West Germany would push German interest rates higher, forcing up rates elsewhere. The dollar rose sharply against the German mark on Mr. Kohl's announcement, but then retreated somewhat when traders recognized that the rate would apply only to personal savings.
East German citizens are estimated to have about 170 billion East German marks in savings accounts. At a one-to-one exchange rate, that would be about $100 billion.
A less favorable rate would wipe out much of the financial wealth East Germans have accumulated over the years. At present, East Germany's currency is officially nonconvertible to other currencies, but it trades on the black market at a rate of four East marks to one Deutsche mark.
Shortly after the Berlin wall was opened in November, the rate soared to 20 to 1, but it has fallen sporadically since and the East German mark has gained strength recently from the speculation that savings would be converted at one-to-one.
The generous rate on savings is likely to be coupled with a severe curtailment of the financial benefits East Germans receive when they resettle in West Germany, according to Reuters news service. It said sources in Mr. Kohl's Christian Democratic Union are saying East German emigrants would receive only the unemployment pay and pensions they would get in East Germany, rather than the extensive financial assistance they currently receive.
 
Currency Panel Meets
The comments by Mr. Kohl came on the same day that an inter-German currency commission charged with mapping the route to rapid monetary union met in East Berlin.
Members of the commission would not give details of the meeting, saying only that considerable progress had been achieved. ''Currency and economic union can be rapidly accomplished given the required political will,'' a statement issued by the commission said. The talks will be resumed shortly after the East German elections, but not specific date has been released.

PUB-DATE: March 14, 1990

SECTION: Section D; Page 1, Column 6; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 992 words

HEADLINE: President Criticizes Deficit Plan

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13

 BODY:
President Bush took issue today with the main elements of Representative Dan Rostenkowski's plan for cutting the deficit, those that would raise taxes and lower Social Security benefits.
But at a news conference where he announced a proposal to give aid to Nicaragua, the President was careful to set a tone indicating that he saw the Rostenkowski plan as the basis for negotiations with Congress.
Democratic leaders in Congress applauded Mr. Rostenkowski's initiative. But, fearful of the political consequences, they said they could not endorse it until the President relaxed his firm opposition to new taxes. 
 
Too Early to Tell
It is too early to tell whether Mr. Rostenkowski's proposal, which embraces sizable tax increases and spending cuts over the next five years, is an important step toward breaking the longstanding political deadlock over the budget or merely another round in the shadow boxing that has dominated the relationship between President Bush and the Democratic Congress.
After saying at his news conference that he could not support a tax increase or a freeze in Social Security benefits, the President declared: ''I don't want to appear totally inflexible, but I'm not about to stand here and give him - give Dan or the Congress - the idea that I want to accept several of the things that are in his approach. But will I be willing to talk when they get all these proposals out there? Certainly. Are we prepared to negotiate? Absolutely.''
 
Source of Power
Mr. Rostenkowski, an Illinois Democrat, heads the Ways and Means Committee, which must initiate all legislation involving taxes and Social Security. That makes him perhaps the most powerful committee chairman in Congress.
But within his own party, he is something of a maverick with a history of working with Republican Presidents. The sweeping Tax Reform Act of 1986, the most important tax legislation in the last half-century, could not have been enacted had Mr. Rostenkowski not joined forces early on with Ronald Reagan.
Before going public with his budget proposal, Mr. Rostenkowski discussed it in general terms with the White House chief of staff, John H. Sununu, and the President's budget director, Richard G. Darman, Mr. Darman said today.
Last weekend, in an opinion article in The Washington Post and in a television interview, Mr. Rostenkowski described a comprehensive proposal that would reduce the budget deficit by $55 billion in the next fiscal year and lead to a surplus by 1995.
About 60 percent of the package would involve spending reductions, including slightly larger annual cuts than the President wants at the Pentagon, a one-year abolition of Social Security cost-of-living increases and a one-year freeze in spending for most other Government programs. The rest of the package involves tax increases, including higher income tax rates for the wealthy and an increase in the gasoline tax.
It was the first time in many years that an important politician had come forth with a budget plan that included the politically unpopular measures that many, if not most, economists believe are essential to bring the deficit under control.
The plan and the President's response to it left Democratic leaders uneasy. They fear that if they push the proposal, Mr. Bush will block it or veto it and then attack Democrats in an election year for wanting to raise taxes and cut retirement benefits. Mr. Bush gave no hint in his news conference that he would not attempt such a political maneuver.
The Speaker of the House, Representative Thomas S. Foley of Washington, said today that he found the President's response ''foggy'' and ''confusing.''
Mr. Foley has been saying for several years that a package like Mr. Rostenkowski's, with additional taxes and spending cuts, was the only way to achieve real budget reduction. But he said today, as he has many times before, that enactment of such a plan was ''politically and governmentally impossible without the prior approval of the President.''
Mr. Bush has an ''absolute veto,'' Mr. Foley added, and Democrats gain nothing by proceeding alone to try to raise taxes or reduce Social Security payments.
Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the Democratic majority leader, picked up on the prospect of a Presidential veto that could not be overridden after the Democrats had stuck out their political necks.
''The President has a pen that's worth two-thirds of us, and that's all you need to know,'' he told reporters.
Despite these reactions, the first buds of support for Mr. Rostenkowski from backbenchers began to bloom today. Representative Thomas J. Downey of Suffolk County, a Democrat on Mr. Rostenkowski's Ways and Means Committee, and Representative Jim Slattery of Kansas, a Democrat on the Budget Committee, were among several lawmakers who spoke on the floor of the House today in favor of the initiative.
 
Wake-Up Call
''It's about time this Congress had a wake-up call,'' Mr. Downey said.
A Republican member of the Ways and Means Committee, Representative Rod Chandler of Washington, urged Congress and the President to ''throw off the shackles of campaign rhetoric.''
And a senior member of the Ways and Means and Budget committees, Representative Bill Frenzel, a Republican from Minnesota, said in a speech in Minneapolis that he disagreed with aspects of the Rostenkowski proposal but added that ''today it's time to be thankful for leadership, even though it may be flawed.''
Most lawmakers kept their own counsel, and no one could measure yet the degree to which support in the cloakrooms might convert into votes on the floor.
Mr. Darman at his own news conference declared, ''Ultimately, serious deficit reduction has to be done on a bipartisan basis.''
But the budget director refused to give any political ground, saying the Administration was not inclined toward flexibility on either tax increases or Social Security cutbacks.

HEADLINE: Banks Shut By Brazil For 3 Days

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BRASILIA, March 13

 BODY:
Brazil's central bank closed the nation's banks late today for the rest of the week until an emergency economic package is announced by President-elect Fernando Collor de Mello.
The three-day bank holiday was decreed at the request of Zelia Cardoso de Mello, the nation's new Economic Minister, who is to take office on Thursday with the new President.
She said in a brief statement: ''The bank holiday was declared to preserve the stability of markets until the whole package of measures is announced. In the past few days, there has been a great deal of speculative activity and we wanted to calm the market down.'' 
 
Plan Is Awaited
Ms. Cardoso de Mello, no relation to the President-elect, offered no further information about the new economic proposals, which are expected to be announced when the President-elect addresses Congress on Friday morning.
The move took many citizens and economists by surprise because only a day earlier Ms. Cardoso de Mello had said, ''A bank holiday is absolutely not necessary.''
Analysts said the bank holiday was in response to large-scale withdrawals from the $60 billion that rolls over every day on the ''overnight'' -short-term deposits paying interest rates of up to 100 percent that the Government uses to finance its burdensome $31 billion public deficit.
Its public deficit contributes a large portion of Brazil's $114 billion foreign debt, which is the developing world's largest, followed by Mexico and Argentina. Most of its debt is owed to United States and European banks.
Investors, uneasy about Mr. Collor de Mello's economic plans, have used withdrawals from the ''overnight'' to speculate in gold and the illegal but widely tolerated black market for dollars, causing wild swings in their values in recent weeks.
 
Free Markets Promised
Mr. Collor de Mello, Brazil's first directly elected president in almost 30 years, has promised free-market economic reforms to try to bring down the debilitating inflation rate, which was 2,700 percent the last 12 months and 73 percent in February.
Bank holidays are not common in Brazil. The last was Jan. 15, 1989, when the Administration of Jose Sarney, the outgoing leader, decreed its fourth austerity package, popularly known as the ''Summer Plan,'' which froze wages and prices on basic goods. Both the President-elect and Ms. Cardoso de Mello have denied they will impose a freeze.
Mr. Collor de Mello's economic package is rumored to include privatization of state companies, layoffs of thousands of public employees and widescale spending cuts.
Business leaders have expressed concern about a possible wage-and-price freeze, the basis of four failed anti-inflationary plans by the outgoing Sarney Administration.
Brazil, with about 150 million residents, has been wracked for years by persistently high inflation that has caused labor unrest. Per-capita income in 1986, the latest figures available, was about $1,740, but real wages have declined for several years because of the high inflation.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene

BYLINE: By Peter Passell;
Social Security: Taxing Options

 BODY:
THE payroll tax increases of the last decade have hit lower- and middle-income families hardest, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan points out. If the tens of billions in surpluses piling up each year in the the Social Security trust fund are going to be used to paper over the current Federal deficit, he says, why not give working Americans a tax break?
One reason, which official Washington is cynical enough to believe but loath to admit, is that the payroll levy is the only tax without organized opposition. Every penny is needed to balance the budget - and balancing the budget on the backs of unsophisticated middle-income taxpayers may be better than not balancing the budget at all. 
A more surprising reason, documented last month in a little-noticed memorandum from the Congressional Budget Office, is that the tax cut Senator Moynihan wants would help the folks who fly first class even more than those who take the bus. And at least one of the proposed fixes, imposing a national sales tax to offset the revenue losses from the payroll tax reduction, would leave those at the bottom of the pecking order far worse off.
The average family's pretax income has risen 14 percent since 1977 in constant dollars, the Congressional Budget Office calculates. But families in the bottom two-fifths of the distribution, those with average incomes below $17,000, have actually lost ground as wages stagnated and social spending withered. And rather than cushioning the blow, changes in Federal taxes have actually added to their woes.
While the richest tenth of families have enjoyed an 8 percent cut in Federal tax rates since 1977, the poorest fifth have suffered a 3 percent increase. The second-poorest fifth - what might be labeled the struggling middle class - pay 7 percent higher rates.
The explanation is simple. Big income tax cuts in the early 1980's did not help lower-income families much because they did not pay much income tax in the first place. But everyone who works has been bludgeoned by increases in the payroll-based Social Security tax.
Senator Moynihan wants to reverse this drift toward income inequality by paring the combined employee-employer pension and disability tax to 10.2 percent from 12.4 percent. The catch, the budget office memo suggests, is that the benefits would not be accurately targeted to the neediest: All wage earners would end up with higher after-tax incomes, but a disproportionate share of the cash would go to the affluent.
The cut would raise after-tax incomes of families in the bottom fifth by an estimated 1.1 percent; the incomes of those in the next fifth would rise by 1.6 percent. Families in the next two-fifths would do even better, however, gaining 1.7 percent and 1.8 percent respectively.
The gain of the richest fifth would be proportionately smaller: just 1.2 percent. But since these families have far higher incomes - they take home an average of $82,000 - the dollar benefit would be $974 for each family, compared with just $360 for other Americans.
In any case, not everyone who favors the Moynihan rollback is prepared to accept the direct budgetary consequences. Senator Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina would make up the revenue loss, estimated at $63 billion in 1995, with a ''value added'' tax - economists' jargon for a national sales tax collected at each stage of production.
But value-added taxes are regressive, even if the basics of consumption - food, housing, utilities, education and medical bills - are exempted. The budget office estimates that substituting a value-added tax for the payroll tax would reduce the incomes of the poorest fifth of families by 2 percent while increasing the incomes of the richest fifth by one-tenth of 1 percent.
Offsetting a payroll tax cut with an across-the-board income tax surcharge would, by contrast, be progressive: Almost everyone's after-tax income would rise, the budget office concludes, save those in the richest fifth.
One has to wonder, though, whether such a tax shuffle is in the cards. The President's proposed budget for 1991 suggests that lip-readers in the White House are prepared to turn a blind eye to taxes called user fees. But they are not likely to play dumb for a revenue enhancer as obvious as a value-added tax or an income tax surcharge. And neither are the majority in Congress, who seem reluctant to fall on their political swords merely to put Washington's fiscal house in order.
All this sounds like a formula for stalemate: much pointing of fingers, leading nowhere. But the gods may yet decide to punish Senator Moynihan by granting him his wish. A lower payroll tax would only marginally help those in need. The resulting increase in the Federal deficit might well stop initiatives for wage, child care and education subsidies dead in their tracks.

HEADLINE: Bush Denies Greenspan Rift

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13

 BODY:
President Bush said today he was not at odds with Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and had never discussed the possiblity of not reappointing Mr. Greenspan when his term expires next year.
''Every President would like to see interest rates lower,''
Mr. Bush said at a news conference. 
''A President has to be concerned about inflation, too,'' Mr. Bush said, but added, ''There is no bubbling war with Alan Greenspan.''
 
Last week, The Los Angeles
Times reported that Mr. Bush was unlikely to ask Mr. Greenspan to stay on when the Fed chairman's term is up in 17 months. The report has drawn strong denials from officials at the White House and the Treasury. Today was the first time Mr. Bush addressed the matter in public.
Some Administration officials are known to be unhappy with the high interest rates the Fed is maintaining in its drive to keep the reins on inflation.
''I'm not in a Fed-bashing mode,'' Mr. Bush concluded. ''I think it's very sensitive in terms of markets and everything else even to go as far as I have done in trying to say very little and succeeding only moderately.''

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Decline 0.9% As Demand for Autos Slips

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13

 BODY:
Retail sales fell nine-tenths of a percent in February, their steepest fall in four months, the Government reported today.
But analysts said the decline was almost entirely a result of sagging automobile sales.
''The nine-tenths of a percent decline is very deceptive,'' said Sandra Shaber, an economist with the Futures Group here. ''It's all cars virtually.'' Elsewhere, she said, ''consumer spending is holding up pretty well.'' 
William K. MacReynolds, forecasting director for the United States Chamber of Commerce, agreed. ''True, automobiles sales fell,'' he said, ''but almost all other sectors experienced nice increases.''
 
Biggest Drop Since October
Excluding automobiles, retail sales actually rose five-tenths of a percent.
The Commerce Department said retail sales totaled a seasonally adjusted $146.5 billion. The decline was the biggest since a 1.3 percent drop in October and followed a strong 2.8 percent gain in January. The January number had originally been reported at 1.6 percent.
Automobile sales plummeted 6 percent in February after jumping 9.9 percent in January, when sales incentives were restored. It was the biggest drop since auto sales fell 26.5 percent in January 1987.
John Silvia, an economist with Kemper Financial Services in Chicago, said the non-automotive spending, combined with the substantial upward revision of January's sales, suggested that consumer spending would be fairly strong in the first quarter.
Mr. Silvia said the level of spending was consistent with other recent economic reports, including employment growth and personal income.
 
'No Economic Recession'
''When you put it all together, you have a package that says that there's no economic recession,'' he said. Retail sales represent about a third of the nation's economic activity.
It also suggests, Mr. Silvia added, that the Federal Reserve will not act soon to lower interest rates further to stimulate the economy. The Fed had supported higher interest rates to slow inflation until early last year when it began to ease slightly to help the economy avoid a recession.
Some economists and Government officials, however, have urged the Fed to ease its grip on credit further because certain sectors, like construction and much of manufacturing, remain under pressure.
Sales of durable goods - big-ticket, interest-sensitive items expected to last more than three years - fell 3 percent in February after gaining 6.7 percent a month earlier.
Except for autos, however, the durable categories rose, with building materials up 3 percent and home furnishings up five-tenths of a percent.
 
'Pricing Problem'
Mr. Silvia said the volatility in auto sales was a ''pricing problem.''
''What seems to be happening is that in those months when we don't have incentives, we seem to have stronger than normal non-auto sales,'' he said. ''And when we have the incentives put on, then auto retail sales come up and non-auto retail sales come down.''
Most nondurable goods categories also posted gains. Department store sales were up 2 percent; apparel, 1.6 percent; restaurants and bars, 1.4 percent, and grocery stores, five-tenths of a percent.
Declines were registered in drugstore and gasoline station sales, but the latter reflected price declines, not volume, analysts said. Both were down eight-tenths of a percent.
For the three months from December through February, overall retail sales were up 1.2 percent.

HEADLINE: Trade Gap at $105.89 Billion In 1989, Lowest in 5 Years

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13

 BODY:
The United States trade deficit declined to $105.89 billion last year, its lowest level in five years, as merchandise exports grew and travel abroad increased, the Government said today.
The Commerce Department said the current account deficit shrank by 16.3 percent from a gap of $126.55 billion in 1988. But even with the improvement the deficit remained above $100 billion for the sixth straight year. The 1989 figure was the lowest since a $104.19 billion deficit in 1984. 
The year ended on a positive note as the deficit declined to $20.57 billion in the fourth quarter, down 10.2 percent from the third-quarter level, and the smallest quarterly imbalance in almost six years.
The current account, also known as the balance of payments, is the most important trade statistic because it measures trade in services and investments as well as in merchandise.
The United States ended the 1980's in a far different position from the way it began the decade. In 1980, there was a small surplus in the current account. America was the world's largest creditor country, and its earnings on overseas investments were enough to offset perennial deficits in merchandise trade.
But as Americans transferred billions of dollars into foreign hands to pay for merchandise imports, the investment cushion shrank rapidly and disappeared in 1985, when the United States became a net debtor for the first time in 71 years.
The growing foreign ownership in America has set off a heated debate over whether the nation is losing control of its economic destiny.
Some economists predict that the current account deficit could rise again this year, reflecting higher dependence on foreign oil and slower sales of American exports.
 
JAPAN SURPLUS FALLS
TOKYO, March 13 (AP) - Japan's trade surplus fell 30 percent in February to $5 billion, from $7.23 billion a year earlier, the Ministry of Finance reported today.
It was the 10th consecutive month of year-on-year declines in Japan's trade surplus but was substantially higher than January's revised surplus of $338 million.
Japan's surplus with the United States shrank 28.5 percent, to $2.96 billion, in February, from $4.14 billion a year earlier, the ministry said.
In recent months, higher international oil prices and strong domestic demand have increased the value of imports, while growing overseas production by Japanese manufacturers has helped hold back export growth.
In February, exports fell 1.9 percent from a year earlier, to $21.9 billion, for the fifth consecutive decline, the ministry said. Imports rose 11.9 percent, to $16.9 billion, it said.
Japan's surplus with the European Community edged down to $1.88 billion, from $1.89 billion a year earlier.
Japan measures its trade balance on a customs-clearance basis, in which freight and insurance costs are included in import figures but not in exports.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
A Sense of Crisis In Tokyo Markets

BYLINE: By James Sterngold

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
THE steep rise of the dollar and the tumble of the yen in global currency trading are contributing to a growing sense of crisis in the financial markets here. Traders and investors say they see little prospect that monetary authorities can turn the situation around.
Many people are worried that the yen's decline is not a result of speculation by financial institutions or a short-term run, traders said. Investors, particularly Japanese institutions, simply see more and better investment opportunities in other countries. 
''The point is that the yen is under pressure from Japanese, not foreigners,'' said Hiroaki Shukuzawa, deputy manager of the Treasury Department at the Sumitomo Bank, Japan's second largest.
In tumultuous waves of trading yesterday, the dollar shrugged off intervention from the Bank of Japan and rose to a peak of 152.90 yen before dipping to 152.67 near the end of the day. That compares with the late quote Monday of 152 yen. The dollar began the year at slightly less than 145 yen.
Later yesterday, in trading in New York, the dollar lost some of its strength and closed at 152.20 yen, compared with 152.63 on Monday.
The rise of the dollar in Tokyo again contributed to jitters in the stock market there. The closely watched Nikkei index of 225 stocks tumbled 747.66, to 32,620.57. With its 624.89 fall on Monday, the stock market has declined 4 percent this week, continuing a slump.
The turmoil in the Japanese markets stems from various factors, both internal and external. The leap in West German and American interest rates has contributed to the weaker yen and helped put upward pressure on Japanese interest rates. In turn, the higher rates have been a big factor in causing the steady slide in stock prices here. A public dispute between the Bank of Japan and the Ministry of Finance have contributed to a perception that the problems are not being efficiently managed. Because in many ways Japan is reacting to a worldwide increase in interest rates, the tumult in the stock market is not sending out strong ripples to other stock markets around the world.
Contributing to Japanese anxieties is a perception that monetary officials here have become paralyzed. As decades of heavy regulation are lifted, the market is still getting used to the idea that the Government cannot simply decree the value of the yen or the level of interest rates.
The central banks of the large industrialized nations agreed in September 1985 to strengthen the yen against the dollar in an effort to reduce Japan's yawning trade surpluses and the United States' huge deficits. A strong yen tends to discourage exports to the United States while encouraging imports to Japan.
But late last year, the dollar started to rise. The yen's continuing slump threatens to undo the progress made in cutting the American trade deficit and could aggravate already strained relations between the countries.
In anticipation of a rate increase by the central bank, market-determined interest rates have been edging higher, too. Bond prices plunged as the yield on the Government's benchmark 10-year bond -the basis for many other commercial rates -jumped to 7.3 percent yesterday, its highest level in nearly six years, from 7.2 percent on Monday. For more than three weeks there has been speculation that the Bank of Japan will raise its discount rate to prop up the yen. Even if the bank does act, traders say, the yen is unlikely to respond because the rate change is anticipated.
''They've delayed so long that they've lost credibility in the market,'' said Takashi Okura, head of foreign exchange for the Bank of America here.
The Bank of Japan has also spent billions of dollars in recent days buying yen and selling dollars in fruitless efforts to reverse, or at least stabilize, exchange rates.
Ryutaro Hashimoto, the Finance Minister, expressed ''serious concern'' yesterday about the developments in the foreign exchange market, but outlined no plan to bolster the yen.
Making matters worse, there is a conspicuous lack of coordination among central banks to bring down the dollar, and that is unsettling the markets here. Five years ago, a coordinated effort did lower the dollar's value.
''The market does not see the central banks cooperating in their intervention,'' said Akira Suzuki, chief manager of foreign exchange of the Mitsubishi Trust and Banking Corporation. ''But the demand for dollars is so strong that intervention is not effective.''
Traders here are nervously waiting for two potential moves by monetary authorities. One is a heavy round of coordinated intervention on the part of the large central banks, assuming some agreement can be reached among them.
Central bankers are meeting in Basel, Switzerland, with the Bank for International Settlements, an organization of central banks. That could provide a forum for coordination.
In addition, the governor of the Bank of Japan, Yasushi Mieno, is to return from Basel Thursday afternoon and plans a news conference that day. There is some expectation that he may announce an increase in the discount rate, currently 4.25 percent, of as much as a percentage point.
