HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Prices Drop

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell sharply yesterday, pushed lower by stronger-than-expected February retail sales data and by reports that the West German Government has a plan to exchange West German marks on a one-to-one basis for the Ostmark, East Germany's currency, for savings.
The exchange-rate plan, an integral step toward forming a monetary union between the two Germanys, was announced by Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who announced the plan at a rally for conservative political parties in Cottbus, in southern East Germany. Participants in the credit markets interpreted the report as being potentially inflationary for a reunified Germany.
''It means higher rates in West Germany and, in all probability, higher rates here,'' one Government bond trader said. ''But the market may have overreacted to the proposal, because we don't know all of the conditions that will apply.'' 
According to news agency reports, the one-to-one exchange rate plan would be aimed at East Germans with ''moderate'' savings. No details on the plan were immediately available.
 
Chancellor Kohl Proposal
The news of Chancellor Kohl's proposal came to credit market traders in the United States after the retail sales report, which had prompted a rash of selling early in the session.
Market participants were particularly concerned with a big 1.2 percentage point upward revision in the January sales numbers. The change showed that retail sales rose by 2.8 percent in January.
In addition, traders tended to de-emphasize February's nine-tenths of 1 percent drop because it reflected sagging auto sales. Excluding autos, sales rose by half a percentage point last month.
Neal M. Soss, chief economist at the First Boston Corporation, suggested the market misinterpreted the retail sales data, but correctly assessed the importance of the day's developments in Germany.
''There is a better tone to the economic data, which reduces the chances that the Fed could ease policy now,'' he said.
''But we are having a period where the numbers being printed are healthier than what is going on in the true economy, partly because the mild weather this winter has been abnormally supportive of economic activity.''
Regarding developments in Germany, Mr. Soss said that ''there is a sense around that monetary authorities in West Germany are about to raise interest rates to compensate for the new risks that are emerging there.'' He added, ''If accomplished, those rate hikes would weaken financial markets in the United States.''
More than half of the price decline recorded yesterday came after news of the exchange rate proposal flashed across trading screens.
 
Treasury Notes and Bonds
Prices of longer-term Treasury notes and bonds, which are more sensitive to shifts in inflationary expectations than short-term securities, bore the brunt of the selloff.
By late in the day, the 8 1/2 percent bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 97 7/8, down more than 7/8 point, to yield 8.70 percent.
Among note issues, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 98 21/ 32 late yesterday, down half a point, to yield 8.71 percent. And the 8 1/2 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 18/32, down 3/32, to yield 8.74 percent.
Treasury bill rates moved modestly higher.
In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.95 percent, up one basis point, or hundredth of a point. Six-month bill rates rose by a similar amount, to a late offered rate of 7.88 percent. And one-year bills were offered at 7.83 percent, up three basis points.
In the market for investment-grade corporate bonds Texaco Inc. offered $250 million worth of 30-year bonds -its first sale of 30-year securities since it emerged from bankruptcy. The issue met with strong demand from investors, and its size was increased from $200 million.
The 9 3/4 percent bonds, which are noncallable for life, were priced at 100, 1.08 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 1/2 percent bonds at the time of pricing.
Salomon Brothers acted as lead manager for the underwriting, which is rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and A+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. The ratings by both services have been upgraded since Texaco's last debt sale in December.
A number of new tax-exempt deals were also priced yesterday, including a competitive bid offering of $150 million worth of serial bonds from the the State of Connecticutt.
A bid from a syndicate led by Morgan Stanley & Company won the issue. Coupons on the bonds that were reoffered range from 6 percent on securities maturing in 1992 to 6.95 percent on bonds that mature in 2009.
The issue is rated AA-1 by Moody's and AA+ by Standard & Poor's.
Participants in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds said that prices of most issues were unchanged on the day.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, prices of actively traded issues dipped by 1/2 point to 5/8 point, traders said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises and Then Falls On Reports From Germany

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar declined in moderate trading yesterday in New York amid confusion about a plan for German monetary unification. The slide reversed earlier gains in overseas markets.
Traders said the dollar, which had opened higher in New York, continuing the overseas trend, rose further against the West German mark on a midday report that Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany had said East Germans would be able to convert their savings to the West German mark at a straight one-to-one rate. 
Economists say the dollar rose because converting the East German currency, which is traded on the black market around four to one, at that rate could cause inflation in West Germany, which would devalue the West German mark.
Later in the day, traders learned that the one-for-one currency swap under consideration would apply only to small savings accounts. The news sparked a sharp selloff in the dollar.
''I've never seen anything like it, and I've been in the market 11 years,'' said Abigail Cook, a dealer with the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation.
She said the dollar drop lasted a few minutes before the currency stabilized at a lower level.
The dollar closed in New York at 1.7120 West German marks, down from its high of the day of 1.7218 and from Monday's late figure of 1.7135 marks. Earlier in Europe, the dollar closed at 1.7165 West German marks, up from 1.7110 Monday.
The market had little reaction to Government reports showing that the the broadest measure of United States trade deficit sank to $105.89 billion, a five-year low, last year, and that retail sales in February took their steepest fall in four months, nine-tenths of 1 percent.
The figures were about what the market expected, said Robert Hatcher, a dealer with Barclays Bank P.L.C.
In New York, the dollar fell to 152.20 yen, from 152.63 yen late Monday. Earlier in Tokyo, it had risen to a closing of 152.67 Japanese yen - the lowest level for the yen against the dollar in exactly three years - from 152.00 yen Monday. Later, in London, it fell to 152.52 yen.
The dollar also fell against the pound to $1.6097, compared with $1.6115 late Monday, although it had risen in London to $1.6005, from $1.6100 late Monday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday, included: 1.5215 Swiss francs, down from 1.5258; 5.7850 French francs, down from 5.7915; 1,264.50 Italian lire, down from 1,265.50, and 1.1761 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1787.

HEADLINE: Bush Turns Down Bid To Help Negotiators

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Baseball's labor dispute lay dormant yesterday as negotiators chose not to meet and President Bush opted not to become involved. The possibility of binding arbitration was raised and neither side rejected the idea outright, but the owners' labor spokesman said it would be ''a difficult sell'' for his side.
On the 27th day of the owners' lockout of players from spring training camps, officials also made no decisions on the cancellation of regular-season games, which are scheduled to begin in 19 days. The commissioner's office said an announcement would be made on Friday. 
The dispute between the players and the owners, which has made it almost impossible for the season to begin on time, reached the White House yesterday, where the President was asked at a news conference if he had any suggestions for ending the dispute.
''I am a ball fan and I want to go to the opening game someplace,'' he replied. ''But I don't want to intervene. I would simply appeal to both sides to get the matter resolved so the Amercian people can hear that cry 'play ball' again.''
 
Seemingly Indefinite Recess
With negotiations in seemingly indefinite recess, no settlement of the arbitration eligibility dispute over two-to-three-year players is in sight. The two sides are holding firmly to their positions, with no indication of a willingness to budge from them.
Charles O'Connor, the owners' negotiatior said he spoke with Donald Fehr, the players' labor leader, by telephone yesterday.
''So far we have not found a way to bridge the salary arbitration issue,'' O'Connor said. ''I can't say we made any progress. We talked about some ideas. The only good news is we're still talking.''
Sometimes when such circumstances exist, the two parties agree to submit their dispute to binding arbitration, a procedure in which an arbitrator determines the resolution based on arguments and proposals from the negotiators. It has never happened in baseball.
 
Differing Views
O'Connor and Fehr were asked yesterday if they would agree to submit the issue of the two-to-three-year players to that procedure if they could reach agreement on all of the other issues.
''I talked to Fay Vincent about it over the weekend,'' Fehr said, referring to his private meetings with the commissioner in Greenwich, Conn. ''If it was binding arbitration that would limit us, we wouldn't accept it. But if we could each submit what we wanted and the arbitrator could decide on the basis of either side's position or anything in between, we'd be willing to think about it.''
But, he added, ''my impression was the owners wouldn't have any interest in doing that.''
Vincent declined to discuss binding arbitration, saying that was something for O'Connor to deal with.
O'Connor said that it would be difficult to resolve all of the other issues and leave the two-to-three eligibility problem hanging because some of the other issues, such as minimum salary and the owners' contribution to the players' pension and benefit plan, have economic consequences and are linked to the way those players would be paid.
 
'Aversion to Arbitration'
''The clubs have an aversion to arbitration as opposed to negotiation,'' O'Connor said. ''It's historic, so it would be a difficult sell. Right now it's a fairly hypothetical question.''
From what he called the standpoint of fairness, O'Connor said: ''The clubs would be asked to put at risk something they have in the current contract. It's not an issue where there is equal risk.'' The players are seeking to reinstitute the two-year arbitration eligibility that was increased to three years in the last contract.
A labor relations veteran, who asked not to be identified, said that if binding arbitration were to be effective in settling the impasse, it most likely would have to be proposed and accepted fairly soon. The longer the dispute continues, he said, the less likely the idea would be accepted.
 
Wrong Terminology
President Bush acknowledged at his news conference that he called the work stoppage by its wrong name last week. He referred to it as a strike rather than a lockout. ''We got some calls from some of the players saying that's not technically what the situation is, please,'' he said.
O'Connor said that clubs had received permission to have their minor league teams play their exhibition games in major league facilities in Florida and Arizona. But, he stressed, the games would be strictly minor league. He also said that Bud Selig, chairman of the Player Relations Committee board, had given owners permission to speak out on the dispute.

HEADLINE: Florio Plans to Balance Budget With $1.4 Billion Tax Increase

BYLINE: By PETER KERR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, March 14

 BODY:
Gov. Jim Florio, facing a growing shortfall in tax revenue, is to propose a state budget balanced with $1.4 billion in new and higher taxes on Thursday. The budgets of many agencies would be cut to achieve what he says is the first actual reduction in state spending in 14 years.
Looking beyond the immediate budget problems, Mr. Florio will also propose a sharp increase in the income tax for New Jersey's wealthiest residents for next year.
The immediate effect of the budget, if the Legislature approves it, would be a rise in the sales tax, to 7 percent from 6. The budget proposal would also mean higher prices for items like household materials, gasoline and train fares. The higher income tax, which would take effect on Jan. 1, 1991, would be used to shift more of the cost of government to the wealthy, reduce the burden of local property taxes and increase aid for poor school districts. 
Mr. Florio is to announce his two-step plan in his first budget message to the Legislature. Some details of the $12.1 billion plan released today by Treasurer Douglas C. Berman make clear that the remainder of this fiscal year, which ends on June 30, and the next year would be periods of bitter cutbacks in services and greater burdens on taxpayers.
 
Democrats See Need for Study
Republicans lashed out at the proposal, calling it the biggest tax increase in state history. Democratic leaders in the two houses of the Legislature, both controlled by Mr. Florio's party, said they were studying the plan. In his campaign last fall, Mr. Florio said he saw no need for higher taxes.
In addition, the size of the actual budget proposal is likely to be debated. While budget documents released by the administration today described it as a $12.1 billion budget, other items - including a surplus fund and hundreds of millions of dollars to restore or repay cuts that Mr. Florio is making in the current budget - bring the total to $12.8 billion.
The proposal calls for raising the sales tax and applying it to many additional products; raising alcohol and tobacco taxes, taxing telephone transmissions and all petroleum products, except heating oil, and ending the popular property-tax rebates for homeowners.
Although Mr. Florio proposes to spend $39 million less than the current budget, which was created by his predecessor, Thomas H. Kean, particularly dramatic reductions may be seen in some areas, including aid to education, because contracts have built-in increases in salaries and other expenses.
In a separate announcement, the Standard & Poor's Corporation, the bond rater, said it had placed New Jersey bonds on ''Creditwatch with negative implications.'' The high ''AAA'' rating remains, but is at risk of being revised. Standard & Poor's described the new budget as ''prudent in reversing the recent fiscal weakness.''
 
Harsh Immediate Steps
Like other Northeastern states, New Jersey has seen revenues fall short of projected increases as government continues to grow. New Jersey's budget doubled, to $12 billion from $6 billion, in Mr. Kean's eight years.
Although Govs. Mario M. Cuomo of New York and William A. O'Neill of Connecticut have responded to similar problems by proposing smaller than usual budget increases and various tax increases, Mr. Florio is proposing harsh immediate steps while calling on the Legislature to examine the tax system.
''New Jersey has the same problems that other states in the Northeast have,'' Mr. Florio's chief spokesman, Jon Shure, said. ''The difference is that Governor Florio is meeting the problem head on.''
To contend with a projected revenue shortfall of $592 million for the fiscal year that ends on June 30, Mr. Berman said, the state will save $150 million by freezing some operations, including hiring and travel costs, $255 million by reducing capital construction and hazardous-waste cleanups, $43 million by refinancing the pension system and $144 million by delaying payments to municipalities until the next fiscal year.
 
New Items to Be Taxed
For the next year, nearly every agency, except prisons and social services, would have their budgets cut.
The increase in the sales tax to 7 percent is expected to raise an additional $538 million. In addition, new taxes on cigarettes and alcohol that would raise the cost of a pack 11 to 13 cents and a fifth of liquor 38 cents would together bring in $142 million. The sales tax would also be applied to telephone calls and other telecommunications, soaps, detergents and non-prescription drugs.
A tax on all petroleum products except heating oil is projected to raise $255 million.
In proposals the Governor will ask the Legislature to enact to become part of the plans for fiscal 1992, he will call for an increase in the income-tax rates for people with incomes higher than $55,000, Mr. Berman said. Although the schedule was not announced, it would reach a maximum of 7 percent for people with incomes of $100,000 or higher.
 
Plan for School Financing
The $1.25 billion raised by that increase would be used for property-tax relief of up to $500 for people with incomes under $65,000. The money would relieve county and municiapl governments of $250 million in welfare and social-service costs. And it would finance a $600 million increase in school aid under a new formula that would try to insure adequate financing for educating students in poorer districts.
The State Supreme Court has heard arguments in a suit challenging the school-financing law as inequitable for poorer districts.
For years the ways New Jersey raises and spends money, and particualarly the dependence on property taxes for revenues, have been the subject of raucous debates. Critics, including liberals and Democrats, often called for shifting the reliance for revenues from property taxes to income and other taxes.
 
Position of Republicans
Mr. Kean, who left office in January, and other Republicans have fought a shift from property taxes to higher income taxes, saying it would retard economic growth and hurt rich and poor alike.
Because Mr. Berman did not disclose important parts of Mr. Florio's plan, including details on the income-tax increase and school-aid distribution, it was difficult to discern to what extent poor cities and school districts, as well as affluent people, would be affected.
If enacted, the income-tax increase would take effect on Jan. 1, 1991. The property-tax relief would take effect on July 1, 1991.
The short-term solutions Mr. Florio is offering to balance the next budget are considered stark and dramatic in a state that has grown accustomed to economic booms in the last 10 years.
 
Effects on Higher Education
State colleges and universities would face reductions that the administration estimates equals the costs of maintaining 1,414 employees; individual institutions will decide on reducing staffs or other costs.
Local school districts would face greater budget problems in fiscal 1991, Mr. Berman said, forcing them to cut services or raise property taxes, at least until Mr. Florio's property-tax relief takes effect.
N.J. Transit subsidies would not increase, making fare bus and train fare increases likely, Mr. Berman said.
The plan calls for ending the Homestead Rebate program, which returns an average of $180 a year to each homeowner.
Financing would be reduced in dozens of areas, including cultural programs, community drug treatment and pharmaceutical help for the aged. Scathed by G.O.P. Republican minority leaders in the Assembly lambasted the program and accused Mr. Florio of cynicism over his gubernatorial campaign in which he repeatedly said he saw no need for new taxes this year.
''While there aren't many of us on this side of the aisle who expected the Florio campaign promise of no tax increases to last the full two years that he stated, we certainly thought the promise would hold for two months,'' said the minority leader, Garabad Haytaian of Hackettstown.
''It seems that Jim Florio and Mario Cuomo are in a race to see who can become the next Michael Dukakis the quickest,'' said Assemblyman Rodney P. Frelinghuysen of Morristown, a Congressional candidate this year.
The Democratic president of the State Senate, John A. Lynch, who is also Mayor of New Brunswick and a longtime critic of the property-tax system, said the plans for property-tax relief and the income-tax increase seemed to fulfill his calls for tax reform to help poor cities.
But he added that the first step in Mr. Florio's proposals would make life difficult for everyone who depended on state financing next year, including the cities.
''It absolutely helps to address the problems of the cities,'' Mr. Lynch said. ''It is true tax reform.''

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East;
U.S. WARNS ALLIES ON AID TO SOVIETS

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 14

 BODY:
The United States threatened today not to join a new financial institution designed to funnel the bulk of economic assistance to Eastern Europe if the Soviet Union were to become a major borrower from the organization.
The threat came from Nicholas F. Brady, the Secretary of Treasury, after representatives of 34 countries met to hammer out the charter of the new institution - called the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development - which has been conceived as the coordinating body for an effort to rebuild the impoverished economies of Eastern Europe on a scale comparable to the postwar Marshall Plan.
Mr. Brady's comments seemed intended to increase pressure on American allies to accept the American view that Soviet participation as a borrower under the plan should be rigorously limited.
 
More Sympathetic View
Most of the Western European countries have taken a more sympathetic position on Soviet borrowing. 
The present plan is to capitalize the bank at $8.3 billion, of which 30 percent would be paid in at the start, with the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France and Italy, each having an 8.5 percent stake. The United States told the Europeans it would be willing to take a larger share - up to 10.5 percent. The Soviet Union would have a 6 percent share.
The idea of a new lending institution for Eastern Europe was first proposed by President Francois Mitterrand of France last December as a means to speed the economic recovery of Eastern Europe, and the institution is expected to go into operation later this year.
At the outset, the United States had opposed any participation in the scheme by the Soviets, but as it found itself more and more isolated it moderated its reservations to accept Moscow in the plan but to insist on limiting how much the Soviet Union would be able to seek for its own economic needs.
 
Delayed Over Weekend
Disputes over Soviet participation and other matters kept negotiators from final agreement on the charter at a meeting last weekend in Paris. Before the bank can go into operation, the member countries have to agree on its charter and bylaws. Then, Congress and other national legislatures would have to authorize the capital to back the bank's loans. Mr. Brady said the United States has told the Soviets that any needs they wanted filled by the bank would reduce the amount of money available for the Eastern European countries. ''Our position is that the U.S. does not want to be part of the bank if a major part of the funds are diverted to Soviet lending.''
Mr. Brady's comments before the House Operations subcommittee on foreign operations signaled new battles ahead with European governments, and further distanced the Administration from remarks last week of the House Democratic Leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, who called for economic aid to the Soviet Union to bolster Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Mr. Brady, a former investment banker, said the Soviets should not be given borrowing power greater than the capital they put into the institution.
 
Working for Principles
For the first time in the postwar period, Washington is participating in the establishment of a multilateral lending institution that it will not control - reflecting the decline of this country's relative global weight.
As Mr. Brady observed somewhat philosophically: ''This bank will go forward, whether the U.S. is a part of it or not.''
Because the United States will not get the veto it enjoys in such other multinational institutions as the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, Washington is working to install the principles it wants in the charter.
In addition to restricting the borrowing of the Soviets, the United States wants to insure that at least 60 percent of the loans go to buttress the private sector of ''pluralistic democratic societies.'' Other Avenues for U.S. If the United States were to make good its threat to stay out of the new organization, it could channel aid to Eastern Europe through bilateral programs, which have been crimped by budget considerations, and through other multinational lending institutions, such as the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.
The World Bank, in which the United States holds roughly 20 percent of the capital, expects to lend more than $5 billion to Eastern Europe over the next three years.
Any break with the Europeans, however, is likely to be be resisted by the State Department, which has stressed the importance of American participation in the European plan to maintain Atlantic political ties.
Michael Mandelbaum, senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations in New York, said the argument that Eastern European countries would be deprived of funds that would be loaned to Moscow might be economically sensible but ''to single out the Soviet Union is wrong and foolish because we'll lose on that. The Europeans won't buy it.''
After meeting Mr. Gorbachev in Malta last December, Mr. Bush has been supportive of the idea of integrating the Soviet Union in the international economy.
A worsening Soviet economy is forcing the nation toward a faster and more radical reorganization of the system, Western and Soviet economists at a Moscow conference say.
Business Day, page D20.

HEADLINE: Mongolia Ousts Leaders and Ends Communists' Monopoly on Power

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ULAN BATOR, Mongolia, March 14

 BODY:
The Communist Party replaced its entire leadership today and voted to give up its constitutional monopoly on power in preparation for free elections expected to be held later this year.
The Central Committee, in a two-day session that is regarded here as a watershed in the transformation of Mongolia from an authoritarian one-party state to a multiparty democracy, also voted to expel its former leader from the party.
Mongolia, between China and the Soviet Union, has only two million inhabitants, half of them herdsmen, but political events here carry a significance greater than the population figure would suggest because of their potential effect on China.
Some Chinese, especially intellectuals and the three million ethnic Mongolians who live across the border, have paid considerable attention to events here since the democracy movement began in Mongolia in December. 
The entire Politburo resigned today and most Central Committee members over the age of 60, about half the total, offered to resign. The new five-member Politburo appears to be made up of advocates of rapid liberalization.
Gombojavyn Ochirbat, 61 years old, a former party official who had been criticized by the now-disgraced party leadership, was named the party's new General Secretary. He had been in the country for only a few days before his selection, and for the last two years lived in Prague, Czechoslovakia, as Mongolia's representative to the World Marxist Review, a journal.
 
A Remarkable Proposal
The Central Committee began its meeting Monday with a remarkable proposal from the Politburo to abolish the constitutional guarantee of power for the Communist Party, formerly known as the Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party. The Politburo also suggested that it be replaced and called for a party congress that would choose a rejuvenated Central Committee and revise party policy.
The changes were prompted by small pro-democracy demonstrations that began in December and attracted growing support with their assertions of Mongolian nationalism and complaints about autocratic policies and economic mismanagement.
In a symbolic indictment of its own past, the Central Committee voted to strip the country's former President and party leader, Yumjaagiyn Tsendenbol, of his party membership. Mr. Tsendenbol, who was ousted in 1984 while on a trip to the Soviet Union, continues to live in Moscow, where he is 73 years old and is reported to be in failing health.
In addition to Mr. Ochirbat, the four other new members of the Politburo are all in their 40's. One is the Foreign Minister, T. Gombusuren, who last year visited Washington and signed a bilateral cultural agreement with the United States. Mongolia is trying to improve its relationship with the United States, Japan and Western Europe as a way of reducing its dependence on the Soviet Union.
The results of the Central Committee meeting were announced to foreign reporters late tonight by the chief Foreign Ministry spokesman, Terbichyn Tchimeddorj, as the meeting ended its session.
Apparently because the meeting ended at about midnight, there was no immediate reaction from the opposition forces. In recent days, several members of the ruling party and opposition have said they favor a coalition government that would include the ruling party and several newly created dissident parties.
 
Party Congress April 10
It was not clear how long the new leadership would serve, because the Central Committee also agreed to call an extraordinary party congress beginning April 10. The congress will choose a new Central Committee, which in turn is likely to hold an election for party leaders. It apparently could confirm those chosen today or elect a new slate.
The former party leader, Jambyn Batmonh, continues to serve as President of Mongolia. But the Great People's Hural, the legislature, is expected to be summoned within the next week for an emergency session in which some delegates are likely to seek to oust Mr. Batmonh and other top government leaders.
Little is known of Mr. Ochirbat, who before moving to Prague was the deputy head of the organization department of the party. He has also served as the Central Committee's ideology chief and as head of the country's trade union federation. In 1982 he was criticized and stipped of the union post, presumably because he offended Mr. Tsendenbol, who was then Mongolia's party leader.
The committee also voted to rehabilitate party officials who had been criticized during past purges, in the 1960's.
 
Many Critical Speeches
The Central Committee meeting was televised, and many critical speeches made by the delegates were printed in the newspapers. Mr. Tchimeddorj said that all the speeches and party documents would be published as soon as possible.
''Many letters and telegrams came from every corner of the country, from party members and nonparty members, from peasants and many others,'' said Mr. Tchimeddorj. ''Every letter and telegram was read before the committee.''
In addition to Mr. Ochirbat and Mr. Gombusuren, the new Politburo members are N. Michigdorg, whose background is not known, T. Oold, chairman of the party's control commission, and L. Tudev, the editor of Unen, the party newspaper.
Mongolia, the second oldest Communist regime in the world after the Soviet Union, had a Soviet-backed Communist revolution in 1921. The Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party has had a monopoly on power since 1924.
A commission that includes dissidents is being formed to draft a constitution and both party officials and dissidents say they anticipate free elections before the end of this year.

HEADLINE: To Her Deepening Political Troubles, Thatcher Adds a Party in Rebellion

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, March 14

 BODY:
Well into her third term, Margaret Thatcher is in political trouble as deep as any she has been in during nearly 11 years as Britain's Prime Minister.
''The worst news for the Government is that its luck has run out,'' Peter Jenkins, the authoritative political columnist of The Independent newspaper, wrote this week, summarizing the effects of more than a year of steadily bad news that is getting worse for the Government all the time.
With their party trailing the opposition Labor Party in national public opinion polls by 17 to 19 percentage points for months in succession, many Conservative members of Parliament are in a restive and rebellious mood. On Tuesday night, 33 of them voted against the Government in a move to amend part of a bill reorganizing the National Health Service. 
Though the 256-to-253 defeat on a move to subsidize retired patients in private nursing homes was later reversed, it was the first such embarrassment since the 1987 elections, when Mrs. Thatcher led her party to her third victory and a 100-seat majority.
 
To Avoid Cabinet Changes
Mrs. Thatcher visited her rebellious troops today and let it be known that after David Hunt succeeds Peter Walker as Cabinet Minister for Wales in May, she would avoid making any more changes in her cabinet, which is still shaking from the reshuffles and resignations of some of the best known ministers last year. Her office also said that she would have talks with President Bush in Bermuda on April 13.
That may touch up her fading image as the senior European leader with the best connections in Washington, but here at home, her embarrassments in Parliament came on top of a continuing national uproar over an unpopular new per capita tax, the ''community charge.'' She is insisting on putting it in place all over England and Wales on April 1, a year after it went into effect in Scotland, and insists that it will curb local government spending.
The ''poll tax,'' as opponents call it, is being set by local governments across the country at unexpectedly high rates of $500, sometimes even much more, for every member of a household over the age of 18. Many people who gave their votes to Mrs. Thatcher's Conservatives for leading the country out of the economic decline of the 1970's are now reeling from high interest rates that the Government had to raise, to curb inflation caused by its own monetary policy mistakes after the stock market crash of 1987. For thousands of them, the ''poll tax'' is the last straw, and they say they are withdrawing their support.
Just how deep the disenchantment really is will become clear on March 22, when the voters of the prosperous, tidy residential and rural election district of mid-Staffordshire in the English midlands go to the polls to replace a Conservative M.P. who won the seat by 14,654 votes, one of the largest Conservative majorities in the country, in the 1987 elections.
 
A Cathedral Town
Until his death last December, the seat was thought safe in Tory hands. It is a rural Midlands constituency winding from the placid cathedral town of Lichfield in the south to the prosperous industrial parks of Stone in the north.
Lichfield is proud to be the birthplace of Dr. Samuel Johnson, but in Beacon Park it also has a stern and possibly apposite memorial to Edward John Smith, the captain who went down with the Titanic in 1912.
For the Conservatives are in serious danger of losing next Thursday, according to polls, politicians, and many ordinary people in the constituency. The likely cause is Mrs. Thatcher's ''poll tax,'' but the underlying issue seems to be dissatisfaction with the Prime Minister herself.
''I'm deeply upset,'' Thelma Bartlett, who said she had been a Conservative voter all her life, told Charles Prior, the party's candidate in the mid-Staffordshire by-election, as he stumped the neighborhoods of Lichfield with his wife, Sarah, on Tuesday. ''I've always been a very great admirer of Mrs. Thatcher, but I look at her now, and she's losing her marbles.
 
'I Know Things Are Sticky'
''It seems you are looking after the rich and not the poor,'' she told the candidate, who disagreed that the per capita charge was unfair because it would replace a real estate tax paid mainly by property owners and people who rented from them.
''I know things are sticky,'' Mr. Prior, a 43-year-old accountant, told her. ''I know things are tough now, but I am sure that in a year we'll look around and see that things have come round all right.''
That may be true for Mrs. Thatcher, but it might be too late for Mr. Prior if the pre-election opinion polls are right. A survey of 862 adults in the constituency by Market & Opinion Research International when the three-week campaign opened found that 50 percent said they would vote Labor, only 36 percent Conservative.
Mrs. Thatcher, who her aides say does not campaign in by-elections, is not planning to do so for Mr. Prior. But Michael Heseltine, the former Defense Minister who is the favorite among the substantial minority of Conservative Members of Parliament who reportedly want her to resign as their leader before the next national elections, campaigned with Mr. Prior today. And Neil Kinnock, the opposition leader who hopes to defeat the Conservatives in the next national elections, is appearing on behalf of the Labor Party candidate, Sylvia Heal, a 48-year-old judge, who, like him, comes from Wales.
Mrs. Heal, between campaign appearances, said she had been selected by her party to run in the Conservative district last January. ''I thought then that it would be a tall order,'' she said. ''Certainly it's going to be close - but while people here have been Tory in the past, they are feeling let down. The main issue is the poll tax, but close behind it are high interest rates and mortgages.''
As in the country as a whole, Labor's chances of upsetting the Conservatives have been significantly enhanced by the collapse of support for the center parties, the Social Democrats and the Liberal Democrats, that figured so importantly in British politics in the early 1980's, before Labor began expelling left-wing militants and gave up its commitment to unilateral British nuclear disarmament under Mr. Kinnock's leadership.
In the 1987 election in mid-Staffordshire, Labor and the center parties won nearly half the total vote, but divided it almost evenly between them.

HEADLINE: Democrats Shift on Military Cutbacks

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 14

 BODY:
House Democrats said today that they had reached a consensus to forgo deep cuts in military spending for the next fiscal year and to seek more dramatic reductions in spending for future years.
''There is a great deal of unity and unanimity in the approach that is going to be used,'' said Speaker Thomas S. Foley, Democrat of Washington. ''There is a solid consensus that we ought to approach it on a multiyear basis.''
The approach would place more emphasis than the Bush Administration budget does on cutting major strategic weapons programs, and it would reduce troop strength more gradually than liberal Democrats initially envisioned. 
Force reductions and base closings are politically painful, and the House Democratic strategy contemplates some form of economic or job retraining assistance to military personnel and communities that would be affected. Major weapons programs that would be cut back sharply in the future include the B-2 bomber, the MX and Midgetman missiles and the proposed shield against a missile attack.
 
An 'Important First Step'
The decisions, thrashed out in two days of closed-door meetings, have not yet produced agreement between conservative and liberal House Democrats on an actual military spending figure, and there is not yet a clear picture of how the budget changes would translate into a revised defense strategy.
''What has happened is a very important first step in getting the kind of consensus we will need for arriving at defense number,'' said Representative Leon E. Panetta, the California Democrat who heads the House Budget Committee. ''But there are a lot of hoops we will need to go through before we reach that point.''
The agreement, such as it is, represents something of a retreat for House liberals, who had hoped to see big military savings in the upcoming 1991 budget year.
 
Approach Called Impossible
Over the past several weeks, more conservative Democrats, including Representative Les Aspin of Wisconsin, who heads the House Armed Services Committee, and Representative John P. Murtha of Pennsylvania, who heads the House Appropriations subcommittee on defense, have convinced their liberal colleagues that such an approach was both politically and logistically impossible.
Mr. Panetta said the most difficult task had been getting liberal lawmakers to understand that even the termination of every major weapons program would not produce immediate savings in the military budget. ''What you now have is a building consensus where liberals recognize that significant reductions will take a period of time to achieve, but will be much more meaningful,'' he said.
At the same time, he added, conservatives are more comfortable because they see a ''responsible transition'' to lower military spending. ''The most encouraging thing to come out of the meetings is that for the first time you will be able to have liberals and conservatives going to the floor and defending the same military budget,'' he said.
A united front is particularly important for House Democrats this year, because leaders believe they will have to pass the budget with little support from House Republicans.
 
The Democratic Approach
The budget strategy means that Democrats will be looking to spend from $290 billion to $296 billion on military programs in the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1. The figures reflect the portion of the military budget known as outlays. President Bush has proposed an outlay figure of $303 billion.
Under the House Democratic approach, the much larger cuts would come in the portion of the budget known as budget authority. Mr. Bush has proposed a budget authority figure for fiscal 1991 of $306.4 billion, and House Democrats are looking at figure that could be as low as $282 billion.
''I think there is an understanding that the defense bill is driven by budget authority primarily and that immediate, very deep reductions in budget outlays are difficult,'' Mr. Foley told reporters. ''But over time, there is going to be a significant reduction in the defense budget.''
In today's closed-door meeting of 155 House Democrats, Mr. Aspin outlined some examples of the kinds of savings that could be expected from various combinations of troops and weapons cuts. Mr. Aspin said that reducing Army and Air Force troop strength in Europe by 80,000 in the 1991 fiscal year would save $1.5 billion in military outlays for that year and $18.9 billion by fiscal 1995.
Troop cuts of 155,000 by fiscal 1993 would save only slightly more in the 1991 fiscal year - an estimated $1.6 billion - but would save $48.1 billion by fiscal 1995.
Halting production of the B-2 bomber after this year but completing research and development for 15 of the planes would save $200 million in fiscal 1991 and $17.6 billion by fiscal 1995. Terminating all money for the bomber would save $1 billion in fiscal 1991 and $21.4 billion by fiscal 1995.
Terminating the rail-mounted MX missile program and MX missile production would save $800 million in fiscal 1991 and $6.5 billion by fiscal 1995. Terminating the Midgetman missile program would save $100 million in fiscal 1991 outlays and $2.3 billion in outlays by fiscal 1995.

HEADLINE: Split Between Army and Marines Surfaces in Debate on 3d World

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 14

 BODY:
The behind-the-scenes rivalry between the Army and the Marine Corps burst into public view today as the leader of each service laid claim to being the primary force for American military operations in the third world.
Gen. Carl E. Vuono, the Army Chief of Staff, and Gen. Alfred M. Gray, the Marine Corps Commandant, avoided any direct criticism of the capabilities of each other's service in a hearing of the House Armed Services Committee.
And there were smiles all around when the Army and Marine Corps leaders posed for photographers along with Gen. Colin L. Powell, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, before the hearing began.
But the thinly disguised competition quickly surfaced despite General Powell's seeming effort to keep peace by telling the committee that the United States needs to maintain a broad array of Army and Marine forces. General Powell had not been invited to testify, Congressional aides said, but asked to appear. 
 
'The Right Mix' Is Debated
Competitive even in times of growing defense budgets, the various military forces are struggling to retain as much of the budget pie as possible as money for defense diminishes. Les Aspin, the Wisconsin Democrat who is chairman of the panel, said the hearing had been called to begin a debate on ''the right mix of forces'' for operations in third world countries.
General Vuono of the Army struck first, reading excerpts from a long statement that advertised the fighting capabilities of the Army's 82d Airborne Division and the need for the service's ''civil affairs'' units that can help third world countries rebuild after an American military intervention.
The American invasion of Panama, an Army-dominated operation in which the Marine Corps played a minor role, loomed large in General Vuono's presentation.
Future conflicts in the third world, General Vuono said, will require ''the overwhelming application of combat power.'' And while General Vuono paid homage to joint operations with other military services, he underscored the speed with which the Army ''can place substantial combat power on the ground anywhere in the world.''
General Gray, whose gruff one-liners have long entertained members of Congress, followed with a formal statement that was laden with political-science jargon.
 
Concerns About Third World
But the main message behind his economic and political theories was that troubles in the third world were on the rise even as the Soviet threat is diminishing and that most of the potential battlefields in developing nations would be near the coastlines and thus within reach of the Marine Corps.
Or as the usually blunt-spoken General Gray put it, ''The international security environment is in the midst of changing from a bipolar balance to a multipolar one with polycentric dimensions.''
He added, ''Migration patterns will continue to shift populations away from the heartlands to the coasts,'' adding to the demand in those areas for food and housing and making them ''breeding grounds of discontent.''
That, plus an anticipated decline in overseas bases and the need for vital resources in the third world, ''drives us toward the development of a strategy that is maritime in character,'' he said.
But General Gray did allow that the Army airborne units were a ''most useful feature'' and that they complemented the capabilities of the Corps.
 
The Discussion Heats Up
The polite discussion over future American military capabilities heated up when Representaive Aspin asked the military leaders to comment on statements by a Marine Corps general who said in December that Army light forces, which could rapidly be transported by plane to third world nations, lack the firepower and capability to sustain a fight.
General Vuono replied gruffly that top Pentagon officials saw the need for the light Army forces. ''I do not think I need to comment any further on the quote,'' he said.
General Gray said that the Marine Corps General, Brig. Gen. John J. Sheehan, had not been denying the need for Army units that could be used in the third world, but that he was raising important questions about the sort of forces that were needed.
''What he was saying was, 'Yes, we need that,' '' said General Gray, referring to Army units poised for third world conflicts. But many Army forces are needed for third world contingencies, and whether they can be afforded ''is a question that has yet to be asked,'' he said.
''I think the statement speaks for itself,'' he added.

HEADLINE: Johnny Could Read in 1905, but Had to Go Work

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In ''Johnny Couldn't Read in 1905, Either'' (Op-Ed., Feb. 24), Maurice Wolfthal attempts to equate the educational failure rate of black and Hispanic children with those he attributes to white European children at the turn of the century. There is no basis for comparison if one is to take into consideration the economic and political environments of the eras.
I might even suggest that a study of those conditions might have persuaded Mr. Wolfthal to consider the circumstances of failure among the white European children of that era as ''extenuating,'' as I might view his comparison attempts as ''palliative.'' I offer myself as a witness since I was there about that time as a first grader in a New York City public school. The year was 1912. 
Consider those circumstances. The ferries from Ellis Island were daily pouring immigrants into the city's lower belly at a rate that simply could not be handled by any civic organization. Manhattan was a gridiron of ethnic neighborhoods growing more stifling as more immigrants sought to settle there. The threat of Babel hung over us.
We were an immigrant family of eight. As the youngest child, I saw how my father was unable to support his family with what sweatshop labor or hod carrying could pay. So, as in many other such families, my older brothers and sisters, left school in their early teens to find work that would help our family survive. They were hungry for education, but their hunger could only be satisfied by devoting evenings to studying at free night schools or with friendly tutors.
I remember the sixth graders in my school who obtained working papers and sadly dropped out to help the family survive. But by the time those kids had reached the sixth grade, they were proficient readers. I can attest to that because the motivation for reading was great. The environment in which we lived made reading our only escape to a world of fantasy and adventure. There was no radio or television, and the movies of that era had not yet learned to talk.
I was amused by Mr. Wolfthal's ''evidence'' of the white children's failures in education. He quotes a complaint by a 1905 principal to the effect that children in the seventh and eighth years couldn't write a sentence without a mistake in grammar. Does this not mean that the children were able to write sentences whose only flaws were grammar?
If reading failures were as high as Mr. Wolfthal suggests, I might point out that Street & Smith publishers could scarcely keep up with the demand for children's dime novels, the paperbacks of their day. Books by such authors as Horatio Alger Jr. and Victor Appleton (the Tom Swift series) were in the hands of every kid in my impoverished neighborhood. Those kids used to go to ''swapping corners'' to exchange their books for others they hadn't read.
If illiteracy existed in an inner city like New York, resulting from the educational failures among the white children of that era, as suggested by Mr. Wolfthal, I point out that the population of New York City (much smaller than now) supported the circulation of more than a score of daily newspapers, including the local foreign-language press. The ubiquitous Saturday Evening Post was a must even in poorer neighborhoods, and pulp magazines to suit every literary taste occupied the entire display front of every newsstand.
Yes, very few of those kids at the turn of the century made it through high school, much less through college, but only because they did not have the opportunities available to children today.
 
EMIL LEAVITT
Huntington, L.I., Feb. 25, 1990

HEADLINE: Johnny Could Read in 1905, but Had to Go Work;
Change Must Come

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Maurice Wolfthal informs us that ''white children of European origin were failing in our schools long before blacks and Hispanics were'' (Op-Ed, Feb. 24). Although the statistics of truancy and dropouts at the turn of the century were higher than today, students who dropped out of school in the early part of this century did not drop out of society. 
A further examination of the statistics will also show that these children found employment in what was then a factory-oriented society. The availability of drugs and sex in today's society, coupled with a highly technological job market, makes it almost a certainty that today's dropouts will add to the statistics of tomorrow's unemployment or homeless.
As educators, we need to study history so that we can alter our future. It seems to me that if we accept that our 40 percent dropout rate today is an improvement over the 75 percent dropout rate of the early 1900's, we are dooming the future of this country. We need to recognize that if what we did in the early 1900's in the classrooms of New York City didn't work and if the same strategies aren't working today, alternative strategies are called for.
Society has changed and the students have changed. The question is when will the schools change to offer the solutions called for in this changing society?
 
JERRY RESNICK
Principal, Clara Barton High School
 Brooklyn, Feb. 26, 1990

HEADLINE: Rostenkowski Plan: A G.O.P. Triumph

BYLINE: By Paul Craig Roberts; Paul Craig Roberts is professor of political economy at the Center for Strategic and International Studies.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In offering a plan to balance the budget by 1994, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, Dan Rostenkowski, was trying to avoid two tax traps. In the process, he fell into a political trap of his own making.
Mr. Rostenkowski wanted to sidetrack both Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's plan to cut the Social Security payroll tax and President Bush's proposal to lower capital gains taxes. In their place, he came up with a plan that plays right into the Republicans' hands. 
Little wonder that the White House has praised his proposal: He has torpedoed the Democrats' image of Republicans, so carefully crafted over the past 10 years, as the party whose fiscal policy favors the rich.
Mr. Rostenkowski has managed to put every element of the caricature of the ''rich man's government'' together in his package: spending cuts that would lower interest rates and raise bond prices; attacks on cost-of-living adjustments; reinstatement of the inflation tax hated by the blue-collar constituency, and regressive consumption taxes that shift the tax burden down the brackets. How can any Republican fault him? Specifically, Mr. Rostenkowski wants to save $105 billion by freezing most Federal spending programs for a year, including cost-of-living adjustments for Social Security.
To this attack on Democratic spending programs, he adds a $200 billion tax hike. The rich, whose top tax rates would rise from 28 percent to 33 percent, would pay $44 billion -or 23 percent. The remaining 77 percent would come from middle- and lower-income taxpayers.
A little more than half would be raised by consumption and pollution taxes: an additional 20 cents a gallon on gasoline and a doubling of the taxes on beer, wine and cigarettes. About $50 billion, or 27 percent of the new revenues, would come from a one-year suspension of tax indexing that prevents workers from being taxed on cost-of-living adjustments that merely compensate for inflation.
Adding a 3 percent cut in military spending that is probably in the cards anyway and $62 billion in interest savings from a lower deficit, Mr. Rostenkowski comes up with a total deficit reduction of $511 billion - enough to please bond holders by producing a $34 billion surplus by 1995.
Mr. Rostenkowski says that his attack on his party's constituencies is motivated by the need for a balanced budget: ''Our budget deficit limits our ability to deal with problems at home and abroad,'' he said. It is impossible for Republicans to hear such music without dancing.
If Mr. Rostenkowski's proposal attracts Congressional support, it will signal the triumph of traditional Republicanism. However, few Democrats may find the deficit so compelling a problem as to want to balance the budget on their constituents' backs. This is especially the case now that Congress sees that the alleged benefits of a balanced budget - lower interest rates and a stronger dollar -are either nonexistent or undesirable.
Supposedly, interest rates will fall when the budget is balanced. Then why do West Germany, with its trade surplus, and Britain, with its budget surplus, have higher long-term interest rates than the U.S.?
Supposedly, the dollar will rise in value when the budget is balanced. But why try to drive the dollar up when we are simultaneously supporting massive central bank intervention to drive the dollar down? Moreover, if ''twin deficits'' explained currency values, it wouldn't be the Japanese yen that is now falling.
The traditional case for a balanced budget no longer makes sense. Today capital markets are international, and the Federal Reserve Board has lost much of its power to sway U.S. interest rates. If other countries raise their interest rates, we have to let ours go up too in order to stay competitive. This competitive pressure is independent of the budget.
Slaying the deficit dragon won't do a thing to lower interest rates or raise the dollar. But raising taxes could put the economy in the tank. And won't that do wonders for the deficit?

HEADLINE: Panel Seeks at Least $5 Billion to Improve Child Care in U.S.

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN

 BODY:
A new study by a panel of the National Academy of Sciences concludes that the nation's child care services are inadequate and calls on the Government to allocate an additional $5 billion to $10 billion a year to improve them.
The report, released yesterday, also recommends that the Federal Government require employers to offer a year of unpaid leave to workers, with their jobs protected until they return, for each baby. The report also calls for development of national standards that set limits on the ratio of children to staff in day care centers and on the number of children who should be kept together in one group, and that set requirements for training and for physical space and facilities.
The report comes at a time when Congress is debating the amount of money the Federal Government will spend on child care. The House leadership said this week that a bill the Senate has passed to help low-income families pay for child care is likely to go to the floor later this month after being stalled for months in the House. 
Including Head Start, tax credits and other subsidies, the panel estimated, the Federal Government now spends about $6.8 billion a year on child care. The report, which did not say where the new money should come from, said the priorities should be to expand Head Start, increase child care subsidies for low-income families and ''strengthen the infrastructure of the child care system'' by steps like improving the training and wages of child care workers.
 
'Quality Matters'
''This report establishes that quality matters, that it matters even more for low-income families and that it doesn't come cheap,'' said John L. Palmer, dean of Syracuse University's Maxwell School of Citizenship and Public Affairs, the chairman of the panel that wrote the report. ''A strong base of research over the last 10 years has shown that the quality of child care influences a child's emotional and cognitive development. And we know what constitutes good care.''
The report, which reviewed existing child care studies, was produced by a panel convened by the National Research Council, the research arm of the National Academy of Sciences, at the request of the Department of Health and Human Services, which may use it as background or as a basis for administrative or legislative action.
The report, a 347-page book called ''Who Cares for America's Children?,'' will be available in late April from National Academy Press.
Because the nation's child care system is such a patchwork of arrangements, from formal day care centers to care in the home by relatives or neighbors, the panel said it was impossible to determine the number of openings in day care that exist nationwide. Nor does the report favor any form of day care over another.
''High-quality and low-quality care can be found among all types of services, whether they are provided in the child's home or outside it, in schools, child care centers, or family day care homes, in programs operated for profit or those operated not for profit,'' said the report.
 
Concerns Over Poor Children
But the panel concluded that only a small percentage of the child care available today meets the standards of good care and that poor children are especially likely to receive poor-quality care that threatens their development. And it said most Federal child care spending is no longer directed at low-income families, as it was in the past.
One of the crucial problems in day care, the report said, is high turnover in staff, with about 40 percent of the nation's day care workers leaving their jobs each year, in large part because of low salaries and poor benefits. According to studies cited in the report, most women who care for children in their own homes earn less than the minimum wage, and the average hourly wage for workers at day care centers in 1988 was $5.35.
Almost half the nation's day care centers are for-profit operations, the report said, and for-profit day care centers consistently spend a smaller portion of their budgets on wages and have fewer staff workers for each child than not-for-profit centers.
 
Some States Set Standards
While family day care, or care provided in a home, is often unlicensed and unregulated, almost every state has established rules on the number of workers there must be in relationship to the number of children at formal day care centers. But there is great variation in the rules. For example, North Dakota requires a worker for every seven 3-year-olds, but Arizona, North Carolina and Texas permit one worker for 15 children.
The report recommends national standards requiring that centers provide at least one child care worker for every four babies under 2 years of age. For 2-year-olds, it said, the acceptable range is one worker for every three to six children. For 3-year-olds, it suggests one worker for every five to ten children; and for 5-year-olds, one worker for every seven to ten children.
The report also recommended limits on the number of children in one group or class. Only six to eight babies under 1 year old should be kept in one group, the report said, while 1- and 2-year-olds may be kept in groups of 6 to 12, 3-year-olds in groups of 14 to 20, and 4- and 5-year-olds in groups of 16 to 20. The report said the standards should also limit group size to 6 to 8 for babies under 1 year of age, 6 to 12 for 1- and 2-year-olds, 14 to 20 for 3-year-olds and 16 to 20 for 4- and 5-year-olds.
The report notes that the United States lags behind almost all industrialized countries in its efforts to address child care needs and parental leave.
The panel found that ''developmentally appropriate care, provided in safe and healthy environments, has been shown to enhance the well-being of young children.'' By enabling the parents to work, the report said, good child care can enhance the families' economic status and the parents' personal and career development.

HEADLINE: Big Splash for 'a Basketball Guy';
UConn's Calhoun Went From Success to Struggle to Success

BYLINE: By MALCOLM MORAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, March 14

 BODY:
It wasn't really necessary for the sun to come up Monday morning. For as the regulars came into the Sugar Shack, on the edge of the University of Connecticut campus in Storrs, the afterglow would have been more than enough.
The coffee is on the house when the Huskies win a Big East game, and there had been a lot of free coffee lately. The Huskies were Big East champions, and the No. 1 seeded team in the East Regional, and they would be playing a first-round game at the Hartford Civic Center against Boston University on Thursday evening. 
Sometime before 9 o'clock on Monday, Jim Calhoun stopped by as he has since his first season three years ago, when his team lost 19 games, several players became ineligible for academic reasons, a baseball player named Greg Economou suddenly became a starter, and there were clouds in the coach's coffee.
 
Hard Offer to Refuse
''I congratulated him,'' said Nick Buonocore, the owner of the shop and a 1966 Connecticut graduate. ''He said, 'How would you like the trophy?' ''I looked at him. 'What?' ''He said, 'How would you like the trophy?' ''I said, 'Are you kidding?' ''
Would the coach of the Huskies kid about a thing like that? Calhoun walked outside to his car and created the biggest stir to hit a doughnut shop in the state of Connecticut since Ivan Boesky was seen at the Mister Donut in Stamford.
Calhoun returned with a silver cup on a wooden pedestal.
''He said, 'Bring this to the office in a couple of hours,' '' Buonocore remembered. ''He said, 'You earned it.' ''
There are more than a few people in this state who feel that the coach has earned the trophy, too. After five trips to the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament in his 14 years at Northeastern University, Calhoun smiles when he hears about a coach who has become an overnight success.
Eight years ago this month, in the first round of the 1982 tournament, his Northeastern team defeated St. Joseph's, which had reached a regional final the year before. It was a major victory for a growing program, but as Calhoun walked to the interview area, a reminder of the relative obscurity of his situation was waiting in the form of a security officer.
 
A Fateful Call
Calhoun was wearing the wrong color pass. He could not get into the room. It was not until a supervisor had been summoned that the winning coach would be allowed to pass.
His teams won 250 games at Northeastern, an average of 17.9 per season. Calhoun would examine his situation after each year, and he said he would have been happy to stay, and make the N.C.A.A. field, and create a splash now and then. But Connecticut called in 1986, and Calhoun remembers asking himself a question:
''But how far could we go?''
John Toner, the athletic director at the time, appealed to his competitive instincts. Calhoun would have access to resources that Northeastern, for all his achievements there, could never provide. The possibilities that have come to pass, a major-conference championship and No. 1-seeding in the national tournament, provided a challenge.
Then, months later, Calhoun's program still had not acquired an academic adviser, and Cliff Robinson and Phil Gamble were ineligible.
''I woke up days and said, 'What are we doing?' '' Calhoun remembered. ''It wasn't that we were doing the wrong thing. No one was doing bad things. But no one was doing the right things.''
 
Pivotal Year
Now he can look back and see that the problems had been a longterm blessing, because academic-related items that had been specified in his contract suddenly became priorities because of the embarrassment the university suffered.
''The key year for Jim was the year he lost Gamble and Robinson,'' said Dave Gavitt, the Big East commissioner. ''For a guy who had the success he had at Northeastern to be able to have the patience to get through that situation, to not overreact, not be tempted to take a short cut, without that he would not be enjoying this success.''
There are three years left on a seven-year contract, and the recent success has already begun to create the sort of speculation that the fans of the Huskies do not want to hear. The process happens this time each year. Calhoun said he was surprised that he was the object of the rumors.
''I'm not exactly a guy who has been jumping around a lot,'' he said. ''I do have a pretty good job. But I don't think every single coach in the country is trying to get this job.''
 
Another Question
The quiet nervousness in Connecticut is this: If a place with greater possibilities showed an interest, would the coach who was ambitious enough to question How far could we go? begin to ask himself How often can we get this far?
Calhoun said that when the season ended, he would follow the same procedure that has guided his career.
''I assess my situation from a professional standpoint,'' he said. ''Where are we going to go? What can I do here? Basketball certainly has a place in this state, and I'm a basketball guy.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Coach Jim Calhoun cutting down the netting after Connecticut beat Syracuse at Madison Square Garden on Sunday. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Negotiators Led to Water but Don't Drink

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Negotiators in baseball's labor dispute saw each other in Manhattan yesterday, but they did not negotiate.
The absence of talks in the owners' four-week-old spring training lockout was not new, but at least the dispute brought the two sides together for a hearing before baseball's arbitrator, George Nicolau.
The Players Association asked Nicolau to order the owners to place $51.6 million in escrow as the minimum amount of damages the union says the owners will have to pay as a result of the collusion case involving players who were free agents after the 1986 season. 
Nicolau, who has yet to rule on the damage phase of the case, took the union's request under advisement. He asked for a transcript of the hearing by tomorrow.
On the bargaining front, meanwhile, no one said or did anything that brought the players and owners closer together in their efforts to negotiate a new collective-bargaining agreement.
Each side continued to hold to its position on the salary arbitration eligibility issue, but for the first time this week, Charles O'Connor, the owners' labor negotiator, was not available to reporters by the end of the business day, leading to speculation that he and his aides were working on something new or different.
However, in recent days, O'Connor and some of the owner-members of the Player Relations Committee board have said they would not move off their position that arbitration eligibility should remain at three years of major league service. Instead, they have said they would negotiate on their bonus pool proposal under which players with two to three years in the majors would receive post-season bonuses from a $4 million pool.
On the side issue of collusion damages, the association contends that based on testimony of the clubs' own expert economist, Louis Guth, and their exhibits, the least the damages would be for the salary shortfall in the 1987 and 1988 seasons is $51.6 million. The players want the clubs to have to relinquish that amount now rather than have it for their use in supporting their lockout.
The owners' lawyers argued at the two-hour hearing yesterday that they shouldn't have to do anything with any amount of money until Nicolau renders a decision on the whole matter of damages. Furthermore, they said, the arbitrator shouldn't do anything now because it would interfere with the negotiations.
The union's lawyers countered by saying it's not their motion that would interfere with the negotiations but the owners' collusion that is interfering because the owners have money that rightfully belongs to the players.
 
Figure Not Disputed
The owners' lawyers questioned somewhat the amount the association seeks for escrow, but they did not disagree vehemently with the number. The association says the total damages for the period in question should be approximately $130 million.
Barring some movement in the negotiations, the next significant development in the dispute is expected to come tomorrow when the commissioner and the league presidents have said they will make the first announcement on the cancellation of regular-season games.
They had decided to wait until the end of the week for the announcement, giving negotiators more time to reach an agreement and maybe salvage the season openers. But the additional time has not produced additional movement.

HEADLINE: The Getty Is Said to Be Weighing Buying 'Irises'

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN

 BODY:
Vincent van Gogh's ''Irises'' is now at the J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., which is considering the purchase of the work, staff members of the museum who declined to be named said yesterday. The painting was bought by Alan Bond, the Australian businessman, for a record $53.9 million at an auction in November 1987 at Sotheby's in New York.
The staff members said that ''Irises'' arrived at the museum last week and that negotiations involving the Getty, Mr. Bond and Sotheby's were taking place. No specifics of the deal are known. 
''The museum has not bought the painting, and I have no further comment,'' said George Goldner, the curator of paintings and drawings at the museum.
John Walsh, the director of the museum, was not at his office yesterday, his secretary said, and he did not return phone messages. Lori Starr, the head of public information for the museum, said the museum would not say anything about the painting.
Matthew Weigman, a spokesman for Sotheby's in New York, said, ''We're not commenting about 'Irises.' ''
 
Recent Gaudy Purchases
In recent months, the Getty, one of the world's wealthiest museums, has been active at auctions, purchasing several expensive and widely admired paintings, including works by Jacopo Pontormo, Edouard Manet and Pierre Auguste Renoir.
The sale to Mr. Bond of ''Irises'' aroused much interest not only for the price paid but also for the terms of the deal Mr. Bond struck with Sotheby's.
When it was revealed last October that half of the price paid by Mr. Bond was financed by a loan from the auction house, and that the collateral for the loan was the painting itself, various dealers, museum officials and others in the art world expressed concern, asserting that the price of ''Irises'' had been inflated because of the loan. Sotheby's has since discontinued using works on sale as collateral.
The New York dealer Richard L. Feigen said yesterday that in lending Mr. Bond the money for ''Irises,'' Sotheby's had ''stimulated the market by giving an incentive to a potential bidder who might not have bid, and thereby they elevated the art market.'' Buoyed by a Falsehood? Critics said that the sale, which came less than a month after the stock market crash of 1987, created a widespread impression that the art market had weathered the financial crisis. They said the spectacular price paid for ''Irises'' smoothed the way for a subsequent series of high-priced sales at auctions of Impressionist and modern paintings, including the $51.3 million paid for Picasso's ''Pierrette's Wedding,'' in November, and the $47.9 million paid in May for a Picasso self-portrait.
''Every painting sold since then has been measured against it,'' the director of fine arts at the Didier Aaron gallery in New York, Alan E. Salz, said of the ''Irises'' sale.
Mr. Bond, who still owes an undisclosed portion of the $27 million loan to Sotheby's (it is not known how much more Mr. Bond may owe in interest), is reportedly more than $5.5 billion in debt because of the failure of several of his businesses. He owns brewing, communications and real estate companies. In November, he sold a painting by Manet to help repay the debt to Sotheby's.
He had also been offering ''Irises,'' independent of the auction house, for roughly $65 million to Japanese and other collectors during the last six months, said one collector familiar with the Impressionist market who asked not to be identified.
Before Mr. Bond bought it, the painting was owned by John Whitney Payson, who agreed, Sotheby's said, to allow financing under the condition that the auction house assume all risk. Mr. Whitney had the work on long-term loan to a small museum in Maine.
