HEADLINE: A New Assault On Brazil's Woes

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRASILIA, March 14

 BODY:
Harried by hyperinflation and mounting debts, a new young economic team takes office here Thursday carrying blueprints of free-market reforms designed to turn Brazil into an economic world power this decade.
The team, led by Zelia Cardoso de Mello, the 36-year-old Economy Minister, is of the same generation as Brazil's 40-year-old President, Fernando Collor de Mello, who also takes office Thursday.
Prepared to act quickly, Mr. Collor and Miss Cardoso are expected on Friday to start a muscular economic package that will be a frontal assault on Brazil's long-entrenched tradition of Government controls administered by a huge bureacracy, state-owned enterprises and monopolies. They also plan an attack on Brazil's 80 percent monthly inflation rate by slashing spending and raising tax collection.
To restore high growth rates to Latin America's largest economy, the team plans to lower barriers to foreign investment and to imports. 
 
Bank Holiday Declared
To calm nervous markets, the central bank here declared a surprise bank holiday on Tuesday that will keep banks closed the rest of this week.
With an eye toward the failure of President Carlos Saul Menem in neighboring Argentina to gradually control inflation, Mr. Collor has repeatedly warned members of the Brazilian Congress that, ''I have only one bullet in my gun.''
''Collor has learned that the only way you get the tail off the cat is with a whack,'' one American economic analyst here said today.
On Friday, Mr. Collor's hatchet will be aimed squarely at Brazil's hyperinflation: In the 12 months ended in February, consumer prices here increased 2,751 percent. Restaurant patrons complain that the cost of their meals goes up as they eat. Shoppers complain that prices are marked up while they wait in checkout lines.
''On March 15, we will declare a state of war against inflation,'' Mr. Collor vowed last Sunday in a nationally televised interview.
While previous leaders have made similar declarations, Mr. Collor's plans will be bolstered by the mandate of Brazil's first fully democratic Presidential election in 29 years.
In that election last November, several candidates argued that Brazil's inflation was caused by the payments due on the $114 billion foreign debt.
But Mr. Collor, an admirer of Margaret Thatcher, advanced a different argument, saying his country's inflation is largely caused by printing money to cover Brazil's yawning Government budget deficit.
Another arrow in Mr. Collor's quiver is a further devaluation of Brazil's currency, the new cruzado. Following a 10.2 percent devaluation this week, he is thought to be planning to reduce its value by an additional 30 percent. In January 1989, when the new cruzado was introduced, it was worth $1. Now, it is worth a little more than 2 cents.
To attack the deficit, Miss Cardoso has vowed to lay off a third of the 140,000 civil servants hired by the departing President, Jose Sarney, and to sell one state company a month to private investors during Mr. Collor's five-year term. This would mean selling about one-third of Brazil's 188 state industries.
In addition, she plans to cut out a third of Brazil's $5.5 billion worth of subsidies and tax incentives.
Many measures are to be undertaken as Presidential decrees, which means the changes go into effect immediately, but remain subject to approval by Congress within 30 days. Mr. Collor's Congressional leaders say they have forged a center-right majority to support his program.
But Brazil's left-wing civil service unions have vowed to fight the sales of state companies to private buyers.
To raise tax collection, Mr. Collor delegated Romeu Tuma, general director of the Federal Police, to run Brazil's equivalent of the Internal Revenue Service.
On making the appointment last week, Mr. Collor estimated that 7 percent of Brazil's official gross domestic product of $303 billion goes uncollected in taxes. This amount is the equivalent of Brazil's entire Federal payroll.
While Miss Cardoso and Mr. Tuma will work from diffferent ends to close Brazil's budget gap, Ibrahim Eris, the new central bank president, is to serve as guardian of the currency.
''The central bank will not be a cemetery for money,'' Mr. Eris, a 44-year-old American-trained economist, vowed after winning Senate confirmation last week. ''It will not be treated like a commercial bank, nor a press for printing money. It will act as a true guardian of the money.''
 
Three Successive Currencies
During the Sarney years, Brazil drifted through three successive currencies - the cruzeiro, the cruzado and the current, cruzado novo. During Mr. Sarney's five-year term, the central bank had six presidents. For months, Mr. Collor has argued that Brazil needs a ''credibility shock.'' Seeking to restore seriousness to Government here, he has introduced most of his 12 Cabinet members to the press saying that the appointments are for five years.
Symbolizing his determination to reduce Government, Mr. Collor has reduced the number of ministries from 23 to 12. In practice, this has created ''superministries.''
Ozires Silva, who will direct the privatization program, will bear the title Minister of Infrastructure. With a payroll of half a million workers, this mammoth ministry combines the former ministries of transport, communications and mines and energy.
Zelia Cardoso de Mello - no relation to the President - will be responsible as Economy Minister for the former ministries of finance, planning and industry and commerce.
''She is going to have a difficult time mananging the machine,'' the Sao Paulo representative of a New York bank said of Miss Cardoso, who was largely unknown until she emerged last year as Mr. Collor's principal economic adviser.
 
Previous Experience
The Sao Paulo economist's previous experience with national Government came in 1986, when she worked with the Finance Minister, Dilson Funaro, in an anti-inflation plan that froze prices but failed to close the budget gap.
Miss Cardoso has promised that this time there will be no price freezes. But fearing a freeze, supermarket owners have increased prices in the last two weeks by as much as 170 percent.
And Rio's O Globo newspaper predicted today that the Friday package will contain a ''one-to-three-month'' wage and price freeze to start the economy in the direction of Mr. Collor's year-end goal of bringing inflation down to 10 percent a month.
''I hope the measures work out, but without a freeze,'' Sandra Piraja, a 23-year-old college student, said today in Rio as she stood in one of the many lines that formed in front of automatic bank tellers. ''We know that freezes don't work.''
For the long run, Miss Cardoso promised the gradual abandonment of a decades-old policy that automatically raises wages, rents and the terms of private and public contracts according to the monthly rise in inflation.
 
Desire for Debt Relief
Also for the long term, Brazil's new economic team plans to renegotiate the nation's $114 billion foreign debt, the largest in the third world. With free-market reforms in place, the economists believe that Brazil will be eligible for the kind of debt relief that the United States Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady mediated last year for Mexico.
Last July, Brazil stopped paying its foreign debt. When Mr. Collor takes office he will inherit arrears of $5 billion. Buy he is determined not to allow the debt to block growth and he has repeatedly vowed to cut Brazil's annual service payments in half.
''We will not sacrifice Brazilian economic growth because of the foreign debt,'' Miss Cardoso said at a news conference here two weeks ago. But she added quickly: ''We don't want confrontation - we want negotiation.''
In recent years, Brazil has serviced its debt by running up large trade surpluses. In 1988, the $19 billion surplus was the third largest in the world, after Japan and West Germany. In 1989, the trade surplus fell 16 percent, to $16 billion.

HEADLINE: Company News;
Combined Net Off at SmithKline Beecham

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. said yesterday that it was encountering delays in reaping the benefits of the trans-Atlantic merger that created the giant pharmaceuticals and household products company last July.
As it announced consolidated annual results for the first time, SmithKline Beecham said net income in 1989, after $559 million in charges from the merger, declined 64.5 percent, to $209 million, from $591 million in 1988. Profits before the charges were $766 million, up 1.5 percent from $755 million in 1988. 
Combined 1989 sales were $7.9 billion, up 13.9 percent from $6.93 billion in combined sales in 1988. British pounds were converted at $1.61, the rate on Dec. 31.
Analysts said interest charges on SmithKline's $3.19 billion debt were responsible for the flat profits.
 
In Line With Expectations
Robert P. Bauman, SmithKline's chief executive, said the company, which was created by merging Beecham P.L.C. of Britain and the SmithKline Beckman Corporation of the United States, was ''pleased with the financial results, which were in line with our expectations.'' But he added in a telephone interview from London that he was ''disappointed'' by delays in finding a buyer for the Yardley and other European cosmetics lines. Money from a cosmetics sale could be used to reduce debt.
''Some of the major trade buyers like Unilever chose to make another acquisition,'' Mr. Bauman said. Unilever P.L.C. bought five cosmetics companies last year, including Faberge Inc. and Elizabeth Arden, for more than $2 billion. SmithKline's efforts to sell the cosmetics units were complicated when the Schering-Plough Corporation put its Maybelline line up for sale. Rising interest rates in Britain and investor concerns about corporate debt added to SmithKline's problems.
Mr. Bauman said he would not accept an unreasonably low price for Yardley. ''It has to be a transaction that makes sense to us,'' he said. The asking price has fallen to below $700 million, from $900 million last year.
 
Analysts Defer Judgment
Several analysts said they were deferring judgment on SmithKline's prospects. ''We probably won't know how well it's going for another six months,'' said Robert H. Uhl, an analyst with Salomon Brothers.
As for Tagamet, the ulcer drug that lost sales momentum last year, pushing SmithKline Beckman into the merger, Mr. Bauman said its sales stayed at ''just over $1 billion'' last year, with worldwide unit sales rising 9 percent. Tagamet has lost patent protection in Britain and will also lose protection in the United States in 1994, after which Mr. Bauman expects ''a substantial drop'' in Tagamet sales.
On a more positive note, he said the company's combined pharmaceutical sales force of 6,000 had helped raise worldwide sales of Augmentin, an antibiotic, by almost 30 percent, to ''over $500 million.'' He said worldwide sales of Dyazide, a SmithKline blood pressure drug, rose 30 percent after disclosures of improper practices forced American makers of low-priced generic versions of Dyazide to withdraw their products.

HEADLINE: Auto Sales Continue to Post Declines

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 14

 BODY:
Sales of domestically produced cars and light trucks continued to decline in early March, falling 3.8 percent compared with the comparable period of 1989.
That follows a 7.9 percent decline at the end of February. But some analysts said the latest weak results were balanced by strong sales in January, giving the first quarter a generally healthy appearance. New-car inventories currently stand at relatively healthy levels, but auto companies have given up profits by cutting production and paying hefty customer incentives. 
''After the strong sales in the beginning of the year, it's normal to see some cooling down and for rebates to lose some of their magic,'' said Scott Merlis, an analyst at Morgan Stanley.
 
No Impact on Production Seen
Car sales fell 3.3 percent and sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 6.3 million in the first 10 days of the month, falling behind last year's lackluster rate of 6.4 million for the similar period. The current rate is well below the 7.1 million rate for the first two months of the year.
Sales of light trucks were down even more, falling 4.6 percent, in early March from the comparable period last year. For the year, truck sales are up 3.2 percent.
The current downturn probably will not affect production plans for the second quarter, Mr. Merlis and other analysts said.
''Even if sales rates remain at this level for the rest of March, inventories would remain healthy and production plans for the second quarter would remain intact,'' said Mr. Merlis.
Still, the number of cars and light trucks that the nation's auto makers plan to build in the second quarter remains 6.4 percent below levels a year ago, according to Ward's Automotive Reports, an industry newsletter.
 
Big Three Down
The Big Three suffered sales declines for both cars and light trucks, while the Japanese producers in the United States all posted sales gains. Together, car sales by the Big Three were down 7.7 percent, while Japanese car sales were up 48.1 percent.
The combined market share of the five Japanese ''transplants'' in cars rose to 12 percent of sales in early March, compared with 7.9 percent a year earlier.
Sales of cars made by the General Motors Corporation fell 7.1 percent, to 76,675, and sales of G.M. light trucks declined by 3.1 percent, to 43,485.
The Ford Motor Company sold 49,734 cars, a decline of 8.1 percent from the comparable period last year, and 35,462 light trucks, down 3.1 percent from a year earlier.
The Chrysler Corporation's car sales were down 9.1 percent, to 20,208, while sales of light trucks fell 13.4 percent, to 20,033 units.
''It's a fight,'' said Robert Brest, the owner of Bob Brest Chevrolet in Lynn, Mass. ''We're fighting against the economy. People are still afraid to make any major outlays of cash.''
 
Japanese Gains
The Japanese producers that manufacture cars in the United States continued to steadily add sales and market share.
Honda of America Inc. sold 8,919 cars in early March, an increase of 2.4 percent. Mazda North America Inc.'s car sales rose 53.5 percent, to 1,331. Mitsubishi Motor Sales of America Inc. sold 1,122 cars, and Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A. sold 6,797 cars, both sizable increases that reflect new production capacity at their plants.
The Nissan Motor Corporation U.S.A.'s car sales increased 17.4 percent, to 1,964, while its light-truck sales grew 25 percent, to 3,372.
Harvey Heinbach, an analyst with Merrill Lynch, predicted that sales of cars made by Japanese transplants will continue to climb ''for the foreseeable future.''
''The Japanese producers continue to add capacity,'' Mr. Heinbach said. ''They are broadening their product lines and their distribution systems, adding more dealers in the Midwest, where they weren't that well represented.''

HEADLINE: Fed Survey Shows Growth Remains at a Sluggish Pace

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 14

 BODY:
The nation's economy continues to grow despite widespread weakness in the auto industry and a gradual slowing in construction activity, according to a survey by the 12 Federal Reserve banks published today.
''Most Federal Reserve districts describe economic activity as expanding slowly,'' said a summary report prepared by the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago.
''The weakness in autos and auto-related industries, however, is widespread,'' it said. 
The report was based on information gathered from business and other contacts before March 6. A different Fed bank prepares such a summary about every six weeks for Fed policy meetings.
 
Consumer Spending Steady
Consumer spending, the main force in the nation's economic growth, continues to be moderate to strong, with the exception of auto sales, which fell after a January rebound, the Fed said.
Manufacturing activity was reported to be mixed, with Boston, Philadelphia and St. Louis reporting declines but most other districts reporting moderate improvement.
Construction was sluggish in most districts, the Fed said, including New York, where residential building has slowed because of high prices and weak demand. ''Most observers are not anticipating a pickup in 1990,'' the Fed said.
The report noted that financial institutions were less willing to extend credit or were tightening credit terms for many types of real estate loans.
''Loan demand also appears to be softening,'' the Fed said, especially for commercial and industrial loans. The New York Fed said loan demand was below levels a year ago despite recent widespread declines in interest rates.
Farm incomes were buoyed by prospects of good winter wheat crops, according to Fed banks in Richmond, St. Louis and Kansas City, Mo. Freeze damage to fruits and vegetables in December pushed produce prices up to the highest levels since 1984 in the Atlanta and Dallas districts.
Resource industries, like mining and forestry, were strong. And oil and gas drilling in the Southwest was up sharply.
Several Fed districts, including Minneapolis and San Francisco, singled out the continuing rise in health care costs as a cause for concern.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Money-Fund Yields Rise

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were up for the week ended yesterday.
Analysts expect these yields to remain near their present levels for the near term, while the Federal Reserve continues its policy of taking no action to influence short-term rates. They said the concern over rising interest rates abroad, which were exerting pressure on interest rates in the United States, was subsiding. 
Donoghue's seven-day compounded average yield for taxable money funds was up from a week earlier by 2 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 7.94 percent. The 30-day average yield was unchanged, at 7.93 percent.
 
Decline in Assets
Assets of taxable funds fell by $870 million in the reporting week, to $383.7 billion, with institutional funds accounting for all the decline. Institutional funds fell by $934 million, to $80.6 billion. Analysts speculated that institutional money managers might have gone to the open market, where rates have risen faster.
The average days to maturity of securities held in managers' portfolios was up by one day, to 43.
Among general-purpose money market funds with assets of more than $100 million surveyed by IBC/ Donoghue, the Harbor Money Market Fund, distributed by HCA Securities Inc. of Toledo, Ohio, reported the best return for the week, at 8.88 percent.
Yields of tax-exempt funds were up for the second consecutive week, perhaps reflecting an increase in the supply of new issues relative to stable demand.
 
Average Yield at 5.28%
Assets increased by $26 million, to $77.6 billion, with the average seven-day compounded yield up 7 basis points, to 5.28 percent.
The taxable equivalent for investors in the 28 percent tax bracket is 7.33 percent, and 7.88 percent for investors in a 33 percent bracket.
Donoghue's said the top tax-free yield this week was offered by both the Calvert Tax-Free Reserves Money Market Fund, distributed by the Calvert Group of Washington, D.C., and the Evergreen Trust Tax-Exempt Money Market Fund, distributed by the Saxon Woods Asset Management Corporation in Harrison, N.Y. Each had a return of 5.85 percent. The top yield was about 57 basis points higher than the seven-day average.
Managers also lowered their average days to maturity by a day, to 47, taking advantage of last week's higher rates.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Securities Prices Rebound

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rebounded yesterday, continuing a recent pattern of highly erratic movement.
The gains, which amounted to more than a point, or more than $10 for each $1,000 face amount of securities, erased big declines recorded Tuesday.
Market participants said that yesterday's bounce was caused by three disparate developments: a very weak report on 10-day auto sales that traders expect to help keep pressure on the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates; a rumor that members of the Group of Seven had not agreed on a common strategy to control the dollar, and an announcement from Columbia Savings and Loan, the big California institution, that it intends to sell its $3.5 billion portfolio of high-yield ''junk bonds.'' Concern that Columbia might unload such a large portfolio prompted some buying of high-quality Treasury securities. 
By contrast, the reaction to a report on economic conditions from the Federal Reserve's 12 regional banks was quite muted. In language strikingly similar to the last report, issued on Jan. 24, the so-called beige book said that economic activity expanded slowly in the roughly six-week period ending in early March.
''It seemed like the Fed went out of its way to issue a neutral report,'' said Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J., firm that provides research and commentary on the foreign exchange and credit markets. ''It seems they are trying to sell the idea that slow growth is good.''
 
Trading Volume Is Thin
Despite the big upward movement in prices, dealers said that trading volume was thin.
''The market is not functioning well in the sense that it is bouncing up and down by about 10 basis points each day on very ephemeral news,'' said James R. Capra, a senior vice president at Shearson Lehman Government Securities. A basis point is one- hundredth of a percentage point.
Once again, prices of long-term Treasury notes and bonds were the most volatile.
In late trading, the 8 1/2 percent bonds of 2020 were offered at 98 30/32, up more than a point, to yield 8.60 percent. That compares with a yield of 8.70 percent late Tuesday.
Among note issues, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered late yesterday at 99 6/32, up 17/32, to yield 8.62 percent. And the 8 1/2 percent five-year notes were offered at 99 11/32, up 9/32, to yield 8.65 percent.
 
Treasury Bill Rates Ease
Treasury bill rates eased slightly.
By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.91 percent, down four basis points. Six-month bill rates fell by three basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.85 percent. And one-year bills were offered late yesterday at 7.78 percent, down five basis points.
Fears that Columbia Savings might choose to dump its entire high-yield portfolio onto the market sent shivers through the junk bond market. Prices were off generally between a quarter- and a half-point in thin trading. However, details of how the bonds might be dispatched were sketchy, and some analysts said that under certain circumstances the liquidation could be beneficial.
''There was nervousness at first that the bonds would be put on top of the market,'' said Kingman Penniman, a high-yield specialist at McCarthy, Crisanti & Maffei, a bond ratings and research firm.
But he said the market began to get the perception that they would be placed privately. He added that ''if these bonds are taken out of circulation that has to be a positive in terms of bringing the market closer to a balance between supply and demand.''
In the mortgage-backed securities market, Bear, Stearns & Company acted as lead manager on the pricing of a $1.275 billion issue of Remic, or real estate mortgage investment conduit, securities from the Federal National Mortgage Association.
The Remic issue is the largest derivative mortgage-backed deal in the seven-year history of the market.
The issue consists of 17 parts, all of which are backed by Fannie Mae's 9 1/2 percent bonds of 2020.
A number of new issues were priced in the investment-grade corporate bond market, including a $150 million issue of 10-year notes for the International Paper Corporation.
The 9.70 percent notes, which are noncallable for life, were priced at $99.87 to yield 9.72 percent, 1.05 percentage points over the prevailing yield on 8 1/2 percent Treasury notes at the time of pricing.
The First Boston Corporation acted as lead manager for the underwriting, which is rated A-3 by Moody's Investors Service and A-minus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Participants in the secondary corporate bond market said that prices of most issues rose by about 1/4 of a point.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, prices of most actively traded issues rose by 1/4 of a point to 3/8 of a point, dealers said.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Outlook on Peruvian Strike Sends Copper Up Sharply

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Copper futures prices climbed sharply yesterday on the Commodity Exchange in New York, reflecting a more optimistic economic outlook and concerns that a strike at Peru's largest copper company could last longer than a few days.
On other markets, precious metals were mixed; coffee and cocoa futures sagged; soybean futures retreated; grains were mixed; livestock and meat were mostly lower, and energy futures were mixed.
Copper futures soared 3.05 cents to 6 cents a pound in New York, with the contract for delivery in March up 6 cents, to $1.25, and the more actively traded April contract up 5.15 cents, to $1.203. Those were the highest copper prices since mid-October. 
The rally began early after the Labor Minister of Peru said he would not mediate talks between workers and management in the three-day-old strike at the Southern Peru Copper Corporation. The company produces about two-thirds of the copper in Peru, the world's eighth-largest producer and second-largest exporter.
The worries about copper supplies were compounded by a Federal Reserve Board report indicating that American manufacturing and industrial production were growing faster than had been perceived.
Coffee and cocoa futures fell sharply on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange, erasing the previous day's gains, after Brazil's currency was devalued overnight. Further devaluation of the cruzado novo is expected after Fernando Collor de Mello is sworn in as President today.
Analysts said the devaluation would likely spur selling by producers of coffee, cocoa and soybeans.
Coffee futures fell 2.55 cents to 3.83 cents a pound, with March settling at 93.60 cents; cocoa settled $15 to $33 lower, with March at $1,080 a ton.
Soybean futures fell sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade in reaction to the Brazilian economic situation and improved soil moisture levels in the Midwest. Corn and oat futures also retreated, while wheat futures rose.
Crude oil futures for near-term delivery settled lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange, but futures on refined products advanced. The action reflected Tuesday's weekly American Petroleum Institute inventory report showing larger United States supplies of crude oil, but smaller supplies of refined products, than the market had expected.
West Texas intermediate crude oil finished 17 cents lower to 15 cents higher, with April at $20.05 a barrel; heating oil was 0.38 cent to 0.51 cent higher, with April at 54.02 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 0.30 cent to 1.46 cents higher, with April at 55.85 cents a gallon.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Drifts Mostly Lower Amid Concern Over Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar drifted mostly lower against other leading currencies in light trading yesterday as traders appeared to be looking for direction.
Traders said there was little domestic economic news to affect currency trading and that concern centered chiefly on speculation about possible increases in Japanese or West German interest rates.
Thomas J. Palladino, a trader with the Amsterdam Rotterdam Bank in New York, said traders appeared to be unsure about the direction of the dollar. 
''Everybody seems to be standing pat, waiting for something to budge them one way or the other,'' he said.
He said traders remained concerned about a rate rise by the Bank of Japan, ''but it's been dragged out so long that it's mostly been discounted.''
 
'Underlying Bullish Tone'
''The market still has an underlying bullish tone to it,'' said Bob Morrissey, a trader with the Bank of Boston. But he added that concerns about possible central bank intervention and overseas rate increases kept the dollar from rising.
The dollar closed in New York at 1.1710 West German marks, down from 1.7120 late Tuesday. Earlier, in Europe, the dollar closed at 1.7131 marks, down from 1.7165.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 152.20 yen, down from 152.67 on Tuesday. In London late yesterday the dollar closed at 152.22 yen. In New York, the dollar bought 152.18 yen, down from 152.20 late Tuesday.
In London, a pound cost $1.6090 late yesterday, up from Tuesday's $1.6005. Later, in New York, a pound cost $1.6103, up from $1.6097 late Tuesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Tuesday, included: 1.15245 Swiss francs, up from 1.5215; 5.7805 French francs, down from 5.7850; 1,263 Italian lire, down from 1,264.50, and 1.1733 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1761.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Tuesday, included: 1.5255 Swiss francs, down from 1.5275; 5.7877 French francs, down from 5.7915; 1.9290 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9312; 1,267 Italian lire, unchanged, and 1.1740 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1775.
Gold prices slipped in New York after rising overseas. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid for gold of $398 an ounce, down 70 cents from late Tuesday. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery also settled at $398 an ounce, down $1.
Gold rose in London to a late bid of $399.05 an ounce, up from $396 late Tuesday. In Zurich, gold closed at $399.25, up from $396 Tuesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold closed at $398.75 bid, up from $398.65.
Silver bullion closed in London at $5.09 an ounce, up from $5.05 Tuesday. In New York, silver bullion closed at $5.081 an ounce on the Commodity Exchange, up from $5.059 late Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Soviet Crisis Worse, Economists Declare

BYLINE: By LEONARD SILK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, March 14

 BODY:
The economic crisis in the Soviet Union is worsening and forcing President Mikhail S. Gorbachev toward a faster and more radical reorganization of the system, say Western and Soviet economists at an international conference here.
Trying to convert the Soviet Union to a market-oriented economy in slow stages, said A. W. Clausen, former president of the World Bank and now chairman of BankAmerica, is ''like trying to extract a tooth slowly.''
Delegates to the conference, sponsored by the Stanford Research Institute, the Soviet Chamber of Commerce and Industry and Deutsche Bank, got a dim view of the results of perestroika thus far. Vladimir A. Tikhonov, president of the U.S.S.R. Union of Cooperatives, said the Soviet economy was ''falling apart.'' 
When asked about charges of corruption at many cooperatives, which he described as the enterprises closest to the Western model, Mr. Tikhonov replied: ''When a society is sick, its institutions are sick. When a mother is sick, her child is likely to be sick.''
 
Further G.N.P. Drop Expected
Anders Aslund, a Swedish economist who is director of the Stockholm Institute of Soviet and Eastern European economies, said that despite Soviet estimates of continued slow growth, the economy was in ''a very serious crisis.'' He estimated that real gross national product fell 4 to 5 percent in 1989 and would plummet 8 to 10 percent this year.
There are severe technical problems in estimating real Soviet G.N.P., because of the suppression of inflation by controls, the paying of under-the-counter prices and bribes, and the disappearance of goods from state stores selling at official prices. Until recently, most American experts on Soviet data have not accepted declines in real output as steep as those offered by Professor Aslund.
But Ed A. Hewett of the Brookings Institution, a leading American expert on Soviet data, said at the conference that the Soviet economy was ''deteriorating at an alarming pace.'' There is no sign of an improvement in the quality of goods and no gain in productivity; the money supply is out of control, and the Soviet credit rating is at its lowest ebb, he said.
The ''reforms'' made thus far, he added, are ''half-hearted,'' and entrepreneurs have still not been given authority to run their enterprises efficiently. ''Prices remain fixed, and fixed wrong,'' he said.
The Soviet economists here did not dispute such assessments. Indeed, high politburo officials have been paying close attention to the analyses made at this meeting. Among the Americans here are Senator Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey and former Senators Edmund S. Muskie of Maine and Gary Hart of Colorado, both now practicing law.
Mr. Clausen saw some positive factors in the Soviet situation, especially the increased stress placed by Mr. Gorbachev and his key supporters on the need for a ''market orientation'' and a ''pluralistic society,'' which, he said, held hope for the future. But he warned that these positive elements were in danger of being overwhelmed by some strongly negative forces.
The G.N.P. ''has turned negative,'' he said, ''and will remain so for the next two years. Soviet policy with respect to attracting foreign investment, he said, was ''unsatisfactory to date,'' and policies to stimulate joint ventures were ''not yet in place.''
Mr. Clausen said the Soviets did not seem to realize that foreign investors had ''real alternatives'' to investing in the Soviet Union, and particularly in Eastern Europe. He told the conference that he had been visiting European countries and asking investors which countries hold the greatest promise for them. ''The Soviet Union does not get many votes,'' he said.
He said it was of the greatest importance that the people trust their Government, and that ''one essential underlies all issues: transparency, gaining the support of the people.''
 
'Not Pessimistic'
Insisting that he was ''not pessimistic about the future of the U.S.S.R.,'' Mr. Clausen urged the Soviet leaders to ''move faster,'' and to concern themselves more with the social welfare. ''There is no social infrastructure in place,'' he said, to protect those hurt by loss of jobs and loss of income that could be expected to result from a radical change toward a market economy.
Fears of such disuption have been delaying the Soviet Government's movement toward a freer economy. Soviet economists have been talking in terms of making the changes in stages, starting with the reduction of the enormous budget deficit, which V. K. Senchagov, chairman of the state committee on prices, said amounts to 165 billion rubles.
There were indications here from Soviet economists that Mr. Gorbachev had distanced himself from the gradualism in the plan for economic reform presented by Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov. They said that during the last few years Mr. Gorbachev had focused on political reforms and had left the economic task to Mr. Ryzhkov and others, but was now dissatisfied with the results. Indeed, there was talk here that Mr. Ryzhkov would be replaced.
Abel Aganbegyan, a Soviet economist who is credited with being a leading pioneer of perestroika, said he welcomed the transition to an executive presidency, in which Mr. Gorbachev would have greater powers, ''especially if he will pay attention to the economy.''

HEADLINE: TRADE TALKS FAIL TO PRODUCE GAINS FOR U.S. OR JAPAN

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 15

 BODY:
Six months after opening talks on the deep-rooted causes of their trade problems, Japan and the United States are dissatisfied with each other's concessions. And the Japanese are fearful that the discussions themselves are making tensions even worse.
Negotiators opened the talks in September, resolving that for the first time the two economic superpowers would set aside the pattern of taking up one narrowly focused dispute after another and instead seek an easing of what they called ''structural impediments'' -deep economic and cultural barriers to American imports to Japan.
That approach came after both Governments realized that more than a decade of negotiations and currency realignments had failed to reduce the American trade deficit with Japan.
 
Tokyo's Condition
Japan agreed to participate on the condition that the talks be considered discussions rather than negotiations, rejecting the idea that the United States had the right to put pressure on Japan in such matters. 
The agenda included basic business and investment practices. Washington complained that the Japanese keep prices high, reduce consumption and permit monopolistic practices, all of which serve as a barrier to imports. The Japanese complained that the United States did not do enough to reduce the Federal budget deficit, encourage savings and invest in education, research and development.
Trade specialists in both countries say they fear that the talks have created demands for changes that could be accomplished only by a broad social revolution that is highly unlikely in either case.
''These talks should never have gotten started,'' said Yoshi Tsurumi, a professor of international business at Baruch College at the City University of New York. ''Japan's structural problems are too embedded in its system to justify the false hopes of resolving them in trade negotiations.''
Echoing the skepticism, Glen S. Fukushima, who resigned at the end of last year as deputy assistant United States trade representative for Japan and China, said it was doubtful that Washington could obtain benefits from the latest talks.
''The talks are a very blunt instrument,'' Mr. Fukushima said. ''The Japanese side may end up choosing structural reforms that will be more beneficial to the Japanese economy than to the U.S. side. For all that we're putting into them, I question whether the talks will be cost-effective.''
Now, the negotiators face an early April deadline for producing an interim report. As some Japanese officials warn that a failure to make progress could lead to a possible rupture in relations with Washington, Japan is assembling a modest package of steps that it hopes will defuse an atmosphere of crisis that followed the talks two weeks ago between President Bush and Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu.
Responding to Congressional pressure, Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, told Tokyo officials recently that the talks should yield at least a ''down payment'' on a ''blueprint'' for action by spring.
Although some last-minute steps could be taken that the negotiators could then pronounce positive, Japanese political leaders and senior bureacrats are divided over how to answer American demands and concerned that the Bush Administration has unrealistic expectations.
''The infighting in the ministries is intense,'' a top Japanese official said. ''We never anticipated that American expectations of the results would get out of hand.'' The Foreign Ministry, for example, would like to accommodate the American request on an increase in public works spending; the Finance Ministry opposes the request, saying it would be inflationary.
After the talks with Mr. Bush, Mr. Kaifu said he would make the trade disputes a top priority of his Cabinet. Going further, Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama asserted this week that trade had become ''a matter of crisis control,'' producing ''a hair-trigger situation'' in which Japan had to act.
Japanese officials say they are preparing proposals to increase spending on public works; tighten enforcement of anti-monopoly business practices, and ease curbs on the the establishment of large retail stores. Such steps could stimulate Japanese consumer spending and improve consumer access of foreign products.
But these officials, who ask not to be identified, acknowledge that their steps fall far short of American demands and will not significantly reduce the trade deficit.
''Whatever we do, it will not affect the trade deficit right away or to a considerable extent,'' a Japanese official said. ''The American negotiators understand that. The problem is that outsiders, especially in Congress, do not understand.''
American officials insist the structural talks are worth pursuing.
''It's a good process, certainly a novel process,'' said Michael H. Armacost, the United States Ambassador to Tokyo. ''It's so novel that it troubles people. But I don't think it's the process that is generating troubles. It's the persistent trade imbalance that is generating trouble.''
But participants in the talks say Japanese officials have already informed the United States that Tokyo cannot accept several American demands, including the elimination of huge interlocking business combines and groupings in Japan.
Such combines, known as keiretsu, have existed since the 19th century. They buy and sell from each other, set prices, restrict the flow of goods and prevent outsiders from entering the market. American officials and business executives view the keiretsu as monopolistic; Japanese officials say these practices are widely accepted, and indeed are a key to Japan's economic success.
Changing these and other practices would strike at the heart of the business groupings that have just contributed about $200 million to the successful re-election campaign of Mr. Kaifu's ruling Liberal Democratic Party, Japanese officials said.
''If you change these practices, the L.D.P. Government cannot survive,'' said a senior trade negotiator who asked not to be identified.
Mr. Kaifu's Government has agreed to take modest steps to improve enforcement of anti-monopoly practices, taking aim at bid-rigging among construction companies. But Japan is rejecting the American request for higher monetary awards to victims of such practices.
The United States is also demanding that Japan do something about the skyrocketing price of land, reasoning that cheaper land would lead to more housing construction, more consumer goods and, possibly, more imported goods.
Under pressures from farmers, Japan is resisting changes that many experts feel could make a difference, like a drastic increase in taxes on farmland, even those in metropolitan areas. Instead, Tokyo is due to promise Washington to review land pricing systematically in the years ahead.
And Prof. Chalmers Johnson of the University of California at San Diego, a specialist in Japanese industrial policy, said: ''These talks could be important because they are taking place at a high level of analysis and sophistication. But they are doomed to failure because Japan will not change voluntarily. To suggest otherwise is self-delusion.''
The structural talks have also been criticized by some people who feel the United States trade deficit is an American, not a Japanese, problem.
''The principal problems in trade are sourced in America,'' said James C. Abegglen, president of Asia Advisory Service, a Tokyo-based consulting company. ''With all due respect, these American criticisms of Japan are none of our business.''
Mr. Abegglen said that if Japan were to modernize its retail distribution system as the United States was asking, there was no guarantee that American exports would increase.
 
Small-Business Power
He was referring to the American suggestion that Japan eliminate, or at least curtail, its retail store law, which allows small businesses in a neighborhood to band together to block the establishment of large stores. Large stores are thought more likely to sell foreign goods.
Mr. Abegglen and others argue, however, that larger stores would not necessarily lead to American products on their shelves. More likely, they said, would be inexpensively made products produced by South Korea, Thailand and other developing countries.''
Also plaguing the talks is that Japan is demanding that the United States be more forthcoming on what Tokyo regards as fundamental problems reducing America's competitiveness and ability to export goods.
The Bush Administration is pointing to its proposed family savings plan, capital gains tax cuts, deficit reduction measures and tax credits for research and development.
A Japanese official said Tokyo was disappointed that these measures were minor in nature and little more than proposals to do something in the future. ''The American list is not very impressive,'' a Japanese official said.

HEADLINE: Bush to Streamline Advisory Panel on Intelligence

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 15

 BODY:
President Bush will soon make major changes in his Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board, converting what has been a wide-ranging watchdog over the intelligence community into a far smaller panel of expert policy advisers, Administration officials said today.
The new panel will apparently be headed by John G. Tower, the former Republican Senator from Texas, Mr. Bush's home state.
Mr. Bush nominated Mr. Tower to be Secretary of Defense last year, but the Senate rejected the choice after an unusually bitter political battle that revolved around assertions that Mr. Tower had a drinking problem.
Mr. Tower denied that he had ever been an alcoholic. In an effort to save his nomination, he pledged to the Senate that he would not consume any alcoholic beverages while Secretary of Defense. 
But a number of the Democratic Senators who voted against him cited the drinking issue as an important factor in considering someone to manage the country's nuclear arsenal and military forces. Questions were also raised about his relations with women. The decision to replace the 15-member advisory board with a more expert panel is potentially important because it could mean an enhanced role for outside consultants in setting the direction of American intelligence agencies.
The intelligence community has traditionally resented outside review of its policies and operations and Mr. Bush, a former Director of Central Intelligence, has found the current panel too large and diffuse to be of much use.
Administration officials said Mr. Bush was likely to give greater weight to a smaller group with more expertise in intelligence matters.
Experts in and out of Government have called on the Administration lately to set a new course for the intelligence community before other constraints like a tightening budget reduce his options.
Among the many issues are whether to collect more information on the United States' economic competitors, rather than its military rivals, and whether to focus some of the intelligence agencies' vast eavesdropping and photography resources on new targets.
 
Tower to Be Named Chairman
Mr. Tower already sits on the current advisory board. He is expected to be named chairman, a post that does not require Senate approval, after the board holds its final meeting in a few weeks. He would then carry the title over to a reconstituted panel. Reached today, Mr. Tower referred questions about his role on the board to the White House.
The White House said it had no comment on reported changes in the panel.
The current board, known by its acronym, PFIAB, held considerable power in intelligence matters under President Reagan.
But Mr. Bush has relegated it to a lesser position and had planned to abolish it, officials said.
In recent months the panel had been all but inactive, and one of its most prominent members, Henry A. Kissinger, resigned last month.
The group's regular bi-monthly meeting, originally scheduled for this week, was cancelled.
Officials said that the board's chairwoman, Anne L. Armstrong, asked to be relieved of her post some time ago, and that it was uncertain whether any of the other board members will be retained on the new panel.
Reached by telephone earlier this week, Mrs. Armstrong declined to comment on changes in the panel.
In conversations with President Bush, Mr. Tower said today, he has stressed the need for a strong advisory board that would report directly to the President.
The present board is a mix of intelligence experts and prominent Republicans appointed as a reward for their political labors.
The new intelligence panel is expected to be half as large as the current board and is likely to include more veterans of senior intelligence positions and experts on technical matters like satellite reconnaissance and electronic eavesdropping, officials said.

HEADLINE: Drug Program Is Said to Curb Peer Pressure

 BODY:
A drug prevention program that teaches high school students ways to resist social pressure can significantly curb marijuana and cigarette smoking, but not alcohol consumption, a three-year study by the Rand Corporation has found.
The $8.8 million study, paid for by the Conrad H. Hilton Foundation, was conducted by Phyllis L. Ellickson and Robert M. Bell, and is published in the current issue of the journal Science.
''Our study explodes three myths about previous school-based prevention programs: that they only help kids who need help least, that they only affect trivial levels of drug use and that they only work in white, middle-class, suburban communities,'' Dr. Ellickson said in an interview.
 
The Degrees of Success
She said the program was as successful in schools with large minority enrollments as in predominantly white schools. 
Dr. Ellickson said the program was designed to motivate youngsters to resist drugs and teach them how. ''It's not enough to tell kids, 'Just say no,' '' she said. ''They need to have reasons that are relevant to their daily lives and social relationships.''
Lauro F. Cavazos, the Secretary of Education, said: ''The Rand study offers further strong evidence that drug education is a critical part of the nation's drug strategy. The report confirms that a key ingredient to any good drug education program is showing students how to confront peer pressure to use drugs.''
The program, Project Alert, tracked 6,500 students, starting with the seventh grade, from 30 junior high schools in urban, rural and suburban communities in California and Oregon. The program was aimed at use of cigarettes, alcohol and marijuana, the drugs youngsters usually use first.
 
Lessons and 'Booster' Lessons
Eight lessons were given for seventh graders and three reinforcement, or ''booster'' lessons were given when those seventh graders reached the eighth grade. Over the next 15 months, as the program was assessed, student questionnaires on substance abuse were backed up - for honesty - by taking saliva tests.
In the first lessons, as the course is designed, students answer questions about how drugs can affect them -smoking yellows teeth and causes bad breath; marijuana and alcohol make one lose control in front of friends -and teachers help students identify pressures on them.
In later classes, the teachers and students come up with ways of saying no, using skits, movies and through the students' own written work.
The participating schools were separated into three groups: 10 in which teachers delivered the lessons, 10 in which teachers were assisted by older teen-agers, and 10 in which nothing was done. These were the ''control'' schools, for comparisons.
 
When Effective, When Not
The researchers reported that the substance abuse education was more effective against marijuana and tobacco than against alcohol and that it was more effective for non-users and experimenters than for users.
Students in the program were found a third less likely to try marijuana than students who had not taken part in the program. The project also reduced the ''experimenting'' by 50 percent.
For students who had tried cigarettes, the program reduced smoking from 30 to 50 percent, but did not help confirmed smokers. Their smoking increased.
The program made some gains on use of alcohol for those in the seventh grade, but because, in large part, of alcohol's acceptance by society, the gains had disappeared by the time the students were in the eighth grade. Why Seventh Graders? Contrary to expectations, using older teen-agers in classroom instruction did not produce better results than having teachers work on their own, the researchers reported.
Dr. Ellickson said seventh graders were chosen because their use of cigarettes and marijuana was still relatively low, and also because, at a seventh grader's point in life, pressures intensify and unchecked drug use more than doubles in the tenth grade.
The researchers are continuing to assess the students' progress through high school. Dr. Ellickson said she would report results in a year or two. ''We're hopeful about maintaining the some earlier gains, but we think that it may be important to add additional booster sessions in high school,'' she said.
 
Looking to Wide Availability
The Hilton Foundation plans to make the program available throughout the country, said Donald H. Hubbs, the foundation's president. But the costs, financing and timing have not been determined, Mr. Hubbs said.
William J. Bennett, the director of the national drug control policy office, said last week that he supports drug education but that it was crucial ''to determine how well it works, when it works and also when it does not work.''
Donald Hamilton, a spokesman for the Bennett office, said officials there had not yet seen the Rand report. ''We believe drug education works, but that it must be part of a larger package,'' Mr. Hamilton said. ''Studies we have shown that school policies on drug use are at least as important as curriculum.''

CORRECTION-DATE: March 17, 1990, Saturday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about a drug prevention program that was described in the journal Science referred incorrectly to participating students. They attended junior high school, not high school.

HEADLINE: New Poll Indicates Confusion Among Voters on Democrats

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 15

 BODY:
A new poll conducted for a Democratic group underscores what many Democrats feared: The voters have little sense of what the Democratic-controlled Congress is doing.
The poll found that 61 percent of voters, and 62 percent of Democratic voters, could volunteer no response to the question, ''What issues do you think the Democrats in Congress are handling best?'' A majority of voters were also unable to answer a question about what the Democrats were handling poorly.
The poll, conducted by telephone Feb. 26 through March 1 with 1,494 people who described themselves as registered voters, was produced for Democrats for the 90's, a Washington advocacy group for the Democratic Party. 
 
A Time of Worry
The poll was carried out by the polling firms Greenberg-Lake, the Analysis Group and the Garin-Hart Strategic Research Group, and the margin of sampling error was plus or minus three percentage points.
The survey comes at a time when many Democrats are worried about a lack of Democratic figures of national stature and their trouble conveying a clear image to the public.
Many Democrats had hoped that their Congressional leadership could fill the void left by three straight defeats in Presidential elections, but others fear that a legislative body simply cannot compete with the White House for the public's attention.
 
Bush's Rating Was High
Like other surveys, the poll found President Bush to be extraordinarily popular, although the poll takers said much of his support was soft.
It also indicated that voters put more confidence in the Republicans than in the Democrats on most economic issues and in the general ability to lead the country: 41 percent said the G.O.P. would do a better job in leadership, while 34 percent said the Democrats would.
Areas were also found that could be seen as Democratic opportunities. When asked about the country generally, 46 percent said it was headed in the right direction and 33 percent said it was on the wrong track. But those numbers were reversed when voters focused on the nation's economic situation: 49 percent said it was on the wrong track; 36 percent said it was headed in the right direction.

HEADLINE: ABROAD AT HOME;
The Cost of Fanaticism

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

 BODY:
Nancy Klein of Long Island, 10 weeks pregnant, was severely injured in a car crash on Dec. 13, 1988. For two months she was in a coma. Doctors had little hope that she would come out of it, but they thought she might have a better chance if she had an abortion. Her husband, Martin, told them to go ahead.
At that point two men who did not know the Klein family, members of Long Island Right to Life, went to court to stop the abortion. Mr. Klein had to fight them through three state courts and the Supreme Court of the United States before the case was finally dismissed. 
Mrs. Klein had the abortion. It allowed her to have new medication and intensive rehabilitation therapy. She responded amazingly well. She came out of the coma. Now she can talk, dress herself, express her love for her family. Her doctors say she is still making progress.
That story tells us something about the extremist opponents of abortion. In their concern for a fetus they were prepared to condemn Nancy Klein to exist in a coma without end. In their zeal for potential life they wrote off a living woman.
The belief that abortion is wrong is a view that deserves respect. But in this country some people in the anti-abortion movement have carried opposition long past the bounds of reason and humanity.
Item. Scientists for the first time have hope of reversing the course of Parkinson's disease. The hope lies with experiments in which they have alleviated the symptoms by implanting fetal cells in the brains of Parkinson's patients.
But the Reagan and now the Bush Administration have forbidden use of Federal funds to implant fetal tissue in patients. Seven states have enacted laws against fetal cell implants.
Half a million Americans suffer from Parkinson's, a progressive and debilitating disease. A cure would lift them and their families out of misery and fear. But the anti-abortion lobbyists are not moved by that great humane interest. Once again zeal writes off the living.
Item. The National Right to Life Committee urges its supporters to cancel their memberships in, or drop their contributions to, 11 environmental and wildlife groups. Among those targeted are the National Audubon Society, Friends of the Earth, the Natural Resources Defense Council, the Sierra Club.
Why? Because the environmental and wildlife organizations, worried about world population growth, support U.S. aid to family-planning groups abroad. They back legislation to reverse Reagan-Bush rules to forbid aid to any such group that also provides information about abortion.
The rapid increase in human numbers, especially in the third world, is destroying the habitats on which birds and animals - and humans -depend. But the obsession with abortion overrides concern about a profound threat to the future of the earth.
Item. Anti-abortion groups pressured the State of California to stop funding family planning clinics. Some of the state's 500 clinics have been closed. Lobbyists are starting to work against clinics in other states.
The clinics give advice on contraception. That course would seem to reduce the likelihood of abortions. Why, then, would the anti-abortion lobby want to close the clinics?
A Wall Street Journal story on the California events quoted one anti-abortion leader as saying that the clinics promoted the idea of ''sex for fun'' - and that women who became pregnant then had abortions. Judie Brown, president of the American Life League, which was active in the California campaign, said: ''We must return to respect for chastity.''
In other Western countries there are many people who are conscientiously opposed to abortion. But there is nothing like the fanaticism of some elements in the American anti-abortion movement, and nothing like the political result in suppressing not only legal abortions but family planning and medical research.
The country that may have come closest to the ideal of the American anti-abortion extremists was Romania under its dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. He prohibited contraceptives and made abortion a crime punishable by up to five years in prison.
When Ceausescu was overthrown, one of his legacies most shocking to the first Western visitors was the misery caused by the policy against abortion and contraception: in the words of The Economist, ''the highest infant-mortality rate in Europe, overflowing orphanages and the deaths of many pregnant women.'' To Ceausescu, as to the zealots here, the lives of women did not matter.

HEADLINE: Yes, Economic Incentives for the Soviets

BYLINE: By Richard A. Gephardt; Richard A. Gephardt, Democrat of Missouri, is House Majority Leader.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
It is self-evident that the people of Eastern Europe have much to gain from freedom and democracy. What is less obvious, but no less important, is what America can gain: billions in defense savings, thousands of jobs, new markets and a chance to pull our children from the brink of nuclear Armageddon.
Yet an amazing chorus of caution warns against using the tools of investment and trade to advance American interests and values in the emerging democracies. But bold action is what these times demand. I have called for economic incentives to open new markets by moving Eastern Europe toward freedom. 
They include loosening restrictions on high-tech exports that are not essential to national security; lifting bans on loans and insurance for private investors in Eastern Europe; forming a ''free-enterprise corps'' to encourage Americans to return to the countries of their ancestors to help a new generation to freedom.
We should create a ''freedom international program'' to enrich both sides of the Atlantic through educational and scientific exchanges on an unprecedented scale and a ''food for freedom'' program to stock shelves and open markets for American farmers while Eastern Europeans move to private ownership. We should waive trade restrictions on countries that meet our requirements on human rights.
Soon a great competition among industrialized nations for these freer markets will begin. And in that competition, American jobs are already on the line. Eastern Europeans want to buy American cars, clothes and computers, but first they must be set firmly on the road to economic success. If Americans are not with them on that journey, they will naturally look to the European Community and to Japan. And what of the Soviet Union? The cheers were deafening last month when President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia told Congress: ''You can help us most of all if you help the Soviet Union on its irreversible but immensely complicated road to democracy.'' Republicans and Democrats alike applauded both the man and the message. But when I seconded Mr. Havel's motion, many of those same Republicans and the Administration balked and cried foul. They are wrong. American trade preferences, food shipments and investment insurance - all tied to progress on economic and political reform - would foster positive change in the Soviet Union.
This would be the logical extension of the moral and political support President Bush has already given to democratization in the Soviet Union. Regrettably, his Administration has not embraced this course of action and thus risks once again being a bystander to history.
The Administration defends its policy of timidity and reaction in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union by saying that we must go slow until we're sure of the success of democratic reforms. But if it won't encourage societies visibly moving away from Communism, why is the Administration subsidizing China, a Communist society that is moving deeper into repression?
The Bush China policy is one of destructive engagement. The U.S. is modernizing Chinese F-8 fighter jets and ammunition plants and selling anti-submarine torpedoes and artillery-locating radar to China. The Administration allows more high-tech exports to China than to Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia combined. Since the Tiananmen massacre, the Administration has allowed $76 million in World Bank loans and $33 million in Export-Import Bank assistance to China's repressive regime.
Unlike the giveaways in the Bush China policy, the measures I propose for Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union have strings attached, strings to pull them toward democracy and free markets. No one is proposing to send checks to the Soviet Union.
The Soviet Union has a long way to go toward freedom. Accordingly, our efforts should be tied to continued progress: to an end of foreign adventurism, improvements in human rights and emigration, and further economic reforms.
Yet the movement toward freedom is undeniable. We must act now to advance freedom and democracy in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. Not because it is good for them, but because it is good for us.

HEADLINE: Our Towns;
From Mean Turf To Green Lawns And Back Again

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING

DATELINE: ISLIP, L.I.

 BODY:
It was Scott Fitzgerald who observed that the very rich are not like you and me - and not, as Hemingway retorted, because they have more money. The same might be said of the very poor, and that, too, it is not merely a matter of money.
''Everybody hates you,'' said Evette Gandia, who grew up in a housing project in the Bronx. ''You look at somebody and they say, 'Why are you looking at me?' You always have to look over your shoulder. There is no safety zone. There is no control. You're out there. You're just out there.'' 
It is not poverty itself, but the conditions of poverty - the squalor, the crime, the brutality and hopelessness and anger - that spin a web that ensnares whole families for generations.
''The majority of parents are just teen-agers,'' Ms. Gandia said, ''and their kids are out there, 5, 6 years old, doing drugs. Kids are selling, controlling the streets. The kids are brought up by street punks. They're the big brothers, they're the support system. Street punks. Who do you look up to?
''You have to get out,'' said Ms. Gandia, a pale, intense young woman with a shy smile and a frail look that is deceptive. ''The Bronx is not a place that gives you support. You have to get away. A lot of the kids I grew up with, half the guys are in jail, the girls are in jail or pregnant.''
Evette Gandia is one who did get out. At 22, she will graduate in June from the New York Institute of Technology here with a degree in business administration and begin a job with a Manhattan advertising agency as a market analyst, figuring out how to sell Arrid Extra Dry.
At 16, a boyfriend taught her how to use a .38. ''It was survival,'' she said, ''because of the gangs.
It's still home in a closet. It's registered under the name of one of my mother's boyfriends. I never used it on anybody.''
Now, ''I just carry a butterfly knife. I even have it here,'' she said, gesturing across the quiet tree-lined campus. ''It's in the drawer in my room. But when I go home it's in my pocket.
''When you go home you definitely need them. Being 16 and being out there. Getting hit for no reason. Being told you're a spic. Being hit, your jewelry, your money you worked for being taken. Being told you can't make it. Because you're short. I'm bowlegged. Being told you're bowlegged. That you're a whore. The anger. It came down to survival, learning how to survive.''
She says it all now without emotion, a matter-of-fact recitation that could be an oral essay in sociology class. She has been at Tech for four years, one of about 100 students here, one of about 7,500 on 79 campuses across the state, who are part of New York's Higher Education Opportunity Program, invariably called ''Heop.'' It is intended for economically deprived students with poor high school records but the potential to make it through college with financial aid, remedial courses, counseling and intensive one-on-one tutoring.
Ms. Gandia runs the student learning center on campus and is a driving force in the Big Brother and Big Sister program, which guides younger students through the academic and personal maze that college often is, especially for those who, like her, spring from backgrounds that ravage rather than nurture. She wants to expand the program to the Islip community. ''This was so good for me, and I want to give something back,'' she said. She was selected Tech's Heop Student of the Year.
But an older sister, an 18-year-old brother who dropped out of school and now has an 8-month-old son, and her mother, who has serious high blood pressure and neglects her medication, still live in the housing project, and, as a college graduate with a good job, Evette Gandia plans to go home to help. She does so with trepidation. The last time she was there, two weeks ago, she was robbed with a knife at her throat and her sister was thrown to the ground.
Here ''the guys look after the girls, you have picnics,'' she said. ''There are trees. I'm asthmatic and I need a lot of nature. You can walk here and feel safe. It's wonderful. I've made real friends. At home, you have to question even your friends. Are they real friends or are they going to stab you in the back?
''These kids in the projects are screaming for help, but they have to be the tough guy, the tough girl, so they don't get abused, don't get taken. I'm two people. When I go back there, I put on the face. Don't touch me. What's mine is mine.
''I don't feel trapped. I just feel anger - the destruction of young people.
''But I've learned from this program how strong I am. How much I can give.'' Small, pale and frail-looking, she holds up her arms in a Rocky-like gesture of triumph, smiles her little-girl smile and the little room where she is talking suddenly seems very big and sunny.

HEADLINE: Florio Defends Higher Taxes, Urging State to Face Reality

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

DATELINE: TRENTON, March 15

 BODY:
Gov. Jim Florio told the Legislature today that his plan to impose $1.4 billion in new taxes in the next fiscal year was unavoidable if New Jersey is to look the future squarely in the eye.
''We are confronted by harsh realities and hard decisions,'' Mr. Florio said in an address to a joint session of the Assembly and Senate. ''The time has come to face them. As one of my heroes, the great heavyweight Joe Louis, used to say: 'You can run but you can't hide.' '' 
Democrats praised their Governor's proposal of a harsh budget that sharply cuts spending for most departments, saying the state finally had a strong leader willing to confront the tough problems that Mr. Florio's Republican predecessor, Thomas H. Kean, had avoided.
 
Republicans Are Critical
Spokesmen for the state's cities, teachers and school districts and groups that will soon feel the sting of more than a billion dollars in cutbacks described the coming year in terms that ranged from bleak to disastrous.
And Republicans accused the Governor of political slickness. Mr. Florio, they said, campaigned last year indicating he would not raise taxes, and now is calling for excessive increases in the state's sales and income taxes in this non-election year to create a budget surplus in time for his next election campaign.
The effects of Mr. Florio's proposed $12.1 billion budget, in which spending is cut for almost every department, would include the following:
* No major increases in aid to school districts, making cutbacks in services and increases in local property taxes likely in the coming year.
* An $89 million, or 11 percent, cut in aid to higher education, making major staff cuts or tuition increases likely.
* Large cuts in financing for transportation, including a $25 million reduction in construction projects and $49.7 million less than New Jersey Transit is requesting, forcing the agency that operates the state's buses and subways to raise fares for the third consecutive year.
* A cut of nearly $20 million, or 15 percent, in financing for the state's Department of Environmental Protection, and a $50 million reduction in general funds for cleaning up hazardous waste sites.
* A freeze on the size of welfare checks and cuts in spending on AIDS and drug-abuse treatment.
Among the few areas that would receive increases in spending would be prisons, the Department of Human Services and three initiatives to improve education announced in Mr. Florio's speech today: a $600 million bond issue to refurbish school buildings, a $5 million appropriation to expand Head Start programs and $1 million in the more than $12 billion budget for a math and science achievement program.
''The budget I'm proposing for the fiscal year starting this July 1st is harsh,'' Mr. Florio said. ''It contains measures tougher than a compassionate people should have to take.''
''But the one-shot fixes, the refusals to face reality, that went into the budget under which we now live - the budget I've inherited - would be shortsighted if we applied them again.''
Like other northeastern states coming out of an era of economic growth, New Jersey has seen its revenues fall far short of expectations in the last two years. In the manner that often typified his political life, Mr. Florio, a former amateur boxer, chose to attack the problem with one swift knockout punch.
 
'Rainy Day Fund' Proposed
To address the budget gap in fiscal year 1991, which begins on July 1, Mr. Florio's proposal calls for raising the sales tax to 7 percent from 6 percent, and applying it to many more products; raising alcohol and tobacco taxes; taxing telephone transmissions and all petroleum products, except heating oil, and ending a popular property-tax rebate for homeowners.
To avoid future budget crises, Mr. Florio today proposed instituting a ''rainy day fund'' to save unexpected new revenues, and a cap on state spending.
And to address the complex web of problems that grow out of the state's heavy dependence on property taxes, Mr. Florio proposed an increase in the state income tax for residents with incomes of more than $55,000 starting next Jan. 1.
The income tax increase would be used to shift more of the cost of government to the wealthy, reduce the burden of local property taxes on individuals and poor cities, and increase aid for poor school districts.
 
Praise from Democrats
Many Democrats today described the swiftness of the Mr. Florio's moves during his first two months in office, the depths of his proposed cuts and his willingness to talk about shifting money from rich to poor, as hallmarks of political courage. Unlike Mr. Kean, and governors like Mario M. Cuomo of New York and Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, some Democrats said, Mr. Florio was not delaying pain for political gain.
''This Governor has demonstrated that he isn't about to run away and pretend we don't have a problem,'' said Senator John A. Lynch, the president of the Senate, which is controlled by Democrats. ''He's facing it head on.''
Mr. Lynch said that he was optimistic that the Senate would support most of Mr. Florio's proposals, but that most legislators still had to review the specifics.
The Democratic Assembly Speaker, Joseph V. Doria Jr. of Bayonne, was cautious about the bill's prospects, but said he preferred that all elements of the proposals, including the income tax and property tax relief for fiscal 1992, be voted on before July 1.
 
A Well-Worn Path
Republicans, predictably, were far less optimistic.
''This thing is called 'get me into a second term,' '' said Senator William Gormley, a Republican from Ocean County. Mr. Gormley said Mr. Florio had followed a well-worn but cynical political path, denying the need for taxes last year to win the election.
On first impression, Mr. Gormley said he believed the increases in sales and income taxes would bring in more money than the state needed, thus causing Mr. Florio the greatest political damage early in his term.
Mr. Florio's strategy, Mr. Gormley said, was based on the assumption he would not have to raise taxes again and that by the time Mr. Florio runs for re-election in 1993, voters will have forgotten the suffering of this year, and the state would be piling up large surpluses.
Representatives of the state's cities and environmental groups expressed disappointment and concern about the effect of the budget cuts on what they described as critical programs. But perhaps the most strident objections came from the New Jersey Education Association, the state's largest teachers' union.
''If this budget is the price of faulty past priorities and misjudgments,'' the association said in a statement, ''it must not be paid by the children.''
''The education budget put forward by Governor Florio,'' it said, ''would be nothing short of a disaster for schools, colleges, communities and children.''
