HEADLINE: Rich and Poor in One World of Film

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN

 BODY:
IF Whit Stillman's droll portrait of Park Avenue debutantes and their beaus catches on, it is quite possible that the acronym UHB (short for Urban Haute Bourgeoisie and pronounced ''ub'') will become a new slang term. UHB is the term invented in the film ''Metropolitan'' by Charlie, a bespectacled collegiate philosopher in an uppercrust clique nicknamed the S.F.R.P., for Sally Fowler Rat Pack, who hang out together at seasonal balls and in their families' gold-trimmed apartments over the holidays.
The film - one of two American features selected for this year's New Directors/New Films series at the Museum of Modern Art - was one of the popular hits at the Sundance United States Film Festival in Park City, Utah, and will have its first New York public screening a week from tonight at the museum.
The Ivory Coast film maker Henri Duparc's ''Dancing in the Dust,'' which will be shown this evening and tomorrow, shares some striking similarities to ''Metropolitan,'' though it comes from a different continent and explores a way of life that would be taboo on Park Avenue. Mr. Duparc's sex comedy contemplates with an amused good humor the uproar in the household of a polygamous village chief known as Demi Dieu, when his beautiful, independent sixth wife brings a more modern urban point of view along with a cheeky self-determination into his closed provincial way of life. 
In all probability the worlds of the S.F.R.P. and of Demi Dieu's harem will never see each other in the flesh. But it is the special opportunity of a series like New Directors/New Films to be able to have them figuratively rub elbows on the same movie screen, since both are part of the festival. Audiences who see both can hardly fail to sense the similarities shared by two closed, cliquish worlds of privilege, each with its own claustrophobic set of rules.
Ann Turner's ''Celia,'' which comes from Australia and has its first screening on Monday, and Pekka Parikka's ''Plainlands,'' from Finland, which plays on Wednesday and Thursday, also explore in elaborate detail the explosive pressures on individuals living in circumscribed social settings.
The protagonist of ''Celia,'' which is set in the late 1950's, is a 9-year-old girl reacting to the death of her much-loved Communist grandmother, at a time of anti-Communist hysteria. Even though the movie is set in Australia, the wary, conformist social mood it evokes is remarkably similar to the feeling in American suburbs during the McCarthy era.
One comes away from ''Plainlands'' with a similar sense of recognition. Set in Finland's farm country, Mr. Parikka's film undercuts the popular image of the Finns as willowy, ethereal children of the midnight sun. Its main characters are a family of embittered, hard-drinking farmers who on one hot summer Sunday afternoon go on a rowdy picnic, taking with them an illegally possessed automatic rifle. The movie presents the image of a Scandinavian type that until now has been unfamiliar to American film audiences: the Finnish redneck.
 
Comparative Sociology
If the chief purpose of the New Directors series, which this year enters its 19th season, is showcasing the work of young, talented directors from around the world, one of the side benefits for anyone who attends several films in the series is the lesson in comparative sociology that these films offer. In a way that ordinary tourism seldom allows, those movies with contemporary settings can plunge the viewer right into the heart of an alien society, with subtitles eliminating the barriers to comprehension. And with those barriers removed, what one usually finds is psychologically familiar.
As the technology of movie making has become more sophisticated and the videocassette revolution has accelerated the dissemination of movies around the world, this sense of familiarity has been increasing. In festivals like New Directors/New Films, one senses the world becoming more of a global village in many ways. The shared vocabularies of film and video are one aspect. A second is music. In Nanni Moretti's political comedy ''Palombella Rossa'' - which will be screened Wednesday and Thursday and is one of two Italian films in the series - the crowd at a water-polo exhibition stands at attention while a Bruce Springsteen song plays. The Platters' recording of ''Only You'' underscores a significant dramatic moment in the Soviet film maker Abai Karpikov's ''Little Fish in Love,'' which also uses the music of Sade in the background. (That film will be shown March 30 and April 1.)
 
The Merry-Go-Round
In a recent colloquy with the six members of the New Directors selection committee, who represent the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art - the organizers of the series - there was a general agreement that the videocassette revolution has made it much easier for film makers around the world to see and react to one another's work and also to have it seen by film festival committees.
Evaluating the situation, Richard Pena, the program director of the Film Society, painted a picture of world cinema as a kind of merry-go-round of interconnected styles and sensibilities.
''You have an incredible confluence of influences,'' he said of this year's festival. ''The Japansese film 'Untamagiru,' which opens the series this evening, could be read perfectly within what we call magic realism, which we tend to think of as a Latin American genre. That's just one example of the kind of cross-fertilization going on. In evaluating films nowadays, it's not at all unusual for us to find a contemporary Finnish film maker whose work looks like that of a Japanese film maker 20 years ago. 'The Seventh Continent,' from Austria, owes more to Bresson than to German film making, while 'Double-Edged Knife,' from Brazil, recalls Hollywood film noir. 'Metropolitan' reflects 1930's Hollywood filtered through someone who really knows Eric Rohmer's work.''
 
Downward Mobility
The worlds examined in ''Metropolitan'' and in Stephanie Black's ''H-2 Worker'' - the two American feature-length films in this year's series - couldn't be more economically disparate. Where Mr. Stillman's wealthy Park Avenue collegians worry about downward mobility and view affluence without significant accomplishment as ''failure,'' Ms. Black's film looks at the hard lives of Jamaican sugar cutters who through a special visa arrangement are allowed into the United States to harvest sugar cane for meager wages in the Florida fields around Lake Okeechobee. Eager to perform the same tasks that American workers refuse to do, they allow themselves to be exploited and cheated out of their contracted wages because a way of life that to Americans borders on slavery is still much more lucrative than what they can find at home.
''H-2 Worker'' is the first film by Ms. Black, a 28-year-old film maker who attended the graduate program of New York University Film School.
''Over 10,000 Jamaican workers come to Florida every year for six months, from the end of October to the beginning of April,'' she explained the other day. ''It's been going on for 45 years. The sugar industry claims that they make $5,000 for the season, but the highest figure I ever encountered was $2,200. The workers themselves are afraid to speak. What I think the sugar industry is trying to do is to create a third-world enclave in Florida. An industry can go to a third-world country to get cheap labor to manufacture things, but you can't ship your land somewhere else.'' Uneasy Over Privilege The early college-age youths who converse in the Park Avenue apartments shown in ''Metropolitan'' have no financial worries and are self-conscious about their privileged status. When two of the men decide to make a spur-of-the-moment trip to the Hamptons to rescue a friend they fear is in danger of losing her virtue, they can afford to hire a taxi to drive them there.
''Metropolitan,'' which was written and directed by Mr. Stillman, a 38-year-old native New Yorker, is deliberately set in an ambiguous timespan that could be anywhere from the present to the 1950's.
''I wanted it to be somewhat in the past, but also a bit timeless so it would not be pegged to one year,'' the director said the other day. ''My own memories are from December 1969. Two years ago, just before we shot the movie, I snuck into a deb party just to make sure things hadn't changed too much. It still seemed valid.''
Mr. Stillman, who went into book and magazine publishing after graduating from Harvard in 1973, became involved in films in the early 1980's when he took a job representing Spanish films for foreign sales. The main reason he chose New York as his subject, he said, was that ''by filming beautiful New York I could have an expensive-looking film without actually paying any money for it.''
''The only living film maker I feel a really direct affinity for is Bill Forsyth, because he likes to deal in this kind of comedy,'' he went on. ''I don't think this subset has been portrayed before in a detailed, authentic way -at least in a long time. Maybe certain things from the 30's like 'The Philadelphia Story' and 'Holiday,' but they put sugar coating on it. Those films were just gaga in love with the very rich. I didn't want my film to be cruel but accurate and funny.'' Haves and Have-Nots As an exercise in comparative sociology, one of the lessons that New Directors/New Films teaches every year - and perhaps this year a bit more forcefully than most - is that the world is made up of haves and have-nots, and that the latter vastly outnumber the former. Poverty is devastatingly addressed in Jorge Furtado's ''Island of Flowers,'' the 13-minute short film from Brazil that plays a week from tonight and March 25 with the Brazilian film maker Murilo Salles's sexy, high-gloss thriller, ''Double-Edged Knife.''
Poverty compounded by disaster is also the subject of ''Water, Wind, Sand,'' the Iranian film maker Amir Naderi's harrowing study of the effects of a drought on a rural Iranian village. In the film, which will be shown tomorrow and Sunday evening, an adolescent returns to his family's poor, drought-stricken community to find his parents have already pulled up stakes, leaving no word of their destination. While searching for them in a raging sandstorm, he finds an abandoned baby boy whom he tries to rescue by leaving him in the path of several departing nomadic groups.
The director, speaking through a translator, said the other day that his film had been made as an homage to the documentarian Robert Flaherty and had been filmed in southeastern Iran, near the Pakistan and Afghanistan border, where a prolonged drought has killed thousands and made conditions unlivable.
''The film was shot in 90 days in the most difficult circumstances,'' he said. ''The temperatures were nearly 100 degrees Fahrenheit every day, and the continuous winds ranged from 40 to 120 miles per hour. Working with only a crew of five people with limited supplies of food and water and sleeping in shelters without any ceilings, we eventually became part of the nature of that area.''
From the corridors of Park Avenue to Iranian desert sands, the selections in this year's New Directors/New Films offer several world tours worthy of armchair traveling. At the same time, however, it is remarkable how much of the psychological territory covered in those thousands of miles will seem familiar.
 
When to See the Films In the Modern's Series
The 19th New Directors/New Films series, a collaboration of the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the department of film at the Museum of Modern Art, begins tonight at the Roy and Niuta Titus Theaters at the museum, 11 West 53d Street. Tickets to each screening, at $6 (or $5 for members), are available at the museum. A series ticket is $100 ($85 for members). Information: 877-1800, extension 489. Some screenings are sold out.

HEADLINE: St. Patrick's Day: The Parade and Much More

BYLINE: By RICHARD F. SHEPARD

 BODY:
It's a strange thing, the way the Irish take over New York on St. Patrick's Day. Strange because in this city of endless diversity - of citizens from the corners of the earth who have unpacked their bags to stay -the Irish are the best at persuading the rest of us that the rest of us, too, have some special attachment to that Atlantic island off the coast of Europe.
Take tomorrow, for instance. The ST. PATRICK'S DAY PARADEhas been a staple of March 17 since Colonial times, and, even as the Irish presence in the city is diminished, gives the impression of becoming bigger each year. Tomorrow's procession, to stress the point, is expected to put more than 150,000 marchers afoot; who knows how many of them actually have roots in Erin? The parade goes from 44th Street and Fifth Avenue, starting at 11:30 A.M., to 86th Street and Third Avenue, where the marchers are expected to disperse by 6 P.M. in a neighborhood that was once a center of Irish life in Manhattan. 
Among the paraders will be 150 bands, providing a portable din of skirling bagpipes and tweeting flutes, and onlookers won't just be whistling Dixie or growing maudlin over the shillelagh me father brought from Ireland. The music makers will come from near and far, and those to be counted among the farthest are bands from Ireland and Bermuda, as well as the Bagad de St. Nazaire, from a section of France from which the Bretons, Celtic kinfolk of the Irish, hail. And if the ears are sated, there will be sights for winter-sore eyes as young (and older and old) men and women pass by in uniforms and civvies, sorted by community here and county there.
For the first time, paraders will carry signs other than the traditional ones, authorized by the parade committee, that urge the English to get out of Northern Ireland. The new banners - signs of the times, really -will proclaim ''Immigration Reform Now'' and are the work of the Irish Immigration Reform Movement, which speaks for the new wave of Irish taking refuge here from economic doldrums in Ireland.
 
Mass and After
The Day of St. Patrick, who has not surprisingly become the patron saint of New York as well as of Ireland, is one that, often lamentably to those seriously immersed in Irish culture, has become, like New Year's Day, one associated purely with revelry. It is worth noting that a mass at ST. PATRICK'S CATHEDRAL,at 50th Street and Fifth Avenue, will precede the parade itself at 9 A.M. tomorrow.
The day undeniably infuses a touch of lightheartedness into the usually impervious city. The EMPIRE STATE BUILDING'S TOWERwill change its illuminated nocturnal coat of many colors to clad itself in glowing green from tonight through Sunday in honor of the occasion. The zealous may even find, in certain precincts, green bagels specially tinted in honor of a saint who may have had only a nodding acquaintance with the product. But man (and woman) does not live by bagel alone. There will be scores of dinners, hundreds of parties and countless special nights in bars and pubs and restaurants that are familiar with the Irish-American trade. Every St. Patrick's Day morning finds a line waiting on Lexington Avenue for the opening at 10:30 of TOMMY MAKEM'S IRISH PAVILION,around the corner at 130 East 57th Street (759-9040). The attraction is an Irish pub in mid-Manhattan that opens early and includes two cocktails as part of the $10 admission.
In the evening, a $10 cover charge buys admission to the club to hear Heather Breeze, a trio that has played Makem's before with its repertory of contemporary Irish folk music. From today through Sunday, there are three sets nightly starting at 8 P.M.; drinks are $4 and up.
 
Theater and Music
Theater - the medium so illuminated by Irish talent over the centuries - maintains its Irish connection in New York, the city that gave birth to Eugene O'Neill, one of the great playwrights of any stripe. More than coincidence has led the three-year-old COLONY THEATERto its current stage program, ''Ode to the Irish.'' The company is performing J. M. Synge's one-act comedy ''In the Shadow of the Glen'' and, on the same bill, a reading of selected poems by W. B. Yeats, memorializing a theatrical association of the two talented Irishmen that began with the Irish National Theater, later called the Abbey Theater. The program runs through March 24, Wednesdays through Saturdays at 8 P.M., at Taylor Hall, beneath the Blessed Sacrament Church, at 152 West 71st Street. Admission is $8; free for those over 65. Information: 662-6193.
The IRISH ARTS CENTERhas been contributing to New York theater life for 15 years, and its current production, ''Away Alone,'' by Janet Noble, is a play about Irish illegal aliens in the Bronx. The St. Patrick's Day performance, tomorrow at 8 P.M. at 553 West 51st Street (757-3318), is a benefit for a young man from Kilmallock in County Limerick who is dying of a liver ailment.
After the show, Black 47, a three-piece group, will conduct a session of Irish music. Admission for entire evening: $40; for the music session alone, at 10:30 P.M., $10.
 
Irish Spoken Here
There are several storehouses of Irish New Yorkiana, but none so open to public and eager to encourage further study as IRISH BOOKS AND GRAPHICS,a tiny treasure house of Irish culture at 90 West Broadway, not five steps from Chambers Street (962-4237). Angela Carter founded the place a dozen years ago and now has it comfortably stocked with about 5,000 items. On the street level are travel books, general books about Ireland in English, maps old and new, and prints. Down a spiral staircase to the lower level is a world of Irish language: books, magazines and tracts in Irish. Small wonder to learn that every two months an Irish-speaking group assembles to discuss, in Irish, new turns in literature.
If there is need for a pretext to visit the shop, which is open today from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. and tomorrow from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M., it may be in the lure of a free talk there tomorrow at 10 A.M. It is in English, and the speaker is Prof. Catherine McKenna, the director of Irish studies at Queens College. The topic: ''Irish Society and Politics at the Time of St. Patrick,'' a subject that takes the listener back 1,500 years.
 
Landmarks
The Irish were once a considerable force in the city: 100 years ago and more, they were the largest single ethnic group in New York, suffering the discriminations that have since been passed along to newcomers. Although New York's Irish Americans have now dispersed to New Jersey, Long Island and other cross-border points, they have left - in addition to a continuing presence in places like Inwood in upper Manhattan and Woodside, Queens - markers of a municipal past distinguished by achievement and trial.
The links between New York and the Irish are forged in steel and concrete, as well as in sentiment. ''The Book of Irish Americans,'' William D. Griffin's fact-filled and anecdote-laden compendium of Irish Americana published this month, lists more than 40 Irish landmarks in Manhattan. Among them: ST. PAUL'S CHAPEL, Fulton Street and Broadway, the resting place of many distinguished American Irish Protestants; OLD ST. PATRICK'S CATHEDRAL,on Mott Street, near Bleecker Street, dedicated in 1815; #7 STATE STREET, MISSION OF OUR LADY OF THE ROSARY, once a shelter for immigrants opposite Battery Park where Castle Garden was once the main conduit for millions of newcomers to America.
There are few neighborhoods the eyes can rest on that do not sport an Irish memento, either in name or substance. CARDINAL HAYES PLACE,near Police Headquarters and the Civic Center, the street where the illustrious former chief Catholic prelate in New York was born; MOYLAN PLACE, off 125th Street and west of Broadway, named for a Cork-born Revolutionary general; CLAREMONT AVENUE,which honors Michael Hogan, born in County Clare and a leading New York businessman in post-Revolutionary times.
These are Mr. Griffin's choices, but it is possible to arrange one's own expeditions in search of Irish memories around town.
The Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank Building - now the NEW YORK CITY OFFICE BUILDING- at 51 Chambers Street, just north of the City Hall compound, is the third home of an institution organized in 1817 to serve the incoming Irish. Almost next to it, on the corner, at #280 BROADWAY,is a landmark building that opened in 1846 as A. T. Stewart's Dry Goods Store, America's first grand department store. It became even grander years later as Wanamaker's, which had bought out the luxury trade enterprise established by an Irish immigrant. It now houses a discount store and city offices.
The Ancient Order of Hibernians, which has a major role in the parade, was founded in 1851 at ST. JAMES ROMAN CATHOLIC CHURCH,at Ames Street, near the Bowery in Chinatown. The church is still active, but its worshipers are more likely to speak in accents Hispanic or Chinese than Hibernian.
Some of these places will be visited during a WALKING TOURon Sunday, sponsored by the 92d Street Y and led by James Shenton, a history professor at Columbia University. It begins at 1 P.M. on the steps of City Hall and will wind past Irish landmarks in Chinatown and Little Italy.
Stops include St. Peter's Church on Barclay Street, built in 1785 and believed to be the oldest Catholic parish in New York State; the old St. Patrick's Cathedral; the former Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank Building, and the site of A. T. Stewart's store. The tour, which goes on rain or shine, costs $18. Reservations are advised: 996-1110.
St. Patrick's Day is also a time to pay homage to famous Irish New Yorkers. Al Smith, the Lower East Side half-Irishman who became Governor of New York and whose Catholicism contributed to his defeat as Democratic Presidential candidate in 1928, has come and gone, along with his famous Brown Derby. So have Jimmy Walker and William O'Dwyer, two of the best-known Irish mayors of New York. Father Francis Duffy maintains a stony presence in the space bearing his name just north of TIMES SQUARE,a plaza his statue shares with that of the ''Yankee Doodle Dandy'' showman George M. Cohan. As tomorrow's parade slogs up Fifth Avenue, it will be easy to remember that at least once a year, you can't take the Irish out of New York. And who would be wanting to, anyhow?

HEADLINE: Brady Sees Bigger Role For S.E.C.

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 15

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said today that the Administration was studying plans to enlarge the jurisdiction of the Securities and Exchange Commission that would strip at least some authority from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.
The measures outlined by Mr. Brady are intended to combat excess volatility and improve enforcement in the securities markets.
Mr. Brady said he was concerned about the effects of the C.F.T.C.'s regulation of stock-index futures. These futures contracts enable an investor to speculate on the future course of the stock market without investing large amounts of money in the actual common stocks. 
 
Enforcement Is Difficult
The Treasury Secretary said that trading in stock-index futures directly affected the price of the underlying stocks and that divided regulation made enforcement and monitoring of the two markets difficult.
He said he was mainly concerned that different financial requirements set by the two regulators - primarily different levels of margin - for trading in the two markets created dangerous and unnecessary stock market volatility.
''The sharp stock market decline of October 1987 made clear that the markets for stocks, stock options and stock-index futures are linked as one market,'' Mr. Brady said in a speech to the National Newspaper Association, the trade group for small newspapers. ''And it demonstrated dramatically how these markets, all operating by their own sets of rules, can interact to stimulate excessive volatility and reinforce the downward spiral.''
He added that such split jurisdiction had also resulted in counterproductive legal battles over whether new investment instruments could be traded on a futures exchange or a stock exchange.
It was one of the strongest statements on this issue by the Treasury Secretary, who has warned about the problems of split jurisdiction since the market crash more than two years ago. Until recently, market experts and members of Congress saw little hope of enlarging the S.E.C.'s authority, because of the tenacious lobbying power of the Chicago futures industry and the lack of support from the Reagan Treasury.
But since the Bush Administration has taken office, the balance appears to have tipped, with a number of lawmakers predicting that Mr. Brady will eventually prevail.
 
'We'll Reap Great Benefits'
Explaining his thinking, the Treasury Secretary cited the regulatory structures of several foreign countries, where both securities and futures regulation is under one large agency. ''Like our market competitors abroad, we'll reap great benefits if we end the fragmented regulation of our markets,'' he said.
Mr. Brady said his office was studying three approaches. One would be a complete merger of the two agencies so that stock, options and futures would all be regulated by one agency. A alternative would be to place within the S.E.C. jurisdiction of financial futures, including foreign-currency futures and interest-rate futures as well as stock-index futures. A third approach would simply be to give the S.E.C. authority to regulate stock-index futures.
''Many have recommended full merger as the most straightforward and the course chosen by countries abroad,'' he said. ''There are arguments in favor of the other approaches as well. What's important is that we get something done, and get it done now.''
 
Battle in Congress
The issue is shaping up to be a major battle in Congress, where the C.F.T.C.'s reauthorization bill has been held up for fear an amendment reducing its powers might be added to it. The battle in Congress is certain to pit the leadership of the Senate and House Agriculture Committees, which oversee the C.F.T.C., against the Senate Banking Commitee and the House Energy and Commerce Committee, which oversee the S.E.C.
But some members of the Senate and House Agriculture Committees have said they favor changes in the regulatory structure. This week, Representative Dan Glickman, Democrat from Kansas, and a prominent member of the House committee, said he would introduce legislation to merge the two agencies into one large one.
Treasury officials have said that in any merger the S.E.C. will come out as the dominant force.
Mr. Brady has been advocating the position he outlined today for more than two years, since he was chairman of the White House Task Force on the stock market crash. Occupied with the savings and loan bailout, Mr. Brady has had little time in the last year to address this issue, his aides say. But with the bailout measure wrapped up last August, they say he has put the regulatory jurisdictional issues among his top priorities this year.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady wants to give the S.E.C. authority over stock-index futures. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: A Drexel Brainchild Haunts 'Junk' Market

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
A once-obscure bond, invented by Drexel Burnham Lambert to encourage financing for takeovers and leveraged buyouts, is now instead contributing to problems in the ''junk bond'' market.
The bond, known as a reset, was conceived to provide investors with insurance against falling bond prices. It does this by guaranteeing that at some point the interest rate it pays will be raised to maintain the original value of the bond. Such an increase could be necessary if interest rates as a whole are rising or if concerns about the corporate issuer's creditworthiness have grown.
While the guarantee is meant to reassure investors, recent developments have dampened enthusiasm for resets, many of which qualify as junk bonds because of their credit risk. Hillsborough Holdings, the building products company based in Tampa, Fla., blamed reset bonds for its sudden decision to file for bankruptcy protection last December. And fears that RJR Nabisco Inc. will not be able to meet the terms of its reset provisions are helping to depress the prices of some $6 billion of its bonds. 
 
How the Bonds Work
All told, more than 40 companies have issued a total of $12 billion of reset bonds since 1986, and some seem unlikely to be able to meet their reset obligations.
In an example of how a reset bond works, assume that interest rates have risen in the 18 months since the issuance of a bond paying 13 percent interest, or that doubts about the issuing company's ability to pay its debts have grown. If the price of those bonds has tumbled from 100 to, say, 85, on the appointed reset date the company would have to raise the interest rate from 13 percent to 18 or 20 percent, or whatever rate was necessary to increase the price of the bonds to 100 percent or so of their initial value.
Similarly, when interest rates are falling or a company's credit prospects have vastly improved, the interest rate on the bond could be lowered on the reset date.
Companies in the throes of an acquisition were willing to take on this added risk because few expected that they would actually have to pay higher interest rates. New owners expected to restructure their companies and sell assets, which would enable them to retire debt or refinance their deals long before the day of reckoning came.
In theory, everybody wins with resets. But in practice, resets, like many new Wall Street products, have their shortcomings. While they have helped investors during periods of rising interest rates, they have not provided investors with any protection from companies that turned out to be bad credit risks.
''I think they're a disaster,'' said David M. Schulte, managing partner of Chicago-based Chilmark Partners, which invests in troubled companies. ''They're trying to fool Mother Nature.''
 
A Case Study
Consider the fortunes of investors in Hillsborough Holdings, which was taken private by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company in 1988. To help pay for the company, then known as the Jim Walter Corporation, Kohlberg, Kravis issued $625 million in three reset offerings, all of which were to come due at the beginning of this year unless they were extended and the interest rate reset.
But a lawsuit filed by asbestos claimants against the company hindered its ability to sell assets to pay down debt. That caused the prices of some Hillsborough bonds to drop precipitously last fall, to about $35 for every $100 of their face value. In December, Merrill Lynch & Company and Drexel Burnham advised Hillsborough that there was no interest rate at which the notes could be reset to have a bid value of 101 percent.
When bondholders refused to accept an alternative package of securities from Kohlberg, Kravis that included some equity in the company, Hillsborough filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. The filing was made two days before the company was required to reset the rates.
The reset provision ''was what pushed them into default,'' said Sean St. Clair, director of high-yield research at Duff & Phelps, the Chicago credit-rating agency.
 
An Improved Version
Hillsborough's bonds belonged to the first generation of resets. Since then, investment bankers have come up with an improved version, with a cap on the reset interest rate. For instance, in the case of two other heavily indebted companies at which credit concerns have grown - the Southland Corporation and Farley Inc. - the interest rate on their reset bonds can go no higher than 16 percent and 17.625 percent, respectively. Those increases are not nearly enough to make those bonds trade close to par. Southland was recently trading at around $32 per $100 face value and Farley at around $24.
Other companies have been able to reset their bonds without coming anywhere near the cap. A $602 million bond issue from Owens-Illinois, which went private in a leveraged buyout in 1987, was reset yesterday at 13.45 percent, up from a rate of 12.625 percent and a long way from its 15.125 percent cap. The bonds traded at par after the new rate was announced.
While caps may take the pressure off companies issuing the bonds, they may deprive investors of higher yields, which could compensate for the increasing risk of owning those bonds. The irony of many resets, said Kingman Penniman, a high-yield analyst at McCarthy, Crisanti & Maffei, is that ''what was intended initially to protect the investor has ended up protecting companies.'' Resets, he concludes, ''have offered a bell and whistle that in hindsight has not afforded the protection it promised.''
The biggest test for resets involves RJR Nabisco, the food and tobacco company that Kohlberg, Kravis acquired in early 1989. RJR has three reset issues totaling $6.125 billion. All must be reset in May 1991. Although these bonds were issued long after the benefits of caps had been discovered, all but $225 million of RJR's reset bonds have no cap. Drexel Burnham advised Kohlberg, Kravis that investors would balk at absorbing such a huge amount of bonds unless the company agreed to forgo its cap protection.
 
Price Down Sharply
Because of jitters in the junk bond market and concerns that RJR Nabisco will not be able to meet its reset obligations, the company's bonds have been severely depressed and two of its issues are now trading in the $60 range. If Kohlberg, Kravis had to reset the rate tomorrow, bond traders and credit analysts said, there would be no reasonable interest rate that would cause the bonds to trade back up to par.
An RJR spokesman said the company had any number of options, and added that 14 months was a long time away. But many bond analysts and portfolio managers said they remained unconvinced.
If RJR is unable to fulfill its reset provision, the consequences could be serious. Even if RJR's bonds trade back up to the $80 range, for example, that would still result in a 20 percent decline in their par value, or a loss to investors of about $1.2 billion.
''That's a lot of money,'' said Talton R. Embry, president of Magten Asset Management, which specializes in buying junk bonds. ''Someone may try to force them into bankruptcy or sue them.''
Despite problems like those with RJR, Mr. Embry is not ready to denounce resets. They may have failed miserably on their promise to protect investors from credit risk, he said, but they do force companies and their investors back to the table early, which could result in bondholders gaining a handsome slice of troubled companies' equity.
In the case of Hillsborough, for instance, investors were offered 10 percent of the company's equity, but that was not regarded as sufficient.
''There is a lever after 12 or 18 months where bondholders can renegotiate the deal,'' Mr. Embry said. ''That part of the promise has held up extraordinarily well.''

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
U.S. Lessons For Soviet Reform

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
DESPITE Mikhail S. Gorbachev's high standing abroad and his unopposed election as the Soviet Union's first Executive President, his popularity appears to be sinking like a stone with his own people as a result of his failure to deliver on his economic promises.
Marshall D. Shulman, the senior director emeritus of the Harriman Institute of Columbia University, who hopes Mr. Gorbachev will succeed, has himself been shocked by the rising public anger with the Soviet leader. Mr. Shulman described a party with old Moscow friends at which the young man of the family, watching Mr. Gorbachev addressing the Congress of People's Deputies, hooted, ''Blah blah blah.''
And a taxi driver, who refused to accept rubles, which he described with a contemptuous epithet, also called Mr. Gorbachev's words ''blah blah blah.''
Apparently seeking to deflect criticism from himself, Mr. Gorbachev appears ready to throw Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov to the wolves. Mr. Gorbachev has permitted a leader of the radical opposition, Anatoly Sobchak, to bring charges of corruption against the Prime Minister over his purported illegal exportation of a sophisticated Soviet battle tank, the T-72. 
A more critical issue, though, is the economy. In accepting the Executive Presidency, Mr. Gorbachev vowed to move his nation more rapidly in the direction of a market economy.
But questions remain whether the leadership has the foggiest idea of how to convert from an economy overburdened with military expenditures to a more efficient, less inflationary civilian economy.
Attending an international economic seminar here, Henry S. Rowen, the United States Assistant Defense Secretary for international security affairs, estimated that Soviet military spending constitutes 20 to 30 percent of gross national product - four to five times the American military burden.
But Mr. Rowen and other Americans here with experience in converting military plants to civilian use after World War II, Korea and Vietnam have concluded that the Soviets are being naive and essentially wrongheaded about how to make such a conversion.
Soviet thinking is typified by that of Leonid Vid, deputy chairman of Gosplan, the state planning committee, who spoke at the seminar here. In an article in the weekly publication Ogonyok in May, Mr. Vid said the conversion of Soviet plants was taking place in various ways; he cited as a good example the Votkinsk plant in the Urals, which previously built the SS-20 medium-range missiles that were eliminated by a treaty with the United States.
The Votkinsk plant, Mr. Vid said, has started producing heat-resistant storage containers. He added: ''The trucks which used to carry missiles will now take tanks of cooled beer, juices and milk to consumers. Each container can hold 24,000 pints of chilled beer, enough to satisfy the thirst of a small town.''
But William J. Perry, chairman and chief executive of Technology Strategies and Alliances of Menlo Park, Calif., a consulting firm that advises military producers, told the Russians here that although the most obvious course for a military company with decreasing orders was to diversify into products for the commercial market, this could be a terrible mistake. In the United States, Mr. Perry said, most such attempts had been ''unsuccessful, some spectacularly so.''
He urged Soviet military companies planning to diversify to assess the qualities that had enabled them to succeed in the military field. In the United States, military contractors' growth had usually been determined by technology and ability to sell that technology to a small, select number of customers, and the profits of these companies had usually been based on costs incurred, not on ability to meet a market price in the face of competition.
These qualities, when applied to commercial markets, Mr. Perry said, ''generally led to failure, since the competitive factors in most commercial markets are quite different.'' Hence he warned that a military systems company should not try to make the enormous leap into consumer products, where success depends on meeting the needs of a large and unsophisticated market, unless it had thoroughly thought through and developed plans for entering the civilian economy.
The danger of the Soviet approach, described by Mr. Vid and others, is that it is likely to transfer the high-cost methods - or even the cost-be-damned methods - of the military into the civilian economy, thereby aggravating inflationary pressures and worsening marketing problems.
Central state planning cannot solve those problems. The preferred approach, made simple in the United States by a sensitive market structure, would be for managers to respond to market signals; as long as the Soviet system remains a command economy rather than a market economy, Soviet managers will have difficulty following the American example. Yet there are examples in the American experience that could be applied here.
Prime Minister Ryzhkov comes out of the planning system, as does Mr. Gorbachev. The great question is whether the Soviet Executive President can at last change direction, gather around him advisers who are prepared to cut loose from the failing system of command and control, and give the people something more than ''blah blah blah.''

PUB-DATE: March 16, 1990

SECTION: Section D; Page 2, Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 418 words

HEADLINE: Commerce Secretary Issues Warning on Japan's Surplus

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 15

 BODY:
After two days of meetings with Japanese Government officials, trading companies and political leaders, the United States Secretary of Commerce, Robert A. Mosbacher, warned today that Japan's trade surpluses had ''achieved a semipermanent status.''
Mr. Mosbacher appreared to be using his second trip here as Commerce Secretary to maintain the momentum created in Japan after the hastily called meeting two weeks ago between President Bush and Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu.
Mr. Kaifu's Cabinet has been working long hours this week, trying to meet a deadline in a few days for a report on the progress of the trade negotiations known as the ''Structural Impediments Initiative,'' a series of trade talks seeking fundamental changes in the workings of the Japanese and United States economies. 
 
Concessions Likely
Japan seems likely to make some concessions in coming weeks, including a strengthening of Government investigations into areas like price collusion and new regulations that will keep local shopkeepers from blocking new, large stores for a decade or more.
In a speech today Mr. Mosbacher warned about Japan's high prices and the barriers to competition in telecommunications, construction and other areas, and said Japan should accept change as inevitable.
Apparently by coincidence, Mr. Mosbacher's trip came at the same time as a visit by Senator John C. Danforth, Republican of Missouri, an author of the 1988 trade bill that established procedures to force faster change in markets that the United States maintains are closed.
Mr. Mosbacher and Mr. Danforth have met separately with many of the same officials and business executives, and both said they had found a change in Japan's attitude.
 
Mature Discussion
''This time, discussions have been very frank and quite varied,'' Mr. Danforth said. ''It wasn't as if I was getting the same speech in every meeting. There were differences of opinions.''
Mr. Mosbacher's aides said much the same. ''It was a bit surprising to us,'' one aide said, ''but it indicates that the discussion is maturing.''
Mr. Mosbacher had little to offer Japan in the way of concrete changes in the American economy that would meet Japan's demand for a restoration of American competitiveness.
''Mr. Mosbacher spoke very well, but he did not have a lot more substantive progress to show since he was here last September,'' said an official of the Keidanren, the big-business organization here, after a meeting with the Commerce Secretary.
